This game seems to be hated by hardcore Resident Evil fans, but playing this as my first RE game I thought it was fantastic.  I liked it so much I went and played 4 older RE games after this.  I still stand by my opinion this is a masterpiece and best-in-series.  The environments are gorgeous and varied despite running really well on old hardware, the pacing and progression is perfect.  It has just the right amount of spooky and non-spooky parts, not too many cheap jump-scares, paired with an interesting story and replayability.  If you are unsure if you will like RE games, this is the one to try.

As always, the Resident Evil game franchise continues to deliver in spades with their survival-horror genre, and this release takes the baton from their previous titles flawlessly.  

Gameplay: Greatly increasing Ethan Winters' abilities, a much larger variety of weapons and strategies are now at your disposal. Continuing the 1st person view from previous works, up to 4 weapons may be quick-equipped, allowing you to select the most optimal equipment to deal with certain foes while preventing damage by dodging, hiding, or blocking. 

Combat: In typical horror fashion, failing to adequately defend yourself often leads to severe punishment or outright death, courtesy of the games' custom execution animations. This becomes most evident on the highest difficulty, where increased enemy health and damage are now accompanied by additional enemy spawns, earlier scripted battle scenes, upgraded enemies, and increased enemy combat intelligence (such as staggering towards the player when shot), mitigating extra content cheats such as infinite ammo. The mid-bosses are slightly repetitive but occur at far enough intervals where they don't become too much of an annoyance. The boss fights, however, are the main focus; a wide variety of specialized attacks serves to uniquely personify their character along with other background information you may discover throughout the map, especially regarding a certain 8 foot tall vampiress.  

Exploration: While not required, adequately exploring the map and pursuing side-missions is heavily recommended, and serves to greatly reward the attentive player, yielding riches of money, supplies, critical enemy information, or specialized tools. Puzzles, treasure maps, and optional combat scenarios await your inquisitive nature should you so choose...

Immersion: The vastly larger and isolated mountainous exterior serves as a stark contrast to the dark and oppressive interior, a classic feature of Resident Evil. Player movement is surprisingly human, displaying small pauses for vaults, movement reversals, or opening doors in addition to other actions. Disgustingly detailed enemy models are accompanied by hyper-realistic combat animations, ranging from attacks to movements to deaths. The nearly overwhelming number of detailed and distinct sound effects serves to root your attention to your screen at all times as you listen to Ethan's nervous breathing or the breaking of sticks in the woods.

Non-gameplay: The game is graphically gorgeous, with falling snow, player/enemy characters, tools, and more. As mentioned before, the sound quality and content is insanely immersive. Quality of life aspects are quite user friendly, with save and loading screens conducted nearly immediately other than the initial load in from the main menu. Finishing the game rewards the player by unlocking additional challenge perks that will serve to greatly alter traditional gameplay, including unlocking a mini-mercenary game or the aforementioned infinite ammo. A DLC with additional story and gameplay content is also available for download (Winters' Expansion - Shadows of Rose).
The trade-off is the high temperatures this game will generate; it is highly recommended to throttle your CPU or graphics cards (reducing electric consumption = less heat), and even then my own computer was hovering in the mid-50 degrees Celsius. You will most likely hear your computer fan running at full blast to cope with this large game, so make sure to have some temperature monitoring software running. 
This website serves as a great guide to bring down your computer temperature: https://www.ultrabookreview.com/31385-the-throttlestop-guide/
  
All in all, a fantastic continuation of the Resident Evil series, and it is clear that a staggering amount of effort was put into the makings of this game. As a RE fan, you will enjoy the continued and surprising changes to the plot and characters in the RE universe, and if you're new to this franchise, this game is user friendly enough where it does not require you to play previous titles to enjoy its content. 

10/10 would highly recommend playing this masterpiece.

If you are a producer or contributor to the makings of this game, know that you deserve a pat on the back and more for your efforts, and I hope you keep up the good work. I look forward to supporting your future products when they are unveiled. 
As a long time fan, thank you for your efforts and service. Please go eat some ice cream or something similar.
The RE Team never fails to disappoint. (except that one time when they made 6)

"Resident Evil 8: Village" is a thrilling rollercoaster of horror and action. From the snowy landscapes to the eerie village and the towering castle, every environment is beautifully crafted and dripping with atmosphere. The gameplay strikes a perfect balance between exploration, combat, and puzzle-solving, keeping me engaged throughout. The addition of Ethan's journey and encounters with new and familiar faces only adds to the intrigue and suspense. And let's not forget Mommy Lady Dimitrescu – a towering presence that's both terrifying and oddly captivating. Whether you're a longtime fan of the series or a newcomer, "Resident Evil 8" is a must-play that delivers on all fronts.

My only complaint for this game is that trying to knife anything other than moroaica to death feels very very bs. But I think thats just me making commentary on how sludge first person control is compared to third person, coming back from 400 odd hours on elden ring. Re8 is a high budget game well optimised for PC as far as i know, so for starts, achievement huge, there. It has guns that look good and feel good and ooomph to use, unlike every other first person game with good looking graphics. Graphics mind, are very nice, but i dont think any game going for an irl look has yet managed to look like rl yet. Replayability for this linear piece is extremely high in my opinion, for the story mode, simply because its a good enough thoroughfare that you want to replay vos new game, but this time take no damage or deal all headshots/only hit vulnerable areas. Or literally, you just want to replay one of your pref challenges, because, to be perfectly honest, finishing headshot only vos is not like learning to kill tree sentinel no damage, every new playthrough youll have only slightly less of a mess in store than last time, in how your reaction speed increased incrementally, and thats it, with the very, very good ai, leagues above above games. Rather, one way to put the excellence of the vos ai, is that when you fail to shoot a lycan as it performs a specific attack, it will then do only that attack until youve gotten a handle or messed up. Further, when you aim at enemies, they immediately dodge, meaning you have to be very very good not to miss once, and hence the ridiculous tragedy of headshot only run. On the case of the mercenaries, getting triple S for all of them, is, very, very fun, and adds a heck of a lot of playtime on (My 265 hours, i beat hardcore, then vos new game, and now i mess about for the story with mainly resource based challenges (i.e. the aforementioned headshot only strife) i have also SSS ranked castle and village, but rather im nowhere near done with the game by any means, so rather, bang for ones buck, achieved). By the way, you do not need full combo for triple S, you take it with a certain score. Rather, i managed to grab triple S at one point, without full combo-this was on castle, normal mode.

ETHAN BEST FATHER LEGACY

Resident Evil Village features a pretty fun and decently replayable story mode. With so many things to find in the games map, fun boss fights, and new game+ encouraging the player to replay the game over and over to max guns out you can easily end up playing through it 5+ times without it getting too stale.

Despite it's good story mode, that's all the game has that's enjoyable. Starting with Mercenaries (A bonus mode that comes with the game) holy shit is this mode is beyond a disappointment. 

Going into Mercenaries I was coming into it expecting it to be something like Jacks 55th birthday from people comparing it to mercenaries mode and damn did it just fall flat for me. The routing is just unintuitive and requires you to know dumb specific triggers to spawn enemies if you want high ranks, the powerups are a very boring addition and are just a full on downgrade from the ones in Jacks 55th Birthday, there's never variety or thought put into which weapons you get, and instead of the timer being important they made the game entirely based on your combo. The timer could have been something fun like having to kill all enemies before the timer runs out and how much time you have left determines your rank. (Also personal gripe is killing only adding to your timer instead of pausing it for X amount of time as it is just not nearly as satisfying.)

The rest of the game can be found in the form of very overpriced DLC that just isn't worth it. ($20 for more Mercenaries and Shadows of Rose is just not a good price)

Shadows of Rose is just a cash grab DLC that just reuses the main game, the enemies are very boring, and it only has two good parts. These parts include a weeping angel segment and a the final boss, both of which aren't even original.

[h1] 🕘          IMPRESSION:[/h1]
* Year 2021: RE8 released 
* After watching the review: Remove this from my wish-list
* Year 2022: Winters’ Expansion released 
* After watching the review: Add this to my wish-list
* Year 2023: Buying the Gold Edition
* 5 hours later: I'm still fun to wandering around in the castle
* 9 hours later: Many exciting places are just silent, make me boring
* 12 hours later: Fun for hunting true story behind it
* 23 hours later: Not exciting as Resident Evil 7, but still good to play
* 26 hours later: 'Shadows of Rose' only fun at beginning & ending

[h1]  🔊         TESTER MUST KNOW:[/h1]
* No official VR support for PC
* Denuvo is removed on April 2023
* Game world timeline: 3 years later, after the story of Resident Evil 7
* The Mercenaries = Arcade Mode with score attack replay value
* Trauma Pack DLC is just little content & extremely overprice 
* Disable weapon charms at the main menu

[h1] ⭐️         COMPARE TO RESIDENT EVIL 7:[/h1]
* Added more gunplay scenario & weapon upgrade
* Added more weapon is unlock-able for infinite ammo 
* Added more combine-able items
* Added photo mode
* Reduced horror scenario
* Reduced puzzle management

[h1] 💎         SAME GENRE COMPARISON:[/h1]
* Brutal Jumpscares, but just temporary
* Instant Healing Water available for sell
* Locked or unlocked door update into map
* Optional hunt animal for cooking meals
* Many element is similar to Resident Evil 4
* Able to change play role in story
* No scoreboard after completing a play-thru

I'm not exaggerating when I say this, but I've beaten the game 24 times. I know where everything is by heart (items, collectibles, etc.), I have infinite ammo for every weapon in the game (favorite is the Wolfsbane), and my fastest speed-run time is an hour and 59 minutes. Not super impressive or anything, but the point is, I've played this game a lot. Story's great, I love each of the different enemies and the lore behind each of the four lords (and the main antagonist, don't want to spoil much), and the best part is, everything in the game ties together with the plot of Resident Evil 7: Biohazard (another game I love so, so much). 

Four Achievements away from finishing the game in its entirety, and it's mainly because of the The Mercenaries Bonus Content. Very good game overall, HIGHLY recommend!

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

This game embodies everything a Resident Evil fan like me wants. A great use of survival horror, jumpscares, conservation of items, creepy characters and awesome boss fights. I'm really happy Capcom experimented with the series in a different way because this is one of the best Resident Evil games in the franchise.

A lot of people complain about the first person mode, and sure, it's not ideal, but for me, it makes the whole game a lot scarier. Sure, if this game was an RPG, it would probably be annoying, but its full use of first person really makes this one of the more unique games in the series.

What I like so much about this game though is that's its a mix of RE4 and RE7. It has the creepy but action packed atmosphere of RE4 (without the escort quests, thank god), and the strange characters and awesome boss fights from RE7. 

Overall, this game is amazing. It fixes all the issues from the previous games, with more interesting levels, game design and variety. I highly reccommend fans and first-timers to play it, especially when you go in blind. Not knowing anything makes the experience 1000 times better. 

In my book, Capcom has created yet another masterpiece.

I like Resident Evil Village! As much as some parts of this game don't make me too excited to revisit it, I've enjoyed my time with this game through completion. 

The combat is not really my favorite in the series, but that doesn't stop me from enjoying some other parts of the game more. I realized that many of the locals are very cool and the art team did an amazing job with basically everything in this game. Visually it's great! The story was silly and the characters were campy. But I liked it! The Dimitrescu family was quite intimidating and Heisenberg is super attractive and hot. Although getting through some of the different locations game play wise was a little tedious at times. [SPOILERS] For example, I wasn't a big fan of the Monreau section and the doll section with the baby kind of slowed the pace down a lot. I liked it the first time, but later playthrough it just became a little stale. The factory also wasn't too fun on my first few playthroughs since the layout was a little confusing for me. I liked the enemies in that area though. It gave me a nice challenge without them jumping away from each shot constantly. 

All in all, I think it's fun to experience this game atleast once with the Rose DLC after you're done. Both are very fun!

Resident Evil 4 because of the style/theme, Resident Evil 5 because of all the action the game puts you through.

Resident Evil Village is a really cool concept of a alternative way Resident Evil 4 could've gone. Instead of Spain, it's more north and having less parasitic zombies and more werewolf-like creatures and European folk-lore monsters. Story Spoiler [spoiler]I really love Resident Evil 4, and the fact there's a connection to the creation of Umbrella Company and how and why there's so many connections and similar twisted ventures of bring people back to life, it's all really cool to see connected and laid out.[/spoiler] There are parts however that feel like Resident Evil 8 tries to do so much different things, it feels jumbled. Like they had multiple teams working on different sections of the game but didn't work hard enough on making them all interlink together to feel natural. Resident Evil 4 feels natural all around with it all while having different themes of horror, still link together. Resident Evil 8 feels like multiple different horror territories but all feel somewhat out of place, like [spoiler] mixing fetus babies with vampires and fish monsters with metal zombies[/spoiler] Many awesome moments, especially ones where you get to feel like a bad ass. Stories really good [spoiler]BUT I HATE HOW YOU CAN'T GET TO MAKE A CHOICE AND TEAM UP WITH HEISENBERG missed opportunity to do a team up with a villain to deal with a common enemy, that from my knowledge hasn't been done before by any resident evil game[/spoiler]. Overall, 8.5/10. I would probably rate it a 9 or higher if I played Resident Evil 7 as there's story connections between the two. I have played Resident Evil 4 though, and 8 is a good time if you really enjoyed 4.

In my opinion RESIDENT EVIL VILLAGE is the best game from the franchise so far. The game is not perfect of course but I can say it is the best action horror video game in my Steam library.

  The game has one of the most realistic graphics and textures I've ever seen. The storyline, the idea, the characters, the music - the whole gameplay is amazing. Personally, I've completed the whole game with everything possible to do in about 12 hours, but if you speedrun the game it will take you two hours and a half, which is actually normal for singleplayer storymode game (ignoring the fact I have more than 62 hours on the game). 
If you have completed the game - there is mini game named - The Mercenaries, where you can fight zombies and "having fun", but here is the part where I think there are some drawbacks.  I believe the main gameplay and storyline do not have drawbacks, but here I will "complane" about the mini game - The are some bugs about the abilities, because when I got one it didn't worked and I died, also I don't like that when you shoot at the zombies' heads they don't react like you shoot them, but like you caress them - but here let's say that is because they are zombies. At the end when I completed The Mercenaries I was very happy I earned my last achievement, but I still want to replay the game.

  To finish with, the game is amazing - there are so much action and there are some horror scenes that have kept me under pressure and the boss fights are amazing, even more interestic that the other RESIDENT EVIL games, but in fact every RE game have unique and amazing boss fights. Also the music in the game make even better experience, also when your with headphones. And that's little spoil and maybe I am wrong, but I've played OUTLAST 2 and then RE7 and RE8, which are of course better than OUTLAST 2 but the storyline is very similar, so I think RE have got  bit from OUTLAST idea ("a bit" because at first if you have played the games - they won't have anything in common, you just have to take a closer look in the both games storyline and details). That's is all I want to say about RESIDENT EVIL VILLAGE.

  So if you want to play ACTION horror storymode singleplayer game with interesing unique storyline and with realistic textures and graphics - play RESIDENT EVIL VILLAGE, but before that make sure you've played RESIDENT EVIL 7 BIOHAZARD to learn the full story of the 2 games. - I hope you enjoy it, because I really did!!

Just as I thought, RE8 strays into a more action and fantasy area than the previous entry, which kind of makes me wonder why they even decided to do this under the Resident Evil moniker of all franchises. And although this series is not a stranger to jumping the shark and overeaching, RE8 still manages to pull it off quite nicely.

RE8 picks up a couple of years after 7, with Ethan and Mia married with a child who becomes the new center of the story. The game takes us to a very RE4 village but instead of ganados, we find lycans, giants, zombies, vampires and all other sort of very fantastical very not much of a Resident Evil bioweapon style enemies. And somehow, they manage to pull it off. As I mentioned before, the plot overreaches. Not gonna spoil anything, but let's just say that it ties itself with the previous games to give itself a reason for existence and for adding an insane quota of fantasy into the series. It doesn't entirely feel like and RE game because of it, but then again, after all the shark jumping the series has been known for, this comes out as somewhat acceptable. I buy it, what can I say...

Gameplay wise, it leans much more into action than it's previous entry. With RPG elements of course, crafting, and a more open ended world to explore, although retaining every element that has made the series style of map exploration. It tries to balance horror with action (again just like RE4) and even if it doesn't get to do it perfectly, which might offend the more classic fans of the franchise, it does the best it can juggling with both genres. RE8 it's not a scary game, but don't get me wrong, it can be terryfying from time to time: house Beneviento comes out of nowhere, and it's f****** scary man let me tell you that, being chase by Lady Dimitrescu is unnerving and the general atmosphere is enough to keep you on your toes; but you are gonna be much more prepared for most of it, it's harder to be left with no bullets in this one, and the general vibe of it and it's creatures, come out more of a startling vibe than a horror vibe. It is a startling game. It's definitively gonna startle you.

RE8 is a great game indeed, doing it's best to balance two genres and, albeit not having the most sublte of the stories, it still manages to keep you engaged and wondering what's next for the series. One of the best of the year for sure.

I'd call this one "Resident Evil's Greatest Hits", because in many ways it feels like an amalgamation of all the best bits of the entire series in one game. 

In some ways it's great seeing all those good bits work together. In others it feels like retreading old ground. Yes there's a Resident Evil 4 village. Yes there's another Resident Evil mansion. Yes there's an unstoppable behemoth stalking the map. Yes there are somewhat ludicrous puzzles and gates that open when you jam things-that-don't-look-like-keys-but-are into them. And yes there's some other bio-engineered bug turning people into monsters - because of course. Right? It's a Resident Evil game!

As a game it still holds together extremely well and Capcom have finely tuned what makes a great Resident Evil experience down to a fine art now. My only real complaint is that the tone of the game goes from dark and grisly, to somewhat cringe as Capcom strays into self-parody with some of the character designs and dialogue. I wish they could settle on a serious tone and not let it get too ridiculous. It's jarring especially when you see the great build up, tension, and horror that they've put into this game - only for them to wreck it with something completely nonsensical.

[h1]I'm Feeling Like Van Helsing Over Here![/h1] 
Resident Evil Village is a 2021 survival horror game developed and published by Capcom. It is the sequel to Resident Evil 7: Biohazard (2017). Players control Ethan Winters, who searches for his kidnapped daughter in a village filled with mutant creatures. Village maintains survival horror elements from previous Resident Evil games, with players scavenging environments for items and managing resources. However, it adds more action-oriented gameplay, with higher enemy counts and a greater emphasis on combat.
 
[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]💾Graphics[/td]
        [td]Reach for the Moon Engine (also known as RE Engine) is absolutely breathtaking. The environments in this game just suck you in into the experience. This is the future for Resident Evil and I couldn’t be any happier. The environments look abandoned and lived in, the architecture is stunning and the lighting is pure next level. The better thing is how good it runs. They truly optimized this game really well. The animations are really well done as well! You can feel the dread in the air, the chills from the cold environments, it's just so well done. The enemy and boss design is superb and the Castle section of the game is so beautiful, and scary at the same time. I can’t find one error in the graphics departments. It’s a true masterpiece![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎮Gameplay[/td]
        [td]Resident Evil Village has a mix of Resident Evil 7, and Resident Evil 4 on the side. Let me explain - You have the merchant bag from RE4. Now I actually enjoyed this a lot. You can upgrade your weapons and inventory from the merchant, and can also buy new and unlocked end game weapons from him as well! You can find currency (just like RE4) that you can use to buy these upgrades and weapons from. You also have collectables to sell and so on, you get the idea. Now this game feels really similar to RE7 in terms of combat, and that's a good thing. The combat felt fluid, and a great balance of action and pace. You have many kinds of weapons in this game and a great amount of enemy variety and I’m really pleased with that. The puzzles were pretty easy and you will have no issues with those, so if you are looking for big brain puzzles here, unfortunately Resident Evil Village is empty in that department.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]📜Story[/td]
        [td]The story continues from Resident Evil 7 and they do a pretty good job with it to be honest. I was absolutely hooked from the beginning, and all the way to the end. Now there are some parts in the story that could have been better in my opinion. The doll house could have been expanded with more horror elements as I felt that game me the most in terms of psychological horror. The boss fights were a mix bag. Some of the fights were absolutely incredible, and some other ones just felt kinda lazy in my opinion. I also wish Chris had more screen time. Capcom kinda did Chris dirty in this game. He was a bad*ass, but would have been nice to see him interact more with Ethan. The last boss fight was also not great and that’s a true shame. The main antagonist could have done some better writing and more screen time. Besides those negatives, I did enjoy the story and I'm happy it continues from RE7, so if you haven’t played RE7, please play that one first because it’s definitely worth the whole story.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🕛Playtime[/td]
        [td]You have a good amount of playtime here for a Resident Evil title. The story took me around 12 hours to complete (which is pretty good for a RE game). You also have some good replayability since you have many unlockables and challenges. The Mercenaries mode is okay in this game. It’s not the best form of Mercenaries mode in a RE title in my opinion. It's still fun to play, but you probably won’t spend much time on it (only if you are trying to get achievements).[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎧Sound[/td]
        [td]The sound design is so amazing here! The music is incredible and fits the game so well. The voice acting is really good, and the ambiance has such a terrifying sound to it. Maybe it’s the music, or it could be that the monsters sound really scary in this game. The gun sounds pretty good and the UI noise is satisfying to hear.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❗Bugs❗[/td]
        [td]I had some minor bugs, the inventory system can be finicky with the mouse at times. I don’t really know any bugs that stood out to me. Maybe I was just too immersed into the game and didn’t pay attention to them lol.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔅Performance[/td]
        [td]For a beautiful game like Village, I had no issues with performance. I played on Ultra and had no frame drops at all! The game was just flawless for me. No stutters, crashes, nothing bad here. The RE engine is just perfect, runs like magic.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]✔️Pro’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Fun and engaging story
[*]Incredible graphics
[*]Fantastic level design
[*]Great animations
[*]Amazing sound design
[*]Chris Redfield is back
[*]Diverse set of locations
[*]Great soundtrack
[*]End game unlockables
[*]Voice acting is great
[*]High replayability
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❌Con’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Boss fights are a mix bag
[*]Chris deserved more screen time
[*]Doll house could have been longer
[*]Antagonist is not interesting
[*]Some parts of the story didn’t make much sense
[*]No FOV slider (mod can fix this issue)
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🏆Rating[/td]
        [td]7/10
This game is worth the full price, but I would wait for a sale if you are patient for around 25-50% off.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔗Conclusion[/td]
        [td]I was really skeptical with the whole vampire theme they were going with, but they really pulled it off! The map design is flawless and has the vampire castle vibe to it that fits so well. It's by all means not perfect as I had some issues with the story, but overall it was a good experience. This is a sequel to Resident Evil 7 (Biohazard) so I do recommend playing that first. This is a must buy for any horror fan. It’s a great game with horror and action. Really well done![/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

Resident Evil Village was a very notable game with very few flaws. Below is a list of pros and cons that I noticed. This is not meant to be controversial, but is my opinion of the game. (Based on the 3rd person play through)
Pros:
-Gameplay mechanics are fluent enough
-Story was riveting (Based off playing RE7)
-Numerous different enemies throughout game
-Huge map
-Every different area is original
-Still has the enclosed scary feeling from other RE games
-The four lords all have their own quirk (making the different bosses new and always a different fight)
-Always on the edge of my seat
Cons:
-Boss battles are a little lack luster and provide little for tactics (all seem to be closely related other than the boss)
-Sprinting while going from W to WD or WA has an awkward movement (still very playable)
-Playable characters don't sprint as if it is life or death (I prefer player models to run like hell)
-Some moments I find myself wondering WTH do I do? (this is not the worst but can also be a pro)
-The game goes by a little quick in terms of what is truly happening in the story.
-Not as scary as some of the older games
-No storage box (Forced to sell items)
-Final boss is not the most enjoyable fight (me personally)

It may seem like there is a lot of cons, but these are not game ruining nor are they that bad. Most of the pros make the game awesome.

[b]Resident Evil Village seamlessly blends horror with action, presenting an enthralling narrative that unfolded with an unexpected twist, leaving me thoroughly impressed. The diverse environments, ranging from the eerie village to the haunting castle, showcase some splendid visuals. Furthermore, the inclusion of familiar interfaces and gameplay mechanics is welcomed, especially for someone like me who isn't a seasoned gamer and prefers simplicity. Moreover, while initially doubting the effectiveness of the first-person perspective, I found it to genuinely amplify the horror! Suffice to say, it excels in delivering a modern and engaging experience that's truly enjoyable: Highly recommended![/b]

RE Village is one of the best experiences in the genre & a prime example of why Capcom is on their AAA game still. Although I waited for the 3rd person mode to be added to play it since I'm not a fan of 1st person horror in this series lately, I still got my fair share of spooks & fun out of it. Village's gameplay felt faster than 7's & RE2R's, but not as fast as RE3R's if that makes sense. A great middle ground was achieved here, even if it can still have that signature Resident Evil clunkiness to it. There are some combat gauntlets in this game that didn't feel 100% designed for the 1st person's horror experience but ended up feeling much better in 3rd person. It was overall enjoyable to play! 

The graphics aren't mind-blowing but still visually appealing; the RE Engine never disappoints! The story is also surprisingly heartfelt, much better than the dud 7's story left with me. And, of course, Village has Lady D; who needs anything else? For the most part, all of the villains had memorable personalities. I enjoyed every minute of the story, even if the middle part of Village could be more precise. Horror-wise, Village has some of the tamest set pieces in the series while also having the scariest horror moment of the last few years; you KNOW what I'm talking about if you played. 

One of my favorite parts of the RE series is how it's not afraid to get campy & ridiculous & Village doesn't hold back in that department; it was very clearly inspired by RE4 & in a few ways, also set the table for the remake we just got. Aside from the flimsy middle portion of this game slowing things down after the AMAZING castle level, I can't think of too many negatives for the base game. It's so wonderfully paced, other than the middle that I want to replay it over & over for better times.

Also, playing as Lady D in Mercenaries is AMAZING, **** that the DLC doesn't advertise itself as having to grind to unlock her instead of at purchase. -_-As for the Shadows of Rose DLC, it's much more horror-focused than Village's action-packed moments, and it was enjoyable, just not all that fun to play. I get Rose is a young girl just trying to help herself & she won't control as smoothly as an adult like Ethan, but things felt significantly clunkier, jumping right into the DLC after finishing the base game. I appreciate the horror focus & there are some genuine moments of terror in the DLC (THOSE FORSAKEN MANNEQUINS)... But other than that, you only get to fully experience Rose's powers at the literal end of the story. It feels great, but I wish we could skip to RE9 to play as a powered-up Rose trying to save the world or whatever they introduce in that sure-to-be jam-packed game. 

Overall, the DLC was an excellent addition but not necessary ****. Village is the most fun I've had with a Resident Evil game. It could be a better experience, but it does so little wrong aside from some story pacing & clunkiness that I highly encourage anyone trying to get into the series or horror, in general, to start here. I LIKE this game so much.

Really enjoyed this one. The graphics are nothing short of amazing. They offer a depth of realism that immerses you completely in the story, like being there in real life. The story is well-written and engaging with plot twists that are truly unexpected. Game play and story work together to deliver a frightening experience. You never know when something will jump from the next shadow to take you down. You can guess, but that doesn't change the fact that you still have to go past the shadow to get out.

Controls were familiar if you've played other RE titles or similar first person horror games. The only downside for me was how difficult it was to look around with the mouse. Even with sensitivity turned all the way up, I found myself constantly having to pick my mouse up to keep scrolling over. Annoying, but not a deal-breaker.

I highly recommend this game to anyone who loves horror games that weave together puzzle solving, survival and first-person action. Top-notch!

A lot to love, and a lot to be annoyed by. The game world is exceptionally designed, full of atmosphere, mystery, and style. The combat is solid, and RE8 features all the features you'd want in a lite survival/crafting action game - inventory organization, limited supplies, crafting decisions, and lots of upgrades to move from a vulnerable twig into beast mode. The early sense in the game that there are lots of treasures to come back and find later on was very satisfying. It's fun unspooling the map and revealing all its secrets.

Acting is good, cinematic sequences are engaging, and the overall pacing felt about right. Although RE8 features much bigger maps than RE7, the playtime is about the same, and I'm not sure the game world really IS bigger ... they mostly just added lots of tunnels to walkthrough between the larger rooms and objectives. Still, it's really beautiful to look at and explore.

But damn does this game have some annoying design decisions. My least favorite was the pointless killing domesticated animals for upgrades system. It's not even hunting; you just walk up to some poor beast and blow its brains out. Felt needlessly sadistic and is unsatisfying as a mechanic.

After you explore a major area off of the hub map, you get locked out of that area -- even if you left essential treasures and obtainable meats ungathered, which can really hamstring you from accessing upgrades later in the game. Yes, I know this was the case in RE7 as well, but it felt less punitive in that game. Here, a lot of the cool things can get permanently missed until the next playthrough.

A real loss from RE7 is the survival horror elements. Gone are any real sneak mechanics. There's very little suspense or surprise in this game; it's mostly just full-on vampire hunter and such. It's still fun to play, but I really think the survival horror in the first three sections of RE7 were glorious, and I wish they had retained some of that. Instead, in this game we get far more wave shooter moments and overall run 'n gun sequences. Most are enjoyable, but I didn't care for the moments when a mini-boss battle took place in a cramped arena. Those were unnecessarily tedious.

Finally, the story is a disappointing morass of retconned elements. It's hard to make sense of anything in this game if you haven't played RE7, but the story basically undercuts that whole game. I won't give it away, but suffice to say that RE8 sacrifices a lot of the significance of the actions in the previous game to come up with some cheap plot twists. While I *love* the Village of Shadows story-within-the-story, the rest of the plotline felt like lazy writing to me.

Still had a blast running through it, but it is definitely not as good as RE7, especially if you're looking more for survival horror than action.

[h1]Easy to Impress[/h1]
(I'm a casual player, I was "wow-ing!" every 5mins)

[b]Messed up Village[/b]
Retrospectively thinking about Re Village, I can see it was very uneven. Levels are paced very chaotic. Initial running sequence > slow introduction to future problems > even slower wondering > inspection, hide and escape > grab and run. And yet every boss fight ends up with "shoot until it dies". And yet we can't choose who to kill next, must follow the linear story. And yet ammo management is unforgiving as always. Thanks for unbreakable knife!

[b]it Looks Awesome![/b]
Mountains. Forests. Abandoned houses. Bridges. EVERYTHING looks photo realistic and deserves to be a cover for atmospheric black metal band. 

The Village Lives. Bright day replaces foggy morning. Animals appear behind fences (free credits!). Flying creeps scared by lycans. Exploring the settlement is thrilling - newly opened doors present ammo, guns or health herbs. It's a crime we can't return to story locations!

[b]Best Mercenaries Mode![/b]
I absolutely loved Village Mercenaries! Here, you can run. RUN. Running and shooting enemies! What is going! It was fun.
Moreover - it's possible to play as Village bosses - Lady Dimitrescu and Heisenberg. Whoa! Get this picture - summoning vampire daughter, grabbing and smashing elite mobs, and occasionally using lipstick or throwing chairs into crowds.

My favorite RE game. Interesting story, occasionally really creepy and scary, good action.  It mixes different horror genres really well and basically takes all the best parts of previous RE games into this new setting. I like the pacing of the game too. There are actiony parts, escape roomish parts, mellow exploration, psychological horror etc. There is a little bit of variation of quality between different parts of the game, but it doesn't drop the ball at 
any point. My only complaint is that it's fairly short. It took me 9,5 hours to complete my first play thourgh, and I searched every nook and cranny, read all the lore and stuff. I'm not a huge fan of multiple play throughs, so that was a little issue for me, even tho I ended up playing this game with different difficulty settings cause I liked it so much. Only the hardest difficulty makes the game a little bit different, and I wish they could have done more variation between other difficulty levels too, other than making the enemies stronger. Otherwise an excellent game and imo the best RE game thus far.

Do I even have to praise a game as high-quality as this?

For starters, in hindsight, this game was clearly made as not only a sequel to Resident Evil 7: BIOHAZARD, but it clearly served as a sort of "practice project" for their upcoming Resident Evil 4 REmake. It was pretty clear from the moment Resident Evil 2 REmake came out & the REmake train started that the remake of Resident Evil 4 was going to be a big deal. RE4 (2005) was a monumental achievement in gaming, & remaking a game as important & impactful as that would require some very careful consideration. So it's clear to me that Capcom decided to make Resident Evil: VIIlage a psuedo-precursor-spiritual successor to RE4 so they could not only figure out how to update the original's playstyle, but they could also test everything out in a game that wouldn't be held up right next to the original RE4 by the public. The result is a game that satisfies all those excellent gameplay wants & needs that made RE4 so successful while also furthering the main story & following up on Ethan Winters & his family after the Dulvey, Louisiana incident with the Baker family & Eveline in RE7. 

SKIP THIS NEXT PART TO SKIP MAJOR SPOILERS

[spoilers] The Winters' have been relocated by Chris Redfield & his team, the Hound Wolf Squad, into a remote village where they can essentially hide in the mountains safely, far far away from the deep, unending blackness of the moldy Baker house. The Winters' have spent the last 2 years recovering from the horrific events that unfolded in Dulvey, Louisiana, where Ethan's wife Mia was held on the property by a Bioweapon child named Eveline. Eveline controlled Mia & the Baker family by infecting them with Mold from her body & using the Mold to control them & turn them into horrific monsters. After a night filled with some of the worst terrors imaginable, Ethan & *Redfield finally take down the mutated Eveline & end the horrific night. (*It's not actually confirmed to be Chris, as he looks different than the Chris Redfield in RE5/RE8. It's widely accepted that this is just a poor attempt at a redesign for Chris, closer to his original RE1 design, but some theorists consider that this might be a different agent, using the codename "Redfield" as either a homage to Chris, an unknown family member/sibling, & one theory posited that it might be Hunk using the codename to hide his identity. It's purely anecdotal that the person named "Redfield" in RE7 & the Chris Redfield who has stayed consistent through every other appearance in the games are the same person.)

2 years later, Ethan, Mia, & their daughter Rose are living a quiet life in the mountains. One night while sitting down to have dinner, Chris Redfield & a squad of me bust into the Winters' home. Chris seemingly shoots & kills Mia unexpectedly, then he & his men take baby Rose & knock out Ethan. The next Ethan knows, he is waking up outside of a wrecked transport truck, bodies littered all over the ground, & Rose missing. Ethan then stumbles through the dark woods, feeling his way through shacks & thick trees, until he finally comes across an old man hiding in a pantry. After the man erratically demands Ethan be quiet & gives him a LEMI handgun, the man is suddenly viciously murdered by a Lycan monster. Ethan is then completely overwhelmed in the Village by hundreds of Lycans, including their leader Urias, a massive beast wielding a giant hammer. After being overwhelmed & captured, a bell suddenly rings out, ending the onslaught & barely saving Ethan's life. Afterward, Ethan meets an Old Hag who tells him through cryptic words that his daughter has been taken by Mother Miranda. Dead set on finding his daughter, Ethan then embarks on another horrifying quest through the darkest pits of terror, this time to save his precious daughter Rosemary before she can be sacrificed by Mother Miranda & the Four Lords. [/spoiler]

This game is absolutely amazing. I can't even begin to explain the feeling I had when searching for treasure in the Village after the 2nd or 3rd boss fight, with new keys & a new Village state. Backtracking for treasure is done in a very organic way here. Very rarely do you actually have to take the long way back to a locked chest or treasure, with new paths with new treasures usually paving the way for a round trip back to the treasure. 

The legendary RE4 inventory is here in all its glory, with the added benefit of crafting materials having their own separate page, not taking up precious inventory squares. The weapons & the upgrade system is very reminiscent of RE4, with you using Lei that is dropped from enemies or found in the world to purchase upgrades for all the different stats for each gun. Again, if you've played RE4, it's exactly like that. You can also buy attachments for each gun, just like RE4. There is a new upgrade system exclusive to RE8 where you hunt game animals in the overworld like pigs, small birds, & goats to get the ingredients to make gourmet meals that permanently increase your overall health, guard, & movement speed. It's all done very organically & if you always remember to check every nook & cranny, you will quickly notice that the treasures, upgrades, prices, all seem to fall into place in a very organic way. You do have to look for the animals, but they are sort of semi-scripted, as if you manage to kill all available animals that can be hunted, you will have just enough ingredients to get all the meal upgrades. It is an excellent experience for those of us who enjoy a rewarding treasure hunt. 

Speaking of treasure, again, just like RE4, the treasures can be either small gems, or they can be elegant combinable treasures worth tens of thousands of Lei. Being a newer title, RE8 has a lot of Quality of Life upgrades to the classic gameplay of RE4, as when checking treasures, the game will tell you when/if they are combinable with other treasures so you don't have to hold on to treasures the entire game in fear of selling a treasure before it's fully combined together. In classic RE4 fashion, you can also shoot crows in the overworld for small treasures & loot drops. When entering a new area, always remember to walk slowly & listen for the cawing of the crows so you can get the shot off before your footsteps scare them away! 

There are puzzles of course. Push puzzles, ball puzzles, scavenger hunts, keys, locked doors, special sidequests for the serious completionists, this game has it all. You might find a key to a treasure all the way across the map, then you will find that, when you get back to open the treasure, there is now a massive enemy guarding the expensive loot. Always remember to check EVERY available area every time you revisit the Village, as the game changes states between areas, & there will be new events, new treasures, & new areas to revisit that were previously blocked off from backtracking. 

All in all, I 100% recommend Resident Evil: VIIlage wholeheartedly. This game was a ton of fun, & to be honest I have 100% completed the game 4 times now, once on Casual, once on Normal, & twice on Hardcore. It is a modern day classic, & in my humble opinion, fits right in snugly in my shelf of Resident Evil games, both physically & metaphorically. This game is the culmination of every fun aspect of every past Resident Evil title, while playing as the very likeable Ethan Winters & living through his amazing story of a loving father putting it all on the line unabashedly to save his daughter, whom he loves more than life itself. Any parents can instantly relate to the deep-seeded fear of having your baby snatched by psychopathic monsters, & would do exactly as Ethan does & charge in headfirst to get her back. 


All in all, PLAY THIS GAME. 9/10

It's always challenging to follow up on greatness, which [i]Resident Evil 7[/i] was for the survival horror genre. Sadly, [i]Resident Evil Village[/i] failed. And I know, I know, [i]"Weird slav man, who haveth a glorious moustache and a smile that brightens up even the blackest abyss, this review of yours has a blue thumbs up, yet it failed? Que?"[/i] Well, thank you. But yes, [i]Resident Evil Village[/i] did fail... in being a good survival horror game — [b]still a damn good action game tho.[/b]

So, let's talk about it.

[h3][b]Remember, no horny[/b][/h3]
Village picks up shortly after the last game. Ethan's chilling in his new funky house with Mia, his lovely wife, and Rose, his baby girl, all the way in Europe. Life is good for our boy, as he's far away from all that mold shenanigans. Anyway, [i]pew-pew-pew, punch, baby grab, car crash,[/i] and [b]bam![/b] Ethan's now staring at a giant medieval castle which looms over a small village and has but one thought on his mind, [i]"Where the heck am I?"[/i]

Oh yeah, and he also needs to find his daughter, Rose.

This is a return of the cheese, and lots of it, with outlandishly ridiculous backdrops and villains. And I didn't really care for the main baddies and their silly monologues, except for Lady Dimitrescu. There was just something different about her. Something [i]big[/i], voluptuous, and arresting of my gaze, but I couldn't quite grasp them.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2996106328
And after two games of seeing him flung around like a prop, Ethan grew on me like mold on a stale loaf of bread. Once again, without hesitation, he runs head-first, bare, into a burning building as the fires are being extinguished with gasoline, risking life and limb for those he loves, laughing in the face of death. And that ending... just [b]perfect[/b], that's all I'm gonna say.

Presentation-wise, [i]Village[/i] is a sensory blessing. I don't even need to worry about RE Engine delivering the goods — [b]it's a done deal.[/b] The design of the characters, enemies, the sheer amount of gore and other nasty effects are just incredible. I feel blessed to have my sight, so I can enjoy the brilliance of the RE Engine.

[i]Capcom's[/i] audio game is also on point, with every voice actor doing a great job, especially the villains. They really doubled down on the cheesy delivery and corniness. I liked it. As for the sound effects, look, my ears busted a nut every time I pulled off a headshot on one of the enemies in the game. Do with that graphic imagery what you will.

Now, onto the gameplay.

[h3][b]Spreading American culture in Europe[/b][/h3]
With a more significant focus on action, the freedom arsenal had to expand. And it did. With many guns at his disposal, Ethan effortlessly spreads the gospel of the freedom church, whether these residents like it or not. [b]Shooting still feels meaty[/b], with heads exploding like pinatas, showering me with all their juicy, gooey brain pulp if I'm standing in the splash zone, and I always am!

The pew-pew did stay the same, with only the [i]"parry"[/i] mechanic being new. You can now push enemies away by quickly pressing the block button after an enemy attack lands. So, not really a parry, but also kinda is... Anyway, other areas of the gameplay were slightly tweaked to complement this shift in focus from survival horror to action.

For one, [b]you can now upgrade every gun's stats[/b] (damage, reload speed, etc.) and even outfit them with [b]special attachments[/b], improving their quality. But guns aren't the only thing you can enhance. A delicious meal will not only quench Ethan's appetite for some good fucking food but improve his health, stamina, and so on. And all you need to do is find some wild game and bring its meat back to the Duke — [b]he'll cook you up a fancy meal in a jiffy.[/b]

[b]Resource management[/b] is no longer necessary, with the game showering you with items. And the famous inventory management mini-game returns, with Ethan carrying one spacious man purse. It can hold many items, big and small, and I got to play tons of Tetris, rotating and shifting my things around, all in the name of having everything compact and my inventory looking clean. Pure pleasure!

[h3][b]We're going to Villageland![/b][/h3]
[b]The game resembles a theme park[/b], with Ethan, the (un)lucky kid, getting to enjoy all the fancy rides. So, each level will have its own tale to tell, and will do so on its own terms. [b]The game doesn't have a single concept for every level.[/b] It loves tinkering; each level will deliver a different experience than the one you just beat. One may be super scary, while the next will douse you in water, probably also guts. One may even require you to look inward and start asking yourself the big questions, [b]"Do I have a giantess dominatrix fetish?"[/b] [i]—Yes...[/i]

But, to not spoil what awaits you, I'll briefly summarise the first level, excluding the village (hub area), to tease you a bit.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2993033059
[b]The castle section blends spooky and action[/b], not committing to full-on horror, like one later level, only flirting with it occasionally. And a [i]Resident Evil[/i] map not interconnected as heck is like going to a slava in Serbia and not drinking rakija until you see your ancestors. You just don't do that. So, it's good to see the castle section deliver in this area.

But this is also home to a few horrors and Lady D, who stalks the halls. She was hunting me as I leisurely roamed her residence, breaking stuff (some on accident, I swear) and looking for that next key story item.

And I'mma be honest, while she thicc, [b]her AI also thicc[/b], if you catch my drift. It's super easy to avoid her (not that I wanted to). She doesn't even have an [i]Ethandar[/i]... it's like a gaydar but used for instantly finding Ethan instead of hunky men. So, without one of those, unless I made eye contact with her big... eyes, yes, those, she wouldn't know I was sniffing the air behind her. And with the castle having plenty of rooms, some of which she can't even enter, despite it being [b]her[/b] castle, avoiding her was easy.

So, while Lady D's presence made [i]something[/i] rise, it wasn't the tension.

Thankfully, my biggest issue with [i]Resident Evil 7[/i] was addressed as [b]Village boasts excellent enemy variety.[/b] Fighting the same three moldy boys just didn't please me, but [i]Village[/i] pleased me — [b]I'm pleased.[/b]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2993516311
And [b]most levels introduce a new enemy[/b], giving combat a new spin. I now had to learn how to deal with this new, different foe from the ones I faced previously. [b]There are even hecking mini-bosses!?[/b] And boy, do they like eating bullets, love 'em, in fact. But feed them enough lead, and they'll eventually end up dead.

But what about them big tidd- I mean, big bosses... Yeah, they're pretty big. Definitely above 5'11''. And while still relying on the lazy [i]pump-and-dump-my-load-into-the-boss'-weak-spot[/i] strategy, each had a cool little gimmick for me to do, which made these fights fun. There's even a fricking mech fight! It was just a blast to blast these big baddies.

So, to end this high-quality review, a conclusive answer to the question, [i]"Is Resident Evil Village good?"[/i] must be given.

I dunno... [b]it's fun tho.[/b] And you know what rhymes with fun — [b]gun...[/b] And you use a gun here. So, make of that what you will.

[i]To see me ramble about Shadows of Rose, the post-launch story DLC, then check it out [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/Sv_Prolivije/recommended/1731080/]here[/url]. [b]But be warned, it contains major spoilers, for the base game as well.[/b]

All of you who made it this far are majestic sausages. And if you enjoyed this review, come, and consume more wisdom from the [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/40407656]Gospel of Sv. Prolivije.

The graphics are top-notch, with intricately detailed environments and the use of light and dark effects that create an even greater sense of realism. The castles you visit in the game are exceptionally well-designed, providing variety in the visual experience.

The gameplay strikes a balance between shooting and solving puzzles, adding an additional element of strategy to the game. The new enemies and bosses offer challenges, and the arsenal of weapons is satisfactorily diverse.

The game's story is mysterious, combining elements of traditional horror with unexpected twists in an intriguing and tense narrative. The ending leaves the player with a sense of surprise and a desire for more.

Despite some criticisms regarding certain aspects of the game design, Resident Evil 8 provides a scary and immersive experience for fans of the series and horror game enthusiasts in general.

Resident evil: village felt for me like a mix of RE4 and RE7.

The game has a great art style. All the Victorian-themed locations with breathtaking visuals, both in and outdoors, The village, the Dimetrescu castle, the surrounding forest. All of the locations are somehow unique, and carry distinctions from one another. Even the weapon visuals are designed in the same style. Engravings, color palette – they definitely feel like they belong to this world.

The engine, first-person perspective and combat system are the same as in RE7, with minor tweaks. Kudos to the developers - the game works smoothly even on my outdated GTX 960!

The gameplay has become smoother, there is more variety in weapons, almost all of them are useful in one way or another. Fighting different monster-mutants with your various arsenal is pretty fun. The weapon upgrade system is almost identical to RE4. And the crafting system is more like the one presented in RE7.

Exploration is pretty entertaining, but I didn’t appreciate that you mostly find money instead of some unique items. That sometimes felt like a lesser reward for my efforts. Might be personal though.

The replayability and additional modes are nice additions too. I personally enjoyed NG+ mode and completed the game like 3 times in a row. And all of the walkthroughs were equally enjoyable.

As for the story, well, it’s typical for resident evil. Yes, it is more down-to-earth and personal, compared to the ones before Ethan Winters became the main protagonist, but still quite predictable. 

To sum it up, Village is yet another solid addition to the resident evil franchise. Very fun and enjoyable, and I definitely suggest you try it.

[i] Village [/i] is definitely a good way to return to the old RE roots of exploration and survival. You can see this title takes a lot of inspiration from [i] Resident Evil 4 [/i] and if anything the Remake of that solidifies it in how to approach this title. 

As its namesake, the main HUB of this game is a Romanian Village. You return playing as Ethan Winters, the new RE protagonist who was introduced in RE7. You can see he had ended up with Mia Winters regardless of the baggage she had brought from the 7th Installment (if anyone was Team Zoey, I am sorry, I was conflicted about that choice as well). This game made me realise, in my least bias, that Ethan is one of the only people who can love and accept Mia. She was a jerk in RE7 and caused Ethan and so many people a lot of problems.

However, Ethan is more interested in building a life with her and even trusts she is private or closed off on certain things despite their history. Mia and Ethan now have a baby, Rosemary Winters. They kind of consider her a miracle and I think it is because of all Mia and Ethan went through in RE7 and I think it is simplified they were worried if The Mold made them infertile or caused mutations that would consider basic reproduction a risk. 

 However, all the events in 2017 Dulvey, Louisiana, has shaken Ethan to the core. He is not the same naive, optimistic person. Rather, he even says "It is not paranoia if they are really out to get you." He is scared for himself and his family and this creates some frictions with him and Mia who, despite being a key proponent to Dulvey, is somewhat over it.If you played RE4 Original and RE4 Remake you can see how Leon had changed significantly after the events of Raccoon City in RE2. A similar shift has happened to Ethan, he is no longer inexperienced and not the shy and passive systems engineer from 2017. Things go South, when Chris Redfield, someone Ethan trusts without a doubt, comes into his home and kills Mia Winters and kidnaps Rosemary, his daughter. These are not spoilers, this is the setting of the game as showcased by Capcom. 

Ethan is SHOCKED at Chris's betrayal and wants to find his daughter again who is further kidnapped by a group of mutants in an isolated Romanian village run by this weird Prophetess/Saint of a Black God named Mother Miranda. Hence, [i] Village [/i] is you, playing as Ethan Winters, uncovering the treacherous secrets of this remote Draculinian place in out of nowhere. I would say the atmosphere, ambiance and setting is quite GOOD for this kind of game. Unlike the heated and fetid swamp backwaters of Louisiana, Ethan now is in the arctic cold of Romanian Winters (his namesake) and must adapt to the weather and dangers that have come into this place. 

[b] GAMEPLAY: [/b] The game is designed around Stoker like symbolism, Romanian myths and iconography. It is Gothic in nature and blood and viscera play a deep role in creating the environments but also enhancing levels of fear, immersion and play. Unlike the visceral entanglements of the virus you have seen as large massive sacs of putrid flesh in RE2 Remake, [i] Village [/i] takes its influences from the medieval and European imagery of dungeons, torture devices and torment. It also has amazing artwork and paintings to heighten that kind of atmosphere and give it an architectural narrative. 

Speaking of architecture, this game is a visual feast. From Castle Dimitrescu and House Beneviento, you can see the creators have shaped it as a tour de force and to show the graphical excellence of the RE Engine. Even though this game was released in 2021, you can see that it has a lot of craft and care that still stands up today. The ambiance and cold of the Village, of castle walls and the houses, all beautifully detailed, are also somewhat hauntingly beautiful. You feel Ethan's sadness and isolation and as you play him in a village surrounded by werewolves and mutants, you feel his pain and dread. 

Gameplay enhances this with Ethan having thrust in cruel and unforgiving situations. His reactions to them are not like Leon, Jill and Chris. They seem to a mix between Claire and a younger Leon, in that he shows shock more often and despair, reminding you, underneath it all, Ethan is still a software guy who is way over his head. It actually makes him more relatable and enjoyable to play at times given that he is not trained exclusively by BSAA and also FBI or is not a cop in any shape or form. The enemies are well detailed and you can see that the first person view is meant to show you their nasty physiques and blood drenched mouths. As European lore is more into this game, the 'zombies' are more Lycans (werewolves), Vampires (mutants) and bizarre beings who fly and swim. They are a far cry to the non-intelligent zombies of RE2 and an upgrade to the Ganados of RE4, having more concentrated behaviour and abilities. New Game + allows you to explore the village more and get tons of goodies as weapons and such!

[b] CHARACTERS: [/b] I am not going to lie. I was never really a fan of Ethan Winters. I found him lacking in certain ways that Chris, Leon, Jill, Ada and Claire were not. Hell, revamped Carlos and Luis is WAY interesting to me. I noticed it also did not help that first person hides a lot of nonverbal stuff about Ethan. So, the new third person addition is awesome. It allowed me to like Ethan more and the secrets surrounding him are also quite appreciated. I loved that Capcom added that twist and I was waiting for something like that in the RE franchise. 

Though, I would not input so much into other characters aside Chris, Mia and The Duke.  Mother Miranda is very one dimensional. Even though she has a rich history apparently in this new RE mythos, she is annoying and kind of makes less sense than Wesker, Birkins and Spencer.  This is a trend in Capcom villains I noticed in their animated movies recently as well.  Miranda has the same sort of appeal as the main baddie from [i] Infinite Darkness [/i] Netflix show. Just there to be culled by you the gamer. Too much powers and less 'meat' to her motivations. 

The Lords, her 'children', are also quite forgetful in a way. You wish to learn more about them and their motivations but you can forget them. They function as obstacles to get to Rose rather than characters in their own right. Disappointingly, Lady Alcina Dimitrescu, who was the game's promotional villain, seems more like that, an ad hoc poster than a character.

Now, in [i] Shadows of Rose [/i] I have to say, older Rosemary Winters, leaves an impression on you. She is very complex and actually has complicated feelings and emotions. You can see her childhood was hard and she pines a lot for acceptance but is not really valued by ordinary people. I get the sense she is a kind of character who we will see more in the RE universe and I am grateful for it. Maybe, I am being a bit too hopeful, but I would want some of the complex philosophical questions RE putting out there to be fleshed out than just binary black and white. 

[b]  LORE: [/b] Lore needs work I think RE has a lot of ideas but does not wanna give them ALL at once. This a problem in modern gaming in general. Before, Games were not made by AAA studios and taking a franchise approach kind of ruins the storytelling process so I hope Capcom works on this. 

Overall, I will give [i] Resident Evil: Village [/i] an 8/10. I think it does show Ethan's (later on Rose's) journey from being unsure about themselves and the world, to being more formulated. It also shows a great way of understanding Chris aside than classic hero figure and we see him mature as well. Learning to trust and move forward in a world where bioweapons and eccentric beings live side by side an uninfected humanity or rather humans waiting to evolve and mutate as well.

Resident Evil oyunları arasında açık ara en keyif alarak oynadığım oyun budur. Oyunun oynanış mekanikleri gerçekten harika ve hissiyatlar gayet yeterli tatmin edicilikte olmuş. Oynanışın dışında oyunun hikayesi orta derecede güzel diyebilirim ancak önceki oyunuyla bir yere bağladıkları için yine de tatmin edici ve bir miktar şok edici hikayeye sahip. Oyunun en önemli unsuru olan korku ise belli başlı yerlerde ağırlıklı olmak üzere gayet güzel verilmiş. Kocaman bir köyde bir başınıza elinde hiçbir şeyi olmayan bir baba olarak ucube kurt adamların kol gezdiği, değişik lordların hüküm sürdüğü ve kendine bir tarikat kurmuş tanrıça Mirandaya karşı bebeğimizi kurtarmaya çalıştığımız saatler boyunca haritadaki yalnızlığımız ve güçsüzlüğümüz gayet güzel yansıtılmış. Grafikler konusunda da Capcom herzaman olduğu gibi harika grafiklere sahip bir oyun yapmış öyle ki bazı sahnelerde oyunu fotoğraflamak için defalarca durdurdum. Çok eğlenceli, tekrar oynanabilitesi yüksek harika bir oyun en kısa zamanda Resident Evil 9'u sabırsızlıkla bekliyoruz.

ngl at first I totally hated this game. I gave it a terrible review. I just didn't get the balance. The superficial simplicity of the combat (and frankly, Village of Shadow remains totally bull****).

but after playing the entire story on hardcore, I stand corrected. While dragged down by its lack of replayability (also don't play Village of Shadows, Hardcore is the correct difficulty), this game is just absolutely excellent. At first I *did not* get the combat system at all. Seriously. To this day I have trouble articulating how it's good at all. Really, truly, it's entirely functional. It gets the job done.

Really it's the set pieces that make this game - and the combat that does just enough to compliment them. You're just powerless enough to worry about how to handle any situation, but the combat system enables you to do exactly enough to get the job done. It's just a perfect blend of helplessness and function.

This game is so fined tuned. From the running speed, to the area design, to the enemy design - it's just perfectly balanced to create an immersive horror experience. It's very hard to articulate how a combat system more basic than 4, 5, 6 (anything's simpler than 6 :P) can work so well - but it does.

9.5/10. Really good game (but buy it on sale).

The game itself (mechanics) work well and is fun to play. Story-wise, the game is just like RE7: fine for the first 2/3rds, drops the ball in the last third of the game. Pacing toward the end feels rushed. However, because Capcom has decided to ban custom mods by adding another DRM tool I cannot recommend this game.

I played RE Village when it released day 1, and the DRM (denuvo) gave me nothing but a stutter-filled experience when I started firing my weapons. It was not a pleasant first experience, so I can only imagine it's going to be the same if not worse by having two DRM tools running in Capcom's games.

The fact that publishers like Capcom can retroactively change a product that YOU bought paid for a long time ago, just because they're butt-hurt over custom mods, is disgraceful.

This game is so good. I sometimes think it doesn't really exist. Like I had a dream about this game. And that's all it was. A dream. But then I wake up and remember that it is real. And it is amazing. Capcom really understood that the franchise was lost after RE4. Five and Six just were not scary, and people barely cared at all about the story anymore. They REvived the franchise with RE7. And managed to give us a game that is story and gameplay sequel to RE7. This game manages to recapture the magic and adrenaline rush we felt when we first got RE4 back to the house and loaded it up.

The gameplay is RE7 and RE4's passionate love child. There's a traveling merchant that sells you upgrades and buys things from you. THE ATTACHE CASE IS BACK. While simplified, the inventory management from RE4 is back. So people like me who like organizing their inventory may have to see a doctor for an arousal lasting longer that four hours. 

Speaking of lasting longer than four hours. The only thing I don't like about this game. Is that it is really short. There are five major areas in the game. One is full stealth and puzzle. One is a drawn out boss fight. One is mostly there for optional exploration. The first and last areas are more like the mansion from the first game. But the game can be completed in 5 hours. It really leaves you wanting more.

Capcom yet again listened to the audience and this time around, you will be fighting more than three types of enemies. It just warms my heart to know that there are still people out there who care about making good games and listening to feed back...okay, well. They ruined the RE3 remake...but no one's perfect.

If you're new to RE then I [b] DO NOT [/b] recommend this. Instead go play RE2 remake and go from there. If however you are familiar with RE or a veteran then I do recommend it.

I wasn't sure weather I was supposed to be scared or horny during the first act, so I just decided to be both. I believe this was the intended experience. The game could have benefited from a slower pace. The first half of the story felt a bit too fast. I was left disappointed by how quickly the most advertised and hyped character was just swept aside. This ended up making some characters come off as shallow and uninteresting. The second half of the game, however, is paced extremely well. I just wish I could have spent 10-20% more time in the vampire game I was expecting. Overall, on par with RE7 and good sequel.

After Act One, I stopped being horny and was just straight up scared. I beat Alien Isolation on max difficulty and assumed this would be a cakewalk in comparison. I was partially right, I wasn't TERRIFIED but I cowered in hidy-holes and procrastinated walking down a hallway for an hour because I no longer had my emotional support shotgun. RE7 WAS terrifying, this was a step down in that regard. 

The atmosphere and visual storytelling is top tier. This is one of the two W's eight takes over 7. I felt like a lone rat scurrying form place to place, always at risk of getting pinned by one of the cat's many claws. The world is beautiful and unsettling. I prefer it over the bayou.

Combat, what this game lacks in fear, it more than make up in panic. Overwhelming forces constantly kept me on edge. I never knew where an enemy was going to pop up and on higher difficulties a single hit will put you on the brink of death. The bonus content, additional orders, is nonstop action combat, and unlocking the special knife is a challenging but worthwhile quest. Additional orders alone is worth getting the gold edition for. The Rose DLC isn't bad either, not great but not bad.

Overall, get this game on sale so the gold edition is worth it. Otherwise, just replay RE7 and RE4. It's not the best game in the series but it's far from the worst.
