[h3] Quick Note [/h3]
TL/DR: It's a fun game, but it's not very scary, definitely less scary than RE7. There was one part of the game that was very scary (didn't rely on jumpscares as it's only horror element) and it was way too short IMO, as well as the final boss fight. I would recommend this game but only at a discounted price. Although it has A LOT of content, a lot of it is extra and I would not spend $40 to play the main story of this game.

  I want to start out by saying that my only experience with the Resident Evil franchise is games 7 and 8, so I'm not deeply attached to the lore or anything of that sort. My review is talking strictly about this game and comparing it only to RE7 (base game: I haven't played any DLC's), as that's the only other RE game I've experienced.
WARNING: RE8 is a direct sequel to RE7, and as such, my review WILL have spoilers for RE7 included that I'm not gonna block. I'll block any spoilers for RE8 that are in my review, but keep in mind that I'm only going to include mild spoilers such as the very start of the game or main characters that you meet, not actual plot points of the game. I know some people hate spoilers of any kind tho, so I wanna be courteous.

[h3] Story [/h3]
  You play RE8 as Ethan Winters, who is also the main protagonist of RE7. Without going into too much detail, after RE7 Ethan and Mia move far away from Louisiana and have a daughter named Rose. At the start of the game [spoiler] Mia is shot dead, and six-month old Rose as well as Ethan are abducted by Chris [/spoiler], playing as Ethan you wake up in the middle of nowhere. Essentially, you're wandering around trying to find Rose when you stumble upon the village, and the story takes place from there. Overall I really liked the plot of this game. It wasn't too confusing, it was sad but did a really great job of depicting how far a parent will go to save their child. The villains had great personalities and I enjoyed spending time with each of them. I would definitely recommend watching the small synopsis of what happened in RE7 at the start of the game if it's been a while since you've played. 

[h3] Pacing [/h3]
  It took me a little over 8 hours to beat the main story on normal difficulty. HOWEVER: I played the game while streaming to my brother (who has already played RE8 and knew a lot of the secrets), so he helped me out with small details that a new player would miss, such as [spoiler] shooting the sparkles in buildings that drop the crystals, where to find the animals you give to Duke (shopkeeper), explaining how to get to chests, etc. basically anything that I would figure out given enough time/looking up a guide [/spoiler]. For example, if I started walking into an area I couldn't interact with yet, he would say "There's nothing over there for you right now". I believe that his help shaved off a SIGNIFICANT amount of playtime from my game. It also made the game inherently easier for me, as it took me less time to get upgrades and money than a regular player would. So, I essentially played 8 hours of straight game; no wandering around, backtracking, looking up guides, etc. I personally think if I didn't have my brother helping me I would have liked the pacing of this game a lot less, as he didn't help guide me through anything significant, mostly just stuff about upgrading your weapons and looting.
  I was pretty disappointed with how they divided up the time you spend with the four bosses of the game. I'm not going to spoiler this because it isn't significant, but you spend the game in 5 different sections: the village, castle/Lady Dimitrescu, Donna's house, Moreau's reservoir, and Heisenberg's factory. As such, the four bosses (excluding the final boss, Mother Miranda) are Lady Dimitrescu, Donna, Moreau, and Heisenberg. It's debatable whether Heisenberg or Dimitrescu's section is the largest. I think Dimitrescu's section took me the longest cuz I was still being a pansy, had bad weapons, and didn't know how to play the game. Moreau's is in the middle, and Donna's section is SIGNIFICANTLY shorter than everyone else's. I'm talking like 45 minutes of gameplay at most, maybe and hour and a half if you're not very good at puzzles, while the rest took an hour or two at minimum. This was INCREDIBLY disappointing to me, as Donna's section was by far the scariest and my favorite section of them all. It's the only section focused strictly on horror, and has no survival or action elements at all.
  Overall the pacing was fine. I just wish Donna had more time in the spotlight, and that Ethan ran faster considering the amount of backtracking you have to do to get materials for upgrades.

[h3] Horror Factor [/h3]
  As I mentioned briefly above, 95% of this game only has jumpscares and a little bit of a ambiance horror. In all of the sections except Donna there are mindless goons you have to fight, which might give you a jumpscare here and there. Dimitrescu and Heisenberg both have enemies you have to strictly run from as you can't kill them, but I won't specify what. Those might give a little jump, but only for the 10-15 seconds it takes to evade them. Unfortunately Moreau has nothing special about his section horror wise that separates him from the others. The end of the game doesn't necessarily introduce anything new, but there's a lot of chaos that might cause you to panic.
  The section that was BY FAR the best in term of horror in my opinion is Donna's section. As soon as you get to a specific area in Donna's house, [spoiler] you're stripped of all of your weapons and are literally defenseless [/spoiler]. This is such a large change from the rest of the game that it immediately made me uneasy. The entire section involves a lot of dolls and mannequins, which I also find creepy. You also spend a portion of Donna's section [spoiler] in complete darkness [/spoiler], which again, is drastically different from the rest of the game and super scary. Essentially, Donna's section takes the game from [spoiler] being about fighting your enemy to running and evading them, similar to the Dad in RE7. [/spoiler].
  Overall, horror was meh except for Donna's section, which was genuinely unsettling and scary.

[h3] Characters [/h3]
  If there's one thing this game absolutely did right in my eyes, it's the characters. They're all so diverse and interesting, and I loved getting to know the details of all of their lives. Heisenberg was my favorite character due to his personality (wink) and his witts. Lady Dimitrescu is tall scary vampire mommy, Moreau is basically a cuckold momma's boy (I felt sooo bad for him), and Donna is a very mentally disturbed and scared girl. Very diverse set of villains, which I loved. Miranda was pretty cool to, but I didn't like her as much as the rest of the cast which I contribute to the fact that you spend significantly less time with her versus the other villains.

[h3] Game play [/h3]
  RE8 follows the trend of all the other RE games of being a combination of survival, horror, and action. On normal difficulty there were many times where I was struggling for resources (mostly ammo), but I think I only died a handful of times throughout the game. It's pretty similar to RE7 game play wise, just a lot less horror elements imo.

[h3] Visuals [/h3]
It's a really nice looking game. There's a lot of details in all of the areas you explore.

[h3] Final Thoughts [/h3]
  It's a great game, but I personally wouldn't spend $40 on it, especially if you only plan on playing the main story or if you're looking for a really solid horror game. I liked the game play, I liked the narrative, but overall it just wasn't scary to me.  Even though I generally dislike horror games, I was still pretty disappointed. Essentially, once you figure out the "gimmick" to the section you're in, any horror factor is gone (except for Donna's section, as there really aren't any gimmicks, it's just scary lol). Would recommend at a discounted price!

[h1]The Gameplay: [/h1]
Basically take RE7 and just add in more engaging combat because Lycans do not play with you. You now have a push mechanic when enemies grab you, as well as having some Quality of Life upgrades such as being able to break boxes without having your knife out. This is coupled with an inventory system similar to RE4 where somehow you don't feel like your choking for space. Overall it's a big improvement from 7's controls and gameplay loop.

[h1]The Story:[/h1]
Bringing back Ethan Winters was an interesting choice, but it allowed us to play someone who wasn't built like a brick shit house and does this every day. It builds up a good mystery and even has a good piece of bait to keep the story going. The big bad also had a nice twist as to the implications of who she is, however, she fell a little short to her underlings. It sort of had a Farcry 3 effect where once Vaas was gone, the big bad didn't matter as much.

[h1]The Visuals:[/h1]
Gorgeous, with their scenery and enemy models. The Lycans were indeed top tier and some of the enemies looked like they came out of Bloodbourne which was a welcome change of pace. This is probably the strongest aspect of this game, and somehow outdoes it's other RE Engine predecessors, which is quite the feat since they are all using the same engine.

[h1]The Sound:[/h1]
The voice actors did an excellent job of making the experience feel magical. They really sucked me in and kept me locked in immersion so hard I forgot this was just a game and not a real exchange at times. The sound effects are truly satisfying and terrifying all at the same time. The music was that and I could not remember it, but it did it's work well.


[h1]The Experience:[/h1]
This game was both not what I expected but also exactly how I imagined it would be. This is gives me hope for the future of Resident Evil in terms of an ongoing story that doesn't rely soley on it's remakes. I am glad they are making those remakes, but I am also glad they are looking to make solid titles for the future. This new vision for Resident Evil is one I am glad has matured to this almost fine wine of a game series. This is an obvious recommend for the game.
In my honest opinion, it's the best RE game: the perfect balance of horror and action. It is the spiritual successor to the renowned RE 4 from 2005.

Loved every second of it. I played this game on PS5 on release and after about 3 years I finally played it again on PC in the new third person camera view and I truly think this game is very underrated and under appreciated, at least by hardcore RE fans. Resident Evil Village does a great job implementing all of the best qualities of the Resident Evil games that we all love. 

The level design was incredible in this game. One thing that I think makes a Resident Evil game amazing is the level design and utilizing the different areas to their fullest extent, which is something I think the OG Resident Evil games mastered and Capcom seemed to forget for over a decade after RE4. Capcom redeemed themselves with recent titles, specifically RE2 Remake and RE7. RE2 remake specifically with the RPD section did so well with this and forcing the player to back track constantly to find clues, solve puzzles or complete objectives while combining this with horror elements. Village does an amazing job providing incentives to go back and search areas you were at before to find things you may have missed and implementing things like secret boss fights and new loot. 

Some of the puzzles in this game were trickier than we've seen in recent RE games and I appreciate the effort they put into this with village. OG RE games had some of the most difficult puzzles and it felt refreshing to feel lost again in an RE game. 

Horror elements were strong in this game and providing a variety of different enemy types and situations that were RNG.

The Winters story was the best in the series with RE7 and Village. RE has never been known to have great stories so it felt good to see them put so much effort into it.

The medieval theme was beautiful and so well done.

I think RE Village is easily top 5 in the series although I know hardcore RE fans will lose their mind over this.

A good game all-around, worth picking up. A few things could be better, though. Keep reading...

--------------

1. This doesn't strike me as a Resident Evil zombie game. It seems more like a Lovecraftian story. I'm not complaining (much), just commenting on it. The bad guys seemed more like fairy tale horrors than zombified. (In fact, there aren't any zombies in this game at all.) There are werewolves, witches, fish men, cyborgs, giants, etc. etc. .... it's just a different genre.

2. Ammo and supplies could be more plentiful, but the shop feature seems to fill in the gap for the most part. 

3. Some of the puzzles and obstacles need improvement. The most glaring example of this is where you have to change the order of six cylinders in a music box so you can gain access to a door key in it. All of the parts look the same, so it's hard to figure out which order to use. Another example would be in Moreau's Reservoir. Here, you have to throw some switches in order for pieces of a bridge to rise up out of the water so you can reach a little island in the middle. The issue is that the bridge pieces will drop back in the water after a few seconds and there's just not enough time to throw the switches and make it to the other side. A few extra seconds would have spared me countless nights of swearing to the Heavens because I couldn't finish this part.

4. The story was excessive, to say the least. The cutscenes go on for WAY too long and reference things from previous titles that just don't make any sense if you haven't played them. The whole story seems to almost have a strange "lost in translation" feel to it, like when you watch a subtitled foreign film and it's just too difficult to interpret. Fortunately, you can skip cutscenes.

---------------

I originally recommended this game.  Having had more time to think about it, and having spent some time on the RE4 remake; I realized.  This game... isn't very good.  Oh, don't get me wrong; it's not BAD.  There's a fair bit that they did right.  The environments are suitably creepy and the graphics are good.   The problem is; it's basically RE4, with a less interesting protagonist, mold in stead of bugs, and less satisfying combat.  Oh, there are other differences; after all, it's in Romania, which is totally different from Spain!  Sure, there's a run-down village, a big castle, a merchant, and all that, but it's different, okay?  The major issue I have is this; the RE4 remake makes it clear that someone who works with the franchise understands having weapons that are just FLAT OUT better than the weapons that use the same ammunition is not fun.  The LEMI is completely made useless by the 1911, and the 1911 is made completely useless by the Vz. 61, or whatever they call it.  There's simply no reason to use anything other than the best weapon.  I also don't care for the (admittedly tense) Beneviento house.  Don't get me wrong, it was fun the first time through, but between just having some weapons flat-out better and that section bringing the pace of the game to a grinding halt while the protagonist works through his fear of fatherhood; it removes virtually all replay value for me.   Which is what this series has mostly been about.  Oh sure, they tried to make up for that by adding unlockable weapons, but guess what?  Those are either a joke weapon (the gyrojet pistol), a totally better than the magnum automag (or a revolver that fires rifle rounds), or... an automatic rifle.  They're also kind of boring.  Also, I pointed out in my original review that the "Not a hero" DLC for REVII proved that ADS is possible in the engine.  I don't know why they just did the tightened reticle in first person rather than having the character use the sights.  Which is another issue; you don't need to aim to shoot, although given the speed of the basic enemies I see why they went that way.  In any case, not the best RE game, and not one that I can really recommend, with the benefit of hindsight.

Resident Evil Biohazard and Resident Evil Village are the best games in the series. I've already written a review of RE Biohazard, so let's talk about RE Village.

This game best depicts the “horror” genre; it is not oversaturated with jump scares, scary music, or darkness.  Each character is unique, with their own story, and frightening in different ways.  I would like to be like Miss Dimitrescu, walking around my huge luxurious castle in a long dress, wearing red lipstick and hunting men.  Well, okay, let's skip this point.

The uniqueness of the game is that in addition to horror elements, it contains a plot with deep meaning.  I haven't seen horror like this often.  Basically, you go around killing creatures just to kill creatures.  The plot does not touch the soul, but here at the end I shed a tear. 

Of course, the game also has its downsides.  For example, not all glass breaks, bullet marks don't always remain, but the game is so beautiful that I can close my eyes to it.

To conclude, Ethan Winters is the best father.

This game is incredible and reveals a great twist on the RE way. The first person does a great job of immersing yourself in the horror experience. I hope more RE games follow the trend set by RE7 and RE8.

It's not as good as RE7, but taken as a whole, the Ethan Winters duology is a strong two-punch return to form from Capcom. The lore and series continuity is as convoluted and as contrived as ever, and I can't help but wonder if 7 could've been their chance to do a complete reboot -- it tried the soft reboot thing with a new first person perspective, a new protagonist in Winters, and taking cues from the likes of Kojima's P.T. and more recent flavours of horror (instead of originally ripping off Romero's zombie canon) but the Umbrella connection is still shoehorned in, Chris still shows up, and it still follows the Mikami formula of tension and dread in an enclosed space >> which opens up to a larger space as more puzzles and combat is laid on >> finally a climatic shoot-out in a high tech lab or some such, etc. Not that any of this matters with how loosey goosey RE can be in its own storytelling logic (and who plays RE for the story amirite).

Ethan Winters is a bit more compelling as a protagonist this time around and the Shadows of Rose DLC is a nice coda to it, to say nothing of its smart reuse of 8's assets, as I felt even Capcom knew they underutilized the fantastic Castle & Beneviento maps, the latter of which gets a chance to truly shine in its redux.

The Steam/PC version is a mixed bag. If you install RE Framework or similar mods to say, unlock the FoV, you may run into system instability like I did (perhaps caused by Denuvo rearing its ugly head if you have the DLC installed?). And really that console level FoV of like, 10, is inexcusable for a PC port in 2023. Playing on KB+M always feels off, while the controls on gamepad aren't great either (something to do with mouse acceleration or some such, IDK). Enabling RT will cut your framerate down by a lot, and offers subtle but barely noticeable differences to my untrained eye, so I'd say leave it off. Lack of Nvidia DLSS support, or an updated version of AMD FSR (stuck on 1.0), or hell, Intel XeSS is also unfortunate. Capcom will go through the effort of having sliders that show the performance impact of each setting on your system components -- great! -- but then bizarrely make you click RMB to back out of its options menu instead of using Esc, or bind Ctrl by default as a Use key instead of crouch -- wth??

Can't say I'm optimistic for RE9, knowing Capcom's history with this series, but 8 isn't any worse than previous games and is a strong, if uneven entry.

Resident Evil Village stands as a testament to the pinnacle of modern gaming, excelling in its visuals and a narrative that keeps players enthralled from start to near-finish. The game boasts unparalleled graphics that elevate the immersive horror experience to new heights. Its storyline, rich in depth and intrigue, captivates players, leading them through a thrilling and eerie journey filled with twists and turns.

However, the brilliance of this game takes a slight hit due to its conclusion. The ending, unfortunately, doesn't quite match the incredible build-up, leaving some players feeling a touch dissatisfied after investing deeply in the game's narrative.

Nevertheless, Resident Evil Village remains a standout title in the franchise, showcasing the developers' expertise in creating an unforgettable gaming experience. Despite its minor flaw, it manages to deliver an exceptional horror adventure that fans of the series and newcomers alike should not miss

Another game I'd really appreciate having a "Neutral review" option for.

There's a lot to like about Village. The atmosphere, the enemy (visual) design, the RE4 throwbacks (only works if you've played and enjoyed that game though)...

But there are so many glaring flaws that really make me wonder how this game still comfortably sits on an "Overwhelmingly positive" review status.

Too much action, not enough survival or horror. The writing gets really corny at times, the plot has infuriating holes, Chris is portrayed like a TOTAL DUMBASS just for the sake of the plot... and to be honest so is Ethan on many occasions.

Then there's the Hardcore difficulty. While playing the 2 and 3 remakes on harder difficulties was fun, this one is just... "what were they thinking?" Enemies are just bullet sponges and hit like a truck, which would be fine if other aspects of the game were balanced so you could effectively play around that... but nope. It's like the devs just cranked up some sliders and called it a day.

I don't think it's a "bad" game by all means, I just can't rightly give it a "positive" review given how flawed a game this is. If you're going to get this game, try to get it on sale, first of all, and then either play it on Standard for your first run, or if you REALLY must play on Hardcore, then look up a guide on how to beat the first scripted sequence so you don't bash your head against a wall for an hour or more.

EDIT: Also god DAYMN the mercenaries mode in this game is a flaming hot pile of garbage. Probably the worst in the history of the franchise. Yet another reason I don't understand the unreal praise this game seems to get. But I wouldn't be surprised if most people just played the campaign and then put down the game without even checking out that mode. Ignorance is bliss, then.

9/10 - I'd highly recommend it. But you need to play RE7 first.

Resident Evil Village is literally a sequel to Resident Evil 7: Biohazard, so, you absolutely need to play RE7 first in order to understand what's going on. It would help if you've played the earlier titles as well, as this game does not hold your hand or teach you how to play. It kind of expects you to know how to play Resident Evil and what Resident Evil is, because it just launches you right into it and I love it for that. The RE formula is pretty simple so there's really no need for a tutorial. It is a horror game after all, and it's supposed to venture a little bit in the unknown and unfamiliar. I think any RE fan would appreciate this as well, because the game flows pretty smoothly as is.

I must admit, the beginning is a little slow, but the more you play, the more I feel this game rewards you. Each new area seems to make the game more fun as you progress and find or unlock new stuff, encounter new enemies, fight bosses, overcome obstacles, and solve puzzles in each section.

All in all, Resident Evil Village is a great game to play. I don't know if it would be accurate to say it's a pure horror game, but it definitely has it's moments. There is a healthy variety of horror, action, fps, story, survival, and atmosphere with this game that makes it a very well-rounded experience that you will want to play again and again. 

In my opinion, RE VILLAGE feels like it's own game mixed in with elements from the original Resident Evil, RE0, and RE4 especially. If you like any of those games you will like this one for sure. I wouldn't say it's the best Resident Evil title of all-time, because the first one still takes the cake for me, but it's definitely up there in contention for top 5 or even top 3. Resident Evil Village is an absolute must if you're a fan of the series or just looking for a fun game to play!

Okay so... I avoided this game for about 2 years because quite frankly outside of a few aesthetic choices, the game looked pretty boring. Having played through the whole thing now, I can say it's not as boring as I expected. As games in general go, it's a bit flawed but pretty good, but as RE games go it's just kinda mid. Honestly I'm 90% sure people just meat ride Village because it's the slightest tinge scarier than RE 5 and 6.

So in regards to story and themes, this game's all over the place. It tries to recreate the vibes RE4 had by redoing a lot of scenes from that game while also trying to expand the enemy variety beyond just zombies, giants, and bugs by taking inspiration from Werewolves, vampires, bog monsters... I think you get the idea. As far as "Civilians who find themselves suddenly in the thick of it" protagonists go, Ethan's reactions and confusion are at least plausible and potentially realistic if nothing else. Frankly only a small handful of moments in the game are actually properly scary (that baby can fuck right off), and I think this is mostly because it lacks the nuance that games like RE4 had. RE4 wasn't scary just because you were fighting freaky monsters in a forested village and ancient castle, it was also scary because of little things like the creepy synth music sounding haunting and unnatural, because of things like the bug monsters and regenerators looking inhuman and making you question if you could even win in the first place, because you yourself were infected as well and were essentially a ticking time bomb even if it didn't reflect in gameplay. In Village, you have what? Lady D? Who looks pretty much like a normal human albeit pale and abnormally tall? The majority of people just fap to her rather than fear her. Most of the time the game just relies on gore to try to scare you, and frankly that isn't scary, it's just gross...

Gameplay-wise there's very few actual flaws at all. Most of the flaws that are present are from the puzzles themselves. They're all pretty easy to be completely honest. I got stumped a few times, but those moments were rare. The levels also aren't super open either, they mostly just loop back into themselves to progress. If you've ever played the indie FPS known as DUSK, you know what I'm taking about. The level design uses the same rules as DUSK, which isn't bad by any means, but that doesn't make the level design open with choices and freedom. Also, most of the time, the enemies you face will be the same werewolf-type enemies you encounter in the village areas. The few major enemies that deviate from that that aren't bosses are the gargoyles, some cellar zombies, and some mechs. The biggest flaw with this enemy roster is that it's short which makes it a bit repetitive, otherwise it's fine and the enemies are fun to fight. The crafting system doesn't really have much to talk about, it's a simplified system similar to the Xbox 360 version of Minecraft.

I made quite a few negative comments about the game, but even so I can't outright say the game is actually bad, because it isn't. Though I probably could say it's a bad RE game, because it rarely felt like one. It felt more like a game made by a completely different studio trying to make a knockoff of RE that also took good notes and ideas from RE but didn't fully understand what made them tick. It understood the series better than 6 did at least, sure, but I still don't think it understood enough.

Yeah, I bought it b/c big lady memes.
I'm not buying another RE game ever again.

Really good installment in the franchise. This game takes a step towards being a military shooter again rather than survival horror, something which RE7 was trying to prevent being a sorta hard reset in the series as that game was purely a survival horror experience, however, I thought this game did a good job at blending the genres together, making the game feel like a survival horror when it wants the player to be scared, while in other sequences your character will be blasting magnito in a mechanized tank. 

Game play (8/10) -
If I had to compare the game to other installments in the series, I would say that it plays like RE4, taking a lot of the game play mechanics like the merchant and the crafting system, but toned it down as you are not a MMA special forces agent. The combat system is not my favorite, but at the same time making Ethan into a one man army that can right hook enemies across the room would've drastically impacted the tone Capcom was going for in this game

Story (10/10) - 
This game probably has the best story in the franchise, there are constant twists and turns that will keep the player on their feet while not feeling too cheep or contrived. Ethan is a very sympathetic character that you really do root for while you are playing through, and the villains and monsters feel like they have a lot of development. I don't want to get too deep into the story as there would be a lot of spoilers, all I can say is to play the game and experience it first hand.

Overall (9/10)
I really enjoyed this game, and like the direction the franchise is headed in, my only worry is that Capcom may go back into making full military shooter games again like the notorious RE6, but as long as they balance their game play as well as they did in this game, it will be yet another great installment in my favorite game series.

Terrible port. Decent game

Resident Evil Village is the 8th main installment of this series, and it brings some awesome things to the table.  I was very close to giving it a 10/10 for the first few hours I played, but some glaring issues came about that kept bugging me and hindered my enjoyment of the game.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
-Resident Evil 4 inspired inventory and gameplay that is great to see return.
-Beautifully crafted, varied environments.
-An interesting story that kept me engaged which continues the events of Resident Evil 7 directly.
-Exciting combat counters with punchy weapons.
-Some intense boss fights.
-Guarding is required more often in this game compared to RE7 which keeps you on your toes.
-New characters that are mostly interesting and likeable.
-Tall Vampire Lady!!  Jokes aside, Lady Dimitrescu and her daughters were awesome.  [spoiler]I think they should have been the main antagonists like the marketing for the game made it seem.  I didn’t care about Mother Miranda as much[/spoiler].
-Some earned scares, and moments where I really felt afraid.

[h1]Things I was mixed on:[/h1]
-Kind of silly, but you can't assign the Mr. Raccoon/Mr. Everywhere charms on more than 1 weapon, the first pistol and first shotgun.  That just seemed strange to me.
-Base enemies don’t feel that varied.  They all behave pretty much the same way, but have a different model to fit the area they’re in.
-Some parts leaned too much towards the action side of things, and felt more on-the-rails than I would have liked.  I get nervous when that happens in this series, because I don’t want it to go back in the direction of Resident Evil 6.
-The game frequently told me I could press LB to push an enemy away, but I couldn't get it to work at all.  I tried several times but I just never got the timing of it.  As of 5-10-2021, I still don't have the achievement for doing it once lol.  
-Story issue: [spoiler] Chris being really mean to Ethan for the first 3/4ths of the game, and not filling him in on what was happening on despite having ample opportunity to do so.  It’s like he reverted back to meanie pants poopy face alcoholic amnesia Chris from RE6.  This is only made worse by how they acknowledge it towards the end of the game, where Ethan and another character say Chris should have told Ethan what was going on.  Yet, despite those moments of the story’s self-awareness, it doesn’t provide any meaningful reason as to why Chris acted the way he did.  It basically just boils down to ‘he messed up’ because he’s human and his emotions got the better of him.  That plot point can work very well in some stories, but it falls flat here.[/spoiler]. 
-The story moves [i]very[/i] quickly towards the end of the game despite moving pretty slowly for most of it.  It suddenly goes from 0-100 and throws so many revelations at you I found it kind of hard to keep up.
-The voice lines for Chris and Heisenberg lacked good direction at some points.  The actors did great work with what they were given.  But, there were some lines where if I was the director I would've called for re-recordings.  The most notable one for me was when Chris is talking to [spoiler]Mia about Ethan being gone, towards the end of the game[/spoiler], and he sounds like he has a Boston accent.  I felt like that delivery just didn't work for Chris's character.  There were also times with Heisenberg where his sentence inflections really stood out to me as odd, but this may have been intentional.  
-The RE4-style inventory is really cool, but it doesn’t work as well as it did in RE4.  In RE4, if you were moving an item and pressed the button to place it down over another item, for most item pairs it would swap them so you place down your currently held item and pick up the other one.  This was useful if you wanted to place a gun in a spot but there was a grenade somewhere in that space – it would put down the gun and pick up the grenade so you could put it somewhere else.  In Village, this [i]only[/i] happens with ammo over other ammo, after pressing the button multiple times.  This got frustrating fast, as my muscle memory from RE4 kept kicking in (I beat it 3 times before Village came out).  It makes organizing the inventory slower.
-The game is really linear.  There is rarely a moment where you have to stop, look at your item inventory, and think about what you have to do to progress.  The way forward is always pretty clear.  It makes the Resident Evil 4 influence obvious, and I felt like it didn’t work as well for this game.  It’s still a really well done game world and its areas flow from one to the next.  But, the no-loadscreen open world design gives the impression that it will be more like a bigger version of the RPD from RE2 Remake or the Baker House of RE7, where you’re having to run back and forth through areas you’ve opened to solve new puzzles as you acquire more key items.  I suppose this could be true about the Village in the middle, but [spoiler]you really just run through it aside from unlocking some bonuses.  Nothing mission critical is present there after the beginning of the game[/spoiler].

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
-Mia. In RE7, she was a badass double agent who put up a cute wife façade for Ethan while fulfilling her own Ada Wong-style agenda with her other secretive work.  In this game, [spoiler]she gets completely sidelined, and turned into a damsel in distress.  Her involvement in the Eveline mold project is never explained.  She does nothing noteworthy and gets no development because for most of the game you think she’s dead[/spoiler].  I wasn’t a huge fan of that.
-Sometimes after getting grabbed by an enemy, another one would grab me immediately after I got let go, before I could get a chance to guard or heal.  Uncommon, but really lame when it happened.  Broke immersion.
-We still do not get to see [spoiler]Ethan’s face, despite there being a cutscene where he is with Chris where there was a perfect opportunity to do so – we see 95% of his head, just not his face.  Literally all he had to do was look up at Chris while he spoke, but for some silly reason he just looks at the ground[/spoiler].  That really annoyed me because it felt like we were going to see it, and then we don’t.  
-[spoiler]Lady Dimitriscu (and her daughters)[/spoiler] and [spoiler]Heisenberg[/spoiler] were criminally underused.  I felt like you could’ve cut out [spoiler] House Beneviento and Moreau’s Resevoir [/spoiler] entirely to focus more on expanding [spoiler]the Castle and the Factory[/spoiler].  On that note, I found the castle to be really short despite marketing making it seem like it would be one of the game’s main recurring areas, which was disappointing since it and Lady Dimitrescu are two of the best things about this game.  I really didn’t like that [spoiler]it’s completely blocked off once you leave and you are not allowed to go back.  Why?  I could understand if the game was even more like RE4 where you completely leave the village/castle and go to another place, but you don’t.  The castle just sits there, barring you from entry[/spoiler].  Lame.

Despite my criticisms, I did enjoy my time overall with Resident Evil Village.  It is a welcome entry to the series and a polished experience.  It's an impressive feat to keep the series feeling fresh and fun despite being over 20 years old. It's not a bad game, it's a good game in its own right. It's just not a great Resident Evil game.

I have played every mainline RE game since its inception in 1996. RE8 is a pinnacle in game design with elements of metroidvania, puzzle solving games like Myst, and slower paced tactical action. Personally I found the gonzo plot enthralling with elements of classical horror, J-horror, and body horror. I have an RTX 3080 and i played the game at 1080p/max settings/60fps buttery smooth. The graphics are close to photo realistic in spots. I hope the developers at Capcom continue to refine and evolve this series and if you have any interest at all in the RE series than i highly recommend this installment.

For the longest time I avoided playing RE Village and 7 because they are first-person and the protagonist is not one of the classic characters. But now I believe Village has the most meaningful story out of any RE title and Ethan is easily one of my favorite characters. They really nailed the fairy-tale vibe it felt like they were going for while still making it feel like a Resident Evil game.
The gun-play is great and first-person view feels really nice. Popping lycan heads is one of the most satisfying things in the whole franchise. But the movement, inventory and a few other things are lacking. Stuff like,
1. Opening and closing the map while running makes Ethan come to a complete halt for a second before he starts running again.
2. Cant swap inventory items unless they are the exact same size and positioned exactly on top of each other.
3. No FOV settings in an FPS game.
4. The beginning part of the game is quite a drag on repeated playthroughs but it's whatever.
5. Can't pop the heads of certain enemy types which feels dissatisfying, since they seem most likely to have their heads blown off.

However these issues were not in RE4R so i guess they wont be a problem in future games either. All-in-all, very fun game. Might even try RE7 someday.

If RE VII was a recreation of original RE but in first person perspective then REVIII is a remake of RE4. 
REVIII is definitely a much better survival horror than IV and that shines on harder difficulties where you are forced to run from the enemies and not engage them. 
The first village section though it's a reference to opening of RE4 overall is more similar to opening of RE2 which is the hardest opening in the history of the series. Sadly it's one of those segments that demands from you some external knowledge to complete it, so I recommend checking a walkthrough were you to play the game on Hardcore or Village of Shadows.
Overall structure is also much better. Village and Castle offer some good old Resident Evil puzzle solving and Factory was a surprisingly good level, usually a quality drops for the last section of the game.
Bosses are fun, some are obnoxious but in the end, it's a very good Resident Evil. I liked it more than RE4(2005).
Mercenaries are sadly disappointing. New structure isn't even half as fun as the one in RE6. Which is a shame because Chris' straight punch is one of my favourite attacks in the whole series.

Resident Evil Village is an exceptional addition to the acclaimed Resident Evil series, offering a captivating blend of horror, action, and exploration. The game's atmospheric setting, set in a mysterious Eastern European village, creates an immersive and chilling experience for players. The narrative is compelling, weaving together elements of folklore, supernatural threats, and personal tragedy. The protagonist, Ethan Winters, is a relatable and engaging character whose journey through the village is fraught with tension and terror. The game's graphics are stunning, showcasing detailed environments, eerie lighting, and grotesque enemies. The gameplay mechanics are polished, offering a balance of combat, puzzles, and exploration. The introduction of new antagonists, such as Lady Dimitrescu, has added an iconic and memorable dimension to the game. The soundtrack and sound design effectively heighten the game's atmosphere, contributing to its overall immersive quality. Resident Evil Village has been widely praised for its ability to deliver a captivating and chilling experience, making it a standout title in the survival horror genre. Whether a fan of the series or a newcomer, players are likely to find themselves engrossed in the haunting world of Resident Evil Village.

Resident Evil: Village on Steam works on Steam Deck, but not on Mac and not in VR even though Steam supports both Mac and VR.
Resident Evil: Village on the Mac devices and iOS devices, but you have to buy it separately and there's no cross-buy on any other platform.
Resident Evil: Village VR is only available on PS5.

Ideal: Buy it on Steam which allows play on Mac and PC with SteamVR supported. Actual solution: Not enjoying any of it.

I recommend to play this game however I'm giving it a negative vote because I can see how Capcom is making this slowly like a Cod survival horror game that is being made for the mainstream audience. The story is lame and the main characters like Ethan/Mia/Rose are such a bore. Dialog and acting is horrendous and not in a good way like how old school RE games were. I would like to see more cool cutscenes instead of this overrated Half-life-like pov camera system during cutscenes. The music was bland. I think the mercenaries missions and the Rose DLC is probably the worst extra content in any RE game to date.

I'm also sick of playing with this dark vignette border around my screen that Capcom loves so much. And this little FOV they gave us in this game... Capcom, if you feel the need to introduce these artificial ways to make the game feel scary, you are doing "survival horror" wrong... The game needed more time in the castle with the vampires. I can't believe they killed Lady Dimitrescu so quickly. She was the most interesting enemy. The end boss was horrible. The rest of the enemies were bland. I thought Magneto was gonna be cool in the beginning but nope. Jill needs to be in the game too. 

One thing definitely needs to be said. DO NOT MAKE RESIDENT EVIL OPEN WORLD CAPCOM. Making games open world ruins almost every other aspect of games. Just look at the new Zelda games as an example with its huge EMPTY world. Making RE open world raises budgets that will invite cheap ways to charge consumers for content. Then you will compete with COD and RE will be mainstreamed. Then Capcom will put too much weight into one franchise because of the massive budget needed for RE games.

Besides all that negative stuff...it was a good game to actually play however it has a lot of glaring issues. You may not initially see or notice it because of the AAA budget RE games get now. I understand Capcom needs to appeal to many people because of the massive budgets, but if they aren't careful, RE won't have an identity anymore. Also, get rid of this stupid Ethan storyline already. No one cares about any of these characters. Maybe create stories off of family members from deceased STARS members. I have a feeling the sequel is going to have you using weird nonsense powers similar to the Rosa DLC.

Resident Evil Village continues the gripping narrative of Resident Evil 7, seamlessly blending iconic elements from its predecessors. It skillfully navigates between the survival horror ambiance of earlier games and the action-oriented approach of later installments. The captivating storyline and atmospheric design create an exceptional experience. If you like the Resident Evil gameplay loop, then you should definitely give it a try. Opting for the Gold edition is recommended, as it includes a compelling story DLC that introduces innovative gameplay elements never before seen in the series. Notably, the DLC features one of the most impressive boss fight in the series.

Lycan-zombies-things bite half your hand off? Pour some disinfectant on it, you'll be fine.
Vampire maggot/fly ladies impale you on meat hooks? Pour some disinfectant on it, you'll be fine.
Rip your hand in half through anchor hooks? Pour some disinfectant on it, you'll be fine.
Get your hand cut off by a 10-foot thicc vampire lady? Reattach it and pour some disinfectant on it, you'll be fine.
Get mauled by a werewolf-person-dog-thing? Pour some disinfectant on it, you'll be fine.

I swear this game is just one long masochism simulator topped by several gallons of miracle-cure disinfectant . Umbrella Corp should really patent this stuff and sell it on store shelves, they'd make a killing off it.
And this big bad thicc 10-foot vampire lady seriously needs to hire a contractor to renovate all those doorways, no clue how she's lived so long in that castle without doing some serious remodeling.

And don't get me started on the atrocious ADS - instead you get a slightly more zoomed in hip-fire. Console devs and their abysmal dependence on crosshairs.

For the most part though, the game is pretty good and I've had some decent fun with it. 

The boss enemies were done well except for the guy that throws gears and sprockets at you. He was just annoying. They could have made an entire game out of the 10 foot thicc vampire chick though - I'd play that - everything else was bland in comparison. Except maybe the doll house, it was fun. But nothing has freaked me out more than the giant baby screaming fetus-maggot-caterpillar thing.

Sadly: Two of the best "mini-boss" characters in the game were lacking on screen time. They could have done so much more with their zones. Like the devs couldn't decide on which direction to go so they just went with a little bit of everything, but they could have added a lot more of a bit of everything.

It’s a game not like any other, if you haven’t experienced other RE games that is. I can imagine playing this for the first time without having any knowledge or experience in the RE games and what an unique experience this must be. RE7 walked so Village could run. I experienced the same sense of twisted wonder as I had in Dark souls (3). 
The areas are extremely detailed, super immersive and varied. It feels like playing through a mix of an Evil dead type action and horror movie. There’s an element that is unique to the series that I feel can't be tied to an existing piece of media. You'll be exploring insanely tense close quarter horror to spectacular gothic setpieces, fighting off enemies that vary in behavior and size. This is what creativity and passion in the AAA space can do and I'm extremely here for it. If you're still indecisive, give it a chance. It really is an impressive true-to-gaming experience.

As for difficulty, if you aren’t as familiar with the tense and sometimes frustrating RE gameplay loop where you manage your resources and often barely survive encounters, where you just want to experience what the game has to offer without significant hicc-ups: go with standard. I often like to play games on their harder difficulties but if I’d started out with hardcore I would’ve probably dropped the game and missed out on this unique experience. I now feel more inclined to replay the game in hardcore as I’ve already experienced the game and its story.

If you are looking for the classic RE gameplay with all its (extremely) tense moments and you like bumping your head at certain sections because of it do go with hardcore.

[h1]8/10[/h1] RE 7 is the pinnacle of atmosphere and unsettling locations in Resident Evil but RE 8 takes its gameplay formula and creates an awesome action adventure.

The puzzles and exploration are really well done, they reward you for visiting old areas by sprinkling new enemies and resources around. Even the main objective isn't super spelled out for you. A lot of stuff you have to figure out yourself. The snowy Romanian village with werewolf monsters is such a unique setting and the environments are gorgeous. There's 4 areas in the game + the main village area. Each location has its own unique personality, its own enemies and bosses. There's 4 bosses in the game (+ some mini-bosses), including the final boss. Each one has its own set pieces and abilities. One of the areas of the game is a puzzle + horror segment and it's easily scarier than most moments in RE 7.

I hated the inventory system and inventory UI. Give me item boxes. Having useless key items and having to scroll through to find the one you're actually looking for is annoying.

Enemies drop treasure that can be sold to the merchant from whom you can buy ammo, meds and upgrade your weapons and character. This incentivises you to kill enemies, instead of trying to conserve ammo and avoid them like other RE games. This works really well considering the more action heavy focus. It feels more consistently fun throughout, instead of being like RE 7 where the second half of the game is painful to get through.
Game Design is on point. Story hits hard and has a gigantic plot twist at the end. Recommend you try this one out. 8/10.

One of the best Resident Evil titles out there, a little hard at the start but things get a little easier when you upgrade your weapons later.

The setting is really good, which is a mix of snowy mountains and Victorian-like castles/buildings which sets a good atmosphere.

There is a decent variety of enemies, the graphics are good and are less blurry than RE7 which speaking of the story follows on from but is much better.

Highly recommended.

For me, the game carried a lot of promise but ultimately failed to deliver. 

It starts well (albeit after a fairly long opening sequence) - the early phases of the game were great and felt like a nice blend of previous Resi games. The inclusion of a merchant character gave me high hopes that I'd get a Resi 4-like experience, but after a while the whole thing starts to rush along and essentially turns into a fast-paced action shooter, with lots of uninspiring boss fights. There were moments later in the game thtat I did enjoy, but these were brief and few. There was nowhere near enough of the exploration and puzzle-solving that I enjoyed in other games in the series, despite (it seems) trying to play with an open-world style setting.

Also, for me there were far too many first-person cut scenes. I found these very frustrating. They were not aided by terrible dialogue (and not terrible in a deliberate campy way like in some Resi games) and a rather convoluted story which didn't really hold my interest.

Other people have certainly enjoyed this game more than I have, but I couldn't recommend it personally.

Probably the easiest of the modern Resident Evil games, and it shares an issue with Resident Evil 7: Biohazard, being the lack of interesting protagonists. I'm almost always left irritated by Mia or Ethan, but enthralled by the villains of the story.

The economy also failed for me. I found myself swimming I resources constantly with little to worry about, but that seems to be much better in Resident Evil 4, so they've at least learned from their mistakes.

The setting is where the game really shines, giving an almost entirely original take on the horror genre while still feeling slightly believable, the latter of which is likely due to the mundane main character. Boss fights are fantastic and the combat feels very polished, though normal difficulty is nowhere near tough enough.

TLDR: First person action/horror. While similar in many points to its predecessor, manages to tweak the gameplay so it feels different. If you played the 7th title but would have liked more action at the expense of some of the scare factor, you might favor this one over the 7th.

Story: Direct continuation of RE 7, so I suggest playing it beforehand. 
At first, and I do mean the first few minutes, you feel like it's going to really be a continuation... You see Mia, realise which ending was cannon, become pretty happy for Ethan with his lil' baby... Then, it all gets thrown out the window and you feel forced into events that are completely unrelated to the previous entry. But eventually... It manages to reel you back in with just enough clever pulls at your heart strings and interesting character developments to make it interesting and coherent (enough). After all, it is Resident Evil, so story was never their forte, but after Resident Evil 7 and 2's remake, I expected amazing quality. So much so that I was probably being unfair.

Gameplay: The combat is VERY similar to RE 7, like, ridiculously so. The only changes are in the weapons selection and their upgrades and customisation (similar to RE 4 & 5), collectable treasures that are sometimes combinable for much more resale value (again, like RE 4), a sales person and an inventory system that is like RE 4. No need to find backpacks to increase inventory size like in RE 2 (the remake) and 7, simply purchase the bigger cases available in the in game store. There is also food/ingredients you can collect from animals which you can craft recipes from to obtain permanent buffs; health, speed, block dmg, etc. I wish the game told me earlier because I'd been selling it since it had no use. The food is finite btw so don't sell it like I did.
The game feels balanced on normal. Though I was never out of bullets, I felt the squeeze when I would miss too many shots. The areas you visit are varied, not so much in locations but more as in you'll have tight quarters one minute and have room to fight the next. A couple of enemies here, and a crowd there. An easy fight here, and an optional big boss there. It keeps things much fresher than in RE 7 where all you had was moldy fellas.

Graphics: Looks good! It's no master piece but it looks really good. Some textures looked a bit off but 99% looks like what you'd expect from any game with RE engine. It's also noteworthy that the game isn't always having you creep around at night. Lots of the game takes place during the day and outside. 

Audio: A lot of the guns sounded a bit wimpy, but then again... maybe it's just that I haven't unlocked some more powerful guns. It might also not help that I've never fired the magnum. I was saving the bullets for later... But then the game was over :( I'm one of those people that save up 99x potions and end up never using them.
The voice actors are ok, and the ambience is as good as RE 7. 

What I initially was let down by was simply that the game did not  INITIALLY feel like a horror game. It threw a few curve balls at me and whenever they were happening I couldn't see myself growing to like them. But when you take a step back and just appreciate it at its face value, the game is actually great. I think this game is very similar to RE7, but it's like the difference of opinion between COD and Battlefield... Same thing, but oh so different.
This game is so addicting lol. The story is good and the combat mechanics are okay. I just wanted Lady Dimitrescu to be the main boss lol.

[h1] Technical performance [/h1]
This game runs really well. It can push the hardware to the limits. I suggest using FSR with adequate resolution and limited filtering options. Otherwise - like all RE games, Village looks satisfying and runs well with support of many modern technologies.

The game runs perfectly well on Linux, with absolutely 0 issues on GE-Proton8-16 (but probably any version really). The FPS is stable, textures are detailed. I had lots of fun.

[h1] Technology [/h1]
FSR and RTX, the game allows a broad selection of settings. I think everybody can find something adequate.
Graphically it's not the Crysis of 2000s, but it was never the major point in this game I suppose. The game does look pretty and I imagine with all "HQ" options enabled it would present itself as one of the best looking games in 2022-2024. Great job for a RE game. Capcom has bought a Customer by delivering high quality games with great controls, animations and polished experience.

On the note of AI - it is not the brightest at the times, but absolutely sufficient. I wish Dimitrescu was a bit smarter in her castle, but otherwise everything's OK.

[h1] Gameplay/bugs [/h1]
Absolutely no issues in terms of controls or gameplay, at least if using the keyboard. Controller is also just fine (technically), but aiming is difficult. Being a mostly FPS type of game, Village just doesn't feel good without mouse/keyboard. It's the reverse Elden Ring situation...

I noticed just one bug on Linux. The mouse would sometimes go a bit crazy in the menu. Everything works fine in the game, but I would experience a jumping cursor in the shop or game's menus. Could be Proton acting up a bit or some kind of incompatibility in between the window compositor and Wayland.

[h1] Genre [/h1]
I never played RE games and started with Village. I bought a couple of different RE titles during the sales. 0 regrets. Absolutely one of the best purchases ever. The lore is great, the enemy design is interesting. Every boss is unique, has a specific style and comes in a different environment. Some of the areas remind me of different games. Having played RE 0 (Resident Evil Zero) I would say that Village is MUCH better and yet still resembles the original games from early 2000s.

[h1] Value [/h1]
100% great value. If bought on a discount then it's even better. It's one of few games that actually delivers what it promised. If you're disappointed with the "AAA" (more like AAA jokes) titles in 2023 then I suggest trying out RE. Additionally there is no mandatory online play, no encrypted textures or anti-cheat bullshit and the game does not require 10 different accounts. It reminded me of playing games in my childhood.

A small drawback - the game is not very lengthy, although it can be played multiple times with different difficulty settings, some DLCs etc. I would say playing it twice is the recommended scenario.

PS: Perhaps the biggest question 'not answered' directly in the game's lore is...
[spoiler] Whose child is Rose after all? It's a moldy subject, for how long did Miranda pretend to be... her mother? [/spoiler]

Resident Evil Village takes every criticism you could have possibly had on any Resident Evil game and improved upon it. It has a rich story (by Resident Evil standards) and has stellar gameplay comparable to that of Resident Evil 4.

If you are a fan of the new take on the franchise, I cannot recommend this enough. This may very well be the best Resident Evil to date.

Capcom's Resident Evil Village, released in 2021, takes players on a nightmarish journey through a gothic and hauntingly beautiful village. Building on the success of its predecessors, Village not only continues the gripping narrative of Ethan Winters but also introduces new elements that elevate the Resident Evil franchise to new heights of horror and grandeur.

Visually, Resident Evil Village is a stunning triumph. The RE Engine showcases its prowess with atmospheric lighting, detailed character models, and intricately designed environments that seamlessly blend the eerie beauty of the village with the grotesque horrors that lie within. The diverse settings, from the dilapidated village to the opulent castle and beyond, create a visual spectacle that is as unsettling as it is captivating.

The narrative weaves a tale of desperation, loss, and survival as Ethan Winters embarks on a quest to rescue his kidnapped daughter. Village introduces a compelling cast of characters, each with their own dark secrets, and the unpredictable twists keep players on the edge of their seats. The enigmatic Lady Dimitrescu and her vampiric daughters, among other horrifying creatures, contribute to the game's atmosphere of constant dread.

Gameplay mechanics in Village strike a balance between survival horror and action, offering a diverse range of challenges. The first-person perspective enhances the immersion, with responsive controls and intense combat encounters. The game introduces a merchant called the Duke, adding an intriguing economic element that allows players to purchase and upgrade weapons, further enhancing the strategic aspect of gameplay.

Village excels in level design, offering a mix of tight corridors, open landscapes, and intricate puzzles that keep the player engaged. The interconnectedness of the various areas encourages exploration, uncovering hidden secrets, and solving environmental puzzles that reward the curious and thorough player.

The sound design in Resident Evil Village deserves special mention. From the unsettling ambient noises to the bone-chilling roars of monstrous adversaries, the audio elements contribute significantly to the game's immersive horror experience. The voice acting is superb, adding depth to the characters and amplifying the emotional impact of the narrative.

While some purists may find the game's departure from traditional survival horror mechanics and its increased focus on action to be a deviation from the series' roots, the balance struck by Village allows it to appeal to a broader audience. The varied pacing, unexpected scares, and the constant feeling of vulnerability contribute to a horror experience that is both thrilling and emotionally resonant.

In conclusion, Resident Evil Village stands as a pinnacle in the Resident Evil franchise. Its breathtaking visuals, captivating narrative, and refined gameplay mechanics come together to create a horror masterpiece that pays homage to the series' legacy while boldly venturing into new and terrifying territory. Village is not only a must-play for fans of the genre but also a testament to Capcom's ability to evolve and redefine survival horror in the gaming landscape.

This game was incredible to play, It was the first ever resident evil title I had played and am glad I started with it. The story line was dense and captivating, I found myself sitting down to play this game and not getting up for hours.  The Action and combat in the game were quite fun though I do regret switching to casual difficulty early in the game as it made it way too easy (you can't change it back up). There were some interesting puzzles though I would've liked some more variety. Now finally, the fear factor. Playing from a first person perspective definitely upped the scares, It made it more immersive and you could see less of the surroundings so when something popped up it was actually a little frightening. The sound design was one of the main things that made the game so creepy, from the mob sound effects to the inclination of tense music everything was top tier, soundtrack definitely deserves a 10. Overall I'd give this game a 9/10, will for sure be playing more RE games after this experience.

I am in love with this game.  I am a huge Resident Evil fan starting with Resident Evil 2 when it first came out in 1998 on the PS1. I love that there are always things to do whether that is looking for goats of warding or completing challenges (like craft 300 items) which make you want to play it over and over.  The gore and creepy environment factor are there for sure if you are wanting it for the horror factor.  From a Resident Evil fan perspective, this game is flawless.  I love how they (spoiler alert) ended the game with Chris saying something which could definitely lead into a great follow up to it.  The Resident Evil franchise is in a great position and it is great to see this at this point in my lifetime.

It's worth mentioning that even those unfamiliar with Resident Evil 7 can play Village without significant issues. This is because the game provides a retrospective of the preceding story right at the start, orientating those who haven't experienced the horrors of Biohazard. Nevertheless, for a more thorough understanding and a potential connection with this new storyline, it could be a good idea to play the 2017 game.

Although it appears simple at first glance, the plot is, in fact, quite complex. Centered around a father's quest for his daughter, it harbours numerous mysteries, delving even into the history of the formation of Resident Evil's main company, the Umbrella Corporation. The unfolding narrative gains depth as the game progresses, culminating in a completely surprising outcome. Despite its intricate storyline, the game is relatively short and can be completed in around ten hours. Yet, true to Resident Evil tradition, Village conceals some treasures and small side missions, enticing the player to experience it more than once. Additionally, the return of the Mercenaries mode adds an extra layer of challenge.

In terms of characterisation, figures like Lady Dimitrescu and Salvatore Moreau are intriguing in their own right. However, what captivated testers the most was the beauty and realism of the environments. From the tense scenes within the Dimitrescu castle to the unsettling moments in the Heisenberg factory, the game maintains meticulously detailed environments throughout. In Resident Evil Village, even the unpleasant becomes beautiful. The only exception to this aesthetic is perhaps a moment in the encounter with the second boss, Donna Beneviento. Nevertheless, despite involving frightening situations, the scene settings remain impressive, justifying the horror they evoke.

Similar to any other game in the franchise, Resident Evil Village demands a considerable amount of curiosity and exploration from the player. It's always crucial to scrutinise each collected object, as some require assembly and/or disassembly to become usable. It's worth noting, however, that in this new chapter of the Capcom series, certain items boast extended lifespans. Additionally, there are regions that, despite appearing early in the game, necessitate exploration later on. This aspect brings to mind the Lego franchise, a delightful association, by the way.

To aid navigation, the map of Resident Evil Village is highly intuitive. It simplifies the indication of unexplored elements in each available area. However, its simplicity can be a real headache for players who enjoy collecting every item.

Despite a somewhat prolonged ending, all the hours invested are justified by the complexity of the story. With stunning graphics and well-developed villains, Resident Evil Village concludes Ethan Winters' journey impressively. It delights players with surprising and terrifying gameplay, featuring a beautiful moral centred around family, hope, love, and determination.

As for the Shadow of Rose additional content, the adventure, on the whole, boasts an intriguing completion time and, once again, a delightful moral of the story. Amidst some scares and tense moments, the extra story proves to be enjoyable and interesting. However, it occasionally feels a bit disconnected from the familiar reality we're accustomed to in the franchise, becoming somewhat disjointed at times. It stands out as one of the best contents I've experienced in a story-based game in quite a while.

After getting all the achievements and 135 hours later RE village has definitely become my favorite resident evil game next to 2. RE village takes all the gameplay elements that made 4 good (except for the 3rd person controls as they were obviously an afterthought added in DLC) and keeps the elements that worked in 7, albeit the game is noticeably less scary so if pure horror is all you're looking for this game takes a big step back. 

This game also has some of the most diverse locations in any RE game I've played, there are 4 fully fleshed out areas with unique bosses that all have a completely different feel and even shake up the gameplay loop sometimes requiring you to completely change how you approach the game to beat the different bosses.

There's an amazing variety of weapons as well with 3 weapons for each type: melee, pistols, shotguns, magnums, rifles, and explosives with multiple attachments to find for each.

Mercenaries also makes it's triumphant return (and with the ability to play as some of the bosses if you pick up the DLC) and is both fun and extremely rewarding for completing all the stages with an SS rank.

My only gripe is that there is no FOV slider whatsoever so unless you install REframework this game can easily make you motion sick because muh can't see means scary i guess... Otherwise fantastic entry in the series and well worth full price.

This is the best marriage of RE7 and RE4, with elements from other RE games sprinkled in.

A much more action focused Resident Evil game with emphasis on a more arcade-y combat, straightforward boss mechanics and even including a few horror focused sections.
Since everyone and their mother knows this game for the big vampire mommy Lady D I do have to warn you - she and her daughters are only about 10% of the entire game. So if this was a selling point to you then sorry to disappoint, and if it's the opposite then you're in luck!

Now RE4 was a somewhat controversial title due to it being a more direct transition into the action genre, with RE3 being an experimental slightly more action oriented horror game. This might feel similar coming from RE7, you will most likely be running and gunning half the time, with some sections even throwing enough enemies at you that you'd want a minigun. Which brings me to a negative point here: NG+.
In previous RE games New Game+ was a fun way to discover new unique weapons and interesting ways around encounters. Here you just get more powerful weapons of the same type you've been using before, with the one truly unique weapon locked behind a Mercenaries mode grind.
The mercenaries mode is a lot of fun, you can even find random power-ups around the levels which almost turns it into a rogue-lite, until you try to get high ranks in the Hard Mode maps though, then it starts becoming frustrating. It would be interesting to see a more open-ended mode like this, with all the maps combined perhaps, to see how a long run would look with you becoming ridiculously overpowered.

Overall a great game, if you are looking for a true Resident Evil experience you might be disappointed, but if you're fine with a bit of action in your RE games (if you liked RE4 and beyond) then you'll love it.

This is one of the best Resident Evil games I've played.  It is pretty much Resident Evil 4 in 1st-person without the tank controls, giving it a perfect balance of action and horror.  Story achievements are easier to unlock even for less professional players, if you use the points wisely in the bonus menu.

A few things to note:
This game is GRAPHICALLY DEMANDING; fps is LOW on my old GTX 980M even at low settings.  Luckily it runs well on my new system retrofitted with an RTX 4090.
I highly recommend playing this game in 1st-person on the first try to experience that horror atmosphere.  After that, you can switch to 3rd-person on every subsequent run for less intense gameplay, especially if you want to speedrun.

Continuing the story that started in the Baker's house this game has probably the best plot and setting in RE games so far, while far from the original story, it's still gripping and intense from start to finish. Not to mention the heavily detailed graphics and animations, and the dark atmosphere this game has to offer. It's definitely worth a try if you like horror games, shooters and survival games or if you really enjoyed previous RE games. 

The shooter element in this game was more present than in previous titles while puzzles were a little bit left behind in my opinion. Still, a 10/10 for me.

The DLC was quite long and definitely worth it, but I'm not gonna mention any details just in case I spoil anything.

Resident Evil Village has quickly become my all time favorite game. The graphics and gameplay are top notch, and the story is incredibly immersive.

One of the things I love most about this game is the setting. The village itself is so beautifully designed, with each area feeling unique and full of detail. The enemy design is also fantastic, with each creature being both terrifying and memorable.

The gameplay itself is a lot of fun, with a good balance of action and horror. I also really appreciate the variety of weapons and upgrades available, which allow you to tailor your playstyle to your own preference.

But what really sets Resident Evil Village apart for me is the story. The plot is full of twists and turns, and I found myself constantly engaged and wanting to know what would happen next. The characters are also well written and likable, which only added to my enjoyment of the game!

Overall, I highly recommend Resident Evil Village to any fans of the series or horror games in general. It's an absolute must-play.

. I certainly enjoyed this Resident Evil greatly. The visuals are some of the best I have ever seen from a Resident Evil title and the characters performances are terrific. The atmosphere again I have to point out makes this game feel immersive and it really suits this title in particular. I can say the same with the enemies they went with here also, this suited really well with the environment they were placed in and the boss fights were very interesting and unique to each individual foe you face. It was well distributed between the combat and the horror so you could roam around very easy and enjoy certain parts of the game without enemies trying to attack you all the time. But this may vary on what difficulty you play on, do not quote me on that. 

. Also, I want to say that this Resident Evil might be my favourite in terms of design and appeal they worked with here. I just cannot explain enough how detailed and extraordinary the places look. To me this is what I look for in a game and it makes me appreciate the title so much more. As a result, an awesome Resident Evil in my book. I hugely recommend this game to anyone looking to play a first or third person horror. Thoroughly enjoyed it and I cannot wait to play more of these titles in the future.

. Do get this Masterpiece on offer or at full price if you do not already own it.

Yet another great horror title from Capcom.

I liked the game even though it had its issues like hard-locked 81 degrees FoV. It caused me to have motion sickness in the very beginning of the game to the point where I couldn't carry on playing anymore.

I had to download 'Lazy FoV' from NexusMods.com in order to fix the hard-locked FoV because Capcom didn't include a slider option for FoV in the vanilla game.

After fixing the FoV back to 90 degrees (acceptable value for first person view games), I have eliminated motion sickness. However, you shouldn't set the FoV greater than 90 degrees, because then it causes visual glitches like your view being obstructed by Ethan's character model or having a fisheye-like screen/the edges of your screen gets visually distorted as you increase the FoV. Next up, you'll want to enable manual flashlight on/off prompt which can be enabled through RE Framework tool which you can also download from NexusMods.com and after this, lastly, you'll want to remove the Vignette effect whenever you crouch, because both sides of your screen gets darker and it becomes difficult to see around. For that, what you'll need is 'Vignette Fix' from NexusMods.com

After these adjustments, you're good to go. The gameplay and story telling is just as much as you'd expect from any other Resident Evil title.

Upon completing the main story, I've played Shadows of Rose DLC, which unfolds the events after Ethan Winters' story ending. You play as Rose Winters, Ethan's daughter. But this time you are playing from a 3rd person perspective, so you get to see Rose and the vanilla game doesn't cause motion sickness. It offers about 3 hours of content on top of the main storyline which was roughly about 9 hours. (not rushed) The Shadows of Rose DLC also doesn't have the issues I've mentioned above, which the vanilla RE Village main game does.

I hope Capcom will perfect their next Resident Evil game in the series, like including an FoV slider, giving player the basic ability of manually turning on/off flashlight and removing the Vignette effect.

Overall, I'd give Resident Evil Village & Shadows of Rose both a solid 8 out of 10.

A really fun horror-light experience. Resident Evil: Village wears the influence of Resident Evil 4, in the sense that it's more action-focused than other games, and it has a bit less in the way of horror. It still has some scary sections, but overall it is way more about shooting than atmosphere, although it still has a great atmosphere.

My biggest knock with this game is that it doesn't let the individual sections shine, instead rushing you through them a little too fast. I really wish some of the sections were just denser and had more to do, but it is what it is.

I really enjoyed Village overall and it's one of my favorite games in the whole series. I felt like it fumbled the end, similarly to 7, but it still was a great time and one that I'll revisit at some point in the future.
