This is a good game but with two major critical points: screenplay and combat system (with some kind of enemies).

Don't get me wrong, I was liking RE8 up until the first half. I really thought that the beginning was perfectly made and the first encounter too. But, for me, everything else has been so lazily written that it eventually got to me. 

I'll say this, though: the Dimitrescu castle and the Beneviento mansion were really well made and I have liked their structure and feel. Each room felt neatly structured, and not simply a random arrangement of objects.  Especially in the castle, I've felt that the actual storyline was being constructed accordingly. 

After that, apart from the aforementioned mansion, everything has gone downhill. Massively. To the point that it began feeling less of an horror story, but rather an average anime saga. Really. 

Dialogues got more and more cartoony, and I can't understand why. I was only laughing whenever people spoke in the second half of the game, as it felt like none of the characters were taking anything seriously. This culminated in the final battle which, even without considering the cringy part with Redfield, was definitely a chore. 

This is the worst part of RE8, for me. And, for a game that wants to be narrative, it makes me really not want to recommend it at all.

The other thing I haven't liked at all was the combat system. I mean, not that RE7 had the best gameplay ever, but here the arsenal was just too vast and pompous for a "normal" guy like Ethan. I wouldn't have minded it, if most of the weapons were completely useless against bigger enemies. I can't stress how many bullet sponges I have encountered. I have played in hardcore difficulty, yes, but I expected something different. Some enemies will literally make you waste mines, pipe bombs, explosive ammos, bullets... everything. A waste of time.
Not only that, but the overall worldbuilding was definitely more spot on in RE7 than here. The story is very predictable.

Excluding the bullet sponges, though, normal enemies were okay. You could kill all of them only with a pistol, if you had enough bullets. And new enemies were always presented in an interesting way, at least for me.

A worthy mention could be made for the DLCs. RE7's ones were kinda genious, here... not so much. It almost feels like a Thirteen Reasons Why + Life is Strange screenwriting, at best.

I'm upset not because the game is bad, but because I was getting invested in it and it changed structure so much that it didn't feel serious at all, at one point. If I had to make a review half into the game, it would have been almost certainly positive.

Not that RE7 is perfect. I still remember how goofy the final battle was. I can't understand why Capcom can't seem to mantain seriousness more than a couple of hours. Well, I hope that the next iteration will be more narration-focused with less flashy weapons and quirky characters. I think that, today, it doesn't work anymore as it used to in past titles.

This game is fantastic. I have spent the last 2 years holding out on this game. On one hand I am glad I took time to experience RE7 first, but on the other (and let me tell you, this game really makes you appreciate the fact that you have both) this game really spoke to me. It was an experience that I think I will be trying to chase for a long time.

Pros:
-Beautiful game, truly looks fantastic and the environments draw you in and adds to the immersion
-Fun, thrilling, interesting story that honestly felt more unique than I expected
-Gameplay does such a good job at creating suspense and tension, really does a good job keeping the horror of low ammo economy alive while also giving you some kickass moments
-Massive UX improvements from RE7, especially inventory-wise
-The games greatest strength though lies in its level design. Full stop. You have to experience it.

Cons:
-Press [P] to skip cutscene

Final Remark, this game (alongside RE7) reminded me of the long lost art of point and click adventure games. Something about the environments man, especially when you have one of those brief solitary moments where you feel safe and very alone for just a little while. I hope they keep it up in the next title.

All style, no substance.
As for a game advertising itself on being the best of RE4 and RE7, it underdelivers on both action and survival.
But, lets get to the beginning.
It begins with quite long walking-simulator section, which interesting on the first playthrough, kills any subsequent rounds just on how dragged and linear it is. There's literally no items to find and as for file hunting, yeah, AAA entertainment right there. After a ton of jumpscares over-relying on  1st person perspective, we're straight up thrown into the action, and all the worst flaws of the game are immediately made known. Fist - pacing. We fight 1 enemy, next door over 4 of them, next a whole horde, then - nothing, some 3 enemies right after, and a TON of walking with no combat for about an hour or two. The game doesn't know what it wants to be - a bunch of encounters thrown together and then LOOONG section with nothing happening at all. Pacing sucks horribly. And when it comes to the fight there's so much BS... 2 types of grunt enemies - 1 fast and 1 slow, that have little to no variety amongst each other, which is as well, since you can't do anything to them besides trying to shoot in the head. Nothing besides blocking and pushing away, which doesn't even stun them! Now I get why people complained about RE2R combat. You can't even knife them when they're down! They're back up in 2 seconds! You still need need to politely wait for them to get up so you'll have a first row to the peak RE8 experience of busting a whole clip to their head and hope for a headshot, since aiming anywhere else is a waste of ammo thanks to horrible hitboxes. What were they thinking?! They're all left to chance (?). Body shots can be shrugged off or make enemies swirl arund like ballerinas. Such tactics, so satifaction. It's a pleasant surprise if you score a headshot or a down, because mostly they tank pistol to the face like nobody's business. 
And you just stand there reminiscing better times.
Times, when there was such a thing as level design, where encounters would be immediately distinguishable and memorable.
There's no level design here 80% of the time. The first horde and last and that's all, and that's stretching. Mostly it's just a plain, flat field, or a tunnel for a change. One instance of grass obscuring your view. You CAN barricade doors, but it neither a common occasion or particularly sound from a tactical standpoint. One differerence is with flying enemies, appearing 3 times, where overhead cover matters, and piss poor AI emerges in its full - awfull glory. No door breaking, window barging, ladder climbing, it only has the enemies simply walk (even run on harder difficulties) in the straight line at you. If their 2 braincells meet they manage to strife. They have two attacks if they're armed, otherwise they just bite. And for a mini boss there's a version that has helmet on that you have to blow up and grill with your guns a little longer. No worries though, usually you can just fall back behind a certain line and they obediently go back to their spawn spot. YEP. Even on the Village of Shadows you can reliably crouch and shank the slow zombies' ankles away. Truly, a worthy succesor of RE4! 
Granted, at the last section of the game a new type of enemies are introduced, which is a breath of fresh air. The trick with them is to bait an attack so they expose their weak spot, which is both a reliable and exciting tactics, but noting can save the overall picture by then.  
Bosses telegraph poorly if you're doing anything to them, so you question if their poorly telegraphed weak spots are weak spots at all. Only final boss is geuinely ingenious encounter.
There're optional bosses, but don't worry, they go back to their spawn if you run away, such obedient little pups they are! You can juke them like that, they don't regenerate health or anything!
Exploration is ok, I guess, a little bit of hoarding for bosses, which rewards smart conservation of resources, extremely nice, no way you're going to have to choose what to keep and what to get rid of since you're virtually never going to run out of inventory space because raw materials are unlimited and separate from your normal inventory bag. Crafting's ok, I guess.
There's one "stealth" section mixed with old school find and use item section. On first time it's intriguing, but once you realize how linear it is it becomes a chore and all pretense of horror are replaced by boredom.
And it's a shame, because the scenery they chose is quite unique. The snow fallen Eastern European village leading to a homey castle, a riverbank and industrial factory. You rarely ever see socrealism represented as an aesthetic in a video game, and contrasted with gothic castle, yum! It's AAA perfect setting for a horror story (trust me)! Attention to detail is great. However, RE3R curse rears its ugly head yet again, there's a plenty of beautiful barren locations! The drawn-out begining and unreasonably glorified "horror" sections are the best examples, the whole point is to input a few on-rails clicks, you're stripped of all your agency (you're literally mysteriously stipped of all your weapons because the game says so), and unable to engage in any optional interaction. The "scary stalker" appears in scripted moments and follows scripted paths. You drain the water from a lake and reveal a village underneath, you know what happens? Boss battle and adieu! You can't even enter the area you traversed on the rooftops before. It's insulting. 
Story is contrived, with a transparent red herring. "I didn't tell you the truth to protect you. I knew you'd seek vengence"- when the protagonist has almost single-handedly destroyed the main antagonist's lair. This is literally Wesker's reveal in OG RE1. You know it would be bad, but you fool yourself into hoping for any improvement. No, scratch that. This is big budget, big news AAA game, they dropped the ball, indesputably. 
Such a shame.
The enviroment design and graphical fidelity is obviously the main, and with time it becomes clear - the only selling point. It's a tripple A a hounted house ride mixed with indie gameplay.
Such a shame because it doesn't bode well for RE4R - Capcom don't do gameplay anymore, they do graphics and marketing campaign. And RE4 was... A brilliant gameplay based on genius level design, reliable gunplay and overall well though out pacing. Everything sung together and it took people out of left field.
RER4 doesn't advertise any of those things.
Overall, if you're not into shooting zombies and love escape rooms instead - give it a try. For anyone who craves an engaging gameplay, avoid.  
We were promised better.
We deserve better.

Hot take: Resident Evil Village is one of the best entries in the series, and it’s in my top 10 favorite games of all time. I originally played it on Series S back when it came out, but recently took advantage of the Halloween sale and picked it back up again on PC. This is one of the best horror games I’ve played and I’ll explain why (spoiler free.) 

Story: The story is top notch. Ethan Winters is probably my favorite Resident Evil protagonist. He’s just a normal guy. Not a John Wick esque, roundhouse kick giving, boulder punching BA. Just a normal dude trying to save his wife and daughter and doing whatever he can. I love it. 

The story takes many twists and turns, including a ton of jaw dropping moments and action set pieces. Without spoiling anything, the game is split up into different “zones” that encapsulate different horror themes and gameplay styles. There’s survival horror, psychological horror without the ability to fight, straight up epic action sequences, and much more. In my opinion, the game stayed fresh throughout and the story kept me engaged the entire time. 

The bosses are excellent. Voice acting is superb. Set piece design is A+. The roster of characters in the game is fantastic, most of them are very well written and memorable. 

The game is a mix of action and horror. The game is overall not the scariest game I’ve ever played, but it has one section… oh God… one section that is THE scariest thing I’ve ever played. I speedrun this game and EVERY time I get to this certain section I dread it. 

The finale left tears in my eyes and really resonated with me emotionally, especially as a new father myself. I was a huge fan of RE7 and RE8 and I loved the Ethan Winters storyline. He truly is the greatest dad ever. 

Gameplay: The combat is top notch. I will say, it is much easier on PC than console because of mouse and keyboard. Part of what made it scary on console is how difficult the aiming was on the game pad. If you have decent aim, the combat is much easier on PC. 

The game is loaded with puzzles and treasures that reward exploration and sharp wit. If you take your time and search every inch of the game, you won’t be lacking in money, supplies, and really cool weapons. 

The game is difficult, but exponentially more so if you just try to barrel your way through the game as fast as possible. 

Presentation/Graphics: I personally think this game is one of the most visually appealing games I’ve ever seen. Whether it’s a dank, dimly lit basement illuminated solely by flickering candles, a gorgeous castle hall, snowy forest, or a factory corridor lit by flashing red lights, the game is gorgeous and makes fantastic use of light. 

Textures are gorgeous. If you run the game on max settings with ray tracing, you’d be hard pressed to find a horror game with better looking textures and light effects thanks to the tremendous RE engine. 

Enemy designs are amazing. Every enemy looks unique and terrifying. Not only do they look terrifying, but their movement is very lifelike and immersive. Enemies don’t just sit still and wait for you to kill them. They sway  from side to side, attempting to dodge your bullets. The blood and gore effects are top notch. Exploding a werewolf’s head with a shotgun always feels nice. 

This game is really fun to speedrun. The whole Resident Evil franchise is consistently a good choice for speed runners because it rewards skillful play and you can really breeze through it if you commit the puzzles and fights to memory. 

Things you might not like: The game is very good, with the exception of a few stale segments that don’t hold up as well as the rest. (Fishing Village, I’m looking at you.) 

Some people might not like the B movie cheese, but those people have clearly never played a Resident Evil game before. 

As mentioned earlier, the game is meant to be played slowly. If you just want to barrel through a story, the game is probably not for you. 

Conclusion: Give this game a chance! It’s a wonderful addition to the series, and in my opinion it’s up there with RE4 in terms of quality. Hope you enjoy as much as I did!

"Resident Evil Village" is a standout title in the storied Resident Evil series, and there are numerous reasons why it should be at the top of a gamer's must-play list.

Firstly, the game expertly blends classic survival horror elements with modern gameplay mechanics, creating an experience that is both nostalgic and innovatively fresh. The game's setting, a desolate village overshadowed by a looming castle, is not only rich in atmosphere but also in mystery, compelling players to explore every dark corner and unravel the secrets within.

The narrative is another strong point, continuing the story of Ethan Winters from "Resident Evil 7" and expanding the lore of the series in surprising ways. The storytelling is personal and gripping, with twists that keep players engaged until the very end.

Visually, "Resident Evil Village" is a marvel, showcasing breathtaking graphics that bring its gothic horror setting to life. The attention to detail in the environment is impeccable, from the decrepit state of the village houses to the opulent decay of the castle, every location is a feast for the eyes and sets the perfect stage for horror.

Gameplay-wise, the game introduces new enemies and creatures that are both terrifying and intriguing, each with their own unique challenges and weaknesses to discover. The game also sees the return of the franchise's beloved inventory management, encouraging players to think critically about what resources they carry.

Moreover, the game innovates by incorporating a hunting and crafting system, allowing players to hunt animals in the village to create dishes that provide permanent upgrades to the character. This adds an additional layer of strategy to the game, rewarding exploration and resourcefulness.

The character of Lady Dimitrescu, in particular, has become an iconic figure in the gaming community, and her presence in the game adds a charismatic yet fearsome antagonist that players will love to encounter.

Finally, "Resident Evil Village" offers a high replay value with its additional content, including the return of the Mercenaries mode, which challenges players to achieve high scores in combat-heavy runs through various levels.

In conclusion, "Resident Evil Village" is a masterful blend of horror, action, and storytelling that is both respectful of its roots and ambitious in its new directions. It provides an immersive gaming experience that is sure to satisfy long-time fans of the series and newcomers alike with its atmospheric world, challenging gameplay, and compelling story.

Village fixes RE: VII's main flaw by delivering its scenario in a much nicer and controlled way than VII. Narrative design is well done throughout the game. The environment art is also stunning and made me stop on a few occasions to watch the scenery. 

The overall structure of the game is really classic but works well, even though I'm not sure what the pseudo openness brings compared to VII. The main flaws of this game are an unnecessary cumbersome "RPG" layer (weapon upgrades, [spoiler]cooking[/spoiler]...) and a few early game sequences which I personnaly found frustrating coming from the previous game  ([spoiler]I felt there were a lot of chase sequences in corridors, which weren't particularly fun[/spoiler])

Overall, great game [spoiler]and a great conclusion to the Winters' story[/spoiler]

Village is less horror-focused than biohazard and yet still manages to be scarier lmao. I'm glad the inventory management and merchant mechanics were brought back for this game, even though I rarely got into a spot where ammo conservation was a huge deal. The environments are beautiful, the areas are interesting and fun to traverse, the characters have a lot more going for them than in 7 (even though I felt Heisenberg's VA didn't really fit), and I just had a good time playing. There is plenty of that RE-trademarked bullshit (which is a good thing) and it manages to be goofy while still maintaining the level of effort that went into its predecessor. [spoiler] Even though he is a goober, it's unfortunate that this might be the last time Ethan Winters appears in a game. [/spoiler] It may be a while until the next new RE game releases, but I hope it is a lot like this one.

ETHAN

[...] Nous incarnons donc Ethan Winters qui mène une vie isolée avec sa compagne, Mia (dans cette histoire, vous l’avez forcément sauvée alors dans le 7), et sa fille Rose. Isolée parce qu’ils ont été mis en sécurité par Chris Redfield, arrivé à la rescousse à la fin du 7. En sécurité de quoi ?  On ne sait pas trop, mais bon de toutes manières, Chris va débarquer au cours d’une soirée d’hiver et abattre froidement Mia d’environ trente balles dans la poitrine et faire kidnapper Rose et Ethan. Ce dernier se réveille suite à un accident de voiture à proximité du fameux « Village » (qui n’a pas de nom, nous voyons juste que la monnaie utilisée est le « Lei », wikipedia me dit Moldavie ou Roumanie) où il va rapidement se faire attaquer par des lycans (loups-zombis-garous) et par Hagrid (ou le père Noël à vous de voir), dans une scène d’introduction qui ressemble ENORMEMENT à celle de RE4. Il rencontre les derniers villageois en vie qui finissent massacrés et Ethan, est lui-même capturé par les 4 seigneurs du coin : Lady Dimitrescu, Donna Beneviento, Salvatore Moreau et Karl Heisenberg. Ces quatre seigneurs sont aux ordres de Mother Miranda qui, il se trouve, comme par hasard, ça alors, a récupéré Rose et laissé Ethan pour mort car c’est elle qui a fait attaquer apparemment le convoi (on notera au passage que le plan de Chris est de mettre à l’abri Ethan, Mia et Rose à côté du domaine de Miranda… Génie).[...]  
Ceci dit, ce qui vient gâcher un peu tout ça, c’est l’écriture de certains personnages… enfin, non, pas certains… Juste celui d’Ethan ! S’il n’a pas de visage, il est assez loquace, mais raconte rarement des choses intéressantes et se retrouve plus à réagir comme un spectateur Twitch plus que comme héros de l’aventure. [...] 
Concernant le système de jeu, on se retrouve devant celui du 7 avec quelques ajustements pour le rapprocher du 4 et du remake du 2 [...] Pour avoir fait le jeu en difficulté « hardcore », j’ai appliqué ma méthode habituelle des RE canoniques : je regarde ma vie, mes balles et j’utilise ce que j’ai de disponible en plus grande quantité pour passer, en esquivant les combats inutiles. Alors ça a fonctionné mais avec le très bon équilibrage du jeu, je me suis retrouvé dans une assez bonne attrition durant les premiers 80 % du jeu, mais c’est exactement ce que j’étais venu chercher ! [...] 
	De temps en temps, mais c’est assez inhérent à la série des RE, il y a des séquences où le système de jeu empiète les intérêts de la cohérence, ainsi les ennemis traînent toujours avec eux dans leurs poches des objets utiles (même s’il y a plus de corbeaux avec des grenades par exemple…), il n’est pas possible de fermer des portes, il n’y a pas de dégâts de chute, la viande n’est pas empoisonnée, un ruisseau n’est pas traversable à pied, il arrive aussi de se retrouver coincé devant un tas de petites babioles, ou une énigme (notamment les labyrinthes à bille) qui techniquement pourraient se résoudre juste en tendant le bras, sans compter les grillages qui nous empêchent de passer et résistent à tous les explosifs sur Terre, ou encore, des lustres à incendier en les poussant péniblement sur des flambeaux alors qu’il y a trente bougies dans la pièce etc. Le jeu est parfois engoncé dans son moteur et son gameplay, et il devrait y avoir un peu plus de développement devant certaines situations, pour les présenter de manière moins frustrantes. 
	Les énigmes sont à mi-chemin de tout cela, il n’y en a absolument aucune qui ne soit vraiment difficile, et il semble toujours bizarre d’avoir un environnement qui fonctionne avec des clefs improbables que l’on obtient de manières incongrues, mais ces énigmes ont le méritent d’exister et sont relativement réalistes et crédibles à dire vrai, dans la localisation des objets, la nature de ces objets et la manière dont ils sont utilisés, même s’il y a ce problème de la grosse pince coupante qui disparaît de l’inventaire au début du jeu et dont on aurait eu l’utilité une dizaine de fois sans doute, ou encore cette scène incroyablement stupide avec la voiture... Ceci-dit, cela reste regrettable que la série des RE semble avoir renoncé à laisser vraiment le temps de se creuser la tête, surtout que le rythme du jeu n’est pas tonitruant, mais il est calibré pour que quelqu’un qui y jouerait une heure par si par là y trouve son compte. Je reste étonné à chaque RE que la solution à la Silent Hill, celle de calibrer le niveau de difficulté des énigmes en début de partie, n’ait jamais été tentée pour les RE. Le symptôme de ce refus de laisser réfléchir les joueurs se retrouve dans les myriades de marques jaunes et d’items scintillants qui indiquent les directions à suivre ou quelques objets à récupérer. [...] 

	Concernant le moteur graphique, le RE Engine, RE8 est sorti au démarrage de la diffusion du Ray Tracing, mais à la fin de l’aire PS4/XOne, et au démarrage de la génération suivante. Le jeu a désormais trois ans et avec les graphismes poussés à bloc, il reste vraiment impressionnant [...] À ce très bon moteur graphique s’ajoute un excellent travail sur les sons [...] Dans les maisons abandonnées, le vent qui siffle, le plancher et le toit qui grincent etc. viennent ponctuer la partition des bruits de pas, des borborygmes et cris des monstres qui sont affreux, hurlants et stressants. Les musiques sont globalement discrètes mais pesantes et tournent vraiment sur un rythme angoissant, elles sont capables de précipiter nos actions assez aisément, même s’il n’y a pas de thème principal qui s’en dégage. 

	Les ambiances sont posées efficacement et sans aller jusque dans le registre de la peur, il y a une angoisse régulière qui vient empêcher d’être serein au moment de la découverte d’un nouvel environnement. Sombre, sale, très emprunt de l’imagerie de la fin du XIXème siècle – les petits villages paysans des tableaux polonais, les palais des anciens seigneurs qui perdent leurs privilèges peu à peu, les constructions en briques, les sidérurgies massives chaudes et étouffantes, un peu de steampunk par là, le loup-garou et l’ambiance gothique générale, des monstres types abomination du Dr Frankenstein – RE8 brille clairement car il est à la fois bourré de références à des opus précédents de la série, mais parce que son ambiance est unique aussi. [...] Dans la zone du Village notamment, il n’est pas inconcevable que des gens vivaient ici : la nourriture est stockée, il y a un lit, un poêle de chauffage en fonte sur lequel faire à manger, des décorations uniques à chaque bâtisse, faite parfois en brique, parfois dans des matériaux traditionnels, les toilettes sont dehors et les gens vivaient avec les deux-trois animaux qu’ils élevaient pour le lait ou les œufs. 
	Ce RE offre une belle transposition de la même critique de la modernité que l’on a dans les anciens épisodes (après-tout, le premier RE paraît au moment où les études sur les gènes, les virus et les scandales alimentaires -vache folle- se font parfois échos dans les débats publics). Le fait d’y ajouter un filtre de lecture spirituel continue de filer la longue métaphore dans laquelle s’est lancée la saga, et ce, de manière intéressante puisque n’appelant pas de réponses franches aux questions que se posent les joueuses et joueurs, RE8 laisse une part d’interprétation et donc, de doutes, et par conséquent, d’angoisse puisque les limites de l’envisageable s’élargissent. Par ailleurs, le fait de se situer dans un environnement archaïque mais assez générique pour être familier des occidentaux implique tout de même efficacement, autant qu’il va sans doute intriguer celles et ceux complètement étrangers à ce type d’endroit et qui seront sensibles à l’imaginaire que peuvent invoquer un village ancien à côté d’un château en ruine, ou d’un vieux moulin qui tourne à présent à vide. [...]

Deutsch: Für mich eines der besten Spiele seines Genres. Ausgezeichnete Atmosphäre, Grafik und Handlung. Die Bosse im Spiel sind auf ihre Art komplex und interessant. As an ardent fan of Resident Evil, I was eager to step into the terrifying world of Village, and I can confidently say that this game is a masterclass in horror and storytelling.

Gameplay in Resident Evil Village is a perfect blend of classic survival horror and modern action elements. The combat is both satisfying and challenging, with an array of weapons at your disposal, but scarce resources that keep you on edge. The story itself is engaging and takes some surprising twists and turns, blending elements of folklore and the supernatural seamlessly with the traditional Resident Evil universe. The game's pacing is excellent, offering moments of tense exploration, terrifying encounters, and poignant storytelling, all in perfect balance.

The audio design in the game is exceptional, from the unsettling sounds of creaking doors to the haunting melodies accompanying the action. The voice acting is top-notch, adding depth to the characters, making them more relatable and convincing. Resident Evil Village's use of RE Engine, Capcom's proprietary technology, allows for smooth character animations, realistic physics, and stunning particle effects. The game also features remarkably detailed textures and environmental effects that contribute to the overall sense of immersion. Whether you're exploring the dimly lit interiors of a foreboding castle or navigating the foggy marshes, the graphics consistently impress.

In my humble opinion, Resident Evil Village is the apex of the franchise. It successfully blends the series' signature elements with fresh innovations, providing a terrifying and immersive journey that keeps players on the edge of their seats. Whether you're a long-time fan or a newcomer, Resident Evil Village stands as the finest Resident Evil title, offering a captivating and unforgettable gaming experience.

[h1]Not as spooky as RE7, nor as action heavy as RE4, but a good middle ground between the two and a delightful time for the most part.[/h1]

RE8 ditches the low stakes setting of a single household, in favour of a more fairy tale-esque setting set in a village.
The village itself feels very similar to RE4, albeit less malicious and more tragic, with everyone looking towards a godly figure known as Mother Miranda [spoiler],basically just this games equivalent of Saddler,[/spoiler] for help.
And looming over this village however are a variety of main locations, such as a flooded watermill, the imposing Castle Dimitrescu, a messed up doll house, and a bit more beyond that.

You've got werewolves, vampires, standards zombies and more, and these are by far some of the most aggressive [spoiler]and tankiest[/spoiler] enemies in the franchise.
You've also got the return of the merchant system from RE4, meaning currency makes a return, along with weapon upgrades and the ability to sell excess supplies and valuables.
Despite the different coat of paint, it's definitely closer in tone to RE4, but where it differs is in the action.
While RE4 throws a lot of enemies at you, RE8 handles its survival aspects better in my opinion by throwing harder enemies at you. These guys are aggressive, they're faster than most RE enemies and they can take quite the beating on average.
Until you get comfortable towards the later half of the game, you may find yourself a bit low on ammo unless you're willing to part with a bit of coin. I genuinely liked this as it made running from battles feel more viable, or if I'm going to fight, I need to make every bullet count.

[h1]Continuing with the positivity, the level design is quite strong, some of my favourite in the series[/h1]

While the game could be divided into chapters, the game keeps funnelling you from major locations back towards the village, with more locations being unlocked each time you come back.
The rest of the game also has this winding level design mentality, what with having plot progression tie into backtracking, but the Village is in the title for this game, and I feel its thematics and level design are enough to justify that. 

[h1]Sadly while I quite like the setting itself, the actual plot/hook is nowhere near as strong as the games I'm comparing it to[/h1]

The games main way of hooking you from the start is shock value, I won't go into massive spoilers here but I will say that the game plays its hand way too early, for the vast majority of the game it feels like what I'm going up against is easier than the last thing when it comes to scale and sheer threat.

Comparing it to the Baker residence from RE7, the persistent threats are nowhere near as menacing, nor do they have any surprises to catch you off guard.
Lastly, the boss fights against the bigger bads here are often pretty annoying, they're usually quite tanky, their mechanics are lame and I felt only one of these had appropriate mechanics to match its absurdity and scale.

I just feel it's a step down considering how well built up the Bakers in RE7 were compared to these guys, a little bit sad but not a deal breaker.

[h1]There's one last thing to mention, and that would be the DLC[/h1]

Aside from the expansion, this DLC also brings in the option of a 3rd person camera, something that I feel should've been included for free, but regardless, is a fair selling point for enough for some people to warrant a mention.

Next is the expansion, the epilogue for the game.
Because of it's place in the plot, I can't go into detail about the plot, but I will say that I found it highly unnecessary, [spoiler]even if it did have some sweet moments,[/spoiler] and concerning for the plot moving forward since in theory, we'll know about the timeline of some characters for a long time to come.
But in gameplay, it's a lot of weak weaponry, reused assets, forced walking and bland hallways.
None of what makes the main game shine is present here, and it makes it feel pretty boring, even if the experience is only 2 - 4 hours long.

[h1]Despite some issues, I still feel this is one of the better games in the series[/h1]
I have no idea what will come after this game, as it feels like RE as a series typically tries to reinvent itself every 2 - 3 games, but these latest entries in the franchise have felt like some of the best they've had to offer, very high quality.

Definitely an easy recommendation to make, just so long as you're not looking for the same tense experience that RE7 provided.

I really liked the story and its stakes, and even the atmosphere and gameplay.
Many people say that Resident Evil 7, which is also very good, and Resident Evil Village are not real Resident Evil, but I say they are.
Already by the connection between these 2 games, we recognize the Resident Evil license, it's just that the approach is different, using new themes.
Enemies and areas based on mythologies, for example, and I personally loved it, it's a change from a simple Zombie or a weird mutation.

The only thing I didn't like was the beginning of the game, where you have to survive the Lycan attack, which is unnecessarily complicated. It's the biggest obstacle, and I gave up on the game 1 year ago because of it.

This game is... maybe 70% cool and fun, but 30% incredibly dumb. We power through the *incredibly* stupid aspects of this game for the stuff about it that are fun and neat.

Ethan, the protagonist, is truly the worst. Whoever coded their boats has apparently never seen water. There are a bunch of bizarre moments where you are sort of thrown into a dying loop because the game does not do any semblance of a reasonable job giving the player an expectation to follow. The guns are laughable even by Resident Evil standards. The story goes with a "we won't tell you anything until the very end when we'll slap you in the face with everything via exposition in writing" approach to story telling which... kind of works? Almost?

That said, the first quarter of the game is awesome. There are some very cool things in this and fun enemy design in a generally gorgeous setting. So it's fun. I recommend it in spite of its glaring flaws.

Resident Evil Village: The Rollercoaster of Horror and Hilarity

Resident Evil Village is like that one bizarre party where you end up laughing hysterically and crying in a closet at the same time. It's a rollercoaster of horror and hilarity, with a dash of existential crisis thrown in for good measure.

First, let's talk about the hero of the game: Ethan Winters. This guy is the master of deadpan humor, facing the creepiest horrors with the enthusiasm of a Monday morning meeting. He's less "Action Hero Extraordinaire" and more "Why did I even come to this village?" But, oh, the absurdity! From stapling his hands back on to nonchalantly carrying liters of health-restoring soup, Ethan's sheer ridiculousness makes you snicker even in the face of grotesque monstrosities.

Now, the village itself. It's like someone thought, "Let's put vampires, werewolves, and a giant metal chicken lady in the same place!" It's as if they spun a wheel of mythical creatures and just threw it all in. You'll find yourself questioning the game's sanity as you dodge Lady Dimitrescu's attempts at a close embrace and fend off her freakishly tall daughters.

And don't get me started on the Duke, the jolly traveling merchant who somehow manages to be a comic relief buffet in this carnival of horrors. He's got the magical ability to turn everything you find into cash, like a hoarder's dream come true. He's the friendly neighborhood capitalist, reminding you that even during a zombie apocalypse, someone's gotta make a profit.

But for all the hilarity, there's an underlying sense of dread. As you uncover the mysteries of the village, you'll realize that beneath the absurdity lies a tale of despair and loss. It's like trying to laugh through a terrifying therapy session that's slowly unearthing your deepest fears.

In conclusion, Resident Evil Village is a game that's so funny, it's depressing. It's a wild, sometimes absurd, often terrifying ride through a village that redefines the meaning of "wacky horror." So, grab your stapler, load up on soup, and get ready to laugh and cringe your way through this horror-comedy extravaganza. Just be prepared for a few nightmares along the way, both in-game and in your sleep.

[h1] Resident Evil Village: A Chaotic Blend of Horror and CInema [/h1]

Resident Evil Village is a mixed bag of horror elements that caters to a wide range of tastes, but this concoction, while intriguing initially, becomes overwhelming and unbalanced as you delve deeper. Just like sipping a complex smoothie, the first few sips are delightful, dark, and brooding, but as you continue, it turns fiery and wild, leaving you with a confusing aftertaste.

In this game, you once again step into the shoes of Ethan Winters, the same resilient yet bewildered protagonist from Resident Evil 7. This time, he's found himself in a chilling, snow-covered village teeming with lycanthropes instead of kids playing. The game manages to blend action and fear effectively during its first half. It starts with a hair-raising introduction that leads you through a village that's as monstrous as its furry inhabitants. Silence dominates the atmosphere, and every creak or snap of a twig sends shivers down your spine. Resources are scarce, firepower is limited, and fights are genuinely perilous. It's an unsettling crime scene that defies understanding, but you know you'll return to uncover the truth. Resident Evil Village shines when it embraces this patient, eerie atmosphere.

One of the early locations you explore is Dimitrescu's Castle, a grand fortress inhabited by a formidable lady, her diabolical daughters, and classic Resident Evil puzzles. More importantly, the castle preserves the village's eerie ambiance. The pacing is superb as you navigate its enigmatic puzzles and hidden passages, all while trying to ignore the suffocating silence.

But not everything in this game is flawless. Some moments prioritize action over fear, with boss fights feeling choreographed rather than genuine tests of survival. This pattern continues through most of the game, where significant encounters feel more like rehearsals with strict cues to follow. However, one location stands out as an exception.

As you progress, Resident Evil Village takes a turn. The village transforms into a hub world with four different zones, each home to one of the game's villains. The area you visit right after escaping the castle is especially exceptional, but I can't reveal any details about it without spoilers. Suffice it to say, it's a nightmarish and inventive experience that will keep you on your toes. It's a moment of vulnerability in the game, and it's masterful in how it plays with your fears.

Each return to the hub world keeps things fresh. The village subtly evolves to reflect your absence, with weather changes and subtle alterations that make revisiting areas feel rewarding. You may find new tools, like keys, during your adventures, making it satisfying to unlock previously inaccessible spots. These moments of discovery, such as finding new weapons or mysterious treasures, add depth to the gameplay.

Resident Evil Village is visually stunning, with detailed environments and intricate objects that bring its world to life. While the game ran smoothly on my RTX 2070-equipped system, I experienced one crash during a cutscene. This occurred during an early review build, so it may not reflect the final product.

The change in tone during the latter half of the game is kind of jarring. Action increasingly supersedes the horror aspect, and the abundance of weapons feels out of place. The introduction of the Duke, a shopkeeper who offers supplies and gun upgrades, makes resource scarcity less meaningful. By the end, the game prioritizes shooting over suspense and unpredictability.

As Resident Evil Village nears its conclusion, it spirals into chaos, with sequences that feel more suited to Call of Duty than a survival horror game. The transition from a chilling, unknown world to action-packed shootouts is unsettling, and the fear of running out of ammo replaces the fear of the unknown. The game sacrifices its unpredictable, chilling atmosphere for more straightforward gunfights.

Despite this shift, the game's story remains engaging. Ethan Winters' predicament hooks you from the beginning, and the conclusion, while messy, ties up loose ends and leaves room for more questions, a challenging feat for a long-running series.

In the end, Resident Evil Village tries to cater to a broad audience, but this ambition comes at the cost of balance. The early horror-focused sections are exceptional, but the game loses its way as it approaches the end, favoring action over fear. Despite this, it remains compelling.

Overall it's a wonderful game and it's a nice change of pace. The serialization and cinimatic focus of recent Resident Evil titles is something I'm enjoying and I'm hoping to see where Ethan's daughter plays in the next game.

Resident Evil Village is an electrifying addition to the iconic Resident Evil series that promises to take you on a heart-pounding journey. While it might not deliver the same bone-chilling scares as its predecessor, Resident Evil 7, it compensates with a more action-packed experience that masterfully maintains the series' signature atmosphere.

As a long-time fan of the Resident Evil franchise, I stepped into Village with high expectations, and I wasn't disappointed. Right from the start, the game immerses you in a beautifully realized, eerie village and its surrounding environments. The attention to detail in the graphics, sound design, and environmental storytelling is impeccable. Every creaking floorboard and distant whisper adds to the pervasive sense of dread.

What sets Resident Evil Village apart from its predecessors is its shift towards a more action-oriented gameplay style. While it may not be as terrifying as Resident Evil 7, it delivers in terms of heart-pounding action sequences, intense boss battles, and an arsenal of weapons that makes you feel like a one-person army against the horrors that await. This evolution in gameplay adds an exciting twist to the series while retaining its core essence.

The storyline is engaging, filled with intriguing mysteries, and memorable characters. Ethan Winters, our protagonist from Resident Evil 7, returns to face a new nightmare as he searches for his kidnapped daughter. The introduction of new characters like Lady Dimitrescu and her daughters adds depth to the narrative, making you question the motives of every character you encounter.

The game's pacing is impeccable, offering moments of respite amid the chaos to explore and solve puzzles. The merchant, Duke, provides a welcome dose of humor and acts as your one-stop shop for weapons and upgrades. Managing your resources and making strategic decisions about which weapons to buy and upgrade adds a layer of depth to the gameplay.

While Resident Evil Village may not reach the same levels of horror as its predecessor, it excels in creating a tense and eerie atmosphere that keeps you on edge throughout. It's a roller coaster ride of adrenaline-pumping action, unexpected twists, and unforgettable moments that will keep fans of the horror genre and the Resident Evil series thoroughly entertained.

In conclusion, Resident Evil Village may take a different route in terms of horror, but it doesn't sacrifice the franchise's identity. It's a thrilling, action-packed adventure that continues to build upon the rich lore of the series. If you're a fan of Resident Evil or enjoy a mix of horror and action, don't miss out on this unforgettable journey through the village of nightmares. Grab your weapons, brace yourself, and dive into this captivating and atmospheric experience.

Before I finish off Shadows of Rose, I thought I might as well update my review after spending 30 painstaking hours of doing achievements for this stupid game.


[b]First off: Denuvo.[/b]
It's gone, No more need to bitch about it anymore.
But I don't understand why they'd wait 2 fucking years just to remove the fucking DRM.
A DRM, mind you, that is capable of being easily cracked in just measly hours or so.

[b]Second on the list, The length.[/b]
6 hours may be an average length for a first time playthrough, but once you compared this to other Resident Evil games, That length is SHORT in comparison.

Compare this to my times with games such as RE4R (8-10 hours max), RE7 (7-8 hours max), or RE5 (10-12 hours max), It's abysmally short, and this really doesn't paint a good picture for a game that costs around $50+ AUD or even at launch when it came out with a ridiculous $90 AUD price tag.

[b]Third, The content.[/b]
Main campaign and Mercenaries. That's it.
The post-game content for this game is minimal and pales in comparison to RE7's content, even without DLC.

The Extra Content shop doesn't even have anything good either, and at worst: The guns you can buy from the Duke can EASILY OUTPERFORM any gun the Extra Content shop offers you.

Case in point, The Handcannon PZ. One of Village's ONLY returning guns after being missing from Resident Evil 7 and Resident Evil 6. Maxed out, it can deal around 3200 damage to enemies and even have one of the best reload speeds in the entire game...

...That is, until you buy and fully upgrade the S.T.A.K.E Magnum.

All of a sudden, the Handcannon easily became redundant as the S.T.A.K.E has 4500 damage, almost nearly close to the Handcannon's damage in Resident Evil 5 (that being 5000 when maxed out) and on top of that, also bearing a MUCH higher ammo capacity, fire rate, and even reload speed. (28 rounds compared to Handcannon's 5 rounds.)

Somehow, they nerfed one of Resident Evil's best post-game unlockables for a weapon you can just buy from the shop without even finishing the game. Why.

[b]Fourth, the story.[/b] (Spoilers here)
Out of the many times I went and ran through the game's story to speedrun, I swear even skipping the cutscenes alone accounts for the fact how fucking long Lady D's portion is, only *a cut* above Heisenberg's section. And yet the "Big Bad" [spoiler] Miranda [/spoiler] doesn't even show up until you finish off Chris's assault on the village, and that's the last 5% portion of the game.

Besides that, The story isn't even remotely good. 

You play as Ethan (who is now a dad), and you have to save your infant daughter against a group of cult maniacs in a enclosed European town.

(I wonder where they got this from... [spoiler] RE4 and Silent Hill 1 [/spoiler])

Once you enter said town, You find a group of survivors and spoiler alert: [spoiler] They die, big whoop. But one of those survivors, Elena, could EASILY become an important character if Capcom tried. But they didn't. She died and Ethan didn't do shit to save her. [/spoiler]

After that, You meet up with Dimitrescu, [spoiler] kill her three daughters, then she turns into a furious dragon. Fast forward, You find a jar with your infant daughter's limbs, and then you go on a wild goose chase to find them all. [/spoiler]

Beneviento was probably the most interesting section of the game, But it wears out quickly on your second run through of the game. [spoiler] One scary baby section of the game, and she's dead. Great. [/spoiler]

Moreau is boring, plain and simple.
Somehow even taking away a boat still can't make the fish fight any less boring than it needed to be.

Heisenberg is the first and only good character you'd meet in the story.
His dungeon is long, and for a good reason.

But I swear, they did him dirty for not giving him an alternate scenario which I'll drop now.

[spoiler] So when you meet Heisenberg again in the dungeon, You (supposedly) have a choice to join him and kill Miranda. which Ethan automatically declines. [/spoiler]
It's a stupid thing that I am disappointed for. If you could choose Mia and [spoiler] Zoe [/spoiler] in RE7, Then surely they could've done it again for Village. But since this is Capcom, who is notorious for reusing assets in games. Why am I even surprised.

Anyway, [spoiler] you kill Heisenberg, and THEN, Miranda shows up again. Only to kill Ethan in 3 minutes. What a record. [/spoiler]

It was then revealed that [spoiler] Ethan had died since RE7 and has mold regeneration inside of him. [/spoiler] And I'll give the game credit, they did a good job explaining how Ethan can even reattach his limbs. Good job.

[spoiler] You kill Miranda, save Rose, and then end the game with a sacrifice of Ethan Winters. [/spoiler]
(This choice alone will be a mistake for what comes next.)
 
So they made an story that's actually average, That's my one of only good points I'll give to this game. Moving on...

[b]Fifth, DLC Content.[/b]
1 campaign and a third person mode that is literally a mod you can download off from Nexus Mods, and extra Mercenaries characters.

I'm not going into detail about the campaign or the third person, because I am saving that for the DLC review when I get to that. What I will go into detail, however, is comparing the DLC to what RE7's DLC offers.

Resident Evil 7 Gold Edition offers:

-Resident Evil 7: Base Game
-Resident Evil 7: Season Pass (which itself offers:)
   -Not A Hero (Campaign)
   -End of Zoe (Campaign)
   -Nightmare (Minigame)
   -Bedroom (Minigame)
   -21 (Minigame)
   -Daughters (Minigame)

All for the low, low price of $56.89 AUD. The same price you can get if you were to buy Village.
All I'm saying now, is that if you can buy Village, you can buy RE7: Gold Editon, which has FAR more content than what Village can offer for the same price.

[b]Sixth, and finally, the Achievements.[/b] (and my problem with Mapmatician)
Effortless, That's what I'm going to say.

You got your usual Frugalist and Speedrun for X hours achievement, even bringing back an achievement where you knock an arrow with your knife from RE5.

But even on the Hardest difficulty: Village of Shadows. It's either a mix of the most effortless and easy parts, to the most ridiculous and bullshit parts in the entire game, and the reward you get for it is what should've been a fucking confetti gun.

The Rocket Pistol is absolutely worthless, can't even kill on the easiest difficulty with it's low damage (500) and low fire rate. It's almost like a sick fucking joke.

In the meanwhile, the Mapmatician achievement can go FUCK ITSELF.
What should've been an easy achievement, became 3 hours of pure agony trying to find any missing items in a room, only to softlock myself and end up restarting an hour's worth of progress due to my own paranoia. 

Noticed how I said "should've"? Because the MAP ITSELF, is HINDERING YOU.

That's right, The map got fucking gutted right after how useful it was for Resident Evil 2 and Resident Evil 3's remakes. It used to show you where you missed ammo and even key items you missed. Only for it to never do that in Village for no fucking reason.

I can understand this for RE7 because that came out before the REmakes.
That, is not an excuse for Village. 

The only reason it's even possible to get the achievement was to repeatedly check the Challenges menu and see how much progress you have gained for said achievement.
But it should've been an easy QoL change to add it on the fucking map itself.

[b]Conclusion:[/b]
I can easily say this is literally the third worst Resident Evil game I've ever played, behind Resident Evil 0 and Resident Evil 6. My disappointment with this game is unfathomable.

If you really want to buy this game. Please, please get this on a discount. It is not worth the full price by a long shot.

If you like this game, More power to you.
But I am showing how disappointed and furious I am with this godforsaken game.
And that is why I do not recommend this game.

I'm tempted to leave a thumb down, not because the game is bad, but because it is such a huge step back from RE7. The game is actually good and enjoyable, but it is no survival horror. I'd say more survival action. Capcom finally nailed it with RE7, they brought back all the horror and anxiety from real RE classics, while adavncing and innovating the survival horror genre. It was a miracle but they already decided to squander it all to appeal the masses. So forget all about the tension, claustrophoby and helplessness that made RE7 great. In RE Village, they wanted to strike a balance between horror and action, and they obviously failed although not entirely. Capcom thought RE7 was good (in terms of sales) but they wanted the next RE to sell even more, so they tried the obvious: they imitated their most (wrongly) acclaimed title in the series, RE4. RE4 was an ok game, but it was also where the series started to rush into the abyss of forgettable crap.

Anyway, given the premises, they did an amazing job. Young and old fans will probably enjoy this RE, even if it is far from the genius of the 7. Enjoyable is a fit adjective for this game, entertaining is too. It isn't survival horror though. In a real survivor horror you need to explore cautiously and make hard strategic decisions and keep your cool else you fuck up. Here you are just required to have fast reflexes and act fast. Assuming you play on hardcore, else it's no challenge at all. "Survival action fps with a bad aiming mechanic" is more adequate for RE8. Yeah you cannot aim down sight like in RE7 Not a Hero for some reason, you always fire from the hip and the aiming just restricts the aiming reticle. Movement and interaction is also downgrade from RE7, doors will open automatically for you far before colliding with them, and you no longer have the hand forward animation whenever you move against a wall. It's all small things but they do break immersion and it was lazy to take them out.

The story is pretty good and interesting, way better than RE standards but also kinda shallow in its execution, probably because they cut much during development. It feels like a collection of very different ideas stitched together to give you an ever changing atmosphere throughout the game. It works somehow though, and they pulled off both the spooky openness of the environment and the less linear way to progress. The weapon/merchant/upgrade system is also fun and adds entertainment. There are a few very nice puzzles, but never too hard and most puzzles are absolute no brainers. Difficulty is toned down to meet the needs of the casual gamer, so I suggest hardcore diificulty for veterans of the series, which equals normal difficulty in RE1, RE2, RE3, RE7. Even the most basic enemies are bullet sponges, but you'll be given a replenished arsenal so you won't worry too much about that after a while. The hardest section of the game is at the very beginning, so after that you're golden till the end.
The RE engine is amazing as ever, with a 1080ti I had almost everything maxed out and still a stable 140fps. Visuals are great and for the most part even improved, except a few things like the explosive red barrels which look cartoonish (RE4 style).

To conclude: great game, but very mid when compared to the previous entry RE7.

Resident Evil, being one of my favourite gaming franchises, it was only normal I went with high expectations for this title, after all, I enjoyed myself quite a bit of RE7 years ago.

Pros:
+ Fantastic graphics and optimization, the game runs with pretty much everything set to ultra with no dips or stuttering, hats off!
+ Ethan is now a fully fleshed character.
+ Voice acting (at least in English) is REALLY good, but I do wished there was British accents thrown in since the game is, in y'know, Romania.
+ They learned from RE7 and now we have decent enemy variety, nothing to write home about but they heard.
+ Awesome level design and atmosphere.
+ The Merchant returns! (well, it's not HIM, but hey!).

Cons:
- Combat is clunky as all hell, I think is even clunkier than in RE7!
- Weapons don't feel good and lack the proper accuracy to make them feel like you're shooting something.
- The whole vampire dommy mommy was a fiasco, she showed up for like 2-3 hours and that's it. Which brings me to...
- Boss fights in RE7 were lackluster (except for Jack's) but here... man, what happened? They're lame af. Villains in this game had plenty of potential to become one of, if not, the best cast in the series, but we ended up with lame and short fights.
- Puzzles are WAAY too easy.
- The whole House Beneviento DOESN'T BELONG to the game, or any RE for that matter. If I wanted to play smth like that I'd play SH/PT. 
- Ending was meh (still better than RE7's).

Overall, I feel like they tried so SO hard to emulate RE4 perfectly-balanced formula they ended up with a game that is, in the end, dissapointing, as it doesn't know what it wants to REALLY be. Sometimes, it wants to be SH, sometimes RE4, and then, sometimes, its own thing. Game lacks the direction needed in order to be a good RE in my eyes.
Even if I love RE4 and I consider it one of the best games ever, its formula shouldn't be replicated, but rather, inspiring.

Final score: 5.5/10, first time since RE6 I didn't enjoy a RE title.

My rating: 3/5 (average)

I'm giving it a positive review, but overall I'd say I'm on the line. This game recycles a lot of concepts and design from earlier RE games. The crafting and upgrading systems are a blend of RE4 and RE7, but simpler and just not as well done as those games. There are so many similar guns it feels like lazy design. There is a Mr. X monster from RE2. They block off going back to areas for exploration after that area's story is done, so you can't go back to finish clearing those rooms and find treasures you missed (why???!)

On the positive side there are some good boss fights (not all of them) and some thematically interesting areas that I really enjoyed.

Also, the game is way overpriced. I say half of that would have been right, like they did for RE7 (which was a vastly superior and innovative game).

[h1]Nasty elegance[/h1]

The meticulous attention to detail is amazing. We can say that they did it with love and a desire for perfectionism. Correctly chosen intonations and voices, musical accompaniment add integrity to the picture.

[b]Village[/b] is more of a movie with gameplay elements than the other way around. The passage was on "Normal" difficulty. This is probably the first Resident where it is approved to fight back against monsters, arming the GG almost from the very beginning with a shotgun and a large number of pistol cartridges. Moreover, monsters give different loot (lei, reagents, crystal skulls, herbs). This encourages you to move around locations more confidently. Whether this is good or bad is difficult to give a definite answer. Players complained that the seventh part was too scary, which is why such changes.

Each antagonist is thought out in its own way. They are memorable. The difficulty of the battle with the bosses gradually increases, although at first it seems that there will be no need to sweat. If you read the diaries carefully, you can learn a lot about their personalities.

But what about the absurdities in The Resident? This is a series where you shouldn’t look for logic in the script. And it’s also not worth judging the game by the actions of the characters. Long labyrinthine corridors, riddles, a frightening atmosphere, ornate monsters - this is the Resident. Even despite the wildness of some decisions, in the end they still try to explain everything that is happening.

There were unpleasant FPS drops that appeared out of the blue under certain conditions (a huge number of flies and a transition from a closed place to an open one, copious amounts of vomit). Otherwise, thanks for 120 fps indoors and 90-100 outdoors. The game does not require such high numbers, but the optimization of everything is magical (except for the cases described above).

Resident Evil Village: A Rollercoaster of Emotions and Zombies

🎮 Main Game Review

Hey, gamers! Buckle up, because we're diving into the twisted, terrifying, and sometimes hilarious world of Resident Evil Village. First off, let's talk about our boy Ethan Winters. The guy's as bland as a rice cake, but hey, that just makes the village's wacky residents shine even more, am I right?

👻 The Good Stuff
1. Variety is the Spice of Death: One minute you're in a haunted castle, the next you're in a factory that even Elon Musk would find creepy. The game keeps you on your toes like a cat on a hot tin roof.
2. Action-Packed: If you're the kind of person who likes to shoot first and ask questions later, you're in for a treat. This game has more action than a Michael Bay movie, minus the explosions.
3. Audio Bliss: The sound design is so good, you'll think the zombies are right behind you. Spoiler: they probably are.

🤡 The Not-So-Good
1. Where's the Horror?: For a game that's supposed to make you wet your pants, it's surprisingly light on the scares. It's like going to a haunted house and finding out it's run by clowns.
2. Boss Fights: More like "Boss Frights," because they're not that scary. Kinda feels like the developers ran out of coffee during this part.

🎮 DLC: Shadows of Rose Review

Alright, let's switch gears and talk about the DLC, Shadows of Rose. You know, the one where Rose tries to live a normal life but ends up freezing zombies and destroying goo. Sounds like my last relationship, to be honest.

🌹 The Good Stuff
1. New Mechanics: Freezing enemies? Destroying goo? Sign me up! It's like they took the base game and sprinkled some magic dust on it.
2. Intensity Level 100: This DLC has some of the most intense moments in the Resident Evil series. You'll be gripping your controller so hard, it might just snap.

🤔 The Not-So-Good
1. Short and Not-So-Sweet: With a runtime of just 2.5 hours, this DLC is shorter than my attention span. 
2. Déjà Vu: No new areas? Really? It's like going back to your hometown and realizing nothing's changed. A bit of a letdown, if you ask me.

Final Thoughts
So, should you play Resident Evil Village and its DLC? Absolutely, especially if you're a fan of the series or just love a good action-horror game. Just don't expect to be sleeping with the lights off anytime soon.

And that's a wrap! Whether you're here for the scares, the action, or just to see Ethan get his butt kicked, Resident Evil Village and its DLC have something for everyone. Just maybe keep a change of pants handy, you know, just in case. 😜

Everything

My disappointment is immeasurable and my day is ruined.

This game is just a bag full of mixed feelings and failed attempts:
- Ethan is an annoying brat. The "every guy" trope worked in Re7 because it enhanced the horror aspect. In Village they tried to force a more "re-like" quirky personality but it just doesn't work the way other protags in the series do (Leon, Chris, Jill, Claire...).
- The game focuses more on combat than horror. That by itself is not a bad thing. Re4 and Re4Remake are one of my favorite Re-games and games in general because the combat focus works so well. Every single aspect in those games' design works together. Village just feels clunky and so does Re7 but Re7 isn't trying to be an action game. Village tries and fails.
- The writing is mid at best and "Ethan no" at worst. This is the most plot hole filled Re-game since Re6.
- Takes way too many ideas from Re4. Almost a ripoff.
+ One of the best horror sequences ever in house Beneviento. Just makes me wish the whole game was as good.
+ The game looks gorgeous and the motion capture and voice acting is great.

I don't completely hate it. It's just overrated as heck. If this is your favorite Re-game, you must be new to the series. Get your standards higher.

[h1] The Perfect Sequel [/h1]
This is the perfect sequel to RE7 and I loved every moment of it, it actually felt like it was trying to implement new features while not forgetting what we loved about RE7.

And I believe that this game is a masterpiece in every way whether it be the story, the gameplay, the graphics, the horror aspects of it etc. In fact, it is so good that I would say it is worth the full price even when it's not on sale. Well, why are you reading reviews? Go ahead and buy it.

Perfect Game #68, Resident Evil Village.  RE Village is, once again, fantastic survival horror.  The village is worn down and overrun by monsters.  It's so desolate and it creates a sort of hopelessness as you explore.  The horror is toned down in this game from RE7, but with keeping the first person POV there is still a lot of immersion and creepiness to be found.  In particular, there is one section that is one of the scariest in any game I've played.  The characters here are also a joy to be around.  Though they are still what you're fighting against, the antagonists are filled with personality and really offer their own ideas and trials that our character must go through.  RE Village is a great mix between survival horror and great storytelling and is another solid entry in the RE series.

My first ever time playing a Resident Evil game, can't say I was disappointed. A solid action game with some horror mixed in for a pretty solid gameplay experience.

PROS:
-The setting of the game is very creepy
-The intro really kicks the story off well and sets the tone perfectly for the rest of the game
-The villains all feel very distinct and each are fun to fight
-Game always keeps you on your toes and it is never long in between big fights
-The dollhouse made me pee my pants
-Lady Dimitrescu ; )

CONS:
-Ethan Winters is a seriously annoying protagonist. You will hear him say "What the hell is going on?" about ten thousand times in your play through
- Moreau and Beneviento really feel like after thoughts as villains when they are both interesting in their own rights
-I recommend that you play through on "hard" difficulty. I played through on "standard" and it felt way too easy
-I beat the game in a little over 12 hours and only did a handful of the puzzles. Even if you were to 100% all of the puzzles and collectibles, you would still beat the game in under 20 hours

FINAL THOUGHTS: Definitely worth your time if you're already a Resident Evil fan or just looking for an action game with a side helping of horror. I would wait to buy it on sale though. 7/10

Mainly leaving a negative review because I don't think this deserves "Overwhelmingly Positive" review score. It's not a terrible game by any stretch of the imagination, but it's one of the worst Resident Evil games I have played, and judging it in the context of other games with similar prices and content (action/shooter etc.) I don't think it's that strong a game.  

I'm not exactly a purist wanting tractor controls and 3rd person, I play a lot of different games, so just "as a game" I found this one to be a little underwhelming based on my expectations because it is: 

1. Not particularly scary
2. Not particularly action-packed
3. Not really a good shooter
4. The story seems more like an anthology that someone found a way to make fit into one semi-coherent story

Don't get me wrong, this is not a bad game. Get it on sale and enjoy it. But it's 20 hours of mediocre shooting, not particularly scary, with a story you won't care about that much.

Loved the game. It is well-balanced between action and horror, maybe leaning a little bit to the action side but still a solid middle ground. The characters are interesting and the story is intriguing enough to keep the player looking forward to what will happen next. The game is short, however, with only 10 hours of playtime, but I guess it is typical for a Resident Evil game. Also, weapon types and enemy types are lacking. THE MOMMY MILKERS STRIKE BACK

The Resident Evil franchise has experimented with many aesthetics and styles of horror, all being based in the realm of cinematic presentation. RE 7 really tried something new with a focus on visceral horror akin to Tobe Hooper’s Texas Chain Saw Massacre. So, it was fitting for the franchise to return to more gothic, fantastical horror, but keeping in the established canon of the Ethan Winters storyline. However, does it improve upon its predecessor?.. 

Ehhhhhhhhh not really.

Resident Evil: Village is an incredible game  with great aesthetic and familiar gameplay. Adopting a more gothic design akin to Stoker’s Dracula meets Dario Argento, the updated location of a castle and village grounds is expansive and expertly designed. It is gorgeous to look at too! The only problem I have with it is that the map feels too big for the atmosphere to be effectively scary. The brilliance of Biohazard’s map(s) was that the farm and ship felt uncomfortably intimate. The scares were more invasive instead of grandiose, but that’s probably due to the different styles of horror. However, there are moments in Hammer’s Dracula or other cult horrors like Suspiria that are far scarier than the jumpscare-y blandness of Village. Also, the horror is lessened by the reduced difficulty of standard, which felt more like easy than anything else. Despite it taking me longer to complete this one than 7, everything felt rushed and quick. 

The design is brilliant though. The creatively found in the characters is truly inspired with extreme levels of detail and nuanced voice performances. Even the mommy milker vampire lady  is a fully-realized minor antagonist with depth. The rest of the intrigue is kind of a let-down, but it’s a decent bookend to the the plot established in Biohazard, making a good two-parter for the franchise. 

Come for the milkies. Stay for the mixed bag.

I say this game is quite good but certain things revolving around the story hold it back. 
This game is interesting in how it expands upon the RE7 formula. 

This game really wants you to get into it as it is more action packed (using the gameplay elements from RE7) than RE7 and if you haven't played RE7 it will even tell you exactly what happened to be to be caught up to speed to get you going.

This game features Ethan Winters, a man who now has to save his daughter Rose from Mother Miranda and her lords such as Lady D. and Heisenberg, the two big personalities. He has learned to shoot and it is even reflected in how he reloads quicker and his gun handling is much better. He even has a book on it in his house. Really great details.
In contrast to RE7 he is more capable as a fighter but he also talks more and has a stronger personality. He has a great motivation to find Rose but he seems to be only about finding Rose. His personality is sometimes a bit naive and otherwise sarcastic. But he is certainly more compelling in this game than the first.
Mia interestingly in this game has a better character model. I will nitpick her model in the first game looked clammy, uncanny and her hair physics were awful. This game much like the first is quite pretty. Well detailed and filled with lived in details. 
I will say just like the first game, use the knife to save ammo as I found saving ammo this time around was harder than the first because UNLIKE RE7 this game has a shop but NO CHEST to store items. It is trying to replicate RE4 and it works but I think the chest being missing sucks.
Also weirdly enough Ethan being more experienced swings his knife twice and gets tired whereas before he could swing as much as you clicked. You can get around this by guarding after swinging twice to do more damage output. 
This game kind of encourages you to go on the offensive more and given enemies now drop money or other treasures it is encouraged to clear enemies. There is no consequence other than ammo for killing enemies. 
The game has a good story but it has some issues. Chris kills Mia in front of Ethan without giving him any time to know why Chris did such a traumatic thing leaving Ethan in the dark and then getting mad Ethan gets involved to save his daughter. A Umbrella agent even calls Chris out on this decision. Some people think this is bad writing. Some say this action by Chris is built into his personality as a flaw. I lean to the former as he should be more professional at this point in is career given the situation and how he knew Ethan would respond. I mean he even takes Rose from Ethan and talks to Ethan like a dog.  
Also Lady D is the first boss and she isn't in the game very long which can be a disappointment to some given she was a big sell for the game and the main face that people simped over. But she has a presence and a lot of personality.
Also the Lords are broken up into their own different territories and once you leave the castle you can't go back to it. But the village is a hub for the other Lords' territories. 
The DLC mostly sucks. You have to pay for a Third person view, gun charms that don't matter, and an Albert pistol you can't get in the main game that gets easily outclassed damage wise by the starting pistol. Some aspects of the DLC are neat like unlocking things you would have to unlock through challenges for free in the main game with no dlc attached.
The Shadows of Rose dlc expands upon the ending and lore. As well as Rose herself. As well as her relationship with Ethan. Its a good dlc for that but the gameplay is too linear and gimmicky to keep you busy.  
Its a solid game but some weird game design choices stop it from being really great but definitely worth a shot.

Edit: I wanted to add this game is less like the Resident Evil games of old and understandably fans, including myself don't like this direction. The devs even admitted to pulling back the horror elements from RE7 that scared little babies. The game is not very scary. It does have some survival horror elements but it is too action packed to be tense. Even RE4 outshines this game in some ways. 
This game is too generous with inventory space. You can have three guns in your inventory, one being a sniper rifle before you need to add more space. 
The castle of Lady D is lost potential as it seems bigger on the outside. You don't explore all of it. The Castle should have come last in the game or Lady D should have had more of a presence as you kill her daughters maybe her patrols around the castle become more aggressive and she isn't too hard to run around. 
You even are tricked into a more linear game where you walk into big rooms with many doors but there is usually only one way to go. Puzzles are braindead easy and the game gives you the answers to them. The game directly hands you a ring with an eye on it solve a simple door puzzle as you are progressing through the basement. Puzzle items and crafting materials don't even take up inventory space. There is even a section where you play as Chris and you just storm the front and gun down enemies without a care for supplies. The game lies to you about how big it is and the directions you take. Oddly enough the factory section is more well designed with more places to go and secret rooms to find resources. 
Crafting has become so simple as not only does it take up no inventory space unlike older titles or even RE7 but now the chem fluid mainly is used to make healing items and certain ammunition. Scrap metal plus gunpowder is used to make ammo now making crafting less of a decision making process on how you use your limited resources. 
You also must pay for for certain DLC like music, a Albert gun, a film filter, a gun charm and even the Mercenaries mode. 

I think this game is good. Quite good. It is fun and well made.
But I might actually not recommend it after I initially recommended it after thinking on it some more. Its worth a try, but Capcom has shown they are withholding content from us as they have been doing since the RE2 remake. The direction from RE7 is not ideal and this game makes a lot of odd and bad design choices for both story writing and gameplay design and level design. Resident Evil fans MAY or may not like it depending on their preference for survival horror mechanics. But don't let the name fool you. It is less like the resident evil games we love. Closer to the goofy action of RE6 the game series tried to run from when RE7 was made than the revolutionary change of RE4. 
I am not against change. Just bad design and the withholding of content.

Village claims to be a survival horror experience. There may be survival horror sections, but a better descriptor would be an action-adventure spectacle with dash of horror. Village is split into several wholly different areas with a village hub. These areas are reminiscent of collecting the lord souls in Dark Souls and adventuring to the underground lava caves of Lost Izalith, or Seath’s castle called the Dukes Archives. These disparate biomes make for memorable areas with clear themes as the bosses, enemies, and set pieces all serve the cohesive vision of that segment. The level design draws obvious comparisons to the classic action-oriented predecessor Resident Evil 4, but that’s not the only connection. Game mechanics like the briefcase inventory system, the vendor that showing up in weird spots throughout, hidden gems and collectibles, and buying weapon upgrades are all stripped directly from RE4 and utilized here. If you loved RE4, Village is for you, if you’re looking for a survival horror experience, look elsewhere. Even the one pure horror segment has zero survival elements and is more akin to the likes of Amnesia or Outlast. I had a similar but different problem with RE7 not feeling like a Resident Evil game and that game had clear survival horror elements. I think, after two entries playing as Ethan, he may be the weak link. Ethan as the guy who went looking for his wife, who also got in over his head worked the first time. But for me, I have zero connection to this character. His one-liners are corny, exacerbating profanities, and the ending reveal just fell flat for me. The developer’s devotion to not showing his face is bizarre and I feel if they went this route, he should have just been a silent protagonist. With all this being said however, Village is a fun action-adventure spectacle while having a little bit of influence from almost every Resident Evil and other horror contemporaries sprinkled in. This one I recommend, but I don’t know how long I will keep playing these games if they continually push towards action and away from survival horror.
