[h1] So We Finally Meet [/h1]

[quote] [b] Score: 10/10 [/b]  [/quote] 

Hot tall vampire lady✅, hot villain who has been lonely for a decade✅, 3 thirsty twins✅, a ripped Chris Redfield✅. What else one could possibly want? This game is easily 11/10. Go play it now!

Now for those who want a more detailed review:

After playing the game for +50 hours, beating the main game 4 times on all difficulties, and playing the DLC twice, I can confidently say that this game is simply amazing. The story is a continuation of Resident Evil 7; you’re back in the shoes of Ethan Winters, this time in search of his daughter. I'd highly recommend you play RE7 first, because this game explains a lot from it and you’d be lost by the end without the backstory. Also, I’d recommend reading the files to fully understand what's going on. The game has a bit of everything. House Beneviento was my favourite part, it’s really scary, definitely scarier than anything from RE7. And just when you think it couldn’t get scarier, they managed to make it even more terrifying in Shadow of Rose DLC which is fantastic btw and has very emotional moments. Moving on to gameplay, it’s a lot of fun and requires some planning on higher difficulties. I feel it’s an improvement over RE7, especially the enemy design, the Lycans simply outdo the molded from RE7. The boss battles are good, especially the last two. They tried something new with the DLC and honestly, I’m all for it. If they can do it right, it could revolutionize the franchise. Graphically, the game looks amazing, running smoothly at 120 FPS on high settings @1440p. Finally, the mercenaries mode is a mixed bag imo, but it grew on me after playing for a few hours. After all, It's optional unless you're going for 100%. So if you don’t like it, skip it.

Resident Evil Village encapsulates you in its gameplay loop, making this one of the most games to replay I've ever played. While this game does have a lot of issues with its story, characters and horror elements, they are not mind-numbingly stupid to the point where this game is bad.

First, the how the game plays. The combat is fun and pretty rewarding. You shoot enemies; they drop loot. More difficult enemies will drop better loop that has more selling value. Some drops will be ingredients that you can use to craft ammo, healing or explosives. Surprisingly, enemies never drop ammo. There is still a problem with ammo over-abundance, however, even if you don't factor in the Duke's ammo supply. [spoiler]The game does a good job of making you face the medium difficulty enemies first, to give you a glimpse into how hard these mid-range enemies are at your current level. After defeating two of these enemies in separate one-on-one battles, you are faced with a swarm of them. The problem with the Haulers, Moroaice and Lycans is that their grab attack animations are too fast that you don't get enough of a reaction window to block them. Their regular weapon attacks are just fine, but if you anticipate a grab attack and instead they perform a weapon attack, you're forced to keep blocking for an uncomfortably long time. Most of the boss fights are pretty good, but it feels like some of the villains should have gotten more boss fights, such as Lady Dimitrescu9 in her human-escu form.[/spoiler]
Exploration is really good in this game that I even enjoy it on multiple playthroughs of the game. It's just fun to run back through parts of the map you've already been to, so that you can get treasure that becomes available. Sometimes there are even new enemies or animals available at said parts. Upgrading all the weapons is fun because of this, although I wish there was an item box to store weapons, because if you sell them, you have to buy them back at full price, complete with all attachments and upgrades (provided you have fully upgraded the weapon).
This leads me to a major gripe I have with the game, the storage space. You simply have way too much storage. I never found myself discarding items or picking what to take with me because:
a) Key items don't take up space nor do crafting items
b) Storage space is huge
c) You get storage upgrades before you need them
One fix around they tried in RE7 with the generous storage space was limiting the stack amount for ammo as well as giving you a lot of item variety to work with.
Another problem with this game is that income is scaled. You get more money on harder difficulties for some reason. This doesn't really matter, as no achievements require you to play on New Game except for your first playthrough. Still kind of stupid for players who want a challenge. If they wanted to make Village of Shadows easier for people playing New Game, they could just make the weapons start with extra upgrades or give you more weapons and items at the start of the game like in RE3R.
The story is just not that great. It's not bad, but it leaves something to be desired. [spoiler]The factory feels out of place and it could have been cut down to allow more time for Moreau or Lady Dimitrescu, who I thought were more interesting characters. The theming just didn’t work for the medieval atmosphere the game was going for. The factory is industrial but it could have gone for the Frankenstein Castle look, which also could have cut out the Lycan fortress and given more time to the aforementioned villains. Village’s story also has a problem with not explaining crucial information to the protagonist. This segways into being a problem for the characters.
Ethan has no idea what is going on the whole game, so he’s constantly asking the same thing, “What the heck is going on?” It just gets really annoying after the 29th time. Mia is also barely in the game, so you still don’t really care for her by the end of this game. Chris is just completely stupid. He doesn’t tell Ethan what is going on when he has two chances that would benefit both of them if he just spoke. The villains are interesting but they don’t have enough screen time except for Heisenberg. Heisenberg has this plan to use Rose and team up with Ethan, but he never fully explains his plan, nor does Ethan try to hear him out.[/spoiler]
Horror is hardly present in this game. Some parts are pretty scary, [spoiler]like the Vârcolac fights, the dungeon and house Beneviento (before you encounter the baby).[/spoiler] But for the most part, this game just doesn’t really try to be scary, especially with the game taking place almost entirely during the day. This was probably because too many people stopped playing Resident Evil 7, due to being too scary.

Overall, this game is worth it and I do enjoy the story even if it is lacking. The progression is what really drives this game for me.

Rating: ★★★★★

Continuing the gameplay style that was changed with Resident Evil 7, this game also offers a richer story and provides a fantastic action horror experience that beautifully contributes an origin story to the entire series. The atmospheric horror is skillfully presented, and while the intensity of fear diminishes as our character becomes more armed, the story it tells, along with the cutscenes and boss fights, are quite successful.

The new third-person perspective is a nice nostalgia for those who loved the old games, but I believe this game should be played in first-person; it's designed with a first-person viewpoint in mind. Character designs and voice acting are also very well done. The pace of the game shifts with each chapter, aligning with the atmosphere of that particular section, pushing you to adapt. Personally, having consumed a lot of content in this genre, I was only slightly tense aside from the beginning, but I enjoyed every minute of it. A 5-star game...

The Rose DLC is the best DLC I've played in the series. It's definitely worth playing.

Resident Evil Village is the first time I've really enjoyed playing through an RE title since 5 (which I only enjoyed because I played with a friend). It's a good mix of action and thriller, and the pacing flows very well. The backtracking in this game isn't as bad as a lot of the older titles, but it still gives you a little bit of that classic RE feel in terms of exploration. I do miss the 3rd person aspect, but 7 handled first person well and 8 continues to do so. If you enjoy first person horror games that lean a little more on the action side then RE:8 is a great entry in a beloved franchise.

When I first started this game I was surprised that someone we all know stole my baby and that his already large jaw seems to have grown another 3 inches in width, pushing him to the next level in his CHADness. 

Then when I got to the Village I was surprised again that you can be eaten THAT many times before you even know the controls. I struggled for a while with trying to crouch because I kept pressing the Quick-
Turn button and face-planting the enemies directly instead of crouching through the hole I was aiming for. 

Then after a while of being mauled to death I finally passed the first fight in the village and I was surprised by a large man with the shirt that is too small for his girth and he sold me cool stuff. 

I got into the big castle and then I met the large woman with the three goth daughters that raise bees and I was surprised that they didn't like me much, I liked them just fine until they bit me. I tried to find their dresses on Temu but so far no luck. 

After that, you'll be surprised by quite a lot of people who want to kill you, including a man who speaks like Buffalo Bill and seems to want to be your friend but Ethan doesn't seem to like him. Possibly because of his hat. 

The graphics are great, when you meet the sales guy you'll see what I mean, everything ripples very realistically the same as it does when I bend over. The lycans are really cool especially when you blow their head off. The goth bee women are sexy and send mixed signals just like real life. 10/10 for that. 

It has a real RE4 feel to it which is always a winner. I'm on my second time round now because I couldn't find all the collector's items because I was always just so scared and crying. This time I've only cried twice and I'm at the castle again so fingers crossed by the time I get to the giant wobbly baby that sounds like my two year old son I'll be able to concentrate this time. 

It's been a long time since I wanted to replay a game that made me wee my pants, but this one did and so I look forward to doing it again when I download the RE4 remake. 

10/10 recommend this game for any RE fan and for people who like to watch themselves get killed in fascinating ways that could have been prevented by pressing the right button at the right time.

While Resident Evil 7 returned to its roots with true survival horror this new entry explains so much more never before known and reveals secrets to those who are true fans of the series.

"Having journeyed with the Resident Evil franchise since childhood, I've watched it evolve, grow, and continually redefine the survival-horror genre. I've been ranked, competed, and deeply invested in every title, each holding a special place in my heart. But, Resident Evil Village? It stands out in a league of its own. The storytelling is captivating, the world-building unparalleled, and the graphics – simply mesmerizing. The journey of Ethan, which began in Resident Evil 7, resonates deeply with me. It's a tale that's both harrowing and poignant. Without a doubt, Resident Evil 8 isn't just a fantastic addition to the series; it's one of the best gaming experiences I've ever had."

Ethan is probably the most tragic character in the whole series, also the toughest one . He is strong not because of his ability to fight but of the role he plays—father. A mountain that protects his family. If you are gonna hurt his family, you have to get over or through him. Simple as that.

As a long-time fan of the series, I've braved zombies, monsters, and jump scares since way back when. Now, this game? It's like the perfect cocktail of horror and adrenaline that's got me hooked.

First off, the setting is a character in itself. The creepy village and its gothic vibes? Yeah, it's like something straight out of a nightmare. Exploring every nook and cranny, just waiting for that next scare, is an experience that horror buffs like me live for.

And can we talk about Lady Dimitrescu? She's basically become the new face of the game, towering over us like a gothic supermodel with a thirst for blood. It's both terrifying and strangely fascinating. But trust me, there's more to the horror than just the lady in charge.
The story? It's like piecing together a puzzle of madness and mystery. 'Village' follows in the footsteps of the franchise by delivering a narrative that keeps you on your toes, constantly questioning what's lurking around the corner.

Gameplay-wise, it's like the perfect blend of survival and action. You're armed to the teeth, yet the tension never lets up. Puzzles, exploration, and heart-pounding combat—it's all there. Yeah, I've had my fair share of jump scares that made me spill my coffee, but that's just a testament to how immersive this game is.
In a world of horror games, 'Resident Evil Village' shines like a bloody diamond. It's a rollercoaster of terror that's got me hooked from start to finish. So, if you're a fan of heart-racing moments and a good ol' dose of fear, do yourself a favor and dive into this masterpiece. As a loyal fan, I can't wait to see where the series goes next.

so good

If you're a fan of RE, then this game is made for YOU. This masterpiece combines both an immersive story along with an exciting / thrilling gameplay and experience. You'll notice right away that this new entry throws you in the mud and makes you want to carefully plan each and every step along the way. The graphics are absolutely incredible and will often leave you stunned. The voice acting / sound elements are also quite good since they add both a sense of intrigue and dread in the player's mind. Overall, this game is a solid 8/10.

The environment and character design is amazing. Lady Dimitrescu and her daughters deserve more screen time and a deeper dive into their backgrounds/stories. I would definitely buy a DLC about Lady D's life before mutation, during, and after. Capcom released one of the greatest characters of all time that brought in all the hype for the game and gave her barely any screen time.

Do I like Resident Evil Village?

The answer is Yes.

- This game takes place after the events of RE7 and in my opinion the story is pretty good in terms of Ethan's story and other characters too. My major criticism of the game in it's story is that many characters we encounter have a short scene for them and we don't explore much of their lore and we kill them early in the game, and I think it's a waste of opportunity in certain areas.

- Gameplay wise can be a mixed bag for some people, I personally like the claustrophobic combat system like what RE7 had (similarly Zombi(U) too). It did unfortunately removed the "horror" aspect of the game which what made RE7 scary, this game is pretty much RE4 but first person instead.

- The environment of the game is really beautiful and give 10/10 for it and you are able to explore different areas of the game which prevents it being boring.

- Now for the DLC, I personally did not like the Winters Expansion because although you get to play as Rose and an option to play it 3rd person. The DLC as a whole was not fulfilling for me personally because it reused areas of the base but it did add some horror elements but it was not enough compared to the RE7 dlcs. 3rd person is a mess for me because it's not fluid movement like RE2 & RE3 has and it feels very stiff at times.

My final rating 8/10

Graphics:  8/10 
RE8 looks good. The textures do look alike in a number of areas but they keep a realistic feel and I don't expect Resident Evil to look cartoonish any time soon. Still, titles such as RE4 and RE2 remake have textures that work so well together without looking cartoonish. 

Level Design: 5/10 
RE8's level design connects paths and makes shortcuts at the player's convenience at all times.  It becomes almost comical how often a short cut will practically create itself for Ethan Winters. In some games this is fun. In RE8 it feels stupid.

Gameplay: 5/10
You simply point and click when you need to kill something. Each gun has it's effective damage output and cool down reload. The way enemies react to gun play has much to be desired. Enemies often tank bullets like they are pellet gun ammo and you get so much ammo to use. This doesn't add to the the difficulty thankfully because most enemies move at a crawl, but playing is boring with no sense of peril. Ethan also basically can't die on standard mode unless the player has trouble with a platform obstacle or the game bugs out. I was really hoping there would be more than just run turn around and shoot here because RE8 is already lacking in the scary department so adding fun physical combat would help a lot. Maybe just a good buy able knife and a pistol that specializes in stunning enemies with weak spot shots but does no real damage. The marble ball puzzles were fun even if they didn't make sense existing.

Characters: 6/10 
My favorite part of this game is Lady Demitrescu and her castle. The player learns so much about her during their time evading her compared to the other big bosses of RE8. She is the best character and still not scary. The other big bosses aside from Miranda are all okay. The player learns their stories as they traverse their dungeons. Mother Miranda was a poorly written character and hurt my overall experience in the game a lot. 

Story: 5/10
The story starts with big plot twist that disconnected me from immersion. The game gives a good enough reason for keeping you out of the loop... at the very end of the game. The story connects decently enough to the events of Resident Evil 7 by the end.

Soundtrack is knives on a chalkboard for hours. 4/10

Overall: 6/10

The only real issue is that Resident Evil 4 (Remake) exists and is better in basically every single way. So, play that first and then if you want more get Resident Evil 8: Village on a sale.



I will note:

-Lycans are not really fun replacement for zombies, especially in what is traditionally a Zombie series. They are also extreme bullet-sponges in the early game, ESPECIALLY on "Hardcore" difficulty.

-You don't (reasonably) have enough ammo to deal with every enemy like you do in RE4(R). So it's highly recommended you either use the knife where you can or that you run past enemies that you can run past to lessen your resource troubles down the road. You can abuse buying "Ammo Capacity" upgrades with an empty clip to alleviate some of this to some extent.

After I finished Resident Evil 7 I was really excited for the direction the franchise was going: first person survival horror, reminiscent of the early games in the series. Heavy emphasis on resource management, solving head scratching puzzles, navigating a maze-like location. I was really hoping RE8 would continue this trend but it definitely doesn't. 

I enjoyed my time with Resident Evil 8 but I don't think I'll be replaying it any time soon. 

Likes:
- Really cool characters such as Lady Dimitresque
- Beautiful landscapes and castles
- Lady D's section feels more like old school Resident Evil
- Heisenberg's section is action packed and really fun. Has a lot of dope new enemies
- Beneviento's section has a spooky set piece that really got me

Dislikes:
- Chris Redfield's explanation at the end for acting the way he does throughout the game is very very very lame. 
- Story is whatever 
- Missed opportunity to have the Lycans swarm you like the villagers in Resident Evil 4. I noticed a severe lack of them during the mid game making back tracking pretty boring. 
- The worst part about the Lycans is they're only truly challenging in the beginning of the game and at the end of the game before you get to Heisenberg. The rest of the game it feels like shooting fish in a barrel. 
- Moreau's section is boring but boss fight is alright
- Beneviento's section is just really simple puzzle solving and the "boss fight" at the end is looking for a puppet to press F on it 3 times.
- Too many set pieces and linearity makes replayability a chore
- The map for the village is confusing and doesn't show roadblocks
- Puzzles are stupid easy

I'd still recommend if you're an action Resident Evil fan. It's still one of the better action based Resident Evil games but I don't recommend if you're looking for more Resident Evil 2 or 7.
Very fun game!

This game makes Resident Evil 7 look like an extended tech demo, that's how insane it is. It improves on almost every part from it's predecessor and goes back to some of it older titles. I like to see this game as a combination of Resident Evil 1, 4 and 7. Well designed levels, brutal and intense combat, crazy scenarios. Good variety of enemies and some insane bosses. I also love the switch to first person in the last two games. A must play for survival horror fans no doubt. Also the doll part? I will never sleep again thank you.

Some improvements from re7, and some downgrades. The downgrades are very minor, though. Its less of a horror game now and more of an action game with it's more over-the-top boss fights (if you've played the game you know what i'm talking about) and more open setting. Story is where this game surpasses re7. the story itself is both better and there's more of it. I'm talking more cutscenes and actual character development. The action-y nature of this game doesn't fit the Resident Evil vibe, though. If Ethan and Mia had different names and the game was called something else it would be almost completely unrecognizable from a Resident Evil game. Also the resource collecting didn't feel as satisfying to me as it did in re7. Still amazing though. 9/10

Great game, although some areas are way stronger than others.

Castle Dimitrescu: Great start that resembles older RE game areas but is over too quickly

House Beneviento: Quite possibly the strongest area in the entire game. Great atmosphere and scares with strong P.T vibes

Moreau Reservoir: I found this area to be the weakest. A collection of poorly designed timed puzzles along with a disappointing boss fight

Heisenberg Factory: A strong area with industrial horror vibes and some solid scares that becomes a pain to backtrack until you unlock some doors

Overall 8/10. I had a lot of fun with this game.

Resident Evil Village is a visually stunning and cinematic game, with great graphics and animations. The game follows Ethan Winters, the protagonist of Resident Evil 7: Biohazard, as he travels to a mysterious village in Europe to rescue his kidnapped daughter. Along the way, he encounters a variety of enemies and bosses, such as werewolves, vampires, dolls and mutants. The game play is smooth and responsive, with a first-person perspective that enhances the sense of immersion and tension. The game also offers a variety of weapons, puzzles and secrets to discover, as well as different endings depending on your choices. The game also connects to the previous Resident Evil games in clever ways, while introducing new characters and lore. The only downside of the game is the story, which is too much of a fairy tale horror for me. The game deviates too much from the realistic and grounded horror of Resident Evil 7: Biohazard, and instead opts for a more fantastical and over-the-top approach that feels out of place in the series. However, this is just my personal preference, and some people may enjoy this style of horror more. Resident Evil Village is a great game for fans of the series and horror games in general. It is a game that will keep you entertained and amazed.

Definitely one of the weaker Resident Evil games especially if you take replayability - something that Resident Evil as a franchise has always been known for - into account but that’s not to say this is a bad game because there are no bad Resident Evil games. 

Right off the bat you can tell this is aiming for a completely different feel than its predecessor by taking the player away from the damp, claustrophobic Louisiana swamp house and dropping them under broad daylight in the titular Village, where the game opens up almost immediately and you’re (mostly) free to explore whichever direction that your heart’s desire. Which imo is both a good and a bad thing. 

The good being I’ve always liked the idea of having a central hub area where you can come back to for a sense of safety and brief respite from whatever crazy shit that’s going down on the outside world since my early days of playing Demons Souls, and despite being a fairly rudimentary implementation of that idea the "village" still serves that function. It’s weirdly comfy just strolling through this snowy, dilapidated village tucked away in some far away mountain ranges in Romania that probably hadn’t seen any outsider set foot in until a random team of video game developers from Japan pulled up and started taking pictures. What’s more the open nature of the map really allows them to play around with optional encounters. There’s now quite a few completely optional and fittingly challenging mini bosses that just roam around freely in some far away corner of the map that you’d have to go out of your way to find like in a goddamn Souls game. That sense of player discovery is unique to Village and I appreciate it. 

The bad being, well almost everything else, really. It hasn’t been that long since my most recent playthrough of RE7 and it really solidified what a masterclass particularly in level design that it was. There’s a lot of intricacies within the Baker House that make it feel like it was designed by a group of veteran architects whose main concern was not to build a house that could realistically exist, but one that’s fun to get around in; intricacies that are sadly lost within the wide, open field geography of the village. Open area with a lot of freedom to move around in is just infinitely less interesting to me and probably requires considerably less effort to design, too, than a confined space where you have to constantly rely on your map to navigate, like in RE7. There are some resemblance of that here in the factory section which is a step in the right direction, but it’s a step too small, and too late because within two hours of you getting there the game is over. 

But I’m getting way ahead of myself. This is where I need to start talking, or complaining, rather, again, about the four different sections that this game is split into. I wanna preface by saying all four of these sections are good, just not in ways that make a RE game good. 

First off we have the castle, which for all intents and purposes is your "traditional" RE experience. Or so I’ve heard, until I played it for myself. Because aside from the gothic visuals this entire section is a pretty far cry from your classic RE formula. The layout is too linear and there’s no routing involved whatsoever. All that branching paths is merely an illusion, a ruse to trick your brain into thinking the map is more open ended than it actually is. When in reality it’s pretty much on rails with the occasional, very scripted appearances of a pursuer type enemy to funnel you down a single corridor. It’s a thrilling haunted house ride but none of it feels very organic like in RE7 or the RE2 Remake. Speaking of enemy unless my eyes are deceiving me I’m pretty sure the hooded blind dead (yes that is a Tombs of the Blind Dead reference) share the same animation skeleton with the possessed medieval armor in the RE4 Remake. I would know because as soon as I saw that sword swing animation my muscle memory kicked in and I almost went in for a parry, until I realized I was playing as Virgin "where is my wife and daughter" Ethan, not Chad "Kill zombies. Behead zombies. Roundhouse kick a zombie into the concrete. Blow zombie heads with magnums. Suplex zombies. Feed zombies to lickers. Throw zombies into lava. Blow zombies up with rocket launchers" Leon. Shame. Another nitpick I have to get out of my system is that the castle doesn’t feel very… castly. It may resemble a castle on the outside but as soon as you step through that castle gate it’s like you’re transported to an entirely different structure where the interior could best be described as Spencer Mansion meets Goldener Saal. Now I don’t mean to endlessly heap praise on the RE4 Remake but this is where I have to once again for it really nailing the look and feel of being inside of a medieval castle. 

On to the next section House Beneviento which I think is masterful. Not in terms of gameplay because there barely is any since it’s just a walking simulator with some light puzzle elements thrown in but the buildup of tension is masterfully done. It’s almost 90% buildup with a very gradual escalation and a simmering score in the background but without that buildup the remaining 10% payoff wouldn’t be as worth it. It’s so good in fact that they remade this entire segment pretty much beat for beat in the Shadow of Rose DLC, and it’s just as terrifying if not more so the second time I tell ya. 

Then there's the reservoir which is a platforming section that plays like a 2D Mario game with the most jank boat control you’ll ever experience in a video game. There’s nothing more to say about it really because it’s a nothing burger of a segment that exists only to pad out the length. At least it’s mercifully short. 

Finally we arrive at the factory which I think is the best section for reasons I’ve mentioned earlier. It’s the only section that resembles a classic RE game with its own unique twist on the key hunting and a non linear progression. The rusty, industrial aesthetic, the killer ambiance, and the literal Frankenstein's Army that are the enemies you face off against also do a lot of heavy lifting in making this entire area my absolute favorite. 

At this point you might begin to notice the biggest issue I had with this game overall and that’s a complete lack of tonal consistency and consistency within the locations. Aside from the fact that geographically they all link back to the same village there really isn’t any cohesion between these locations. They feel and play so different from one another it’s hard not to pit them against each other and choose a favorite, like I just did. Hell even RE Revelations, the LITERAL episodic RE game, feels less disjointed than this one. Now I don’t like being overly analytical or worse yet overly critical on things that I’ve enjoyed since I did very much enjoy this game, but it’s hard not to given it bears the RE name, and directly following up RE7 no less - a game that not only revitalized an almost 30-year-old franchise, but one that lots would consider the single greatest survival horror game ever made.

Village is perhaps the first survival-horror game I've played where I just couldn't put the controller down. It combines some of the best elements of the Resident Evil franchise and sprinkles some new magic on top. The gunplay is smoother than ever, and the maps are beautifully haunting. Granted, it isn't quite as terrifying and grotesque as RE7, which actually makes it a step down in the horror genre, but the variety in map design and overall great action combat well makes up for it.

As somebody who hadn't played any of the other Resident Evil games, I can say that this was an actually fun experience. It wasn't too scary, but at times (House Beneviento) it did get a slight bit creepy. The story was actually not terribly written as well, which made the experience that little bit better.
Throughout my time playing this game I found that the game play was well made, the story well written, but some of the paths that I was meant to take were a bit confusing. At some times I even found myself running back and forth for 10s of minutes, which does take away from the experience and atmosphere.
Other than the few times that I got lost, this game was enjoyable, a slight bit spooky, and has made me want to check out Resident Evil 4, and Resident Evil 7.
It wasn't as scary as Resident Evil 7, but it was a better game over all. This game kicks total ass!

If I told someone, "take Resident Evil 7 and make it Resident Evil 4," this is what I would expect. This game, like 7, has an incredibly addicting game play loop, up there with games like RE7, Half-Life Alyx, and to an extent the original Half-Life. This game really and truly feels like a mix of all of the best elements of Resident Evils 4 and 7. Take the survival elements of 4, such as being able to hunt animals like chickens and fish for food, inventory, huge mutated boss fights, and the most god-awful, cringe inducing one-liners you have ever heard, mixed with 7's insanely creepy approach to horror in sections like House Beneviento. I would recommend this to anyone who liked either 4 or 7. Plus theres Lady Dimitresqu.

I love horror games like Outlast,Amnesia,SOMA etc but one thing they all lack is actually having the ability to fight back. REV is essentially that, a first person horror game with guns. Without giving the story away this game is almost like a Resident Evil spin on Outlast combined with Dark Souls 3. For the record I loved the old-school RE1-3 games but wasn't a huge fan of 4 for its ridiculousness and branching away from horror, REV actually manages to up the ante with its action whilst still maintaining its Horror game characteristics

A very fun, thrilling and intense semi-open world story based game. Action is hard but not so hard that you're gonna rage quit, the world is fun to explore and the story is intriguing. 

However there are some glitches and the biggest one that I've encountered is that there is no audio with the main characters dialog. I tried various fixes but none have seemed to work for me unfortunately, so have had to resort to turning on subtitles. 

Apart from that this game is very enjoyable

+Strong points :
- Very good atmosphere
- Generous and varied in its content (multiple weapons, situations, etc...)
- A slightly more open play area without diluting the storytelling
- Some surprising passages
- Fights a little more interesting than those of Resident Evil VII

- Weak points :
- Unlike its predecessor, no VR
- The structure, almost identical to  RE VII
- Repetition in certain sequences, clichés, implausibilities...
- The fear/action balance in favor of powder

Summary : More successful than its predecessor from which it shamelessly steals its structure, Resident Evil Village is a complete experience filling with a quiet force all the boxes necessary for the success of a survival-horror in first person action-oriented view. Although it draws its inspiration from the bottom of the Spanish dungeons belonging to Resident Evil 4, the title of Capcom manages to pull out of the game thanks to its atmosphere tinged with original fantasy for the saga. The unforgivable absence of virtual reality and the presence of a feeling of “already played” prevent him from claiming the title of eminent leader of the village. However, not enough to initiate a quarrel: this Resident Evil is a success.

amazing game

- Really interesting characters and story. They all feel alive and unique, and all the cutscenes and the story are interesting.
- Very pretty. There are some quite imperfect areas, such as clearly 2D grass and other things the game does not manage to hide very well and slightly break immersion, but, at least, the performance is very acceptable even with ray tracing on, so it's still pretty fair.  The game really misses DLSS though, being the main graphical downside of this game.
- Very cool and/or badass cutscenes, and very cool extra Village of Shadows story. One significant issue is that you can't re-watch the dubbed version of it on the Extras menu, as it is hardcoded to english on the main menu version, so that's a significant and annoying oversight.
- Gameplay is usually around a 7/10. Some parts of the game are too easy to get lost in, or you have to walk all the way back, and that could be better, The default difficulty is a bit too easy and most bosses died on the first or second try, yet I'd be scared of the hardest difficulty so I couldn't go for it.
- Some of the "water boss" section is very annoying. The water platforms that fall and instakill you are unfair, tend to oneshot you and just aren't fun, alongside with some similar mechanics on that area. That boss fight itself was pretty meh too so it felt like that entire section was not worth it and not as good as the rest of the game
- Good atmosphere and gameplay balance overall. Fun progression.
- Several bits of good AI, enemies that already attack you as they're coming out of the ground unlike other games or being dragged out of your safe spot by an enemy that knows he can't reach you there just makes the game so much more scary as the enemies are not robotic and those interactions really caught my attention by how much they improved my experience. On the other hand, there are a few bits of bad AI, like Dimitrescu being extra dumb when chasing you, or that clunky fight in a small space against the giant near the end of the game - though if those bits were improved AI-wise, the section would become too hard or too annoying on the current design, and the game ended up going with the dumb route - though thankfully that is only in a few minor parts of the game.
- DLC is too expensive, so I didn't get to play it

Overall 8/10.

finished the game in 2 days while sick.

ive had this in my libary for a while and felt "eh gowan then lets give it a crack". bare in mind before i go further this is my first resident evil game so any problems i have that are a series staple know this... i really dont care. 

a bit of quick backstory as well, im an indie game developer currently working on a horror game my self so i wanted to play this for inspiration and to see what i could learn from too. 

now to the game. 

the level design and atmospehere was absolutally incredible. the gameplay and the way gun combat works really accents how they want guns to really POP and it becomes rewarding later on in the game when you start blasting lycans in the head with a fully upgraded shotgun. i dont know if its my dark souls back ground or the game is designed to make you feel powerful but it felt amazing. 

there were times however where i was frustrated and that was the boss battles. they where great but i really couldnt tell how much damage i was doing and scrambling for ammo with no hope is just tedious and boring because the fights were not particularly hard as the game had no real dodge mechanic. they where still very well designed and made however. 

the player health as well was always a mystery. so thats my one gripe SHOW THE PLAYER HOW LONG THINGS HAVE TO DIE. that and i find rose ugly and mia annoying and expressionless.

i loved the castle the most and avoiding vampires tickled a soft spot for me as i adore that kind of setting. 

each levels visuals appeared to get better and better. 2 days (7hr 30 minutes) to complete is the minimum standard but i felt the game could have gone further. 


i dont know what it is however but while i did enjoy the game and it really felt like it kept going on tangents and "get x amount of objects to progress" which led to moments where i felt lost. i think the village and castle should have been the focus the whole time. so for that i would have to give village an 8.7/10

Resident Evil always kills it

Resident Evil Village (RE8) is an experience in survival horror like never before. "With detailed graphics, intense first-person action and masterful storytelling, the terror has never felt more realistic" indeed. Capcom have truly outdone themselves with the RE Engine and this Resident Evil game. If they keep going the way they are going... no other "survival horror" game will ever stand against RE ever again. Resident Evil Village is a continuation after the events of Resident Evil 7, so... if you have not played RE7 or do not know what happened, please watch some videos or go buy it first and play it, it's 100% worth it.

[h1][b] PROS [/b][/h1]
⚫I personally love how the "Village of Shadows" story book is the actual story for the game. How Moreau is the Fish King, Heisenberg is the Iron Steed, Donna Beneviento is the Dark Weaver and Lady Dimitrescu is the Bat Lord, the 3 black bats are her daughters (as a massive DRACULA fan I appreciated this so much with the references to Dracula's Brides). All controlled by the Witch, Miranda.
⚫Animations are amazing for Ethan and enemies alike.
⚫Puzzles are not overly complicated and not stupidly easy either. I did find myself occasionally scratching my head but then I remember "Did I inspect this object yet", haha.
Game has a heavy emphasis on exploration to find lore and hidden items such as guns, gun parts and treasure to sell to make some money.
⚫Story was amazing from start to finish. It honestly blew me away. I, WE all really needed this story. Resident Evil is FINALLY back on top. 
⚫Some of the most memorable boss fights in the series so far and characters (Ok, who will forget Lady Dimitrescu after all that XXX of her)
⚫Soundtrack is AMAZING. Especially the ending song for Resident Evil Village is just fucking awesome. I just cannot get enough.
⚫They also added back in the popular mercenaries mode which adds TONNES of replayability.
⚫You can grab yourself even more content as there is a decent DLC for Village - Winters Expansion.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wpp_1J2jyjs Amazing song. 
If it gets removed just type in youtube or spotify -  Yearning for Dark Shadows

[h1][b] CONS [/b][/h1]
⚫When ethan swaps weapons... he has 4 arms basically. You need to see it to see what I mean but if you swap weapons really fast you can see another set of arms on that weapons as you swap quickly between them.
(I could not think of anything else wrong with the game but this. Its PERFECTION in a nutshell)

[h1][b] My Verdict [/b][/h1]
I cannot recommend this game enough. I love it. The story and characters.... the modding and freedom you are given... its just what Resident Evil should be. With the new RE Engine added in the game looks absolutely stunning and to top that off the amount of mods you can get out there for this game... what can I say... this game is truly AMAZING. DO NOT miss out on this 10/10 game.

Spoiler Free Review:
This is an alright third person shooter with a horror setting but a pretty terrible Resident Evil/Biohazard game.  If you've never played RE or don't generally care for the series this will probably be a fun shooter romp for you!  Long time RE fans shouldn't pay more than 20 bucks for this.  Solid 5/10.

Spoilers:
[spoiler]
This game has literally no purpose in the RE universe other than "Oh wow, werewolves and vampires are canon now."  RE isn't a series I hold to a strong story with consistent narrative and plot; but this one doesn't make even a single ounce of effort.  Oh, Miss D. and her 3 daughters are weak to cold?  Good thing they live in the mountains where it's perma-winter.  Oh, and Miss Ds bugs are weak to cold except in the last fight against her where you have to hide inside, away from the cold, to disperse her bugs because the devs have no consistency ever in this game.  

Oh, and Miss D's weakness?  A knife with a bunch of poisons on it that she keeps in her house and never cleaned the poisons off of for...reasons...and then she waits to attack you until you open a coffin and grab the knife in the slowest animation ever.  Because the devs couldn't bother making her first phase weakening her enough that the knife isn't guarded anymore.  They also couldn't make the mansion a mission of getting the poison so you can stab her...instead you get masks to get the knife that has the convenient poisons.  Like...ANY EFFORT...ANY EFFORT AT ALL...and the game could make sense but the writers are not good at their jobs.

Oh, and Miss D that got Twitter all horny, the only reason this game is well reviewed and liked is because twitter got horny for Miss D btw, is only in the game for about 30 minutes.  She's the first boss.  She's not important to the plot at all other than she was there.  

This RE entry also features more walking simulator segments than anything I've ever seen in RE before.  If you really like walking around doing nothing but listening to dialogue and avoiding a giant insta-kill fish...this game has you covered.

There was exactly one (1) fun segment in this whole game: Heisenberg.  The voice actor for H had so much fun with his role and you could really feel it.  The combat in that section was genuinely engaging, the progression felt like old RE progression, and the final fight for that segment felt so epic that they should have just ended on it tbh.  It was perfect.  That section should have been the whole game really.  Just expand it. 

The actual final fight was extremely mid however.  Run in a circle, shoot, run in a circle, shoot, shoot 3 orbs, run in a circle, shoot, repeat.  RE final fights tend to be a let down, so I wasn't surprised, but I wanted a bit more after how epic the preceding fight had been.

Lastly, the DLC.  The DLC was complete garbage.  50% walking sim, 40% Dragon's Lair love letter (QTE sim), 10% actual gameplay.  The final boss was the same final boss from the base game too; which didn't help.  The game tried to make Miranda returning a plot twist; but it was incredibly obvious that Rose was being manipulated by her from the start.   
[/spoiler]

I’m really conflicted about this game. There is so much to like, the setting the characters, the callback to RE4 are all very well done. The return of the “Merchant” titled “The Duke.” The music and sound effects are well done and most of the battles are entertaining. I think my issues with the game it that it tries to be Resident Evil 4 without trying to be its own thing and unfortunely relies of the nostalgia factor. To me RE7 is flat out the better game because of how fresh it was and while the feeling of helplessness was tough at first it eventually became understandable on how to play the game.

RE8 meanwhile just feels off in how they want you to play the game. At first you are completely helpless just like in the last game but over time it becomes much more of a run and gun time game. With that said however the aiming is not great and the general idea of just running in circles to avoid an enemy gets very repetitive especially with most of the boss battles at the end.

I also don’t understand why Chris Redfield’s character becomes so absolutely useless to our main character and the lack of information characters share with each other becomes quite a nuisance. With that said the game certainly is not bad but I would argue unfulfilling. While the characters are interesting we barely get much time with each of Miranda’s “children.” It’s also a big point that there is just a lot of empty parts going on in the game and it feels less like an exploration and more of a to do list. Having so many things revealed early on doesn’t help things either.

Spoilers: I’m not sure how I feel about Ethan, Mia or Rose. I guess Ethan’s story makes sense and it certainly explains a lot of things but Mia still being alive and the mystery of Rose that is just never explained becomes frustrating. Miranda in general is really boring because we flat out do not interact with her at all until the very end. Heisenberg and really all the other children were far more interesting and much more interaction with our main character.

All in all the game does a lot of things right but I think in an effort to recapture the RE4 magic it lost what had made RE7 so refreshing and we are left with a game that doesn’t know what it wants to be.

I enjoyed this a lot after having played the RE4 remake. RE Village is more of the same style of gameplay, though with significantly worse writing (though that mostly adds to the entertainment). This game is lots of fun, and has a couple of truly memorable scary moments.
OUTSTANDING GAME

Good, but disappointing.
The entire game is a mashup of different concepts from several other Resident Evil games:[list]
[*]Storywise is reminiscent of Barry's European excursion from Revelations 2: extremely similar main plot, setting, AND themes. Though the Eastern European setting is more original in Rev2, since it isn't just RE4's village+castle combo, it's a post-Soviet era town with surroundings.
[*]Speaking of RE4: the setting, the desperate defense from a horde of enemies in the beginning, a merchant, upgrading weapons and inventory capacity, no item box, finding treasures, a fish boss. Even the head explosions are similar. There's also a doll based "boss", which seems to be a concept from one of the early versions of RE4.
[*]Mercenaries mode is Revelations 2 Raid Mode with 2% of the content. At best.
[*]RE7's first person camera and a few characters like Ethan.[/list]

There are many problems with simple mechanics:[list]
[*]Enemies are fairly damage spongy even on Standard difficulty.
[*]Hitboxes on enemies and their attacks are inconsistent, e.g. sometimes they attack you through walls (Moreau’s spit), their attack which is supposed to be blocked by terrain, isn’t (Urias), they can damage you in cutscenes (going inside the safe room for the first time in the castle while being chased by Lady D), enemies with thrusting drill attacks (Soldats) have hitboxes so large you’d swear they were swipes.
[*]Some of the boss arenas are poorly designed. What are these areas with the Urias fights supposed to be? Small, cramped spaces against a giant wielding a huge double handed hammer who can spin to win? 2 of the 3 fights against Dimitrescu’s daughters are also 2x2 meter rooms or corridors so narrow you have absolutely no room to maneuver.
[*]There are locations where the enemies just stop pursuing you and walk away after you cross an invisible line. They do not regenerate their health, so it’s easily exploitable.[/list]

My other issues:[list]
[*]No FoV option, even though it was present in RE7. 
[*]To quit the game you have to press Delete; you cannot use the mouse.
[*]Inventory management is pointless. If you buy the larger attache cases, you will only run into inventory issues on your NG+ runs. On your fresh save you don’t have to do anything.
[*]Takes a while to get to the game proper. A ton of cutscenes and scripted sequences at the beginning make repeated playthroughs a chore.
[*]Enemies spam grab moves which have animations so long you'd think they're death animations. Some of them are nearly 10 seconds long. On Village of Shadows difficulty it's even worse.
[*]Puzzles are lackluster. There's one statue puzzle in the castle that has a description more confusing than the actual puzzle.
[*]Ethan behaves either like a badass or a total wimp. It's really jarring and inconsistent. He's also constantly commenting on everything, in contrast to RE7 where he barely reacted to anything: I preferred him mostly silent.[/list]

Biggest positives:[list]
[*]Looks absolutely gorgeous.
[*]I like the Metroidvania gameplay of the village itself.
[*]The combat is satisfying.[/list]

They tried to appeal to both horror and action fans, and while RE6 failed spectacularly in this endeavour, Village appears to have succeeded when looking at the general reception. For me, however, while it's a significantly better game than RE6, it's still unfocused. Each section is distinctly different from the other. It’s theme park horror by design. RE7 was laser focused: it knew what it was and what it wanted to be from start to finish. RE7 was a labor of love. Village seems a corporate creation.

It's still a good game. I finished it several times in a row. But it's a disappointment and I don't think I'll ever touch it again after unlocking all achievements.


Shadows of Rose[list]
[*]The mannequin bit was outstanding. Too bad it lasted only a few minutes and was followed by an awful stealth section that was way too long.
[*]Great scares ruined by a protagonist who doesn't shut up.
[*]Constant re-use of locations.
[*]Unfulfilled potential with the Mutamycete storing memories: they could’ve shown more Lord backstories, or even the Bakers again.
[*][spoiler]Capcom went to comedic lengths to hide Ethan’s face.[/spoiler][/list]

Resident Evil: Village plays as a blend between the presentation and tone of Resident Evil 7 with the setting and greater focus on action of Resident Evil 4. Seeing as those two titles are clear high points of the series, this seems like a great concept on paper. However, I find the execution somewhat lacking; Village doesn't quite meet the consistent level of entertainment that RE4 had, nor does it match the engrossing story and atmosphere of RE7. 

Ultimately Village is a solid game that I would give a recommend, especially if you enjoyed either or both of the aforementioned older titles but still want more. I'm just left a bit disappointed to find that it's less than the sum of its parts.

When I first heard about an FPS Resident Evil, I was very skeptical. In fact, I had just written Resident Evil off and decided to ignore 7 and then later on 8. I was one of the many RE fans that didn't really like how the series went with the success of 4. I liked 4, found 5 to be meh and I didn't play 6 because I heard from reviews that it was basically a pure action game and the survival horror bits from old were pretty much all thrown out, and those were my favorite parts from the RE series. The claustrophobic feeling, finding keys and solving puzzles, all the while killing monsters and worriedly watching your precious ammo dropping, wondering when you'll find more. Those were my favorite parts of the RE games. And they were slowing moving away from that, and with 4, started in a new direction. So I figured 6 killed the franchise since I'd heard it didn't do well and so wrote RE off. But like the zombies of old, they rose again with RE 7. At first I was excited, they were coming back to their survival horror roots, yay! They were bringing back the keys, puzzles and central locations, yay! And it was FPS... crap!
The thought of an FPS Resident Evil filled me with dread and confusion. I thought they were just jumping on the bandwagon of those survival horror games like Alien Isolation, the Amnesia series, Slenderman and all those other FPS games that pitted you against some horrible monster that you couldn't kill, or didn't even have weapons like with some games of the genre. So I wrote off 7 and 8 and just hoped for something better. Then the remakes came along and I was revitalized. With the 40th anniversary of Capcom putting all the RE games on sale, I decided to bite the bullet and fill out the rest of my collection and snap up 5, 6, 7, and 8 for the PC. 7 and 8 are very damn good. I was, quite frankly, shocked and amazed at how good they are. They are pure Resident Evil, all the keys and puzzle solving, limited ammo but enough to kill everything you run into if you aim right and make the right crafting choices. I also was ashamed of myself for not giving 7 or 8 a chance and ignoring them all these years. I might be late to the party, but I finally got here and I am completely enjoying myself.
Bottom line, if you are a fan of the game style of the older games, the puzzle solving, the keys and the claustrophobic feeling of the environment, then 7 and 8 will be welcome editions to your Resident Evil collection!

Resident Evil 7 was clearly a reimagining of the first Resident Evil, with the mansion, the relatively few monsters and the overall scariness. This one is Ethan Winters' very own Resident Evil 4. You get the intro with a village filled with monsters, the castle tour, the giant aquatic monster, the hordes of monsters, the merchant of dubious origins seemingly everywhere, the weapon upgrades... I like both formulas so I'm fine with it, but it's interesting to see how different those two games are.

I very much liked this opus. It might be because I don't play that many AAA games, but I'm quite impressed by the level of graphical quality. I think it's a very beautiful game. I feel it's important to note that the game handles brightness much better than Resident Evil 7 did. You can actually see what's happening, and you don't have to wait every few seconds for the silly simulated eye adaptation to stop fiddling with the luminosity. The gameplay is standard action Resident Evil fare, except for the lack of melee hits. The progression is a tad weird because the game plays the four heavenly kings one emperor card straight but only two of those five enemies really feel fleshed out. The other three mostly look like quickly thrown-together arcs made just to keep to the original five arcs plan.

The game is of standard Resident Evil length: 2-3 hours if you rush, 8-16 during your first run. After your first run you unlock a new game mode, a new difficulty and a bunch of cheats that become available by getting the game's achievements like in the Resident Evil 2 remake. The additional game mode isn't that good in my opinion, and is mostly about speedrunning through the story levels with different enemy placement and weapons to earn a high score.

The main complaint that I have after putting down the game is about something relatively small, but it really sours my entire impression of it: you're forced to watch a bunch of stuff countless times over. I find it particularly irritating that despite the fact that the developers put in a way to skip cutscenes, they made a conscious effort to make it crappy. They introduced a system that makes it so that for most cutscenes, there will be a pretty long delay between the start of the cutscene and the moment when you can actually skip it. The way they do this is by disabling the game's menu for a time. They also use the same system quite often when you're grabbed by an enemy, making it impossible to go to the menu and choose restart for a few seconds. It is a problem common to lots of games and it is always very irritating, but for this one I'd even call it puzzling, because it's clearly not a mistake or an oversight, but truly intentional, and I just can't begin to comprehend what could go through a guy's head that'd make him waste time to implement something actively bad like that. There's also the issue of some cutscenes not being identified as such and thus being unskippable by default.

In short, it's pretty good but who's the idiot that thought forcing players to sit through cutscenes and grabbing animations was a good idea? Especially in a game series that has always strived for replayability. Please fire that guy. Really.

Resident Evil 8 is an awesome game but Echoes of BioShock Infinite than a Resident Evil game.

Resident Evil 8, the latest installment in Capcom's long-standing survival horror franchise, presents an intriguing blend of familiar elements and novel innovations. One of the most striking aspects of the game is its aesthetic and gameplay similarities to BioShock Infinite, a critically acclaimed first-person shooter developed by Irrational Games. This comparative review will explore these parallels and their implications for the overall gaming experience.

Firstly, the visual design of Resident Evil 8 is reminiscent of BioShock Infinite's distinctive aesthetic. The game's setting, a mysterious European village, is imbued with a sense of eerie beauty that mirrors the floating city of Columbia in BioShock Infinite. The architectural design, color palette, and atmospheric lighting in Resident Evil 8 all echo the art direction of BioShock Infinite, creating a similarly immersive and visually stunning environment.

The gameplay mechanics of Resident Evil 8 also bear a striking resemblance to those of BioShock Infinite. Both games blend elements of exploration, puzzle-solving, and combat in a seamless manner. The player is encouraged to explore their surroundings thoroughly, uncovering secrets and resources that aid in their survival. The combat in both games is intense and strategic, requiring the player to make effective use of their limited resources against formidable enemies. The presence of powerful, unique adversaries in both games—akin to BioShock Infinite's Handyman or Resident Evil 8's Lycans—adds an additional layer of challenge and unpredictability to the combat scenarios.

Also, the narrative structure of Resident Evil 8, while retaining the franchise's signature horror elements, incorporates themes of existential dread and moral ambiguity that were central to BioShock Infinite's storyline. The player is confronted with complex characters and moral dilemmas that blur the line between good and evil, echoing the narrative depth and complexity of BioShock Infinite.

However, it is important to note that these similarities do not detract from Resident Evil 8's unique identity. The game retains the franchise's core survival horror elements, such as the tension-filled exploration of hostile environments and the constant threat of gruesome enemies. Furthermore, the game introduces new mechanics, such as the ability to block and counter enemy attacks, which add a fresh dimension to the gameplay.

Lastly, Resident Evil 8's aesthetic and gameplay similarities to BioShock Infinite contribute to a rich and immersive gaming experience. These parallels, combined with the game's unique elements, result in a compelling blend of familiarity and innovation. While Resident Evil 8 clearly draws inspiration from BioShock Infinite, it successfully integrates these influences into its own distinctive framework, thereby enhancing the franchise's legacy and appeal.

Roaming the streets of this game is like visiting a disturbing and deadly Disneyland, where every attraction is a house of horrors. I got just as big a thrill out of revelling in its frenzied violence as I did retracing my steps through the gradually revealed recesses of its sizable village setting to uncover the darkest story secrets of its monstrous main cast. Boss fights are a bit of a letdown but the great variety of enemies throughout keeps things tense. The fact that it's very much a throwback to the fast-paced action of RE4 also means it largely takes a step back from the slow-burn scares of RE7's excellent opening hours, which may well disappoint those who prefer more psychological dread to blowing off heads.

Gaming Moments of 2021

So I went for a walk and came across this old European whistle-stop.  No one was burning the police tied to a stake but as soon as I started breaking and entering into these tore up wigwams a hobo pulls me through the floor and nearly bit my traffic finger off which instigated a snickersnee I barely won and not before alerting a dozen or so of the hooligan's associates.  So there they all are giving me stink eye from the roof tops and the minute I get back to my burglary spree they start howling for their mates to bum rush me.  I feel obliged to fashion a rampart out of some gaudy Ikea crap by the door and we commence a staredown until their buddy Andre the Giant rolls up with a hammer to extirpate my blockade forthwith.  Even after fulminating the nearest barrique I have to make for the roof before I find a truncheon embedded into my breast pocket.  No sooner have I stood on a shingle before this rabble has taken to firing crossbows from the neighboring gambrel and they do not cease even after I Mario back to the thoroughfare and make for a nearby wicket.  Everything starts moving in slow motion and I think all we need now is some maniac-wielding chainsaw to put a cherry on top of this here fiasco.  I am quickly brought back to the present as a bolt pierces my shank so hard I think I may never skedaddle again.  Much to my chagrin Andre has caught up to get me mirandized for the act of fornication I am about to receive and wouldn't you know it the Krispy Kreme is now open so I get to talk to grandma.

10/10 would kick the homeless with an empty sawed off until this happens again.

[h1]Resident Evil Village - A Thrilling Blend of Storytelling and Engaging Mechanics [/h1]
Resident Evil Village, and I must say that it exceeded all my expectations. 

This game masterfully combines an immersive and captivating narrative with refined mechanics, creating an unforgettable gaming experience.

The narrative is intricately woven, keeping players on the edge of their seats with every twist and turn. It expertly blends horror, mystery, and even elements of folklore, creating a chilling atmosphere that keeps players engaged from start to finish.

[hr][/hr]
The characters in Resident Evil Village are memorable and well-developed, each with their own distinct personalities and motivations. 

The game's antagonist, Lady Dimitrescu, became an iconic figure even before the game's release, and rightfully so. Her imposing presence and the enigmatic nature of her vampiric family add an extra layer of intrigue to the game's narrative. And let's not forget the splendid performance by Neil Newbon, who just nailed Heisenberg's eccentric and daring nature.

[hr][/hr]
The game strikes a fine balance between exploration, combat, and puzzle-solving, providing a satisfying gameplay loop, [b]except for the Beneviento Mansion[/b]. The first-person perspective intensifies the feeling of vulnerability and helps immerse players in the game's unsettling world.

The addition of the merchant, Duke, provides a welcome respite from the horrors, allowing players to upgrade their weapons and replenish their supplies.

[hr][/hr]
Unfortunately, the Beneviento Mansion suffers from a lack of random events, that could make the encounter a little bit more startling and scary. If you played the story once, I believe you will not feel the same way. 

[hr][/hr]
I played the game for 5 times and did every challenge, except for 3, and had fun all those runs. I highly recommend the game if you want to experience a wonderful story with engaging puzzles and mechanics.
Besides the big tiddy lady Dimitrescu memes, the game is disturbing, scary and awesome.

The first RE game that has it all. Good characters, good level design (fuck RE 2 shit sewer system),  noncluncky mechanics, interesting boss fights... and a good ass story.

This game should serve as a benchmark for all future RE games to come

One of the best RE games.

I don't think I can really recommend this one. If you can get it on sale for like, 10-20 bucks, go for it, but it was absolutely not worth the $70 or whatever I spent on it at launch. There are some absolutely outstanding chunks of this game, notably the first two or so hours are fantastic, and the mid-card haunted dollhouse is crazy fucking good, maybe some of the best interactive horror content I've ever played. 

Now that I've complimented it, this game is pretty bad on average. It really lacks any grounding characters. The antagonists are kinda fun in a camp horror kind of way, but they all overstay their welcome a bit just due to the nature of this being a video game and not a b-horror movie. The entire last half of the game is truly awful as well, in all respects besides visual. It dives deep into being utterly nonsensical in a really frustrating way. 

To sum up my feelings, the best sequence in the game is a stripped-back encounter with a scary monster in a small haunted house. The worst sequence in the game sees you climb into a mech suit, then chainsaw a boss to death with your mold-powers. This is NOT a game that knows what it's going for, and it makes me really worried about RE IX, whenever that comes out.

I wish I could give this a neutral review. The game looks and sounds great, and it's not [i]unfun[/i]. But it's just not very good. Puzzles are pretty much non-existent now, and the game is extremely linear. There is almost no exploration or wandering around. The combat is piss-baby easy and boils down to "pump the enemy full of lead as fast as possible" with very few exceptions. Apart from the [spoiler]fetus encounter[/spoiler] and a few darker sections in Heisenberg's factory, Village is entirely absent of spooks. 

The plot and characters are handled abysmally as well. I expect dumb, cheesy stories and characters from RE. This is just incomprehensible. Ethan is one of the worst video game protagonists I've seen in a long time. Chris Redfield's reboot is stupid. The much-hyped Lady Dimitrescue is a far inferior version of Mr. X and is only around for the first quarter of the game, if that. There was no reason for [spoiler]Ethan to not take Heisenberg's deal, or for his daughter to be split into four different parts, or for Chris to not tell Ethan what was going on.[/spoiler] The entire concept of the mold is utterly stupid, as is the retconning of RE lore to fit with the schizo plot of this game. I'm glad this is apparently the last we'll see of [spoiler]Ethan Winters[/spoiler] and one can only hope the next first-person installment has entirely new characters.

Buy it on sale if you like FPS games with a hint of survival horror. It's an ok game. It's not a good RE game.

Only played for five hours so far but have enjoyed every minute of it. Its like Bloodbourne had a baby with Resident Evil 4.

It has a great Gothic art style, there is lots of back tracking and unlocking new paths that eventually lead to short cuts back to areas you need to return to. ammo and items in general are scarce and enemies are few but challenging. There are puzzles to solve (not particularly challenging but challenging enough for me) and key items to collect as you would expect from a resident Evil game. 

The characters are great and the voice acting is top notch.

Graphics are also fantastic here, i have a low end PC (Ryzen 5 2600x, AMD R580) so on something more powerful im sure this looks even better. The character design looks great and the faces especially can look quiet real at times. 

There is also a VR mod which is amazing although my PC does stutter at times when i try this mod probably as its just not powerful enough.

Overall i can see why this game has overwhelmingly positive reviews. I grabbed this in a sale for a bargin price and i highly recommend it even if you are not a huge Resident Evil or survival horror fan in general (like me) i think you will enjoy it.

Nice addition to the resident evil franchise even if it strays a lot from the previous games.
The action is good and there are some horror moments, but there are are few of them.
On the graphical side, the engine and the art direction do a superb job, the game looks very good and runs well too.

The only big problem is that the game is way too simple, enigmas do not impose a real challenge, every solution is way too simple or too close to the player to get you in real trouble, there's no challenge at all on standard difficulty.
The challenge and game time are also virtually inflated by the fact that you can't unlock all upgrades for your weapons, it imposes the player to replay the game several times. I would have prefered a complete adventure on one playthrough with better balancing.

The DLC is cool, clearly on the horror side. But the character and the justification for her presence seem hard to believe.

Rating: 9.6/10 (It's scary good, but not without a few creaky doors)
Resident Evil Village takes the beloved survival horror series to new heights, delivering a spine-tingling adventure that will have you clutching your controller for dear life... and occasionally snorting with laughter. With its mix of creepy ambiance, pulse-pounding action, and a story that's a little more out there than usual, this game is a wild ride that deserves its almost-perfect score of 9.6 out of 10.
Prepare to be immersed in a world of gothic horror and supernatural weirdness. From the moment you step into the village, you'll be greeted by towering castles, mist-filled forests, and a bunch of weirdly friendly locals. The stunning graphics bring every grotesque creature and hauntingly beautiful environment to life in vivid detail. It's like a haunted house comes to life with slightly better Wi-Fi.
The storyline of Resident Evil Village is a deliciously campy mix of Gothic literature, folklore, and B-movie horror. You'll encounter mysterious witches, hulking werewolves, and a certain tall lady who's captured the internet's attention for reasons we won't discuss here. It's a narrative that balances between genuinely creepy and downright hilarious, keeping you engaged while occasionally making you question the sanity of the developers.
The gameplay in Resident Evil Village is a heart-pounding rollercoaster of fear and action. The gunplay feels satisfyingly punchy, and the enemies are delightfully grotesque. Whether you're running for your life from a pack of werewolves or engaging in a tense boss battle, the adrenaline rush is real. And let's not forget inventory management, where organizing your herbs and shotgun shells becomes a strategic puzzle worthy of a Ph.D. in Tetris.
Speaking of puzzles, Resident Evil Village offers a mix of brain-teasing challenges that range from clever to "seriously, who designed this?" Some puzzles are brilliantly designed, requiring you to think outside the box and uncover hidden secrets. Others might leave you scratching your head, desperately trying to find the one obscure item you missed while accidentally throwing explosive barrels at yourself. But hey, it's all part of the fun!
Now, let's talk about the real star of the show: the larger-than-life characters. From the gruff but lovable protagonist Ethan Winters to the delightfully eccentric Duke, the cast of Resident Evil Village oozes personality. And, of course, we can't forget Lady Dimitrescu, the towering vampire queen who has become an internet sensation. She's tall, she's elegant, and she's the reason everyone's upgrading their monitors. Kudos to the developers for creating a character that has taken the world by storm.
While Resident Evil Village is a masterclass in horror and hilarity, it's not without its quirks. Some of the voice actings can be a little... let's just say "charmingly wooden." And there are a few moments where the game takes itself a bit too seriously, causing unintentional bursts of laughter. But hey, it's all part of the charm and adds to the game's unique flavor.
In summary, Resident Evil Village is a spooky, silly, and thoroughly entertaining experience that deserves high praise. It's a game that will make you jump, laugh, and possibly question your sanity. With its hauntingly beautiful visuals, engaging gameplay, and memorable characters, it's a must-play for horror aficionados and fans of the series. Just be prepared to embrace the scares and enjoy the hilariously eerie ride. With a rating of 9.6

I played finished the story in just below 100 hours and i enjoyed every second.

I'm bored so fuck it, we roll. Time to write a review. 

Overall, the game is an amazing experience, especially on your first play through. It's a game where you can easily immerse yourself in with the main character, the first person is a nice benefit. However, this doesn't mean the game has no flaws so let's get the negative parts out of the way: 

[spoiler] The game has problems in terms of enemy scaling. On Village Of Shadows (The games hardest difficulties) I got softlocked at one point due to a lack of ammo. This caused to have to restart my entire game. To ensure it wasn't a verified "skill issue" I used a side mod to reveal enemy healthbars. After using every part of ammo in the arena, and buying as much as I could from Duke the boss was nowhere near dead. [/spoiler]

The game is too lenient on Action instead of Horror

The boss fights feel lacking at times. There was only one boss on [spoiler] Village Of Shadows [/spoiler] where I actually felt accomplished upon defeating them. I'm not sure if this is because I personally found the boss too easy, got extremely lucky with critical hits or just am an outright boring bitch lol.

In my lovely opinion, the [spoiler] Factory [/spoiler] part of the game felt rushed, almost like a filler to make up for something greater that was cut? [spoiler] Why didn't we get the option to team up with Karl Heisenberg? What happened to Ada Wong, as there were concept models for her to appear during the game. Why are they still insistent on hiding Ethan's Face, even though Capcom knows full-well we know what our monotone protagonist looks like. [/spoiler] 

And my biggest pet peeve, call me "horny" or whatever, but [spoiler] they killed off Lady Dimitrescu way, way too early. Angie + Donna should have been first, then you get a scene with Dommy Mommy. Then you kill Moreau, then finally the castle segment begins. Also, the castle was too short. For a massive fuck off castle you'd expect... more. I know the castle like the back of my hand, for something that grande I shouldn't be able to memorise a layout so easily. There also should have been traps. [/spoiler]

Ranting aside, let's talk about the games many perks: 

It's a fun playthrough. That's what's most important, right? 

You never feel too confused on where to go, and (for the most part) all enemies and bosses are balanced according to your difficulty. 

The Duke and his many wares are a great, welcome addition that adds to both the replayability, gameplay and even depth of the game. Love ya' my big boy. 

There's a 9'6 woman with booba. 

There's a fine variety in enemies and even weapons. Even certain enemies have evolved forms of themselves [spoiler] Such as Armoured Lycans [/spoiler] 

The story is immersive and easy to understand. [spoiler] Angry Dad looks for his daughter in a village full of bad people, finds Mother Miranda who is doing some Voo-Doo Shit with his daughter to revive her dead daughter. Chris "boulder-punch" Redfield finds Ethan Winter's presumably "dead" wife in a cell and you find out Mother Miranda was Oswald E. Spencer's mentor, some real neat shit. [/spoiler]

The game rewards you for exploration in many ways such as [spoiler] Collectables, Treasure and even a few "secret" boss fights for Steam Achievements and more treasure. [/spoiler] 

I give the game a 7 / 10 overall. Nothing is perfect and admittedly the game does have room for perfection but that doesn't make it a bad game. I recommend this game to anyone.
