[h1]Ethan Winters, Welcome[/h1]

[u][b]Initial Impression:[/b][/u] After playing RE7 as my first resident evil game, I was hyped to play this one. Most of the time I am always dissapointed with sequels but not with this one. It takes the story to a whole new level. This time instead of playing in a house, you are exposed to outer world, which is a fresh take. All the characters are awesome and memorable with amazing boss fight. At the end, it connects all the dots to RE7 which is a huge plus point for me. The story is amazing and graphics are demanding (Played in 1080P Ultra settings consumed 7.2GB of VRAM :) but still the environment is damn gorgeous.
https://youtu.be/NfPiB_1ktGo
[u][b]Gameplay:[/b][/u] A lot less scarier than RE7, which I think is a good thing as most of the players will feel comfortable to play. It has some puzzles similar to RE7 and it was pretty easy to solve. I played in standard difficulty and died only 3times, so it is easily playable. Now I am replaying  with Hardcore difficulty. All the levels were neatly designed and the one thing which impressed me is that all boss fights were unique. Those of you who are new to resident evil games, I would prefer you to play RE7: Biohazard first as the storyline is connected. 

[u][b]Final Verdict:[/b][/u] It has a replayable value. Definitely a 9/10 for me. Would strongly recommend it. Added the DLCs to the wishlist, hope it turns out good as the RE7 DLCs :) Good job Capcom !!!

RE Village doesn't fully live up to the expectations I had, but nevertheless, one of the best of its genre!

This is a sequel to RE7 as you once again play with Ethan, who's now settled in Europe in an attempt to start a new life with Mia and their new-born.

RE8 must be praised by its beautiful graphics and environments, but this is a PC port. Although well-optimized, some functions don't seem to work quite well on PC. When navigating in the menu, e.g., you must right-click the mouse in order to go back, instead of the usual ESC, which makes it a bit clumsy to navigate. Some graphical settings such as Anti-Aliasing seems inexistent. I'd recommend watching the Digital Foundry review for more info on that.

Once again, enemies are bullet-sponge. Headshots are not as effective and enemies also tend to dodge your bullets. Despite all that, they are not quite challenging (in the normal difficulty, at least). I haven't died once while in combat. I get way too many resources in this compared to RE2 remake. My ideal Resident Evil scenario would be having more enemies and taking more damage when hit while having fewer resources, but also getting rid of these bullshit headshots that aren't nearly instant kill and enemies miraculously embodying Neo from Matrix.
Village of Shadows Hurt, But I would recommend this game without a doubt

I'll say that RE8 is perhaps (one of) the best in the series. The RE2 Remake is the only really comparable one. RE3 Remake was good, but butchered and short, RE4 Remake was great as well, and RE7 was good, but extremely short. (we can skip the remaining ones, because they're either not all that great or very hard to play (RE1 Remake, although that was kinda enjoyable as well, if not for the fucking doors!) today).

The 1st person camera does wonders here and the graphics are superb, while the game just ... works and runs without glitches, bugs or graphical issues at a solid frame rate.

Gameplay wise it's probably the most varied entry in the series as well, with 4 very different areas (and bosses), as well as a sort of "hub" you'll be returning to multiple times, but every time it's changed and you have more possibilities (hopefully).
Shooting is fine and the guns finally sound more like guns, instead of pea shooters like in RE7.
Puzzles aren't too difficult, but there's lots to explore and upgrade. All in all just solid. Just too bad, that there are once again no iron sights, but oh well.
And, again, unlike RE7 this game actually has some varied enemies!

Then there's the story ... and imho I think it's pretty good. A father is on a quest to save his daughter and has to fight evil forces! It fits the fairy tale intro (literally an animated children's horror story Mia reads to Rose) perfectly.
On this quest he meets a mysterious ally and an old acquaintance and, of course, all is not as it seems.
My only real gripe with the story is that it involves Mia. And I hate Mia with a passion. I let her die in RE7, but of course that's not the canon ending. I just can't fathom why Ethan would risk so much for an ego-centric bio-terrorist of all people. Or why the new Umbrella (not to be confused with Neo-Umbrella, I guess -.-) or the BSAA don't put her behind bars. Maybe I missed something, but as far as I'm aware she's the sole reason the whole debacle with Eveline and the Mutamycete even began, although it feels like they retconned a lot with the latter anyway ... or purposefully mislead people/didn't explain stuff.
Anyway, the Muta is back, baby... 
Ethan on the other hand is just a soft noodle and a blank slate, but I can forgive him for that. I can't forgive Mia though. That character should have died in RE7. Rose could have been already born by that time, held in an Umbrella lab, for instance. Or they could have "created" her with their genetic material later on. Fits the character better anyway imho, but we'll get to HER in the DLC review (Spoiler: It's not going to be positive).

If you want like 13 hours of fun horror gameplay (seriously, that 2nd level!) in a gorgeous game with solid mechanics, go get it. Beware though: Without having played RE7 you're missing big parts of the experience, even though there is a "Baker Files" recap video.
It's just freaking awesome!

Resident Evil Village is an incredibly fun game, with somewhat of a retarded story, most noticeably in the second half. The villains are quite fun, even when ignoring all the memes although I have to admit that Lady Dimitrescu has awakened things inside me I really don't want to talk about, and the environments can really look quite gorgeous, and the signature Resident Evil gameplay is here, with lots of items and secrets and puzzles strewn around the well-built levels and environment. That is all awesome. But for someone whose favourite Resident Evil game is unequivocally Resident Evil 7, Village is a step backwards in many aspects. Ethan was in 7 too, but he wasn't too bad as a protagonist, and even though he isn't as bad as some would make him out to be, he can still be unbelievably obnoxious at times, especially after everything he's already been through at this point. The story is nowhere near as tight and compelling either, and especially in the second half, all the cracks really start to show, quickly descending into the almost nonsensical. Another thing that was sadly sacrificed for a more expansive setting is the atmosphere, which was masterfully textured and layered in 7, every nook and cranny of the bayou oppressive and foreboding, fear lurking around every corner, which sadly resulted, at least for me, in Village feeling and playing like more of an action game rather than the unbelievably tense survival-horror experience that made Resident Evil 7 so Goddam incredible. Where 7 was about tension, and fear and atmosphere, Village opts for spectacle and throwing enemies at you. Mostly. The doll house chapter was superb, horrifying and tense and hitting all the right spots of paranoia, by far the best chapter in the game for me personally, and it just kinda soured the rest of the experience a bit, realising how different the whole experience could have looked. Now this sounds like I'm just crapping all over the game, but the truth is I actually had a lotta fun playing it, and I realise most people really loved it, and everything it sets out to accomplish it does accomplish more or less, this is more about personal taste rather than actual faults. I recommend Resident Evil Village, even if I vastly prefer 7, and I really hope Capcom goes back to the survival-horror experience I loved so much, in the next game.

Incredible survival horror game, which is a sequel to Resident Evil 7 and the winter story.

The gameplay as well as the loot system and the dealer are quite innovative and very entertaining and really make you want to loot all the zones. The card, which gives a price as to whether the room has been completely looted or not, is particularly helpful.

The story and the artistic direction are excellent. The game itself is very innovative and provides a real renewal. Although the game is easier than its predecessor, the exploration, zone unlocking, and puzzle systems are excellent. The DLCs are also successful and fun. The bonus shop with the expansions and benefits that can be unlocked and purchased through successes has also been implemented well.

In summary, it's one of the best Resident Evil games for me, especially in terms of gameplay. So I recommend it to anyone looking for an excellent survival horror with enough modernity and around 15-20 hours of gameplay.

A cross between horror and first person shooter, it excels at neither. Found myself enjoying much more the horror parts, well thought out in terms of atmosphere and rhythm. for the FPS aspect, character speed is so sluggish it's frustrating, and since there are only four weapon shortcuts, you quickly find yourself pausing a fight to go rifling through (pun intended) your inventory for the next weapon. 

Story is very linear, which is fine, but could have been done better. If you're often googling questions about the game, there's a problem. For instance, you find ingredients (rare items) for food, the game says "take this to the merchant". Once there the only option is to sell the ingredients; later in the game a cooking option is unlocked, but what you sold is lost...

What saves this game is the story, which is not compelling but good enough to keep you engaged till the end.

One of the best entries in the Resident Evil franchise. I would say it's a really good survival horror game, just generally, but I have to admit that — just like the many Resident Evil games before it — it begins to have some pacing issues, especially near the end. Things become less survival horror-ey and more action adventure-ey. That said, I feel like this game handles the pacing switch-up really well. While I definitely prefer the survival horror elements of the Resident Evil games, I was at least still worrying about my resources up until the very end (except in one particular section where you have infinite ammo).

But by far my favorite segment of this game is the beginning up until the last quarter of the game or so. That's whenever the survival horror element of the game is at its best. Classic puzzles, tense combat encounters, etc.. But this game isn't my ideal survival horror game. Unlike a game like Resident Evil 2, there isn't much emphasis on deciding what enemies to take out or leave. Even on the harder difficulties, you're pretty much expected to be able to kill everything you see. I would prefer a system where leaving enemies behind often makes sense and where killing an enemy is more of a strategic decision.

That said, this game was still a blast to play and is a favorite of mine in the genre! I even plan on getting 100% achievements!

Title: Resident Evil Village: A Hauntingly Captivating Horror Experience

Rating: ★★★★☆

Resident Evil Village continues the iconic survival horror franchise with a chilling and atmospheric journey that is sure to keep fans on the edge of their seats. Developed by Capcom, this eighth installment in the series offers a captivating blend of intense combat, exploration, and a captivating narrative, making it a worthy addition to the Resident Evil universe.

The game's setting is a standout feature, as players find themselves in a mysterious and foreboding village that exudes a sense of unease and dread. The environments are beautifully rendered, from the decrepit old houses to the dark and haunting forests, with attention to detail that adds to the immersion. The game's atmospheric soundtrack further heightens the tension, perfectly complementing the eerie ambiance and jump scares.

Resident Evil Village brings back beloved protagonist Ethan Winters, as players navigate through a twisted narrative filled with supernatural elements, memorable characters, and mind-bending puzzles. The story successfully keeps players engaged, unveiling secrets and twists that will leave them guessing until the very end. While the plot may feel convoluted at times, it is a rollercoaster ride that fans of the series will appreciate.

Resident Evil VILLAGE follows Ethan Winter's story as he searches for his missing daughter. Having just left the events of Louisiana behind, his past comes back to haunt him once again. Once again, we experience the events unfold through The World's Best Father's eyes. if Resident Evil's 7 inspiration was the Original Resident Evil with its looping level design and focus on gore and horror then Resident Evil VILLAGE's inspiration was RE4. Throughout my playthrough I felt a sense of familiarity from its level design and gameplay, which was very welcome. It combines some of the best aspects of past games to create an overall great package: Persuers from past RE games, gameplay and level design from RE4 and a really nice story. If you've played RE7 (which I recommend you do if you haven't) you know what to expect. Memorable characters will haunt, torture and mock you as you traverse each of their twisted dungeons. I recommend turning aiming reticles off for a much more immersive experience. Family plays a very important role in the story and seeing Ethan overcome daunting obstacles in the name of love really moved me. I'm still in awe at how much I cared about Ethan, Rose and Mia.  Speaking of Rose, she gets her own DLC story which further strengthens the family bond. At first, she comes off as a bratty teenager going through an emo phase but by the end of it, I came to really like her and felt nothing but compassion towards her. This is one of the most heartfelt pieces of DLC I have ever played, When Rose reads a letter she finds, I started crying because of how sweet and heartwarming was. I'm happy and excited for the future of Resident Evil, hopefully we get to see Rose develop further as she deals with life and discovers who she's meant to be. 
NOTE: Please do note that you'll need the DLC in order to play in third person mode and access Rose's Story.  I'd advise waiting for a price drop to get both in the Gold edition. This goes for Mercenaries mode as well. Personally, even though the game was conceived with a FPS camera in mind, it plays and feels much better in Third Person mode. Not just that but it feels much more cohesive with the rest of the series and sidesteps headaches due to low (and unchangeable) FOV.

In the hallowed annals of the gaming pantheon, there emerges a beguiling opus known as Resident Evil Village, an ambitious endeavor that, alas, stands as a valiant attempt to recapture the transcendence that was Resident Evil 4. Verily, it must be said that this endeavor hath not achieved the zenith of its predecessor's brilliance. However, in the realm of relative comparisons, it doth soar above the lamentable shortcomings of Resident Evil 7, thereby illuminating a glimmer of promise within its sprawling tapestry.

Within the vast expanse of this intricate creation, one finds oneself inexorably drawn into its dark embrace, ensnared by the intermingling threads of nostalgia and novelty. Its visual opulence, meticulously crafted and rendered with an attention to detail that borders on the ethereal, stands as a testament to the wondrous potential of contemporary graphical prowess. From the foreboding shadows that dance upon ancient corridors to the sinewy textures that breathe life into the uncanny inhabitants of this macabre realm, every pixel reverberates with a sense of foreboding and visual splendor.

Yet, it is not merely in its visual majesty that Village finds its potency, for the audial symphony that accompanies this harrowing journey is an orchestral marvel in its own right. The soundscape, a delicate fusion of haunting melodies, spine-chilling ambience, and bone-chilling sound effects, ensnares the senses in a vice-like grip, heightening the atmosphere of dread and trepidation. It is in this synergy of sight and sound that the true horror of this realm manifests, leaving an indelible imprint upon the very fabric of one's psyche.

Among the rogues and miscreants that populate this twisted landscape, a particular figure emerges with an air of resplendent magnetism. Heisenberg, a villain of enigmatic allure, exudes an aura of cool detachment that captivates the discerning eye. Clad in a sartorial elegance that befits his status, he commands attention and leaves an indelible impression upon the annals of gaming antagonists. His enigmatic presence, coupled with his formidable abilities, stands as a testament to the imaginative prowess of the game's designers.

As one delves deeper into the intricate web of Resident Evil Village, it becomes evident that the echoes of Resident Evil 4 reverberate throughout its corridors, seeking to rekindle the fire of adulation that once burned so brightly. Alas, despite its earnest endeavors, it falls short of replicating the transcendence of its forebear. The magic that made Resident Evil 4 a timeless masterpiece remains elusive, casting a shadow upon this valiant attempt to capture lightning in a bottle once more.

Nevertheless, it would be remiss to dismiss Resident Evil Village entirely, for within its flawed tapestry lie moments of undeniable enjoyment. The ebb and flow of gameplay, the heart-pounding encounters with grotesque abominations, and the spine-tingling exploration of its treacherous environs coalesce to form a compelling experience. It is in these fleeting instances of triumph and discovery that the game shines, pulling the player deeper into its haunting embrace.

In conclusion, while Resident Evil Village may fall short of the lofty standards set by its illustrious predecessor, it does possess a measure of merit that outshines the lamentable missteps of its immediate predecessor. As one traverses its winding corridors and grapples with its harrowing challenges, the visual splendor, haunting audial tapestry, and the charismatic allure of certain individuals within its nightmarish domain create a captivating experience that deserves recognition. Embrace its flaws with tempered expectations, and thou shalt find a journey worth undertaking within the tenebrous heart of RE: Village.

Hello friends! Firstly, this long-awaited game combines horror and action in a magnificent way, offering gamers an unforgettable experience.

Starting with the graphics, Resident Evil 8: Village presents a visually captivating world. The game's realistic atmosphere, detailed character models, and environmental effects provide an immersive experience that completely engulfs you. The dark and eerie atmosphere of the village further emphasizes the game's horror elements.

In terms of gameplay mechanics, while staying true to the previous games in the Resident Evil series, Resident Evil 8: Village also introduces innovative elements. The series' characteristic features such as weapon inventory management, puzzles, and exploration are present in Village as well. However, the game offers a more fluid gameplay experience, striking a successful balance in terms of pacing. The combat mechanics are highly satisfying, and the enemy designs are truly chilling. The boss battles also provide an exciting and challenging experience.

The story connects intriguingly to the Resident Evil universe and immerses you in a thrilling adventure. Playing as Ethan Winters, who arrives at the village, players encounter a mysterious family and various creatures. As the story progresses, you uncover the deep secrets of the village and face events that heighten the suspense. The voice acting and performances of the main characters are also remarkably well-done.

Another significant aspect of Resident Evil 8: Village is its replayability. The game is packed with various difficulty levels and additional content. Additionally, by exploring different sections of the game, you can delve deeper into the story details. This provides players with a long-lasting experience.

In conclusion, Resident Evil 8: Village is a fantastic game that will satisfy horror and action enthusiasts. It is visually captivating, features smooth gameplay mechanics, and offers a compelling story. Capcom has successfully brought a fresh breath to the series with this new Resident Evil game. If you have an interest in horror games, Resident Evil 8: Village is definitely a must-play.

Well, where to start.
I had never played the original Resident Evil games until the remakes 1, 2, and 3. I even found it interesting but the twists and turns and lack of contact with other characters is weak. 
After two rounds of The Evil Within and The Evil Within 2, I decided to take a chance on this VILLAGE and man, what a game. At 45 years old, there is little horror that scares me anymore but when you put in giant mutant babies that scream and go after you to eat you, you either call your mom or your wife.
I admit I skipped Biohazard and am already regretting it.
The graphics are good, 7/10, the story is interesting and quite catching despite having some flops 7/10, the sound effects are brutal and really well placed 9/10. But what impresses most is the nature and construction of the characters 10/10.
Well... move back to VII.

As with RE7, I enjoy the new mechanics and pieces of the new story but am regularly annoyed by the forced tie-back to the original universe. For those looking to continue deeper into the RE lore, this game will disappoint you. For those looking for a fun, unique, horror, action game, RE8 is great.

The pace continues the theme since RE4, where you begin in a seemingly unwinnable situation but then a cut-scene takes over and the game truly starts. From there it's a good mix of fighting, exploration, running, puzzles, etc. My only gripe is that, especially early on, the mini-boss battles come out of nowhere. Yes, that is a part of the dread, and is realistic, but also creates a trial-and-error feeling that is less immersive and more annoying. The weapons, custom parts, crafting, and meals add a nice layer while remaining simple, unlike many modern action games. 

All-in-all, I really enjoyed the game as a game. But to the writers - Resident Evil has been around for 30 years and had 6 main installments with a dozen side games. It's okay to tell a new story in the spirit of the game, without referring back to the original characters or plots. You won't upset any legacy fans and will gain many new ones. I groaned out loud when you learn that ****** ******* knew *******, that was painful and had little logic behind it.

This was another fantastic game (including the remakes), now spread your six wings and wow us with a compelling new story.

Amazing sequel. Love the character development of Ethan Winters: he moves faster, shoots better, definitely hardened from his experience from RE7. So yeah, great game. Easy recommend.

Playing this after the RE4 Remake was a mistake. Village is overall just a clearly inferior product.

Map is trash. Overworld has items but doesn't have completion indicators. Tons of missable paths that you can't return to just because you've chosen a wrong fork in the road and triggered a cutscene. Supremely unintuitive treasure placement - precious stones just stuck to random metal gantries with no map marker.

Encounter design is also bad. Mooks are fine, but boring because all they do is hiss and roar. Minibosses are hillariously bullet-spongy. Random tall dude with an axe has more HP than the story boss that is supposed to command him. Like, I can't overstate how ridiculous it feels to pump dozens of sniper shots into an enemy's head and then still need to use *multiple* explosives and shotgun blasts to bring it down. I can buy El Gigante needing that, but not just a tall humanoid. The fight with an enemy that creates a shitton of visual clutter on your screen, does a ton of damage and is invincible relies on you noticing a tiny lever which is obscured from the direction you enter the boss arena. Enemies have artificial traversal boundaries set, so you can abuse the AI by going one room too far away, then returning and shooting the enemy in the back, rinse repeat.

Hilariously, the input prompt during the final fight is bugged and shows the wrong mouse button.

Go play re4make instead. This game isn't worth it.

as a fan who started on this series 15 years ago & played through the entire franchise at this point, I want too say this game gives it justice too the series I knew it as. But I won't lie too my own view, this game cannot hold itself up too the standards of the originals. it shouldn't be a bad thing, but it doesn't even try getting close & that is bad. 

The story it wants too tell is confounding & inconsistent, the characters, that I do have some hope for, don't cut it, the hype was over the top (as usual it seems these days) & the idea of the RE engine for its graphic fidelity is in question too me (I played Resident Evil HD Remastered and it still looks more beautiful then anything i've seen in the past 5 years since the RE engine was first announced). 

I cannot force anyone's hand, but take my word for it. I do NOT Recommend this too a first timer of the series. it its a false representation of what the series is & too disagree is blinded by the hype. as for hardcore fans.... Idk if waiting for a sale too just have it in the collection is even worth it.

Edit: fuck you Capcom, you took my $75 to give me a sub par game with shitty DX content & you couldn't be arsed to give us, the ones who bought this shit at full price + DX content, the DLC? Fucking degenerates don't deserve another penny for this game.

This game became my most favourite RE game after I played it!💖
The graphics are phenomenal and the plot for the game to be played in an open and beautifully designed world is awesome. The enemies are more unique and had their own abilities and difficulties than RE7 or some other RE games. Exploring the village and the other places in it is so enjoying and the unique twist of having 4 Powerful Lords, Mother Miranda as the main villain and the Megamycete. The twist of this game connecting all the RE games to it as because the virus and the mold originated in the village is also cool and the rest is for you to find out. First person perspective is also nice yet still has some issues with it. Weapons, combat and fights are also well made and worth it. The merchant or the Duke is also really helpful and has more options. The boss fights are also amzing yet despite having more boss fights than RE7, It's also strangely a bit easy to beat. The puzzles are also unique and vary in different special ways but can be straightforward and easy to hint though.
The scares and horrors also are both terrifying and awesome, with unexpected jumpscares, adrenaline, and the horrorific aura while exploring, never knowing what, when, where or how it will happen. The idea of making this a survival horror game is nice yet overly focused. The depth and informations behind all characters are well described and shown here, especially for Ethan, Lady Dimitrescu, Mither Miranda and some but some are still missing and left for the next game or for us to find. The Mercenaries mode and the other gameplay modes is also coola nd even having the models of each character, items and enemies in the game which you can buy is also a good concept. The songs and soundtracks used are awesome and memorable, hits a new medley and original in their own way. The story concept for the intro and credits is also uniqye and I swear I got Coraline Vibes from it. The cutscenes and acts are really pretty amazing and oh, all the items, treasures, weapons and crafted products are all still goodly unique. Although this game has issue with its action movements, camera and some bigs in the game, it's still an awesome and legendary game for us.💖💖
The voice actors also did a great job and the story, plot and overall are amazingly good and memorable. I love it and recommend to all other gamers there.
hope you'll all enjoy this game as much as we do.
Have a nice day!!!😇😇💖💖

Well, after finishing all achievements, i can say that The Mercenaries are way harder than the main game itself.

About the game, i have mixed feelings. On one side, it's a nice RE (although it lost -again- the horror factor that RE7 had brought), but i felt it TOO similar to RE4: first a village, then a castle, the acuatic monster, an industrial map, etc. The villains didn't felt too kind to RE (the "monsters" theme doesn't suit very well the universe) but at least their mutated forms were closer to what we already know. The story was a nice finish for what it started in RE7 (and a great explanation), and i'm thankful to have back the more classic Chris look. The game itself is really not that hard (the fact that you can finish it in 2 and a half hours with knife only is a big giveaway), but the Mercenaries was brutal. Taking count that it took me like 16/17 hours to finish the games 3 times, is well over my ability. I tried to get SSS in all of the maps (i know, is more that it is asked for in the achievements but i wanted the laser knife) but still failed on the last one. Probably will try to get it in the next couple of days, to see if i can finally finish it. 

EDIT: I just finished the DLC and even that it gave some more story to the Winters, it felt cheap and rushed. Only about two hours, i would have expected to be just a "side story" that would have been included in the main game (Like Separate Ways or Assigment Ada in the original RE4). The story goes way beyond the usual RE thing, even more than the main game, so thats not good. The new Mercenaries map are ok and the new characters and mechanics on it makes The Mercenaries a bit easier. The new achievements are nothing out of ordinary, you can get them in one go if you play the DLC on Hardcore. A bit dissapointed with the DLC. P.D: House Benaviento still the creepiest "part" of each story.
P.D:  Still don't know why Capcom keeps insisting in not showing Ethan's face. In the DLC felt ridiculous that in almost all shots his face is covered or seen from an angle/distance.

Still, recommended to play and be in tune with the story. A 6.5 out of 10 (i took half a point because of the poor DLC)

Ah Resident Evil, licence culte du genre  Survival Horror. 
Me concernant, j'ai commencé la licence au 5  J'avais adoré Resident Evil 5 à l'époque sur Xbox 360, même si le Gameplay était particulier, et même ici l'ayant refais sur PC avec les DLC's, je continue à adorer ce jeu, et je vais le dire, c'est celui que je préfère de la Licence. 

Avant de vous parlez de ce Resident Evil Village, je me dois de vous donnez mon ressenti sur les différents Resident Evil auxquels j'ai pu jouer:

J'ai découvert Resident Evil 4 il y a quelques mois seulement sur PC, et personnellement, je ne comprends absolument pas son succès et pourquoi tout le monde considère que c'est UN des meilleurs de la Licence, les gens ont critiqué violemment RE5 car trop d'action et le côté Survival Horror a été délaissé, alors qu'entre nous, RE4 c'est la même chose mais à mon sens en pire. J'ai passé un mauvais moment sur le 4 car principalement je trouve les environnements franchement pas dingue (notamment la dernière partie sur l'Île qui est infâme), les Boss sont pas dingues non plus (excepté U-3 et le Verdugo que j'ai beaucoup aimé), les musiques sont pas marquantes quand tu les compares au 5... Bref, je n'aime pas le 4 et c'est UN des pires auquel j'ai pu jouer.

J'ai pu me faire récemment Resident Evil 6, et on ne va pas se mentir, c'est pas un Resident Evil, c'est un jeu d'action TPS, y a réellement la Campagne de Léon qui représente Resident Evil avec une ambiance angoissante et horreur, la Campagne de Chris est catastrophique (c'est Call of Duty), la Campagne de Sherry j'ai personnellement bien aimé (sauf le passage dans la Neige qu'est pas ouf) et la Campagne d'Ada je l'ai trouvé très moyenne. Bref, c'est un très mauvais RE mais un jeu d'action sympathique.

Concernant Resident Evil 2 Remake (je n'ai pas fais l'original), j'ai énormément apprécié le jeu, le seul défaut qui m'a franchement dérangé, c'est le backtracking (notamment t'as plus de place dans ton inventaire, donc il faut que tu retournes dans la pièce de Sauvegarde pour déposer ton stuff dans le Coffre), pour ma part, c'est un très bon Resident Evil. 

Pour Resident Evil 3 Remake, j'ai personnellement apprécié la partie de Jill mais j'ai détesté jouer en tant que Carlos (car une fois de plus, c'est du Call of Duty), et le Nemesis et ses 3 ou 4 affrontements sont bidons (sauf le 1er que j'ai plutôt apprécié), en conclusion, je n'ai pas aimé RE3 Remake (même si ce n'est pas une merde, mais c'est très très moyen).

Voilà, nous allons pouvoir passer à Resident Evil Village, je n'ai personnellement pas joué au 7.

Je vais commencé par les Qualités du jeu puis j'enchaînerai sur les Défauts du jeu:

Qualités:

Le Lore, c'est personnellement UNE des choses que j'ai le plus aimé dans le jeu , l'Univers à la Castlevania, le bestiaire (Lycans, "Vampires", Gargouilles... y compris la majorité des Boss à l'exception de Moreau), les Environnements proposés (le Village, le Château Dimitrescu, Maison Beneviento...)

- Son Ambiance, c'est lié aussi au Lore mais j'ai trouvé l'ambiance franchement génial, mention spéciale au Meilleur moment que j'ai pu vivre dans un Resident Evil tous jeux confondus de la Licence (passage Beneviento), ce passage est exceptionnel, ça respire du Resident Evil à l'état pur.

- L'Histoire, j'ai trouvé le Scénario plutôt intéressant, alors certes c'est tarabiscoté par moment (notamment sur la fin), mais je l'ai trouvé intéressant et plaisant à suivre.

- Les Graphismes + La Direction Artistique, le moteur RE Engine est magnifique (mais c'est pas étonnant, on a déjà pu voir ce moteur sur le 7 ou sur RE2 et RE3 Remake), les Textures sont très jolies et mention spéciale aux effets.

- L'Optimisation, elle est bonne, j'ai quelques chutes d'FPS de quelques millisecondes à certains moments bien précis mais c'est pas dérangeant, en revanche, le jeu consomme beaucoup de VRAM (j'en ai 12 et j'ai pas pu mettre au Max les Textures, le reste des Options Graphiques aucun souci).

- "L'Exploration", j'ai adoré me perdre dans ce Village ou dans les autres environnements afin de récupérer tous les Trésors ou à affronter les Boss Optionnels.

- La Bande Son, elle fait le taf, les doublages sont bons (notamment la VO mais la VF est bonne), les Musiques sont sympas mais beaucoup d'armes manque d'impact, c'est le petit reproche de cette bande son selon moi.

- La Durée de Vie + La Rejouabilité, j'ai terminé le jeu une première fois en 10 heures environ (en Hardcore et ce qui est bien), trop ça aurait été chiant (j'y reviendrai dans les Défauts), concernant la Rejouabilité, cela va dépendre de vous, vous débloquerez le Mode Mercenaire et puis vous débloquez la Boutique Spéciale ainsi que les Défis (qui vous donnent des Points pour acheter des Figurines, des Arts Works mais surtout acheter la possibilité d'avoir munition infinie sur l'arme que vous voulez, cependant vous devrez améliorer au maximum l'arme que vous voulez ce qui est très chère). J'ai refais le jeu 4 fois au dernier niveau de difficulté soit Village of Shadows puis j'ai joué au Mode Mercenaire un peu, j'ai donc terminé mon "Aventure" en 37 Heures environ.


Je vais désormais passer aux Défauts:

- Le Gameplay, il n'est pas mauvais, il est plaisant mais j'entends par là que dans les phases ou ça dégueule d'action, le gameplay n'est pas adapté car tu te fais défoncer et c'est bordélique.
- L'Effet Sacs à PV, c'est ce qui m'a le plus gonflé dans le jeu, tous les ennemis sont beaucoup trop résistants (en Hardcore, comptez 8-10 balles en Headshot sur un simple Lycan (même lorsque votre Pistolet est amélioré, en Village of Shadows j'en parle pas, c'est terrible), c'est la même chose pour les Boss (qui ont tendance à traîner en longueur à l'exception de Beneviento et Heisenberg).

- Le Game Design (notamment le Passage de l'Usine d'Heisenberg, je trouve cet environnement mal pensé, je m'y suis perdu plusieurs fois tellement c'est mal fait).

- La Progression du Jeu, j'entends par là que le jeu m'a fait rager à plusieurs moments et ça chauffe le chaud et le froid: 
 le début est catastrophique (où vous devez survivre à l'assaut des Lycans), c'est catastrophique car ici c'est Call of Duty mais t'as pas de balle donc tu peux rien faire. Ensuite, le passage au Château Dimitrescu est relativement bien (l'exploration), mais les Combats contre les Filles Dimitrescu et Dimitrescu elle même sont pas fou).
Le passage avec Beneviento est exceptionnel, je n'ai rien à redire.
Le passage avec Moreau est pas dingue du tout, l'environnement est très dégueulasse et n'est pas intéressant, et le combat contre Moreau est beaucoup trop long et n'est pas très palpitant.
Le passage de la Forteresse est d'une nullité affligeante, là sans rire, vous affrontez une soixantaines d'ennemis, c'est très mauvais car le Gameplay n'est pas du tout adapté à de l'Action pure contre des dizaines d'ennemis).
Idem pour l'Usine d'Heisenberg, environnement pas intéressant et bordélique avec beaucoup trop d'action, l'exploration reste cool et le combat contre Sturm et Heisenberg je les ai bien aimé).
Le passage avec vous savez qui je l'ai bien aimé mais c'est également du Call of Duty avec du Gears of War, ça dégueule d'action.
Et la dernière partie où l'on affronte le Boss Final est sympathique.


Pour conclure, j'ai passé un bon moment sur le jeu, j'ai quand même presque 40 heures mais honnêtement, il n'y aurait pas eu les Défis et le Mode Mercenaire, j'accorderai au jeu un 13-14/20, ici grâce à la rejouabilité et j'ai pu plus apprécié le jeu, je lui accorde un 15/20. C'est un Resident Evil que je trouve sympathique mais loin d'être incroyable, si vous aimez la Licence, je vous le conseil mais en promo, pas au prix fort.

Game was good in parts, much more expansive than traditional RE games. Had some fun puzzles to solve, but frustratingly I couldn't get VR mode working, which would have been a much better playthrough. I picked it up on a 50% off sale, so it was worth it, but I wouldn't pay full price for it.

This is entry into the franchise has become my second favorite in the entire franchise. The Castle like setting fits the theme of this game so well. The village portion of the game also fits in just as well. The weapons you are able to use are very fun use, especially if you use the fully upgraded S.T.A.K.E. on the "Village of Shadows" Difficulty. The Mercenaries mode is alright for what it is. It's a total nightmare on the Hardcore versions of them if you're going for all the achievements like I did. The Shadows of Rose DLC is easily some of the best content a Resident Evil game has ever put out. The way the character is written and the vast abilities she can use is just down to the bone perfect. The ending of the DLC makes the ending of the main story hit even better than it originally did. If you love downloading mods to spice up the gameplay for all the repeated the runs, I would highly look into it as it made each playthrough feel different, but humorous. I would HIGHLY recommend buying this game.

Pretty much a masterpiece. I'm giving this a yes because I suppose I'm awed at how professionally dumb Resident Evil Village is. I guess Resident Evil was always kind of dumb and unsubtle -- but this game just probes the depths of dumb. 

Don't get me wrong, I like when media goes full ridiculous just to see if it works, but I feel as though Resident Evil 9 might not be able to top this level of dumb without becoming something only a 10-year-old could enjoy. 

It comes right out of the gate with a ridiculous cast of baddies, each dumb in their own way. Internet Meme Dumb, Creepy Dumb, Gross Dumb, and Fedora Dumb, and their respective sequences get increasingly dumber as the game continues. I was somewhat shocked when I had to fight the equivalent of the Truckasaurus and the game wasn't over. And yes, it continues to get dumber, though I won't spoil it other than to say "Michael Bay". 

I mean, I guess I'm glad there's something this boldly dumb. I think I mostly hate it but I appreciate that it's here for diversity. I only fear Resident Evil 9 might enter the realm of the Banal Dumb. I don't want to feel *nothing* when I play it. I hope it gets a little more self-aware and throws in some fart jokes. Maybe they could have the player traveling through a big monster's large intestine and joke about how it stinks in there. Or have characters break the fourth wall occasionally. I would write it if they asked me.

Resident Evil 8: A Dark Turn for the Franchise


Resident Evil 8, oh how the mighty have fallen. As a long-time fan of the Resident Evil series, I can't help but feel a deep sense of disappointment with the direction the franchise has taken. While Resident Evil 7 was a masterclass in survival horror, its successor, Resident Evil 8, is a shadow of its former glory.

One of the biggest letdowns in Resident Evil 8 is the departure from the grounded and immersive atmosphere that made Resident Evil 7 such a standout title. Gone are the claustrophobic corridors and tense moments of suspense. Instead, we're thrown into a hodgepodge of supernatural elements, including werewolves, vampires, and even mythical creatures. It feels like the game has lost its identity, trying desperately to be something it's not.

Another glaring issue is the lack of cohesive storytelling. While Resident Evil 7 had a captivating narrative that kept players engaged and invested, Resident Evil 8 feels like a convoluted mess. The plot jumps from one bizarre scenario to another without any clear direction or purpose. It's as if the developers threw a bunch of horror tropes into a blender and hoped for the best. The result is a disjointed and confusing experience that fails to resonate with fans.

One of the strengths of Resident Evil 7 was its tight and focused gameplay. The first-person perspective added to the sense of vulnerability, forcing players to carefully navigate their surroundings and conserve resources. In contrast, Resident Evil 8 introduces a misguided attempt at action-oriented gameplay, sacrificing the tension and strategy that made the series so iconic. It feels like a generic shooter with no real substance or depth.

Additionally, the characters in Resident Evil 8 lack the depth and development we saw in its predecessor. Ethan Winters, the protagonist from Resident Evil 7, was a relatable and sympathetic character whose journey we cared about. In Resident Evil 8, he becomes a bland and forgettable vessel for the player, devoid of any personality or growth. The supporting cast suffers from similar issues, with shallow motivations and uninspired dialogue.

Lastly, the visual design in Resident Evil 8 is a step back from the impressive graphics of Resident Evil 7. While the game still has its moments of atmospheric beauty, the overall art direction feels uninspired and lacks the attention to detail that made its predecessor visually stunning. The environments lack the same level of intricacy and immersion, leaving players feeling detached and unengaged.

In conclusion, Resident Evil 8 fails to live up to the legacy established by its predecessor. It abandons the core elements that made Resident Evil 7 a masterpiece, opting instead for a scattered and inconsistent experience. The game loses its identity, sacrificing immersion, storytelling, and gameplay depth in favor of generic action and a mishmash of supernatural themes. It's a disheartening departure that tarnishes the reputation of the beloved franchise. Fans of Resident Evil deserve better than this lackluster and misguided entry.

Esse jogo possui uma gameplay excelente e ótimos gráficos. A variação dos cenários é interessante, assim como inimigos e os Bosses.

Infelizmente nem tudo são flores. Se levar em conta que é um Resident Evil o jogo é uma catástrofe. 
- Áreas do jogo são como mundos diferentes. Cada Boss possui um "mundo" diferente de acordo com seus poderes. Isso quebra muito a imersão. Parece que a cada área estamos em um jogo diferente, ou seja, o jogo não tem alma. É um misturado de ideias.
- Os Boss possuem transformações sem noção. Novamente faz parecer um jogo de fantasia e não de terror.
- A ultima área, do Magneto, é terrivelmente chata. Pra piorar temos um dos Boss mais toscos da franquia. Aquilo é uma piada de mal gosto, superpoderes total!

1. Defrost your steak (in less than an hour)

I’m not a great planner, so there are plenty of nights I’m in the mood for steak but the only steaks in the house are in the freezer. Not a problem. I fill a bowl of water (not warm) and place it on the counter and put the frozen steak (in its package) in the water for an hour. Sometimes I’ll change the water halfway through - and 60 minutes later my steak (or ground beef, or chicken breast) is thawed. Tip: There can be small holes in the cryovac plastic wrap so inspect your meat package before placing it in the bowl of water. 

Never defrost your steak in the microwave or on the kitchen counter - for food safety reasons.

2. Don’t cook a cold steak
To ensure the steaks cook evenly, it’s important to let your steak come to room temperature before cooking it (if you have time). You don’t need to wait until the meat is exactly 72 degrees. And you certainly don’t need to take its internal temperature with a meat thermometer. I usually try to leave my steaks out for an hour or so before cooking.

3. Pat your steaks dry before cooking
Before placing your meat on the grill or in a pan, pat them dry using paper towels. This is particularly important if the meat is seeping a bit of blood. One method I use is to place a stack of paper towels under the steak and another stack on top. Press down gently and pat down the sides of the meat. 

Drying the meat with a paper towel just before cooking will ensure good contact between the steak and the pan. If it’s not dry it won’t get crispy on the outside.

4. Don’t over-season your steak
I’ll admit it right off - the only seasoning I use on my steaks is salt. Salting is a crucial part of the seasoning process. Salt releases moisture in the muscle of the meat and releases the natural flavors of steak. I season my steaks with kosher salt just as I put them in the pan - but some chefs suggest adding the salt right after you take the meat out of the refrigerator. I don’t think that matters a whole lot - but whatever you do, don’t wait to season until you’re serving.

Even top steakhouse chefs limit their seasoning to salt, black pepper and, perhaps, garlic. You want to let the wonderful flavor of the steak be the star.

5. Use the right cooking oil
I was doing this one wrong until very recently! I was using olive oil but it was always smoking. I discovered that’s because it has a low smoke point (300 degrees). The best oils for cooking steak are avocado oil, soybean oil, and canola oil - all of them have a high smoke point between 400 and 520 degrees. Another alternative is clarified butter - with a smoke point of 450 degrees. 

6. Use the right pan and make sure it is very hot
These days, many steakhouse chains  use infrared broilers with their steaks to ensure extremely high temperatures and even heat distribution. Unfortunately, most of us don't have the luxury of such kitchen gear at home. I recommend using cast iron skillets  because they hold heat, which ensures the right sear and caramelization. Since cast iron is a dense metal, it also ensures even heat distribution. This, in turn, translates to evenly cooked and browned steak. No matter what, insure your skillet is very hot, but not smoking.

7. Don’t worry about how often you flip your steak
You’ve probably heard that you shouldn’t flip your steak too often. I’ve read up on this and it seems top chefs say not to worry about it - and, in fact, flipping it often might improve the final result (because it will cook more evenly through the center).

8. Don’t overcook your steak
My daughter recently told me she was nervous about cooking some Ribeyes and I reassured her there was only one really bad thing she could do - she could overcook it.

It can be tricky - This is because how fast your steak cooks depends on the thickness of the cut and the temperature of the grill or skillet. Sure, you can cut into the steak to check whether it's ready but I don’t recommend doing that since it lets out the juices.

I use a meat thermometer - always. Available in either digital or analog versions, meat thermometers are inserted into the center of the meat to gauge its internal temperature. In the case of a medium-rare steak, this should be around 125-130 degrees Fahrenheit. However, because the steak will continue to cook on the plate, it should be removed from the source of heat when it's 5 degrees Fahrenheit lower than the desired temperature.

9. Let the steak rest before serving
When you prepare a steak on a scorching hot skillet or grill, you're forming a crust that locks in moisture. If you cut into your steak right after it's removed from heat, you risk losing all these wonderful juices. Thin steaks should rest between five and seven minutes, while thicker cuts of meat should sit out on the plate for at least 10 minutes. You can even use a meat thermometer to check if your steak is sufficiently rested. No matter how thin or thick the steak, ideally you want its center to cool down to 120 degrees Fahrenheit.

10. Cut against the grain and serve on a warm plate
How you present a steak can have a huge impact not just on its visual appeal but also on its flavor and texture. If you want to cut the meat prior to serving, always cut against the grain or perpendicular to the direction of the muscle fibers. Since muscle fibers can be on the tough side, slicing through them will make the beef more tender. Slicing along the muscle fibers, on the other hand, will have the opposite effect, making the steak chewier.

Another trick to elevating your home dining experience is by warming the plate prior to serving. This is because a warm plate helps to maintain an even temperature of the food while a cold one absorbs its heat, which could translate to a lukewarm steak. One of the best ways to warm your plates is by stacking them in the oven set at a low temperature or by placing them on the stovetop burner.

Enjoy!

This game is an incredible addition to the franchise and stands out as one of the best horror games I have ever played.

Firstly, the visuals are absolutely stunning. The graphics are incredibly detailed, and the environments are beautifully designed, from the eerie village to the Gothic castle. The sound design is equally impressive, with spine-chilling sound effects and a hauntingly atmospheric score that perfectly complements the horror experience.

The gameplay perfectly blends classic Resident Evil survival horror and new gameplay mechanics. The exploration and puzzle-solving elements are challenging and engaging, while the combat is fast-paced and intense. The variety of enemies is impressive, and each presents a unique challenge, keeping the gameplay fresh and exciting.

The story is well-written and captivating, with plenty of twists and turns to keep me engaged from start to finish. The characters are well-developed, and Lady Dimitrescu quickly became one of my favorite video game villains.

My only complaint is that the game is relatively short but still packed with content and offers a high replay value. Overall, Resident Evil Village is an outstanding horror game and a must-play for fans of the franchise and newcomers alike.

Resident Evil Village is the 8th installment in the franchise. The series has had dynamic shifts since its original releases, from camera angle to genre shifts. While Resident Evil 7 was an entirely new package with lots to explore and get scared for, its promising first act leaves the finale less than desirable. With this newest installment, I was excited as to how the game would play out. At first glance, there was immediately an emphasis on more open world and a particularly dashing vampire mother. The trailers built up major hype, and I was more than ready for the release. After playing, I'm sad to say a lot of the hyped aspects of the games such as the castle and horror fall flat. Almost pathetic puzzles ruin any sort of brain usage, and the ammo and health crafting is completely foreign in comparison to its horror SURVIVAL label as a game. That being said, it's hard to fault the story, considering this is Resident Evil, but my main complaint I still hold is how Chris was butchered. The writers forced things that left me confused and angry. In terms of strength, this game still has many. MOST of the bosses are cool and their fights enjoyable. A large weapon variety builds on that Resident Evil 4 feeling of being an action hero in a desolate battlefield. Enemies are engaging and mostly well designed. The horror aspect is there, especially in the factory. I genuinely felt fear for the first time in a long time from a game. Exploration, while limited, is rewarding and fun. The game runs vert smoothly with beautiful graphics. Witty banter is exchanged between the Duke and Ethan, which lightens rather dark moments. But that brings me to Ethan. As much as I ignored his dry attitude in the last game, I simply can't help being pulled out of the thrill by his empty remarks. He simply cannot shut his mouth during awesome parts of this game, immediately ending any immersion. Overall, I'd say new players will enjoy quite a bit, while returning players may feel it to be repetitive and nuanced. 8.5/10.

Ok horror game but lacking in many departments. It's very enjoyable in some parts but inconsistent and low quality at times. 

Not as good as its predecessor Biohazard 7 or the recent remakes Resident Evil 2, 3, and 4. 

My advice to you is to play Biohazard 7 first, since Resident Evil Village is the continuation of the story and has somewhat similar gameplay. If you like Biohazard 7, you will also like this sequel. 

Keep in mind that Village has more action and is less survival horror. The puzzles aren't challenging and you'll have plenty of ammunition. It's not as scary either. The boss fight are a bit bland and could be improved. 

Glad the story of Ethan Winters comes to an end in this opus as he is not the best protagonist in the series. Other characters from the franchise are much more charismatic and lovable. 

Overall, passable and disappointing and not the best Resident Evil game.

The RE franchise tries to do more horror in their games, and this is one of the entries that tries and almost fails that attempt. While doing so, almost ruins the gameplay loop to boredom and repetition but only almost.

This game is more horror and intense, but also not. My advice would be : ignore certain story points. The story is weakness and strength. On one hand it has intense moments that let you feel the horror and on the other you think the protagonist has severe brain damage and needs a doctor or a severe blow to the head. Another thing is certain NPC and the PC are "over acted" in their voice, and it feels cheap and/or annoying but other times and sounds amazing, and you can hear the emotions clearly.

Gameplay wise there are some good points: the look and the atmosphere, but sadly the shooting feels not good. The problem goes for the whole fighting system. As if the game was designed at the base without fighting and the fighting added later. It is clunky, slow, unresponsive. BUT at some points the fighting feels right (certain bosses). As if the game knew "Oh Lord, he/she will ALT+F4 any moment I need something to keep him/her on the game" and throws a good moment or boss at you. 

As you can see there is a pattern of "boring and/or annoying" and "cool, give me more" that repeats until the end of the game. For me it was enough to carry on.

TLDR or short verdict:
The Story is badly written, with sometimes good dialog and ideas surrounded by boring clutter. The optic and atmosphere is most of the time great. The performance is okay, but sometimes there are some FPS drops, but only for a moment (at least for me). 

So all in all a solid experience 6.5 out of 10.
(For reference, a good game begins at 8 and a bad is below 4, ergo everything between "above 4" and "below 8" is a solid experience with some drawback)

If you like easy horror with intense moments and can ignore a boring story and sometimes bad game loop? Go buy it. All other people wait for a sale.

I've played a few hours of RE7 and it's not necessarily a bad game, it's just not what I'd call a Resident Evil game and neither is this. RE to me is about observing your surroundings to collect things and figure out puzzles with limited ammo and a poorly written yet somehow still entertaining story. 

In 7 and 8, observing your surroundings doesn't matter much. There are areas where things are and the rest of the world doesn't have anything. There's WAY too little ammo and they basically turned the combat into a puzzle because of that. I loved RE1 which had rare ammo but even still, the game wasn't about killing, it was about the overall puzzle with killing sprinkled in. RE4 was about killing but it had enough ammo to make that fun. RE8 is about killing but lacks the ammo to make it fun.

Its review score says I'm clearly in the minority but I'm not a fan and I'm glad for refunds :)

The level design of this game is immaculate. You always know where to go next, while you are also encouraged to explore and find secrets. You never have to backtrack, unless there is something waiting for you along the way, and you revisit a lot of places for a sense of nostalgia throughout the game. There is a kind of hub area as well, that you come back to fairly frequently, and throughout the game you unlock new paths around the village so that exploring becomes easier. I'm a sucker for good level design and this game just does it perfectly.

Combat is really fun as well, especially because you can explode the heads of certain enemies, which is really satisfying. Enemies also react to where you shoot them, so you can develop your own strategies against different enemies, depending on how you want to play or if maybe, you're short on ammo.

The pacing of the game is great as well. Areas usually start off a bit slow and ramp up until a climax where you can have some peace of mind, before either continuing that sense of serenity to give you an opportunity to enjoy the environment or give you a hint that the worst is yet to come. Some areas show this type of curve through combat, where you kill a few smaller enemies, then some larger ones or greater numbers, leading into a bigger fight later. Other areas contain no combat, but play more into fear and panic to give the same sort of tension.

In terms of gameplay elements, there are only a few (seeing as it is an first person horror game, that shouldn't come as a surprise). You shoot enemies with your weapons, explore to find resources and valuables, which you can use to upgrade your weapons. For me, this type of gameplay loop is a big hit. It's simple and to the point, but every element of it has been mastered. Exploring is really fun, killing enemies is really fun, and getting upgrades makes you feel powerful, which, you guessed it, is really fun.

The story is a give or take. The very short version of the story is that your daughter is kidnapped and you have to go through five lords in order to get her back. Of course, there is much more to it, most of which you have to read in files that you find throughout the game. Either you like it or you don't, I won't say much more about it.

I can't exactly explain why, but the game has incredible replayability value. I've replayed the story around 15 times and I still think I'll play it again. Worth every last penny.

My favorite Resident Evil so far.

I probably haven't got much to say that hasn't been said already, but the game is fantastic.

Graphics are amazing indoors but outdoors it suffers a little, making terrain and nature look very weird and unrealistic sometimes. Sound design is very well done. Gameplay and controls? As you would expect of the RE franchise. Nothing new really, but it's very well done.

Level and game design are also great, innovating on each area whilst unlocking treasures in old ones. Progression and objectives are clear, there are no tedious sections or puzzles and I really value that. The game is way more action-based than RE7 losing a bit of the puzzle aspect of the previous one; whether that's good or bad is up to you. There's one area in particular in which the game turns into a survival, but other than that, you'll probably have a good stock of ammunition throughout your playthrough.

I loved the story. In fact, RE8 is one of those games in which I even read all the documents I found scattered throughout the game. It's well integrated and brings new perspective to the old games as well.

Content-wise, again, it's as expected of a RE game. You have your relatively "short" campaign that you can replay with many unlockables after you beat it the first time. It took me eight and a half hours according to the game's stats. There's some DLC which I won't get but I'll definitely watch the Rose one on YouTube.

And finally, of course, I had a lot of fun playing this. To put it into perspective, in 2021 I gave RE7 an 8.2/10, in 2022 I gave RE2 an 8.9/10 and RE3 an 8.6/10 and now, in 2023 I give RE8 a 9/10. 

Right now, my GOTY of 2023.
fun game

Despite the internet going crazy over the tall lady the four villains you face throughout the campaign all have pretty poor character design. The Baron however is an incredible character and a few of the survivors you meet early on are believable and interesting.  In terms of the story the series jumped the shark long ago so every installment stretches things even further at this point. If you stop to think about the plot at all things immediately start to fall apart and make little to no sense but if i'm being honest i'm not here for plot or character design. This is a Resident Evil game. The characters are rarely interesting. The stories stopped being good a long time ago and i'm here for the gameplay and atmosphere.  I'll start by addressing atmosphere. The good news is RE8 has a incredible atmosphere. The environments are visually stunning and distinctly Resident Evil.  It doesn't do anything exceptional with environmental story telling, but you can expect to find a few interesting documents and letters to read throughout the campaign that add to the world building of the universe and aren't that bad but nothing like what's found in early installments. Overall i will say the world i wonderful to live in with a brilliant gothic atmosphere and captivating scenery. Now I saved what i consider most important for last which is the gameplay and I am happy to report the moment to moment gameplay is lots of fun. Continuing in the footsteps of RE7 this installment is first person but takes ques from RE4 in the speed and pacing of the gameplay. This game is a massive improvement over the gameplay in RE7.  You move faster, there is more enemy variety, the story and campaign moves at a very nice pace all things that Capcom from the feedback they got with 7 and it really shows. However the addition of enemies dropping ammo and lots of heavy firepower really take it more towards that RE4 Action Horror genre and away from that traditional RE Survival Horror genre that I do much prefer but honestly both are great.

At first, I was a disgruntled Resident Evil player, the ones who whine that newer games are becoming more and more sellouts, but the game did end up being a great piece of art. It plays more like Resident Evil 4, which would've been nice to hint at the start. Instead, they drop the player into an arena with 20+ zombies and a giant final boss at the start of the game. Otherwise, gameplay was rewarding and satisfying, but not as majestic as Resident Evil 2.

The story on the other hand, though I was hesitant at first, ended up proving itself and took the Resident Evil world to a new level. Representing the dark side of the Promethean and Faustian ideals of human progression. In Resident Evil Village, we begin seeing much more complex bio weapons that are becoming more associated with human evolution. The story in this game, is my favorite in any of the Resident Evil games as it establishes more world building; instead of virus = x, stop y from using x, the end.

Horror games are great because you overcome the worst possible scenarios and they inevitably do leave an impression after you play them. You feel great about life, better hope for overcoming challenges, and understand more important values. All I can say, I wish I had a loving family like this...

I am a 58 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son Tim, who is 36 now. My son got this game for Festivus in 2021 from his uncle Frank, so we installed it on his Macintosh and he started playing. By the end of the first day he had 29 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends playing bum darts or just watching Xhamster. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he friended and invited me to join him. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died in a hot noodle accident. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside of our bunker. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories. it was truly “a Festivus for the rest of us”

Better than its dumpster fire predecessor in almost every single facet.
Pros: I'm running this on two 3080 RTX's with 15 gigs of ram on a 10 year old motherboard and was able to play in ray tracing mode with no loss in frame rate or loss in performance. 
The first play-through was in Hardcore Mode and felt well balanced, forcing you to be conservative with ammo and strategically combining items according to whatever dilemma you're in. Like a true survival horror, you always had barely enough to push forward even after missing a few shots. 
This game has near photo-realistic graphics. The level and sound design are absolutely terrifying and kept me on edge even after enemies have been cleared out - especially Heisenberg's factory and the cellars/dungeons throughout the game.  
Loot, treasures, and puzzles are actually worth trekking back for - often with a few surprises along the way so you never let your guard down. Also, that lock pick you've been anticipating for a few hours might actually open something worthwhile and not like 3 fucking hand gun bullets as in RE 7. 
Also, unlike its predecessor, this game actually has enemy variety.
Cons:
The latency after hitting space bar to block feels unresponsive and can be extremely frustrating when anticipating an attack you see coming. Even more frustrating is when swarmed on all sides and Ethan is moving like a sloth with a load in his pants, getting stuck on boxes, railings, and what not.  On that same note, the game sometimes confuses the player with obnoxious camera rattling, noise, and other vision obscuring screen overlays - this is often in combination with cut scenes where you're not sure if you're actually playing or not. In short, it feels like they're breaking the "fourth wall" to effectively cheat the player in the name of immersion. 
Also, historically RE games would give you some kind of warning before perma-leaving an area - like RE 2 before departing on the train - but this was left out  in this installment, so even if you're persistent in finding everything you may have to reload previous saves (something to keep in mind in Luiza's house before the chaotic cut scene or opening the sarcophagus after finding all the masks in Castle Dimitrescu).
Overall, I would recommend. This game is well-polished and an absolute trip.

Esse jogo não é Resident Evil. Apesar de contar com a presença do ilustre Chris Vermelhocampo, e uma singela aparição do emblema da Umbrella, de RE esse jogo não tem nada. Like RE7, RE8 is a callback to the original games. It's a twisting labyrinth through hell, and while it's not quite as scary as RE7, it has a great cast, an interesting story, and very fun combat mechanics. If RE7 was a tribute to RE1 - which I believe it was - then RE8 is a tribute to RE4.

I want to start by saying, this isn't a bad game. 

I think this game has a very nice aesthetic, and it really draws you into its world. But the more you play I feel the worse it gets. For a Resident Evil game the puzzles were very simple, and this game has practically no reason to return to older areas. It plays very linear which I feel is out of place for a Resident Evil game. Every time I faced an enemy I was more frustrated than worried, because if I died I would lose all the progress I made in the last 10-15 min because of the poor checkpoints and auto saves. 

This game's story is also very bad, it has horrible pacing and I lost all interest after the first hour or so of playing, and the plot twist I feel just made everything that much worse. 

Like I stated earlier, this game is not bad. But compared to what came before (RE7) I think this is a huge step down in quality. 

I would not pay full price for this game, but if its on sale and you are just looking for a game to enjoy on a more surface level approach, It'll do.

This game is definitely more videogamey than RE7. They dialed back the horror some and start sliding back into the WEIRD aspect of recent RE games, which I think are drawbacks. The horror, immersion, and level design is definitely what I LOVED about 7, so I still prefer 7 by a significant margin. Resident Evil is at its absolute BEST when it is pure "survival horror" the genre it created. Look at RE1, 4, and 7, widely considered the best 3 in the franchise. However I do appreciate a lot about Village, the setting is still super cool, even though I think there should've been more focus on the castle (Lady D died too soon), the skippable cutscenes make subsequent playthroughs much better, the variety of guns (even though I like how the guns feel better in 7) and the dollhouse is the most TERRIFYING experience in any game I've ever had, hands down. Excellent game.

3. Removed resident evil 7 option for auto crosshair remove when not aiming instantly. 
4. Also added skip button to cutscenes (that ruins screenshots making)  also removed it with mods, thank you modders.
5. Capcom started treating their players stupid or something, puzzles are easy for the most part, and really capcom ? yellow duct tape ? 

In conclusion worth every penny. PLAY RESIDENT EVIL 7 ITS AMAZING AND ITS A MUST FOR ANY FAN OF RESIDENT EVIL.

They went over the top with graphics, to the entire detriment of computers, and like to use lots of particle effects and fire, which is the best way to kill performance. Cinematics can be out of sync with the voices. The keybinding is like no game I've seen before, just like if the person setting it up never used a computer before and to the point I'm surprised WASD is actually used to move -> quick healing is CTRL, cancel/escape is right-click, V is map, crouch is right next to turn-around, hitting run while crouching make you stand up, you can't activate blocking if you aim, game ask no confirmation to use your components whenever you click a recipee to check it out or even by accident, and way more,

The game has no real tutorial, you're travelling from cinematic to cinematic for the first hour instead, the story make absolutly no sense, and do not tie together in any way shape or form. You're then forced to flee enemies for over 5 minutes without the game giving you any hint that is what they intend you to do, so prepare yourself to die over and over and over until you ran away a certain amount of time and find the exact right spot for the next cinematic to occur as there are infinite enemies (they go Dark Soul on your ass). You're then spared for the stupidest reason (actually an easter egg referencing RE4, the bell rang you see?). Then, you encounter NPCs with absolutly no sanity, the story make even less sense, only to make less and less sense as you progress.

This game is closer to a fantastic-horror fairytell than a Resident Evil, from which it only borrow the name, and that twice by taking over Chris Redfield and the protagonist of RE7 and doing an intro "linking it together", when in actuality it doesn't matter at all, doesn't relate to it, and would make MORE SENSE if they didn't tried to. It is sad nowadays companies fear that their game will not be "as popular" if they do not borrow names from established franchise, because it would be a good game on it's own storywise, but as a Resident Evil, it is a senseless shame that doesn't build into the world nor lore of RE. The only way it would make any sense lore-wise, is if the protagonist wake up and it was all just a dream, and THAT tells it all. It totally feel like somebody had a great idea for a game, and the company told him to use the RE name on it, and forced him to do something to make it seem it was supposed to be related while it definitely was not.

To summarize : The game style and lore can't integrate into the RE series. Some features that try to make this "RE" relate to others are just half-assed gimmicks. The story make no sense. The controls are terrible. The graphics are terrific at the expense of player accessibility. There is way too much cinematics and character interaction animations for no real good reason other than to amaze people, and that ultimately end-up making you feel the loss of character control as well as a loss of imertion (sit back and watch the movie rather than actually play a game). Level design is not good at directing you nor building up intrigue, only tension. The game doesn't introduce you properly to any of its mechanics. It takes way too much time before you can ACTUALLY start to really play the game and not run from cinematic to cinematic, but that will still happen ALOT throughout the whole game.

My advice? Remove the entirety of introduction, stop pretending it is Resident Evil, make your own characters with more defined personnality traits other than being the "victims of RE7", properly map the controls, rework the tutorial, and BOOM, it become a 9/10 with the only flaw being WAY too much cinematics and not enough gameplay. As a Resident Evil though... I'd give it 6/10, and story-wise, a 3/10, best way to enjoy it is to turn your brain off and forget the name along with any expectation coming from it.

I played a majority of the game on my ps4 originally (I'll get back to it eventually) up to the Stronghold section of the game and since I'm almost there with this playthrough, I decided to drop my review now with possible edits after I beat the game fully.

edit: I've since beaten the game (casually it took me about 9 hours on standard difficulty with unlimited ammo) and it is still a fun game to play and the story was enjoyable. It made sense of some things that'd make you go 'why did this happen?' and tied in to the other older games in the series in an interesting way that I enjoyed. I'd say my only real complaints was that the factory segment was perhaps the weakest in terms of the aesthetic vibe the game had and the monsters were were kind of lame and more tedious than anything to deal with. And the segment where your perspective shifts I also found a bit tedious as it feels like it throws enemies at you for the sake of it because you naturally get a lot of ammo in that part and its hard to get breathing room for one part. Overall though, fun from start to finish and Ethan Winters wins best dad award.

I've gone on a weird journey with the series, playing the games out of order for the most part with starting at RE2R, then 3R, the previously mentioned playthrough on my ps4 of this game, part or RE6, Revelations and RE4R on console which started as me trying to get over scares and play more scary games in the process. I'm still a long way from that goal as I am still a big baby but at least I get to play good games in the meantime. 

Atmosphere and aesthetics-wise this game is really strong with cool monster designs and vistas that are pleasing to the eyes with each having a different vibe to invoke a feeling from you. Sound and music is also very good with voice work also being stellar as well along with the moment to moment gunplay also being an enjoyable experience. The puzzles for the most part are fairly easy and give enough hints about how you are supposed to accomplish them. Story is also enjoyable and while this is a direct sequel to 7, they do have a cutscene that you can watch to summarize the events of the game for those who didn't play it (like me but I watched lets plays of 7 before so I knew the story in sweeps) to not feel totally lost. The few things that are sort of annoying to deal with are some of the button keybinds are sort of weird and in the menu if the mouse is at a certain point and you are trying to scroll with the wheel, the menu will snap back to where your mouse is so you sort of pingpong in the menu briefly. Also if you're someone who wants to be chased all game by big mommy vampire, she's the first major boss of the game which means she won't be around for the majority of the game so get your jollies in as much as you can in the castle before she's gone.

Disclaimer: I bought the dlc which unlocks infinite ammo/special weapons at the jump since I am a bad at ammo management especially when I am scared and even with them boss fights and other fights still take a hot minute and the risk of death is still present in moment to moment gameplay. When I first played this partly on my ps4 it was before the dlc came out and I beat the castle and house segments with ammo management intact so I still partly experienced it.
