"Resident Evil: Village" has very high highs, and very low lows. It takes a while before it gets going, but then it throws you into a middle of an awesome castle level. Soon enough it transitions into a non-combat horror section that will scare the pants off of most players, just to then transition into a weird, setpiece-driven water level. By this point you start to realize that you haven't really had many opportunities to shoot monsters because the games sprinkles the encounters very conservatively. "Village" seems to take note, because it then throws you into a long combat-heavy section, and does not let up the pace until the end. What I'm saying is that it's a rollercoaster, and that's good. Some sections are boring and overdone though, especially late in the game, which is not great, but only really becomes grating during subsequent playthroughs. Still, "Village" kind of lost me in the third act, not because it cranked up the absurdity, but because it felt more dumb than fun. The plot is the weakest link of this game, and that's including Ethan Winters, the unfortunately-not-silent protagonist. It's clear that Capcom was going for "Resident Evil 4"-type vibe, but the combat feel is too close to the slow survival horror entries and does not allow for enough creativity. I'm mixed on "Village", but I still find it worthy of recommendation.

Just play it for the journey.

This is the first RE game that I played all the way through from start to finish. In fact I've beaten this game 6 times now, was honestly surprised by how much I enjoyed the game. It's very well balanced between the horror and action aspect imo. The first play through will definitely keep you on your toes. I'm now hooked on this franchise and will be playing through RE2, 4, and 7 in the future.

It's a good game with fantastic graphics and art design, but only a mediocre Resi game in my opinion. It is very action focused and extremely linear for the most part. Puzzles are also pretty much non-existent. 

On top of that the story and especially the writing can be quite cringe inducing. I know Resi never had truly great stories or writing as I played almost all of them (except for the the Outbreak games, other online games and the light gun games), but the issue is that in older titles (definitely up till part 4, maybe even 5 or 6...) the acting was also so campy and things usually were just overall so ridiculous that you couldn't take it seriously for a minute anyway - it actually added a fantastic trashy flavor to the games. However, since Resi 7 the acting actually "improved" to a point that you actually feel inclined to take things seriously from time to time (I did at least) and then the writing and dialogue just hits you... Also, Ethan is boring and a wuss and I just never liked him or Mia - it was still bearable in 7, but here it was too much for me. Hopefully, we'll never see them again...

Still, overall a great game - just go in with the right expectations!

Bought RE 7 and 8(village) together in a bundle while it was on sale. I initially wanted to finish RE7 first to play them through in proper order but I was extremely disappointed in RE7 for various gameplay related seasons that I abandoned that game after about 2 1/2 hours. RE7 disappointed me so much that I was even hesitant to try RE8. I'm glad that I decided to give the game a chance though as I actually had a pretty good time with the game.

In many aspects it feels very similar to what RE4 did years ago. You have a somewhat similar inventory. Enemies drop loot that you can use to buy and upgrade stuff and even the whole atmosphere of the village is very similar to what RE4 did from what I remember. The movement and overall combat of RE8 is faster than in RE7. It actually looks and feels like you're running. The game also switches the focus from time to time. Some sections are more action oriented while others are designed to be creepy horror. The game sometimes uses jump scares but it's rare. My favorite section is a part where there isn't even any combat. It's just pure constant tension buildup where things get crazier and crazier while it then ends with a pretty satisfying finale and gives you some room to breath afterwards.

The overall story is coherant and servicable but unfortunately also has some problems. I can't really get into it without spoiling to much. I'm just gonna say that I would've handled some sections and character interactions differently as at least one character is a bit wasted within the story even though there's a cool boss fight. RE8 also has quite a few puzzles, most of which are easy or at least reasonable in terms of difficulty. There were one or two puzzles that left me scratching my head looking for a guide though. In addition there are quite a few hidding items. There have been a few rooms in my playthrough that still indicated something was there but I couldn't find it.

There are some parts I don't like in RE Village. The heavy use of video sequences in some parts of the game can be pretty annoying as it constantly takes away control from me as a player and there is no indication that you might run into a extensive video sequence. You open a door and *bam* you're watching a movie for the next few minutes...

Also there heavily scripted events as well. In one situation Ethan ends up in a cave with a deathly trap while being shackled. After dying the first time because I had no idea what to do I though about using the trap to unshackle myself. So I went closer to the trap and then ended up dying again because this was not the right solution. What the game expected me to do was crawl into a specifically prepared corner of the room that left a bit of space so I wouldn't be killed by the trap and then the game did for me what I wanted to do before with the shackles. I feel cheated in these kind of situations as I would like to figure something like this out on my own and actually do it myself instead of just watching a movie sequence doing it.

Also with boss fights it often comes down to "cause enough damage to the enemy to trigger the kill movie" because basically all bosses are the same in this regard where you shoot them for a while (maybe hit a specific spot) and then at some point the finisher sequence will start and you can watch a movie of the boss dying with Ethan doing something outside of your control.

And while I can criticize the game I had a good time with it and played it through in 2-3 days (about 15hours) and I added another 2 1/2 hours with the DLC right afterwards. So I would easily recommend RE Village if you can get it while it is on sale.

Wow! I usually wait until I've played through the game 2 or 3 times with a resident evil title before I give my full thoughts. But I've just finished my first playthrough and wanted to give them now. This is spoiler free. 

Resident Evil 8 feels like Capcom sat down and said "Okay, we feel like our best games in the series were 2,4, and 7. So let's take the best parts of all those games and mash them all together." And they absolutely hit it out of the park on delivering that!

it has a merchant (called the duke) with buying, selling, upgrading, and finding treasure like resident evil 4 with some sections in the game where you are shooting multiple enemies with plenty of ammo again like 4. 

It has sections with really interesting puzzles and backtracking with barely any shooting while being stalked by a mr x type stalker enemy (lady D) which reminded me of Resident Evil 2. 

And it also had a big section where they took inspiration from Resident Evil 7 which had quite intense horror and puzzle rooms (think the birthday puzzle room in Resi 7). While yes on the whole this game is less scary than the previous entry. This section in particular made me feel more scared and uncomfortable than even Resi 7 (people who have played probably know the section I'm talking about)

The story was fantastic and is of course a sequel to 7. While they do a brief rundown from the events of 7 I still recommend playing 7 first to understand every reference and story callback to that game (also it's just an amazing game you should play). Though it isn't necessary if you watch the 7 recap at the start (or a youtube video to explain 7 if you really don't want to play it for some reason)

The only thing I noticed was usually in past entries the standard difficulty mode was REALLY well balanced for a first playthrough before ramping it up on a second or third playthrough. I noticed here the standard felt a slight bit too easy, especially on boss battles. So word to anyone buying who likes a fair challenge, I would recommend going on the difficulty above standard. Not really a complaint just something I noticed. 

Overall this is a great Resident Evil game. and just a good game in general. As with all these games, new difficulties, cosmetics, weapons, and beating your time, all await you after the credits roll and I look forward to further playthroughs. 

Well done Capcom you've smashed it again! like they did with 7 and the remakes. The future of resident evil feels like it's in very safe hands and has a clear identity again.

Great game, and the best Resident Evil game that came after RE4. The story, horror and combat all well balanced and keep you engaged. The first half of the game is definitely the best part and similar to old RE vibe, but overall the game is a most-play for all Resident Evil fans.

I'm a fan of the series, I think Resident Evil 7 was better at this point of gameplay (about 6 hours), but it is a solid game so far with a lot of the things I liked about the previous game, Village story looks kind of supernatural (at least so far), but it has a great atmosphere, tension, action, and beautiful graphics.

Similar to the previous part, but with a completely different feel, because if the first part was more stealth-oriented and created psychological pressure by focusing on a smaller territory, [i]Village[/i] is more action-oriented and tries to charm with a much larger map. Which one someone likes more is obviously a matter of taste, but I think the seventh part had a stronger effect on me. [i]Village[/i] is undoubtedly a very interesting game, but the more I played it, the more I wondered if it would ever end, because although they tried to diversify the environment, in the end, all your actions were very similar, and I personally was not fascinated by the story as well. I often felt like I had seen or played it somewhere before - all these symbols and themes etc. Sometimes I also had the feeling that the whole village could be a bit more interactive or lively. The few domestic animals that scurried around here and there and could be shot for soup material added a little, but I would have liked it if there was something else to make the whole area not so dull. Yes, the key may be in the word "isolated" (environment), but there is a limit somewhere. Because one thing is an isolated and abandoned small territory, another thing is a whole big map that needs to be filled with something. Maybe what I mean is that something could have surprised every now and then. I don't know, maybe a plane could have made an emergency landing or a school bus could have lost its way there. Just something to work with. But there were only similar-looking houses and enemies that appeared from time to time. Okay, there were also puzzles, not all areas in the village were accessible at the very beginning. Also, I'm not convinced if the four main bosses were put into the game in the best order. Because after Lady Dimitrescu, none of the subsequent areas in the game were that gripping. But at the same time, it was a turning point, from where the game became more action-like and focused less and less on sneaking, so maybe it was necessary for the overall picture of the game. Anyway, in my opinion, all in all a good entertainment, maybe a bit long, but overall definitely a recommended game for those who like the genre. Plus it's quite replayable and "The Mercenaries" bonus game adds even more gametime.

Okay so, after completing basically all the modern era RE games I can officially say this is one of them. Now it definitely isn't the worse, nowhere near the worse, but it's not amazing either.

Ranking as of now goes:
1. RE4R (10/10)
2. RE2R (10/10)
3. RE7:B (9/10)
4. RE8:V (8/10)
5. RE3R (7/10)

As you can see, not to say it's bad or anything, but it isn't the best of the bunch. It kinda feels like RE4 in it is more action and less spooky, but it falls more flat on the action, seeing as the gunplay and movement aren't all that good in the fps versions of RE. Hopefully this will change when I play through it again in Third Person but we will have to see.

anyways the bosses are great, the graphics are great, it's basically really great, but doesn't live up to it's predecessor or the remakes.

I just went back and rated RE3 Remake again and I feel so invigorated that I'm gonna write a full review for this one too. It's been a minute since I played it so this won't be a great review (but who's gonna see it anyway?) I'm no OG player but as someone who's completed about 4.2833333 RE games, (33.333% of RE4 remake, 95% of Biohazard and all of 2 Remake, 3 Remake and Village) I think I'm qualified enough to say this game is pretty subversive as far as the series goes. This is the most recent entry in the main series and the most recent chronologically as well. It is the second and final game involving Ethan Winters, a boring but sweet protagonist who will forever live in Leon's shadow. This game is very good. I like how much it goes against things it already establishes during the game, from lord to lord in new and wacky scenarios. I love the ending, the lore, and the possibility of seeing Rose in future installments. I actually have less to say about this game than I thought so I feel stupid right now. What's new? Anyway, I liked my first experience with having a dedicated shop where you could collect treasures to sell for money. I love games with collectibles, especially when they appear on the map. I forget if they appear on the map here or not but uh. Cooking was an interesting mechanic which I enjoyed. Every area felt unique. The voice acting for everyone except Ethan and a couple of other characters was kind of mediocre. Interestingly enough, this game introduces the megamycete as the source of all of the chaos seen in the franchise thus far but actually does a lot less explaining or rationalizing the effects it has on the enemies and characters seen in this game compared to the previous ones. My fingers are freezing because of the vent underneath my desk so I'm gonna end this review by saying that this game is, for a Resident Evil game, a breath of fresh air and a good ending to the new experimental first-person horror style, even if this one was kind of a departure from horror and more into action territory.

[h1] Introduction [/h1]

First my knowledge with Resident Evil started from 7-th part, and I really enjoyed this game. I have played Resident Evil Village twice: first time I passed this game when it was released on Mac and second time - now in Steam.

[h1] Main Plot [/h1]

The story of Village is a direct sequel of part 7. From the very beginning I had many questions to what is happening. The game very beautifully sets the tone and the formed questions after the introduction make you run forward for answers.

We don’t have straight answers until the very end, and only before the last fight game gives us all answers and admirably connect this part with the whole RE saga.

RE Village doesn’t give all answers in cutscenes, in turn, more answers are given in notes. This is done in the spirit of the old parts, where there were no beautiful cutscenes, and all the answers had to be given in the form of notes scattered throughout the game.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

When I was playing the first time - I really was scared almost all the game. This game doesn’t have many screamers, in turn it casts a mood of constant anxiety. During the passage, my mood changed very quickly from panic and apathy to peace and tranquility in the save rooms. So all gaming experience may be explained as emotional rollercoaster.

The game is based on Village [spoiler] and 4 extra locations with 4 boss fights + the final boss. In the house of Beneviento game takes all our weapon and we need to pass it only by solving puzzles. [/spoiler] And it was the most scary part of the game.

The last location is [spoiler] Heisenbergs factory [/spoiler] and it is the only location during which I was tired from the game. This location is very big and long. And due to this location I felt boring. When I played this game second time, only [spoiler] Heisenbergs factory [/spoiler] was stopping me from playing.

[h1] DLC and third person view [/h1]

DLC Shadow of Rose is made perfectly in all canons of DLSs. Where taken already Ken locations, has been changed to fit the new story and was realized as a new small game. And it was done perfectly. The second location which is [spoiler] Beneviento’s house [/spoiler] I was really scared and got all emotions which I wanted to have.

I haven’t played the RE village with a third person view, but have seen few play throughs, and what I have understood is - all screamers and cutscenes are done for a first person view. So those who really want to try it as s new old experience may lose a big part of emotions. As well need to notice that in all cutscenes camera moves to a first person view, even if you play with third person view. According to this I believe that this is a detriment to the player immersion.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

I have really enjoyed Resident Evil Village, that’s one of those games which I enjoyed to play second time. DLC Shadow of Rose is not bad, it had many good moments, but I haven’t seen in it any of revealing hidden storylines. For all my gaming experience I haven’t seen any of gaming bugs or optimization problems. So from technical side game looks really perfect.
I may easily recommend this game if you enjoy some horror.

If you played Resident Evil 7: Biohazard this is basically continuation of the story but this time the game itself is slightly more action oriented and not as much effort is put on horror but it sure is a great game. Now there is a certain part of the story which was quite scary but that was a relatively short part of the game. 

I myself usually avoid linear scripted games and generally play open world games but because I enjoyed Resident Evil 7 a lot I gave this one a chance as well and was most pleasantly surprised. The DLC Shadows of Rose also complements the main story really well, it is a great story.

In short the game is a very solid 8/10 for me
Pros:
The visuals, story and atmosphere are all 10/10 keeping you immersed and invested in the game and the sound is good as well. Despite the game being linear they have added a lot of progression and interesting features to keep people entertained for at least 2 to 3 campaigns which would be 15 to 30 hours. I guess for a linear game this should be counted as a good thing. Progression system in the game is done really well.

Cons:
Gunplay itself is not too great but definitely the best of all RE games. Despite being the best linear game I have ever played I will still count the game being a linear game as a con. Once you finish the story the immersion diminishes because the game itself is heavily scripted so you are not surprised by the events in the game anymore but still the progression might be enough to keep quite a few players playing despite that.

Definitely a great game, I got it on sale myself but wouldn't regret the purchase even if it was full price.

Another great start like in previous game but yet they still managed to downgrade a lot than the previous one. This game has very good characters actually well just Dimitrescu family. Because Miranda is cringe as hell, Heisenberg is your usual tough guy and there's pathetic Morbeau which could have been much much better if they didn't decide absurd design decisions. And the last Beneviento family maybe the worst of all. Because the puzzle they designed is so straightforward and throughout the level there's no tension at all. Because level design is so linear, it's very obvious what to do when chase occurs.

Inventory management becomes completely useless, don't bother purchasing inventory upgrades at all. You can carry basically unlimited amount of crafting materials and if you create them when you need, probably you never run into any kind of problem when dealing with inventory.

Except for the first ambush part, you'll never have a problem with ammo. In the last fight I had 60-70 sniper bullets and each of them deals 2k damage. Naturally boss can't stand a chance and it was terribly designed boss as well. Merchant system makes the looting a lot more worthless because after some point game starts giving you money instead of useful resources. So that you can buy everything you want since merchant stocks replenish frequently. And yes this happens at hardcore difficulty. I can't even think how the game looks like in lower difficulties.

At start, I thought this game we'll be spending more time within the castle instead of village like Dimitrescu family becomes our nemesis and we occasionally run into each other but no. Castle level is progressed so fast and most iconic characters passed away without doing any significant thing. Literally they're wasted for nothing. Because there's no "tension" when a scripted chase occurs, because you know when you got into some room you just got away and game leaves you alone until you progress to another section. There's zero randomness in this game, everything is scripted and lots of cinematic scenes which takes the control away from you thus kills the immersion.

Factory level feels so empty, over-designed because there's not enough content inside of it. Just empty large rooms most of them has no loot or readable thing at all. Enemies are so bland and scarce. They really missed a chance to horde of machines chasing us similiar to like at the start. Heisenberg fight is a literal joke, he couldn't even perform one of his skills and just got killed in seconds on my first try. 

Reservoir could have been very different if they give Morbeau to ability to hit through any kind of obstacle instead of just passing through some thin lines. He's literally a giant fish and yet can't even properly catch you even the place its home. And that boss fight is also terrible as well.

There's no story. Even saying bad is an insult to the word itself. Last hours of this game belongs to something else, I still can't believe it. Such a cringe, bland and hollow way to end the Ethan's story. Game wants you to feel "something" but with this kind of dialogues and actions, all you can do is laughing it at.

Capcom greatly fails to innovate gameplay, level and boss designs. Instead they keep removing stuff, makes the game a lot easier and as a result removing the tension because you can kill everything with your super powered weapons. You can skip past some monsters but when you don't have to worry about ammo why would you do that? When I'm playing I felt more like it's a cheap copy of Doom.

If you want a very casual shooter game, you'll definitely like this. If you're an RE fan, you probably be disappointed.

[h1]Resident Evil [i]Village[/i][/h1]
Is the newest chapter in Capcom's popular survival horror franchise. The game follows on from RE 7: Biohazard, (2017), and is full of blood, fright and a lot of action.

[h1]Complex plot...[/h1]
In this new Resident Evil game, once again the player lives a story starring Ethan, the main character of RE 7 After the torturous events of the 2017 game, the character tries to return to normality alongside his wife Mia and daughter Rosemary . However, right at the beginning of Village, he is surprised by the already known Chris Redfield, who murders Mia and kidnaps Rose.

Knocked out in a fight with Chris, Ethan wakes up in a village completely in ruins, which seems to have a special fondness for a quasi-religious figure named Mother Miranda. There, he starts his journey in search of Rosemary, facing several enemies and unraveling countless secrets.

[b]Although it looks simple at first glance, the plot is actually quite complex. Under the premise of a father's search for his daughter, several mysteries are kept that involve even the history of the formation of the main company of Resident Evil, the Umbrella Corporation. The entire unfolding of the narrative deepens as we advance in the game, and the icing on the cake is its completely surprising outcome.[/b]

Despite its complex story, the game is relatively short and can be beaten in about ten hours. As usual in Resident Evil, however, Village keeps some treasures and small parallel missions, which make the user want to play it more than once. In addition, there is also the return of the Mercenaries mode to challenge the player even more.

It's worth saying that even those who don't know Resident Evil 7 can play Village without major problems. This is because the game presents a retrospective of previous history right at the beginning, situating those who did not live through the horrors of Biohazard. However, for better understanding and even affinity with this new storyline, it might be a good idea to play the 2017 game.

[h1]Powerful and well-varied enemies[/h1]
In the demo released, Capcom knew how to hide the depth of the story of Resident Evil Village very well. If we started the gameplay with the certainty that our biggest enemy would be the already known Lady Dimitrescu, we were soon surprised: there are at least three other villains that we must defeat.

They are Donna Beneviento, Salvatore Moreau and Karl Heisenberg. They are Mother Miranda's followers, and each poses different difficulties to the player. It is worth mentioning that, for TechTudo, the most terrifying moments were due to Beneviento, while the greatest battle difficulties were found with Heisenberg.

Furthermore, Resident Evil Village is also interesting for the variety of types of enemies. In this game, there are vampires, witches, killer dolls, creatures that resemble werewolves and even robotic villains, in a striking cyberpunk aesthetic. The tip here is that the headshot is not always the main way out - however, it's always a good idea to keep your aim properly calibrated.

[h1]Guaranteed horror with terrifying soundtrack[/h1]
This new Resident Evil game is definitely one of the scariest in the franchise. To keep a comparison in mind, the last time I felt so terrified of a game in the series was with Resident Evil 2, released for PSOne in 1998.

In addition to having several jump scares to scare players, Village also has a haunting soundtrack that keeps players in a constant state of tension. It is even possible that this is the scariest track of all the games in the series, delivering a magnificent job of setting in survival horror.

[h1]Excellent graphics in realistic scenarios[/h1]
As expected, the RE Engine did an excellent job on Resident Evil Village, which features exquisite lighting and realistic environments. The video game engine was launched in 2017, for Biohazard, and now comes with a game that runs well even on more limited hardware consoles - as is the case with the PS4.

Although the very characterization of the characters, such as Lady Dimitrescu and Salvatore Moreau, for example, is interesting in itself, what most called attention during the tests was the beauty and realism of the scenarios. From the tense scenes in the Dimitrescu castle to the unpleasant moments in the Heisenberg factory, the game maintains neat environments full of details at practically all times.

In Resident Evil Village, even the ugly is beautiful. The only exception to this logic is perhaps a moment present in the second boss of the game, Donna Beneviento. However, although it involves a frightening situation, the setting of the scene is still impressive, making its horror justified.

[h1]Traditional and expected franchise mechanics[/h1]
Like any other game in the franchise, Resident Evil Village demands a lot of curiosity and exploration from the player. It is always necessary to look closely at each object collected, as some must be assembled and/or disassembled to actually be used.

It is interesting to note, however, that in this new chapter of the Capcom series some items have extended lifespans. In addition, there are regions that, although they appear at the beginning of the game, must be explored later.

To facilitate the trajectory, the map of Resident Evil Village is quite intuitive. It shows in a simplified way if there is still something to be explored in each of the available areas, but its simplicity can be a real headache for players who like to collect any and all items.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Resident Evil Village is an excellent new chapter in Capcom's traditional franchise. With mechanics already known and loved, the game made a beautiful debut in the new generation.

Although it has a slightly long ending, all the hours invested are justified by the complexity of the story. With beautiful graphics and well-developed villains, Resident Evil Village ends Ethan Winters' journey with a flourish, pleasing a lot with its surprising and terrifying gameplay.

What a ride! where to start? First of all this is a direct sequel of Resident Evil 7, continuing with the story of Ethan and his family. I love how the game story unfolds and gives an end to what the 7 title started and also expands on the whole lore of the franchise. The gameplay is a little bit different from the previous game as this one focus more in the action than the terror, it is as if re7 and re4 had a child, still has it's great moments of horror, but it is not the main focus. I'm actually kind of confounded that this game has overwhelmingly positive reviews on steam, because I really did not enjoy this one and think its easily the weakest of the more recent entries. I've kinda become a big fan of the franchise after playing RE7 a few months ago, and have played all of the new RE engine ones since (including 4 remake), and enjoyed all of them but this one. 
The rewarding exploration and problem solving of the previous games is largely absent, replaced with monotonous trudging around a linear path of houses and sheds or stone hallways. The village is not fun to explore; you don't get to just walk around it because that would too convenient, instead half the areas are blocked off by a tree or something meaning you have to go through a house and into the backyard where there is a shed that has a small hole on one side that you have to go through (although its easy to miss because there are a ton of sheds and outhouses that don't have anything in them). Most of these areas aren't even level-gated, there is no reason for the geography of the village to be so frustrating to navigate.
Its not really good as a survival horror game because it's not scary and I never really struggled to survive as ammo and health were plentiful and I never ran out of inventory space on normal difficulty. Not that I wish I had played on a higher difficulty because the combat encounters aren't really enjoyable and I can't imagine a higher difficulty making them anything other than more annoying. Resident Evil 7 just executed the first person horror so much better.
It's not really good as an action game because shooting stuff isn't exciting, guns aren't punchy or satisfying, and enemies aren't fun to fight. Also Ethan controls really awkwardly. Also I didn't know where to put this complaint but the big tiddy vampire lady is only in it for like 2 hours.
I probably have more to say about it but I don't wanna. Bad game, everything done here is done better by another entry. Don't recommend.
Also I forgot to mention there's no FOV slider, I had to download a mod.

Resident Evil Village: Come for the Horror, Stay for the Tall Lady

Resident Evil Village is another installment in the beloved survival horror franchise. As a die-hard fan, I was excited to jump back into the world of zombie-infested wastelands and grotesque monsters.

The graphics are top-notch, with detailed environments and character models that will make you feel like you are right there in the creepy village. The sound design is also on point, with every creak and groan sending shivers down your spine.

The real star of the show: Lady Dimitrescu. She is the tall, elegant, and utterly terrifying vampire lady that has taken the internet by storm. And boy, does she live up to the hype. Every time she appears on screen, I found myself both terrified and strangely attracted. I know that I am not alone in this.

Back to the game itself. The gameplay is a nice mix of exploration, puzzle-solving, and combat. The village is full of secrets to uncover, and the puzzles are just challenging enough to keep you engaged without being frustrating. The combat is intense and satisfying, with a variety of weapons to choose from.

This is a must-play for horror fans and anyone who loves being scared out of their wits.

"Resident Evil Village? More like Resident Evil 'Welcome to the Village, it's gonna be a bumpy ride!' - because this game takes you on a wild and crazy journey through a village filled with werewolves, vampires, and a really creepy doll.

First off, let's talk about the protagonist - Ethan Winters is back and more clueless than ever. I mean, who just follows a random old man into the middle of a creepy village filled with monsters? Ethan, apparently. And let's not forget about his miraculous healing powers - the man can reattach his own hand like it's no big deal.

But the real star of the show is Lady Dimitrescu and her vampire daughters. They're like the Von Trapp family, but with a thirst for blood. And let's be honest, who doesn't love a tall, elegant woman with a taste for the finer things in life? Even if those things happen to be blood and human flesh.

The gameplay is intense and exciting, with plenty of boss battles and moments that will make you jump out of your seat. And let's not forget about the inventory system - because what's a Resident Evil game without some inventory management?

Overall, Resident Evil Village is like a horror version of Beauty and the Beast, with a dash of The Shining thrown in for good measure. It's intense, it's exciting, and it's a lot of fun. So, grab your controller and get ready to run for your life

A great addition to the Resident Evil franchise that further builds upon the events of RE7. I cannot wait for RE9, the final chapter of the Winter's trilogy! 

Pros:

1) Gorgeous areas. The first and second areas that the game will take you to (After the side-boss characters are revealed) are truly something else. This is not to say that the others are bad, but those are spectacular.

2) A nice balance between horror elements and more action-oriented bits for the most part of the game. (There is one area that falls short)

3) The DLC adds a lovely bit of extra story, effectively setting up the protagonist character for RE9.

Cons:

1) While the graphics in general are really good, some random textures can look especially rough, almost like they belong to a game from 2008. These are random textures on environmental objects though so its not the worst thing.

2) As with most RE games, do not expect a grounded story that makes complete sense. It is fun, it is entertaining, but if that is not enough, maybe look elsewhere.

3) There is a certain area when you go to a 'stronghold' region in the main story. For that small section, the game becomes far too action-oriented in my opinion. It is jarring compared to the rest of the game. Regardless, once you get past that, it goes back to being solid.

[h1] Resident Evil: Beautifully impressive yet cringy horror game lacking the horror 8  [/h1]

So this is the first resident evil game I beat from start to finish. I'm never really interested in these types of games but decided to give it a try.

Right off the bat im gonna say. The graphics, The atmosphere, level design, audio and overall concept is really impressive.
But the mix and match of:

[spoiler] Vampires, Lycans, "Zombies", Paranormal, "Heisenberg able to control the magnetic fields", tall big t**** vampire lady with claws, Swamp Shrek acid big fish", "Evil dolls", "Halloween ready, dressed vampire teenage girls" and finally "Cod WW2 zombies lookalikes" As much as I appreciated the variety of enemy types. It took me right out of the "Horror" experience. I found myself cringing multiple times, and going like wtf is this? [/spoiler]

Its like the game director either didn't know what idea to stick with or straight up wanted to make some kind of weird fan fiction. I really couldn't take it seriously for one second and found myself literally running in each room with my shotgun blasting like it was some kind of shooter.

I'm being serious the ONLY time in my entire 9,3h playthrough where I thought the game would finally start to scare me was at the Beneviento house. That was a really interesting and creepy level. (it almost seems like it was inspired by P.T)

I played the previous entry for around 6 hours( until I got bored of backtracking) And it was much more scarier. they say in this game that your supposed to feel powerless but... im sorry hot girls chasing me while I have the firepower of an army is just not it man.

The first half of the game I was really trying to figure out how this game is related whatsoever to RE 7. I guarantee you if you guys saw the trailer and it wasn't named RE 8 you would have never guessed this was a resident evil game.

Basically my overall impression is: WOW this game looks good, This is Cringe, is this supposed to be horror, Meh.

Im giving it a 7/10 its a good game, Entertaining but incredibly short... dont expect to be scared.

I am a fan of the series, movies and games, but I can't recomend this entry of the series.

First off the good parts: 
- the Art and Design of the things and enemies is pretty good and cool 
- there are parts of the game that have a nice gameplay flow
- good first half

Why don't I like it?
Well, two reasons:
- the writing is getting worse and worse the more you play it
- the last few hours were boring and unimaginative in my opinion (gameplay + story)

My thoughts:
Ethan doesnt work in this game. He is the most boring MC. It made sense for part 7. There it worked because we were trying to survive this hellscape and could imagine very well, how it would be to be in his shoes. 
But in this game the motivation is finding his daughter. Already a position not everyone can relate to. Regardless of if you can imagine yourself as Ethan, there is another problem: the goal is of a more realistic, serious nature. It is portrayed by the game in that way. Allright. I mean part 7 was pretty serious and it worked, so it must work here as well, right?

[b] Incorrect Buzzer Sound [/b]

In 7 it worked, because all the crazy mutation stuff was hidden and only revealed slowly. But this game here is not trying to hide it. The entire premisse is absurd. The children's book thing and the fantasy monsters. It just doesn't fit the more realistic approach of the story. 
The story in itself is full of holes btw. 
It is full of headscratchers and confusing things and the resolution at the end is unsatisfying and incomplete.
Mother Miranda is the most boring supervillain imaginable and I just wanted to get it over with in the end. 

The beginning, where you are introduced with the village and Castle Dimitrescu is pretty good, because the story is kept very brief at this point. The bit with the next villain is very well executed as well, but it is downhill from there.
The story bores and the game gets more filler and plotholes which is not good for a AAA game. I feel like the the part in the factory could have been easily half as long, whitout sacrificing quality.

I get a very marvel movie vibe from the characters in the story, which I don't like. Also a lot of what the game offers is copied from earlier RE entries I feel. Especially, but not exclusively, the end resembles Part 7 in a lot of ways. Without being as effective as the predecessor.


[u][b]Verdict:[/b] underwhelming[/u]

[h1] Resident Evil Village (2021)  [/h1]



Resident Evil Village (2021) is the 8th installment to the Resident Evil Franchise, this follows up 4 years after the events of Resident Evil 7 (2017) with returning characters Ethan Winters, Mia Winters, and Chris Redfield, along with new characters such as Rosemary Winters, and Chris's Wolf Hound Team which are all part of Blue Umbrella as suspected that Chris Redfield left the BSAA American Branch. The game has similar elements from Resident Evil 4 (2005) with the Merchant Duke, with an actual connection with the Duke and the Merchant from Resident Evil 4 (2005). Though most of the elements that are connected with the 2021 game is Resident Evil 7, same mechanics and some items came back to the 2021 game. Though as to be stated, the game is centered around Europe in which Chris Redfield stationed the Winter Family there for protection, in addition, Rosemary Winters was born in 2020 which Ethan Winters and Mia are the parents. However, both Ethan and Mia before Rosemary was born and after are still stunned and are in a traumatic condition following up to what happened 4 years ago in the 2017 game. Continuing, Rosemary Winters was taken by Mother Miranda as a disguise of Mia Winters while it's later revealed she was taken captive and held for experiments. Chris Redfield and his team tried combating Mother Miranda in the beginning sequence of the game. An enraged Ethan believed that Mia Winters was killed by Chris, but later Chris finally reveals that he was combating Mother Miranda while it wasn't Mia Winters to Ethan. In protection, Chris took Rosemary and Ethan in a van to safety, but was ambushed somehow and Rosemary was suspected to be taken. Ethan waking up and discovering the van completely not functional while the people who were driving it are dead, he later walks in a dark tundra area with a passage which Ethan discovers his mission to save Rosemary and overseeing the Village and Castle D. Which the main course of the game Ethan has to survive and defeat wild and insane enemies. Down below will be the details why I say it's recommended with some setbacks.



[h1] Advantages [/h1]


The advantages of the 2021 game is that most of the elements was taken from other games in the franchise, such as Resident Evil 4 and Resident Evil 7. The game has excellent graphics, while thus performance, the models, weapons, the story are otherwise excellent. A addition with a first person while in the latest installment of Rosemary Winters adolescents beyond after the end of the 2021 game, along with more The Merchanaries, expansion of Rosemary Winter's story and also third person mode for the main game and the DLC. 




[h1] Disadvantages [/h1]


The game has some setbacks, such as the stalker enemies, Lady D lacked horror, not very a creepy feeling is established when she's following you in the Castle D, and mostly she follows you in the Castle section, and also the Winter  Family story has came to a close with a conclusion that Ethan died and Rosemary Winter's story in conclusion, though I wish there was something more to the story.




[h1] Conclusion [/h1]


I like Resident Evil Village (2021), it's a good game, but I will play this game more in the future when it comes to seeing this game and the accomplishments I see within the game, I will rate this 2021 game down below.

Awesome game. Short campaign (took me 9 hours first time, then 7 on the second), but has a lot of replayability. Scary, tense, fun. It may be short but the experience is quite unique and worth full price.

This is about the most inventive of all the games they've made so far - a spooky, Gothic fantasy that has a level of tension from beginning to end. The upgrading of weapons and the style of it is reminiscent of RE4 (even more-so with the RE4remake out) which is a good thing for any fans of that game.

Lots of mutants to fight, and monsters very akin to classic archetypes of Vampires and Lycans, and loads of weapons to play with too. It's a large game and the puzzles are solvable without resorting to walk-through guides

I played the game in third person mode, with 3 very basic mods installed which enhance the animations,  giving Ethan animations from RE2 Remake, and it makes third person mode feel like it was originally intended (outside of the first person cutscenes, of course).

Overall recommend it. And you can mostly buy it for cheap now, too.

Boy does this game live up to its literal title:

Your home life is interrupted by some evil residents,
You make your way through the titular village, inhabited by many evil residents,
You find yourself in a spooky castle whose residents are (promiscuously) evil,
You get the picture, many residents of evil.

Stupid eye catching intro aside, Resident Evil Village is a great addition to the series we all know and love, and a fantastic sequel to its predecessor released back in 2017. This is another one of a game where I felt compelled to write a long review no one will read because I had such a fantastic experience with it, but more so because I was on the fence about even getting it up until 4 weeks ago when it was on major sale.

To put it bluntly, I thought a lot of the hype around this game was purely because of the "big mommy vampire meme hehe," wave that EXPLODED and was inescapable when the trailer dropped. That compiled with this horror setting from the 1930s (feudal village and spooky castle) paired with classic movie monsters (vampires, werewolves, swamp creatures), had me confused about what this game was going for and how it fit into the series. I wasn't particularly interested and it took a super sale, coupled with my longing for the RE:4 Remake and needing something to tide me over before its release for me to pull the trigger. Simply put, I've got no regrets: I beat the game multiple times, completed every challenge minus DLC, and frankly should have jumped on the Dimitrescu bandwagon earlier. 

Going back to my previous point: how does this game fit into the series? While it contains everyone's favourite boulder punching a-hole, I view RE:7 and 8 as separate from the main series. They're their own unique games and it's not just because of the shift to first person. I think what sets these games apart is that Capcom really struck a perfect balance of ridiculous, over the top, WTF plots, with fantastic characters, amazingly portrayed and brought to life, set in truly unique environments, which can be considered characters themselves. Take RE:7, the focal point of that game was the Baker family and their disgustingly beautiful Louisiana plantation manor. The three antagonists in that game were incredibly iconic, making for scenes ranging from unsettling, to hilarious, to terrifying. It also helped the player build up these twisted relationship with each of them, ultimately culminating in memorable showdowns.  

That formula is repeated here, but built out further with Mother Miranda and her "family." This is where RE:8 truly shines: here's a cast of truly memorable misfits, each one more unique than the last, but most importantly, all fantastically voiced and acted. I know everyone loves to talk about Lady D (for obvious reasons, memes or not), and yes she is an amazing character (Maggie Robertson killed), but honestly all the children do such a fantastic job. I'd argue Neil Newbon as Heisenberg is equally fantastic and makes for such a fun villain. How he enunciates "Mother Miranda, that b**ch," will forever by stuck in my head and his showdown was quite the- experience to say the least. My point is that these wild and wacky characters, brought to life by passionate VA's make this game such a fun time. On my first playthrough, I couldn't wait until my next encounter, but there were moments in subsequent playthroughs where I'd happily watch cutscenes in their full length.

The other thing to point out is that this game never takes itself too seriously, and that's why it truly shines compared to other RE games. They really nailed the precedence RE:4 set back in 2005, but the series seemed to lose shortly thereafter *cough* RE:6 *cough*. There's actually a lot of parallels to RE:4 and this game and probably the reason why I had such a great time with it. But in terms of plot, this game takes place in a spooky village straight outta Transylvania a la 1800s with werewolves and vampires, there's no way to play that seriously and thank god they don't. You can tell the devs had a lot of fun coming up with the story, characters and setting, and honestly if it weren't for the title and one character, this could just as easily not be an RE game. Aside from that, this plot has more twists and turns that a daytime soap opera. There's drama, romance, highs/lows, aforementioned memorable characters, plot twists, ect- my god it's got it all and never seems to hold back. In fact as the game progresses, it gets even more ridiculous, but again it embraces it and is even able to poke fun at itself at times. I think a fair comparison could actually be how Metal Gear treats its stories: serious plot/setting, sprinkled with moments that come out left field. 

In terms of gameplay, just like the characters and plot, it's a wild ride. This game has something for everyone. One minute it's survival horror, then it takes a complete 180 and suddenly you're playing something akin COD, mercilessly blasting everything in sight. It can be a walking sim, then a looter shooter, hoarding every penny for an insane weapon upgrade. It has horror moments hiding in lockers straight from Amnesia and then classic RE puzzle moments solving nonsensical/overly complicated door locks with statue pieces. Then you're fighting a boss that violently transforms into some eldritch abomination- it's all here and you better be ready. Caught up in this whole mess is our protagonist turned super dad Ethan Winters (also fantastically voiced), and if you loved how much of a literal punching bag he was in RE:7, this game is your wet dream. It's an absolute roller coaster of emotions seeing how much abuse poor Ethan takes in this game, yet inspiring how he perseveres through it all. I don't want to spoil the fun, but they really up the punishment compared to what he endured in RE:7 and don't hold back at all.

Now I mentioned RE:4 and yes, this game screams of RE:4 and I'm all for it. I'll admit it's a bias on my part- RE:4 was my official introduction to the series on GameCube back in 05 and it left quite the impression on me. That game introduced a lot of elements to the series that are now quintessentially "Resident Evil," and it was such a welcome surprise to see them back in this game. There's the setting of course (castle, village, swamps), but also treasure hunting/combining is back, along with a currency to spend at a merchant for buying/upgrading weapons. Special shout out to The Duke- he is an absolute pleasure to deal with and sucg a fun side character encountered throughout the game. Also, love it or hate it, the RE:4 attache case and inventory management is here too, which is a fun minigame on its own. It's interesting because the RE:4 remake was clearly in development while this game was, and while there are a lot of parallels between the two (btw: the Remake is phenomenal and I'll be reviewing it as well), RE:8 offers its own unique flavour to the mix.

My only critiques with this game are first; the movement speed. My god is Ethan slow, its RE:7 all over, and even with a supposed "speed increase perk" you move at a snails pace, which can be especially frustrating during enemy heavy encounters (the ending for example- yikes). Second, sound design for weapons is hit or miss. A lot of the guns sound like peashooters, even after maxing them out, and it just seems off. Thirdly, while the game looks fantastic and runs superbly on damn near max settings (even on my older 2070), how certain things are rendered in the RE engine can be weird. You'll go from beautiful, hyper detailed interiors, to smoke/clouds that look like literal pixels, or animations being jerky/stop motion like when viewed at a distance. I'm sure it's to help performance, but it kills immersion at times.

Anyway this is long and I'm rambling. TL;DR, come for the vampire mommy, stay for the wild ride of a story and engaging gameplay it has to offer

Best manline since 4, and while a very enjoyable game, I don't think you'll need more of it.

Everything that made 7 fresh with adjustments to improve it, with a lot of the qualities you’d expect on a game so heavily nostalgic to 4.
While it would never top that gauntlet of a game, it tries it’s best by having a wide variety of environments that all behave differently from the last, with a great progression feel and changes of the situations you come across.
The game starts strong, then fuzzles for a tad in a two-section that was admittedly a breeze on a second run, to end strong with one of the best levels of the series. There is a section after I flat out dislike but it lasts like five minutes at least.
In general it’s more of the polished good looking camp, even if I do lament how puzzle-lacking it is however. While I do argue it’s the best mainline we had in a while, it certainly is not perfect, and if you don't enjoy it’s shooter heavy approach, you’re absolutely not going to see anything else here.

Once you’re done with the campaign, there is the replay incentive of NG+, maximizing the gun upgrades, unlockables and the return of the beloved Mercenaries for pure arcade joy, albeit changed into a mediocre linear shooting gallery in actual structure.

That’s really the sentiment I have in general, enjoyment. This was the best time I had with a mainline entry in a while, and the second FOV is patched I have zero hesitation to recommend it to newcomers or established fans, further if in a discount. That said don't be surprised if you end up not really interested in replaying it much after you had your fill.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

Resident Evil 8 has got the same issues for me as Resident Evil 7 had. A lot of walking, beautiful environments and graphics but very little to interact with or read. Very few item descriptions setting the scene. It's a very slow start but once you've played for a few hours things heat up quite a bit...The action is what sets this apart from previous games. Unlike RE7 there are a variety of enemies to play with. Some are big, some are small and some can fly...a huge improvement. Action can be stressful as taking down enemies isn't as easy as just shooting them as wasting ammo will leave you vulnerable. The animations of the enemies is so advanced now that hitting a head shot feels special and you'll want to hit them, not for a one shot kill, but for a slight knockback...Blocking/defending is also more relevant now. Once you block you can press the button again to push the enemy away with a kick and a shove. Again, worthwhile learning this one early on as it becomes integral within combat to stay safe, save ammo and place your shots in the right places!The story is OK and the characters are interesting. Classic Resi Evil really...far fetched but well done...Turns into a real journey once you hit the 4-5 hour mark...it's paced well with the beats in gameplay changing at the right times as well as good upgrades/weapon goals...Performance is good, it runs a lot better than RE7 did upon release. I've got an old i5 processor and a GTX980Ti and I've got most of the settings on high. No frame drops or pauses to be seen anywhere!!I've put this review to "Not recommended" as they locked third person view behind DLC. Disgusting practise! These games would sell even better if these extra quests and view changes were unlockable during gameplay. This has also been repeated for the recent RE4 release with unnecessary DLC. Capcom would get a lot of respect and even more cash in the longrun if it stopped this. I will always buy RE games in a sale until it stops...Pleasantly surprised but the DLC should have been part of the main game.7/10

I thought Resident Evil: Village was immersive and continued an ongoing great story. The combat was fast paced (enough for me anyway) and more than acceptable mechanically. The puzzles were pretty easy for the most part, but fun. Overall, I really enjoyed the game!  I've not played the DLC yet with Rose. I'm not really a fan of 3rd person, it breaks the immersion for me, but I imagine I will get around to playing it and add to my post.

I started Resident Evil 8: Village on it's release date in 2021. I finished it the nearly 2 years later. Just one day before the RE4 Remake comes out. It took me 2 years and multiple restarts with giant gaps between play sessions. It probably doesn't seem like I love Resident Evil 8...but I do love Resident Evil 8.I can't entirely explain how i got so distracted so many times but every time I sat down to play this game i had an absolute blast and yet I didn't come back for some time. Resident Evil 8 is not particularly scary...at all really. I mean there's that one level that everyone talks about. It's spooky once. I certainly jumped a few times but none of this game really scared me. RE8 is very campy horror. It's fun horror but maybe that's why it's so fun. I love the aesthetic of horror even when it doesn't scare me.Resident Evil 8 is also not particularly challenging. This is one of the easiest RE games i've ever played. Resource management isn't really a thing. Maybe on the higher difficulties and maybe i'll try those some day but i barely died in this game. Barely ever ran out of ammo. Not that you can't instantly craft more with your bottomless crafting inventory. It's not ideal but it's in no way a deal breaker for me. The shooting is fun and the enemies are fun to shoot. I'm not complaining. So what worked for me if the game wasn't scary and the gameplay didn't challenge me? Just being in this world. It's just fun. The 4 antagonists are a lot of fun with huge personalities and their own personal domains. Each sporting a different campy horror theme. 2 of them clearly have more love given than the others. So basically you have 2 well crafted villain domains and the other 2 are shorter set piece driven sections. That's where the Village itself comes in. It's ever expanding as a sort of central hub that you keep returning to. Sporting more treasure and threats every time you return to it. So besides the charm of the setting, themes and villains the other part that really worked for me was the story and Ethan Winter's himself. As a Father the story of village really effected me way more than it would have a few years ago. I know it's become a meme to make fun of Ethan but he's easily my favorite RE protagonist. Sure he's goofy and arguably kind of stupid sometimes but he's an every man. A dad who will do anything to save his daughter. I unironically love his cheesy trash talk that he spits out every time he takes out a big enemy. "Hell yeah brother! Tell em!" His insults are hilariously tone deaf and sometimes unnecessarily nasty and they never ceased to make me laugh or sometimes they just buffed my ego. Give me Ethan Winters over Chris Redfield any day. Village currently still has Overwhelmingly Positive reviews on steam and I remember people being super positive on it when it came out but recently the discourse seems to have soured on it significantly. Not so for me. It certainly doesn't fit with old school RE games in terms of tone or themes but when you reach the 8th mainline game in a series (more if you include all the remakes and spinoffs) you have to reinvent yourself. Without this new direction and the remakes I doubt the series would still be going this strong. I love the og RE titles and we can have both but for my money I'd prefer Resident Evil to keep being this Horror Bio Weapon Anthology series over the endless "evil corporation with zombies vs 80's action movie characters" thing. Keep being weird and keep being fun and that's all i can really ask for.

Resident Evil: Village is a very successful horror game that does an excellent job in many areas.
The structure of the game world is strong, both in the atmosphere that is always created and in the way in which the different parts of the world are connected through the village.
The structure is also good in the story, where the player finds out bit by bit what is going on.
The game has a good balance between wandering, puzzles and action.
If you're on the Resident Evil train, this is another tour de force, and if you're not, it's a surprisingly welcoming place to start.
The game enjoys its tone and delivers an Eastern European nightmare world that's an absolute blast to play whether you're sneaking with caution or shooting live.

The recent iterations have turned Resident Evil from an enjoyable horror-inflected (but still relatively cartoonish) adventure series to the gritty experience adult gamers have been craving, thanks mainly to the phenomenal visual and sound design.

This game is really a mixed bag. If there was a "meh" option regarding recommendation, I would choose that. In hindsight, I don't really think RE is the right franchise to do Gothic horror. I think Capcom creating a new IP for something like this would've made more sense. Granted, the artistry and world design of this game is top notch, but I feel like its existence doesn't really build upon any of the cool setup that 7 did and it doesn't really add anything overall in terms of story. 

The combat, while better than 7's, feels pretty middle of the road. I suppose the best comparison you could make would be with Resi4, but enemies are nowhere near as responsive to gunshots/attacks. The combat almost feels like padding in between Village's various set pieces, which are pretty memorable to be fair. I don't think this is a bad choice for people who are new to the franchise. If you want a resident evil game that's a bit heavier on action and less anxiety inducing, Village, Resi4, and Resi5 (if you can put up with co-op) aren't bad options. However, if you're a classic RE fan and are looking to get back into the series, I'd play 7 or wait a few days for Resi4 remake to come out.

Despite my reservations with First Person Shooter Resident Evil (not including the bewildered survivor series), this is the defacto evolution and sequel to RE7 that enhances a lot from Ethan Winter's first journey to Biohazards. The gameplay despite being noticeable as gimmicky and a few shortcomings, makes a stellar weekend play, goes balls to the walls crazy (Have you seen the factory?) and full on finishes the sage of Ethan with an excellent finale. The gameplay and some levels are the more apparent issues but don't detract the experience. A worthy buy specially on discount. Although I feel the Original and not Gold is more worth your while, unless you want the Shadows of Rose DLC.

---

It's been an up and down for me since I've started continuing to play the RE series. Been playing up to RE5, then recently started with RE2/RE3 remake (which were brilliant), then played RE6 and RE7 - but had to drop both mid-game as I didn't feel like it was the RE that I liked/loved.

RE6 suffered from non-stop action fueled testicle and liver smoothie generator.
RE7 suffered from identity crisis followed by looking for inspiration from popular first-person horror games.

RE6 I could never recommend.
RE7 I concede is a great game and I do recommend, yet it wasn't for me.

RE8 tho? Fuck me, that was one of my Top RE games if not the top game. I'm glad I didn't play on release since the newest DLC added a third-person option. You know, I'm not 100% sure but I personally feel like first-person horror comes with the knowledge that whatever happens to scare you - it'll happen in your viewpoint. Like when you're going down a hallway, you always can expect something coming in front of you. With third-person you're much more likely to see your surroundings (similar like in Real Life since you're usually not looking through a tunnel but can see shit happening at your side (peripheral view)), maybe appreciate more details and be prepared for *anything* and not just whatever comes in front of you.

Despite VIIIage not being designed for but as a afterthought for third-person, it was a delight still. The level design was superb, I almost felt like playing RE4 back again (Can't wait for the remake of RE4 soon). The story was very good, and questions over questions were eventually answered at the end, as you're thrown into a village with little to know except to survive. Boss fights felt more like the usual RE style - you can shoot your way, but still needed sometimes a thing or two to activate to be able to do weaken it. 

There's also an addition which I usually don't like in other games, but was executed well: Mini-Bosses.

The range of weapons is great, however, I do not know why it was considered necessary to introduce you the same weapon type over and over again with a new model which has its base power well over your modified/upgraded weapon you already possess. It almost makes you feel stupid for solving puzzles finding upgrades when it becomes obsolete in 1-2 hours by a new one...

Resident Evil Village is a very good game & I am not even close to unhappy with the game.

Village, being the 8th main installment in the RE franchise follows Ethan Winters a few years after the events of Resident Evil 7, and it is a good continuation of the Winters' family & their story.

I have been getting into Resident Evil recently, starting with 7, as I know the franchise is really good & I really want to be into it now. After finishing the freak-horrorshow that was Resident Evil 7, my next game was of course Village. RE Village is not nearly as scary as the previous entry but it does not suffer from that, it still has its scares of course, but it is not near the amount as 7. There is one specific area (that I won't name to not spoil!) that is very scary, not exactly the level as RE7, but quite close.

The main big bosses of Village are very different from one another, but are one big family! You will definitely enjoy meeting this odd group of siblings, and their mother.

The game begins with your baby daughter, Rosemary Winters, being taken to an unknown place. This happens with an intense sequence of events that will be especially shocking to players who successfully completed RE7 and saw the ending. Many things happen until you find yourself walking a very dark, cold and snowy path in the woods. How you got here? I won't tell, but you'll see. It's intense. This path leads you to a Village of course, and your quest begins there: Find Rose. It's an intense ride, and Ethan Winters surely wasn't prepared.

Before witnessing the terror within this mysterious Village, I highly highly recommend you play it's direct predecessor, RESIDENT EVIL 7. There, you will learn all about Ethan Winters himself, his wife Mia Winters, and the journey that led them to this point. That game is a roller-coaster of horror and you will love it, I am sure.

Both RE7 and Village don't connect too much with previous entries in the franchise, as 7 was a soft-reboot of sorts, but you should definitely still play the rest! You witness great terror, many catastrophes and a great cast of characters, all fighting to rid the world of bioweapons.
This game has one returning character: Chris Redfield! He's a lovable character and usually the hero, but he seems to be much more dark and brooding here... just look at that cover art!

Village was a great experience for me and I can't help but love it. I am really hoping you will too.

Well, the game got black boxes on top and bottom of the screen and when I move around my mouse to look ingame the cursor from windows shows up in those two boxes and it is extremely distracting. How has this game been out for 2 years and still not patched this issue?

[edit]

Yknow what my solution has become? Use adhesive putty, put it on the screen at top and bottom then use black lego pieces to cover the entire black sections so I don't see the mouse cursor when it goes there. This is inexcusably fucking incompetent on Capcom's behalf.

Anyway, I'm just gonna keep the negative train rolling cause they don't deserve less from this incompetence.

SPOILER WARNING GOING AHEAD

So when you get to this guy with a shotgun he is pulled by a wereman up into the attic and then blood comes down and after Ethan goes "say whaaaaat" a werearm shoot up through the floor and grabs onto your leg and pulls you into the root cellar or whatever below the house where a ton of bodies are stacked up. After moving about 3 feet another cutscene moment happens where a weremouth nibbles a few of your fingers and then throws you through a wall outside. When you kill the werewas you notice that the wall is destroyed. Ah, because YOU got thrown outside. Got it. Wait... I was in the basement... This hole leads to the kitchen where I got pulled down from. Wait... Why is there no hole in the floor? So let's recap. Me = Kitchen, first floor. Arm, pulls me through floor. Me = Basement. Thrown through wall = Outside. Outside perspective looking at the house, the wall that is destroyed leads to kitchen. Kitchen has no hole in the floor form where weredere pulled you down into.

What in the world is happening?

[edit2]

Right, so a few more things.

The werefolk surround you and get ready to kill you but then don't because they wanted a scene that would look cool but didn't want to commit as the game would obviously be over at that point and so then just have them scurry off because of plot armor.

Then you come across a field where some of them are still there and they reaaaally want to kill you. So why didn't some of them just stay behind previously to just kill you?

Anyway you come across a bunch of people and yknow what I hate in horror anything? When characters just exist solely for the reason to die. It's so boring. They introduce like 6 or something characters who wear their character on their sleeve and then just kill them off. And it's like, what was the point of that? Why even bother introducing characters that you're just gonna kill off? Why? Cause spectacle. At the end the girl who came with her father falls down into the fire and dies and you fail to save her and it's like they want the payoff of a great story moment while putting in the absolute bare minimum.

So you leave the burning house and can finally enter the castle.

Before I comment on that though.

The gameplay is inspired by REvil 4 but has none of the charm or variety. Remember how you could vault out of 2nd story windows? Or Even just 1st story windows? Can't here. Remember how you could shoot a fernando in the knee to make him drop down then dropkick his ass? Can't do that here. Remember how you had freedom of movement and could go up a ladder then when la puta comes climbing up you kick down the ladder? Can't do that here either. Also enemies are insanely damage spongy and unfun. And have fun with every hit on you being a little cutscene. That don't get old at all.

Anyway, you move on to the castle and the big bads have meeting which metal jesus brought you there for in chains and after an argument the biggest of bads says that metal jesus gets to deal with you and his solution for that is to send a bunch of weredads after you so he destroys the chain holding you down and then... Let's you go... So you run down a whole which is essentially just a ACTION MONTAGE HOLY COW THIS IS SO COOL AMIRITE that consists of you holding down the W key while occasionnaly using the interaction key for a roadblock. And at the end of it is a trap that is just... It has no reason to exist. Now I know REvil has had some silly traps before but I mean  it, this thing literally has no reason to exist at all. It is completely nonsensical for why this contraption exists at all in the space that it does. Again, it is just spectacle.

Finally, Ethan is insufferable to listen to. It's like they asked the writer for his dialogue to write commentary from his perspective on vague things that are happening so they had no idea what to make him actually say and they wouldn't have known what to say anyway cause they're not a writer, it's actually the janitor being asked to write dialogue. Ethan spots a crib in a house "what is THIS doing HERE!?!?!? O_o" Oh gee I dunno Ethan MAYBE OTHER PEOPLE THAN YOU HAVE FIGURE OUT THE CONCEPT OF PRODUCING SPAWN!!!!

We want to have it for the sake of having it: The Game.

It is a step up in term of boss battles and enemy variety and combat, but has less horror than RE7 overall. Except that one segment which is terrifying, beyond that other levels has quite a bit of combat. 

Story-wise it connects to previous RE games and leading toward RE 9 and has an excellent ending.

Other complains i have is The Mercenaries in RE Village. It's not the same as Mercenaries in RE4, RE5, RE6 as they are about surviving and making score until the time runs out. But in RE Village it's about knowing where the enemies will spawn and killing and keeping combo and run to the next area until the last enemy is killed. The reward for beating all mercenaries stages with SS rank is very weak and unsatisfying for the effort you need to put in to get it.

It's a pretty good game so i highly recommend it to anyone who is new to the series.

Note: the DLCs are for gun cosmetics, RE7 in-game screen effects and starting supplies. So you should only get it for cosmetics reason or supplies, the RE7 handgun isn't worth it. You can't upgrade it and it will be obsolete very soon into the game.

I've only played it about 30 minutes and turned it off, and my uninstall. 

My experience: 

I got the game because of the Steam Spring sale discount and had heard that the game was pretty fun. I installed it and started the game. The first thing that happened is that it gave me a Capcom popup dialog box asking me to agree to the statement that I needed a codec, but nothing happened prompting me to tell me where to get it or auto-download. The box looked like malware as it resembled something from Windows 3.1 or something. Then, after I clicked OK the game launched in Windowed mode and the game only took up about a quarter of the window. I thought something went wrong so I closed the game. Then I reopened it and it did it again minus the codec box. When it reopened it did the same thing again. I googled the issue and apparently it's a known issue. Really?! Capcom can't release a game that works correctly? Apparently you need to start the game in this weird mode and then adjust the settings to match your system, in 2023, WOW. I don't understand how it can't auto detect like every other game made today does. I went in and fixed all of the settings and got the game working. Major red flag. Then when I go to play the game I could only play for about 25 minutes or so before I got motion sickness. Huge disappointment, I wish I could return it.

10/10 game, doesn't try to be an horror like RE7 (which failed miserably at that for anyone that isn't a complete pussy and gets scared from 3mt tall black men), map is gigantic and filled with details and secrets, gunplay is very, very good and refined compared to RE7, story is good but becomes amazing in the final hour of the game and the finale contains a very small teaser for RE9. ---> Edit: (It actually was for the DLC lol)
The experiment capcom did by making a semi-open world game paid off and i can't wait for the sequel especially if it will have similiar gameplay and action, the only 2 things i didn't like much is that ethan does not raise his hand to open doors anymore but instead they just open automatically, also dimitrescu castle and the vampires could have had a much bigger role in the story but unfortunately they didn't last long and were mostly an intro to the game, still, the castle is beautiful and probably the most detailed part of the map.
Yes, good AAA game idk what to say. Decent gunplay and fun if you can buy on sale.
