I'm sure the game plays great when it works, but i wouldn't know because it performs terribly. The cut-scenes' audio and visuals are out of sync and the game lags so badly that the atmosphere is completely ruined.

This game is functionally fun with a pseudo decent story. The Lady Dimitrescu portion that everyone talks about is actually a very comparatively small portion to the rest of the game. It acts like RE2 while you are in the castle, but then goes for a more RE 4 vibe for the rest of the game. Some of the plot or character interactions don't make sense until the very end of the game, so if you have the patience stick with it. Be careful of flying through the game over screen if you die twice in an area because you can easily lower you difficulty by mistake and not realize it until everything around you is dying much easier. I was unable to find a way to raise the difficulty again. By the time I found out it lowered I was several hours further into the game. 

I would strongly recommend getting this game on one of its 50% off sales. I beat this game in 10 hours, others have reported as quick as 8. There is some unlockables and replayability, but it's not as tight and functional as 2 was. You will spend a lot of time running from point A to point B to get the next section started. 

It may sound like I'm dunking on this game, and I am a bit, but for all it's biased faults it's a very pretty and functional horror game. Get it on sale and don't expect too much and you'll have fun.

So I haven't played Resident Evil in awhile, I haven't played Biohazard and the story of this game seems to be really dependent on having played Biohazard.

Story wise I found the game a bit frustrating, there were some odd decisions like making Chris a total dick when he totally owes you an explanation, and dancing around some basic questions that could have been answered earlier. 

The game play its self is very well done, even if it doesn't exactly reinvent the wheel on anything, its a very standard FPS game with some survival horror thrown in. 

Performance wise it plays great. I had most of the important graphic settings either maxed of close to max and the game played without a hitch. The graphic settings also has a nice feature that shows how much Vram you will be using on the graphics card so you can dial in your needs and not crash your system.

Overall it's an enjoyable game, my only fault being that story wise it's a bit obtuse and depends a lot on you finding notes to help fill in the numerous questions you will be asking yourself.

I can not believe what I am seeing. It feels like my eyes are playing tricks on me but no, it's legit. I had my FPS counter up the entire time to confirm I wasn't crazy.

In short, this game runs like f*cking butter. Holy sh*t it is so, so smooth. Rock solid 144 FPS in my 3 hours of playing (at the time of this review) and it never dipped once. Not even from gameplay to cutscene transitions (which is typically when FPS dips occur), or even when moving from one area of a map to the next (another common offender of FPS stutters). 

I am nowhere even close to finishing the game but the performance alone gets a thumbs up from me. It's extremely rare I say that in this day and age with all the god awful PC ports constantly being released. I do recall hearing back when this game originally launched that there were performance issues regarding how Denuvo was implemented or something along those lines. So, I came into this game wary and with expectations tempered. Either it was fixed or those FPS drops only affected a small selection of people. Regardless, as it stands this game is unbelievably well optimized. 

I got this game for sale along with RE7 for roughly 60 bucks and that includes the gold edition of both of them. If you were like me and got any of those 2 games on sale, they are an absolutely steal. Yes I recommend Resident Evil: Village, it is fantastic. May or may not come back to update this review when I finish the game but like I mentioned before, the performance is so good it gets a thumbs up from me regardless.

Alright 10 hours later I have finished the main game and everything I wrote before still applies. There were a couple instances where the FPS would dip for a second but those instances were so rare it doesn't matter. It's not like I expect games to run flawlessly 100% of the time without any single hiccups. This game still runs like a dream and is an absolute blast to play. 

In comparison to RE: Biohazard, this game is a little less scary in favour of more action. Not necessarily a bad thing depending on how you view it, but something to think about. I personally didn't mind and found the wide arsenal of guns and the implementation of a shop system quite a fun departure from what was done in 7. 

I really liked how each antagonist had their own area and theme surrounding said area. The game has a village in the middle and surrounding it are 4 areas that each of the lords occupy. Beneviento's was my personal favourite, though it was shorter than I expected. For a roughly 10 hour game there is a surprising amount to do and see. It certainly felt much longer than 10 hours and it's one of those games where it's so good you wish there was more. However, it's easy to miss collectibles and with the game's challenges system, it incentivizes repeat playthroughs.  

On the topic of playthroughs, I finished my first game on standard difficulty. Definitely consider ramping up the difficulty if you're considering doing more playthroughs because at that point you are familiar with the game's systems and layout. I think I can count on one hand how many times I died in this game on my first playthrough. That is certainly a byproduct of the game giving you lots of resources during combat, but it's also a testament to how well the game gives instructions. There's plenty of chase sequences and puzzles to solve where it's not like my ammo or guns would even matter in those scenarios. But the game does an excellent job of nudging you on the right path to take when you're being pursued, or dropping subtle hints when trying to piece together clues to solve a puzzle. 

So I had a very smooth and pleasant experience with this game. Certainly part of it was the abundance of resources, but also the game itself just does a really good job of guiding the player without frustrating them. I could have all the ammo and healing in the world but if I kept dying to some chase sequence or stuck in a room for an hour it would be a very different discussion. None of this is to imply that the game is boringly easy or anything like that, it's just a solid experience all around and it strikes that perfect middle ground of challenging but fair.

In short, Resident Evil: Village is fantastic and I recommend it to anyone who isn't afraid to try some survival horror.

So it will sit in the menu while I scroll mindlessly on my phone. I maaay finish the achievements, eventually, that's just a compulsorily thing, but I can't help feeling like this is the weakest addition to the series, imo.

Resident Evil Village is an excellent, well - paced, and tense continuation of Ethan Winter's endeavors to yet again rescue another member of his immediate family. Having played Village immediately after completing Resident Evil 7, The Ethan Winters Saga came to a meaningful and satisfying close (albeit with enough unanswered questions to allow the series to continue). 

      From the onslaught, Village's excellent presentation in terms of visuals and audio design is impeccable. Story moments are immersive due to the superb animation, made possible by motion capture technology. Furthermore, Each member apart of the wide cast of characters was performed exceptionally by their respective actors, especially by that of the four lords. Enemy encounters and atmosphere are made far more tense due to the great audio design, allowing for needed tension and horror to build when needed. The variety of environments in which this game takes place in also add to the experience, in areas such as Victorian Castle Dimitrescu, the dilapidated Village, and Heisenberg's underground factory. The level of detail and polish that went into each of the environments by the team at Capcom is phenomenal, made possible by the latest version of the RE engine. 

      Combat this time around, when compared to Resident Evil 7, is the forefront of the experience. The gunplay is satisfying and fairly balanced overall, although continue to expect enemies to act as "bullet sponges", a staple of the resident evil franchise. Ammunition and weapon variety is increased considerably over Resident Evil 7, allowing for a more action - oriented experience. As a direct result of this, enemy encounters are less scary this time around, mostly due to the fact that they can be easily disposed of due to the emphasis on combat. Moreover, the jarring nature of many of the enemies found throughout the game also become less tense as the experience progresses, as you will see many of the same enemies due to the lack of variety. This was an issue with Resident Evil 7 as well, although this is a minor gripe. Furthermore, boss encounters are a delight and a considerable leap forward from Resident Evil 7, having mitigated the use of weak points which I find quite basic. Each combat encounter is still fairly streamlined and simple however, allowing for the game to progress at a fairly quick rate. The difficulty can be increased, to the extent of the inclusion of "Village of Shadows" which in itself is a much more challenging means to play the game. 

      Post launch content has been a treat as well, due to the likes of "Shadows of Rose" DLC, the expansion of the mercenaries mode, VR support, third person perspective, and more. This further adds to the replay value of Village, although this has always been a given for most Resident Evil titles. 

      Overall, I have had an incredible experience with Resident Evil Village and look foward to see what the team at Capcom will continue to with the Resident Evil Franchise! I thoroughly recommend!

I really enjoyed my time playing and beating Resident Evil Village, a game that was heavily inspired by Resident Evil 4, taking on the Role of Ethan Winter's who's daughter Rosemary Winter's is kidnapped and taken to a near by Village, and it's up to Ethan to rescue Rose and bring her home safely, but turns into a Nightmare that'll be his END!

If you didn't know in Resident Evil 7, Ethan Winter's actually died when he first arrived at the Baker Family estate, when he was fighting his Wife Mia Winter's who has been turned, and controlled by the Mold that Mother Miranda has been experimenting with!  Yes, you heard right, when Jack Baker came from behind Ethan, that stomp to the head actually killed Ethan, but the mold consumed his body and recreated him, which is why Ethan can literally take a beating!

When this game was announced to the Public with Teasers, and Teaser Demo's, we thought Resident Evil 7 was the big deal, no, Resident Evil Village had taken a bigger step forward, and taken all the Graphical design and inspiration from RE4, and turned it into a Hellish Nightmare you won't forget!  This games Visuals are Outstanding!  The first Teaser Trailer we saw, wow, we had no idea what was being made.

I remember finishing off Mother Miranda in that last epic battle, I thought I wasn't gonna be able to finish, but I did it.  Apparently head shots with a sniper rifle do a ton of damage to Mother Miranda, so I just kept shooting her in the head, and I done did IT!

Game is Fantastic and you should DEFINITELY play this game, and also the Upcoming Resident Evil 4 Remake, soon to be upon us.

Resident Evil Village is a great entry to the series. It leans more into action from the beginning than Resident Evil 7 while still having some quality spooky areas. I definitely recommend Village, and it is a great blend of RE4 and RE7.

---DLC---
Shadow of Rose is a nice short 3 hour campaign while adding additional content to the Mercenaries mode. At this point you should probably just be buying the Gold edition so "should I buy the DLC" is somewhat irrelevant. It's quality but $17 on sale for essentially just a 3 hour story is a little steep given that I got the base game for $24 which is much more replayable. You do also get a 3rd person camera for the main campaign but I personally didn't have any issues with the first person view. Overall, it's worth it if you want more time with RE8 and definitely a bit more of a horror focused campaign.

How many franchises have survived so many drastic changes, rebirths, reincarnations, remasters, remakes to come out once again with such an outstanding piece of work? I can't recall one. Resident Evil Village is when you combine two of the best original games in the series (4 and 7) and do an extraordinary work on game design. The location, the village with its castles and secrets looks stunning and arguably one of my favourites. The story and the drama of the characters living here is of interest. Another masterpiece of CAPCOM.

Resident Evil Village is exactly what you get when taking the more successful aspects of former games and combining them into one truly remarkable experience. It is tense, terrifying, and exhilarating game and while you may not always like one or two parts of the game, there is surely a scenario or two that will be a standout as one of your lifelong best gaming experiences. While it does not always do its best to tell its story, the story we do get is engaging and heartfelt and surely deserves its place as one of the best Resident Evil games.

I know there is now a PSVR2 version of this game that slaps, so that is fantastic. Thankfully there is no RE8 3rd party VR mod that does the same thing as the PSVR2 version, because this hypothetical mod could hypothetically cut into the Playstation 5 profits (I would have bought a PS5 but Sony made it impossible to buy one for the first 2 years after its release, which was a huge slap in the face to every loyal consumer on the planet), but if this mod did exist, I would say it was an amazing experience and shouldn't be missed by anyone with a really beefy computer.

During his time at Capcom, Shinji Mikami created two great things - survival horror with the classic RE, and its reimagining with RE4. It's been almost 20 years now Capcom is exploiting these concepts, again and again. To the point that if you played RE4, you played Village as well:

Dirty village? Check
Majestic castle? Check
Modern factory? Check
Boat and giant fish boss? Check
Weapon upgrades? Check
Finding and combining treasures? Check
Shooting chicken for stuff? Check
and the list goes on

All that, to an extent, would not be a problem if Village was a good RE4. It isn't.

1) Setting. It's no secret that RE came to be heavily associated with Raccoon City, Umbrella, and zombies - to the point of everything that came later seen as heresy. That said, RE4's Ganados were pretty much "zombies with weapons" so it worked well. However, Village throws in too many stuff that feels like it belongs in a different game - including vampires, werewolves and scary dolls.

2) Combat. There is not much difference to where you shoot anymore, you won't be crippling or disarming your enemies, they merely get staggered every 3rd shot so the combat feels much less nuanced and a step back on the whole. The weapons likewise lack nuance and each new one is simply a straight upgrade over the previous one, even with all the improvements - making the system superficial. 

3) Identity crisis. There are generally two kinds of horror games - in first, you are a weak schoolgirl with no or barely any weapons and the fear factor comes from the fact any engagement might prove fatal; in second, you're a spec ops with a machine gun and you're only ever scared of one thing - running out of ammo. Village tries to be both at the same time, and it doesn't work. The segment where your weapons are taken away and you spend about an hour solving puzzles and hiding in closets from a giant monster feels super disconnected from the rest of the game - the existince of this segment alone is enough to discourage replayability.

4) Pacing. Which is all over the place. It starts slowly, with village itself serving as a prologue/tutorial. The Castle, first actual area, is everything you'd expect from a RE game - action packed, fun puzzles, memorable characters, decent lengh. In contrast, House Beneviento and Reservoir are fairly short and straight to the point. And when you're already tired and are ready to watch the credits, the game throws a lengthy tedious labyrinth called the Factory at you. Imagine if Resident Evi 1/2l's laboratories were longer than the mansion and the police station respectively, and you'll see what I'm getting at. 

5) First person. I only got Village after discovering they added a third person view, but to be honest - it's not good, definitely not what the game was designed for. The Mercenaries mode is still first person only, giving me heavy PS1-era Biohazard Gun Survivor vibes, and that's not a compliment.

TL;DR Village tries to copy RE4's successful formula, but feels underwhelming in the most core aspects and as just a clone in the others.

Resident Evil Village is a game that's not to be missed. Its stunning visuals and immersive storyline will keep you hooked from start to finish. The characters are well-crafted, each with their own unique backstory and personality, and the voice acting is top-notch, adding to the overall immersive experience of the game.


The gameplay is a perfect mix of action, exploration, and puzzle-solving that will keep you on your toes. The combat system is smooth and intuitive, making it easy to take down enemies. The exploration aspect of the game is also great, with hidden secrets and items waiting to be uncovered throughout the village. The puzzles are challenging but not overly difficult, adding to the overall enjoyment of the game.


The storyline is one of the standout features of Resident Evil Village. It's engaging, suspenseful, and full of unexpected twists and turns that will keep you on the edge of your seat. The game also pays homage to previous Resident Evil games, making it a must-play for long-time fans of the series.


The variety of enemies that players face is another great aspect of the game. From werewolves to vampires, each enemy requires a different strategy to defeat, adding to the overall challenge of the game. The boss battles are also well-designed, with each one providing a unique challenge that requires players to use their skills and weapons to their fullest potential.


In conclusion, Resident Evil Village is a must-play game for anyone who loves action, exploration, and puzzle-solving games. Its stunning graphics, immersive storyline, and well-designed characters make it a game that's not to be missed. So, if you're looking for a thrilling and suspenseful game, then Resident Evil Village is definitely worth checking out.

Resident Evil 8 is a unique take on the Resident Evil formula by having it attempt to try to mesh together both aspects from Resident Evil 7 and Resident Evil 4. However it fails to bring many of the aspects that made those games great. It fails to make a genuinely scary or survival experience that was seen in Resident Evil 7. It also fails to bring back the expansive combat or replayability that was in Resident Evil 4. If you're looking for a Resident Evil experience, you'll definitely find it here, just don't expect anything too revolutionary or groundbreaking. Definitely worth checking out on sale.

[h1]One of the best [strike]horny[/strike] horror game in 2021! ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)[/h1]

If you enjoyed [b]Resident Evil 4[/b] and [b]Resident Evil 7 Biohazard[/b], you'll most likely enjoy [b]Resident Evil Village[/b] too. When [b]Capcom[/b] first announced [b]Resident Evil Village[/b], I was both excited and enthusiastic about to play because I'm one of [b]Resident Evil[/b] fan and I love all [b]Resident Evil[/b] games and movies.

The characters in this game are really fantastic and so well done. And the graphics are very detailed and unbelievably good. I was absolutely astounded by how amazing [b]Lady Dimitrescu[/b]’s castle looked in particular, whilst the entire village was hauntingly beautiful. And exploring the village and all the other places in [b]Resident Evil Village[/b] is so exciting and enjoying and the unique twist of having 4 Powerful Lords and [b]Mother Miranda[/b] as the main villain and the [b]Megamycete[/b].

The twist of this game connecting all the [b]Resident Evil[/b] games to it as because the virus and the mold originated in the village is also cool and the rest is for you to find out. First person perspective is also nice yet. I don't know why some players don't like first person perspective. Since [b]Resident Evil 7 Biohazard[/b], some players don't like to play in first person perspective. For me it's really perfect with that type of horror game.

Weapons, combat and fights are also well made and worth it. The merchant named [b]The Duke[/b] is also really helpful and has more options. The enemies are more unique and had their own abilities and difficulties than [b]Resident Evil 7 Biohazard[/b] or some other [b]Resident Evil[/b] games. The gameplay was similar to [b]Resident Evil 7 Biohazard[/b] but [b]Resident Evil Village[/b] added a lots more customizations.

The boss fights are also amazing and having more boss fights than [b]Resident Evil 7 Biohazard[/b] and it's also strangely a bit easy to beat. The puzzles are also unique and vary in different special ways. But can be straightforward and easy to hint though.

The scares and horrors also are both terrifying and awesome, with unexpected jump scares, adrenaline, and the horrific aura while exploring, never knowing what, when, where or how it will happen. The idea of making this a survival horror game is nice yet overly focused. The depth and information behind all characters are well described and shown here, especially for [b]Ethan Winters[/b], [b]Lady Dimitrescu[/b], [b]Mother Miranda[/b] and some but some are still missing and left for the next game or for us to find.

The Mercenaries mode and the other gameplay modes is also cool and even having the models of each character, items and enemies in the game which you can buy is also a good concept. The music and soundtracks in this game are really unique and awesome. The story concept for the intro and credits is also unique and I feels I got [b]Tim Burton[/b] and [b]Coraline[/b] vibes from it.

The cutscenes and acts are really pretty amazing. And all the items, treasures, weapons and crafted products are all still goodly unique. And the gameplay feels a lot smoother too. The optimization is good enough on the launch day and no bugs or anything while playing.

And The voice actors also did a great job and the story, plots and overall are amazingly good and memorable. For me, honestly [b]Resident Evil Village[/b] is one of the best survival horror game with amazing story. I absolute recommend for players who like to play horror games with amazing story. I believe that everyone should play this amazing horror game with good storyline.

Thank You :)

This is exactly what Capcom intended to make the franchise play and feel like with the recent games. It uses horror as a theme and to spice up the pacing, but this is action heavy Resident Evil made today and made well. Playing it on Hardcore make me finish multiple bossfights on my last magazine of ammunition. Learning the dance of combat with Ethan's loadout and blocking mechanic felt like what 7's gameplay always wanted to become. The story is back to being batshit insane half the time, and desperately trying to be a corny, but amazing, action movie. Which is weird, because I think Resident Evil is better at being an action movie than anything I've seen at a theater.

I loved how fast this game moved through it's setpieces, and how the opening immediately beats the shit out of you to establish that action focus. How the early game plays compared to the late game is the most Resident Evil progression imaginable.

Spoilers below:

[spoiler] Chris Redfield in this game is the best rendition of him there is. His section finally bringing back that late 4 and 5 action is probably very surprising to people who have only came from 7, but this game really ties everything into the Chris Redfield side of Resident Evil. He is still kinda dumb and blunt as he should be, but it seems like the extra layer of intimidation and efficiency is where he would realistically be in the canon at this point. Steamrolling everything that gave Ethan trouble with a tricked out AK and a squad that blows every recent Tom Clancy game out of the water in cool factor is perfectly Chris. [/spoiler]


This game does tie into the greater Resident Evil lore, and you will be sort of confused about who Chris Redfield is without the previous knowledge of the games. If you haven't played 7, then you are missing an even bigger chunk. This is a direct sequel to 7 if you didn't figure that out yet.

But still, especially from a gameplay standpoint, this does kind of stand on its own if you get accustomed to the suspension of disbelief that RE asks of you quickly. Holy fuck, is this a well put together, good looking, good playing, and fun video game. I've started using the newer Resident Evil games as a view into the lost future of AAA games being actually good, and I will continue to do so.

There are some big issues with the plot and some rough spots in the writing, but that's nothing new for the franchise.

Capcom literally took the best parts of RE4 and RE7 to create this perfection.

Resident Evil Village is a wonderful survival horror adventure game that includes shooting, exploration, puzzles and inventory management.
Most of the action takes place in an isolated village in Eastern Europe, in Romania, but you will also visit a beautiful castle, a house of horror, a water reservoir, a metal factory and more.
The characters look amazing and boss-fights are exciting, my favourite is probably a fight against Moreau.
The music and graphics are really nice, the game is also well optimized.
The story can be a bit confusing but you will figure it all out in the end, especially if you don't skip the lore files.

Resident Evil Village exceeded my expectations and provided a fun and thrilling experience.
I recommend you to try it out, but it is advised you play RE7 first.

The story is a little meh in the beginning because of the lack of detail Chris gives you later to find out that he totally could've told you why he did what he did from the start. Other than that the game play is pretty good and the level designs are unique. The DLC was a fantastic addition where you get to play as Ethan's daughter and her play style is refreshing and in 3rd person. The DLC also included the 3rd person mode for the original game as well. The game is optimized to get the most out of your GPU and the graphics menu lets you see the changes based on the graphical options you select but I didn't see a benchmark test option in there. I give the game an 8/10 it lost 2 points with info unnecessarily withheld from your main character and because this game had a few missed opportunities to be scarier. RE7 had lots more scarier moments than this game in my opinion. All in all it's a great buy.

Resident Evil 7 is a thrilling and immersive first-person shooter that revitalizes the Resident Evil franchise, and brings it back to its roots. This game is a masterclass in horror, from the tense atmosphere to the grotesque enemies that players face throughout the game.

One of the most impressive things about Resident Evil 7 is how it manages to balance horror with action. It's not just about shooting enemies, but also about exploring the environment, solving puzzles, and uncovering the dark secrets of the game's story. The pacing is perfect, with moments of intense action interspersed with quieter moments that allow players to catch their breath and take in the eerie atmosphere.

The graphics in Resident Evil 7 are stunning, and the game's attention to detail is truly impressive. The environment is richly detailed, and the character models are both realistic and terrifying. The game's sound design is also exceptional, with every creak and groan of the dilapidated mansion adding to the overall sense of dread and unease.

Another thing that makes Resident Evil 7 so great is its focus on exploration. There are plenty of secrets to uncover in the game, and players are rewarded for taking their time and thoroughly exploring each area. This gives the game a real sense of depth and replayability, as players will want to revisit certain areas to uncover every last secret.

Overall, Resident Evil 7 is an amazing game that showcases the direction that the Resident Evil franchise should be heading in. The game's first-person perspective adds a level of immersion that was missing in the previous games, and the horror and action elements are perfectly balanced. This game is a must-play for anyone who loves horror games, and it's a sign that the Resident Evil franchise is in good hands moving forward.

The game itself is excellent. I am enjoying playing it, and probably will continue enjoying it.

But the lack of an FOV slider is a massive step back for the franchise in terms of accessibility and player experience. I had to download a third-party tool (which breaks the sniper scope zoom-in btw) to avoid getting motion sickness. Apparently there used to be a fully functioning mod for fixing the FOV, but the game has since been patched and this no longer works.

Aside from the FOV issue, there are a few other things that just scream rushed PC port to me. Weird default key mapping. Awkward map/inspect controls. Clumsy inventory management. It is glaringly obvious that the game was built with controllers in mind and keyboard controls were a complete afterthought. It's so strange to me that they slipped up here considering RE7 and the remakes did not really have these problems.

The game is not bad, but PC m&k players deserve better treatment than this. Shameful.

VERY IMPORTANT: I would highly recommend to play RE 7, before RE 8. The whole story is absolutely worth it and the ending will hit even harder.

Prelude:
Although RE:2 and the RE remake for Dreamcast are my favourite REs, Resident Evil 7 blew me away. 
The horror was real, the jumpscares were perfectly placed, and the story was great. At first I really disliked the setting, but after 1 hour, I was hooked and loved every minute (except Mia, I just hate Mia. She is a borderline stereotype and I wouldn't be surprised if she was a cheerleader in High School. Still liked her chapter in RE 7, though, storywise). 

Now, let's get to RE Village.

Pro:
- Combined with the amazing RE 7 (which was better for me) it gives you one of the best storylines in the RE universe
- The ending surprises and breaks your heart at the same time.
- The scenery and landscape is eye pleasing and has a lot of different settings
- The graphics overall look great
- There are a lot of secrets to discover, and you will happily hunt down every one, because it will boost your dmg output by a LOT
- The game is hard (I like difficult games)
- The gameplay feels good, although running (especially away from enemies) feels a bit clunky.
- The upgradable weapons and abilities made me search every possible secret location. Worth it!

Cons:
- The game is hard. Even though I like difficult games, at certain points, the enemies are down right bullet sponges just for the sake of it.
- Lazy enemy design at some points througout the game (see above).
- Mia
- The game is less horror and more shooter, which I dislike. I love RE for the horror, not for 360 noscope lycans
- The enemies were too much fantasy for me. Werewolfs, giants, teleporting vampires. It was all a little bit too far away from beeing explainable with a "virus" or "mold". 
- Some bossfights are just annoying, at least on hard (Bullet sponge problem).

Verdict:
Overall I have to say that RE 8 is worse than RE 7 for me. RE 7 was way more horrifying than RE 8. Nevertheless, the game was still very fun to play through and, well, the ending was such a blast.

Graphics ok, though shadows are too dark even in rooms with light sources. Sound = good. FOV = stupid. I've played an hour and I hate that stupidly narrow FOV that cannot be adjusted. I'm done. No more CAPCOM games for me. Sure, it can be modded, but it shouldn't have to.

[h1]Resident Evil Village[/h1]

With the success of Resident Evil 7 Biohazard, a upcoming sequel was practically guaranteed. Resident Evil Village continues the survival horror line of recent Resident Evil games by combining the survival horror properties of RE7 with fast paced aspects taken from RE4 to make this a critically successful title in the franchise.

[u]Story + Characters (Possible Spoilers!)[/u]

[spoiler]The story of Resident Evil Village takes place a little over three years after the events of RE7 and is set in Romania. Ethan and his family were relocated under Chris' orders to protect their existence from the public (and unsavory organizations) after the events of RE7, but when Mia is killed by Chris and Rosemary, Ethan's infant daughter, is kidnapped, his chase leads to a nearby deserted village where Ethan's search begins.[/spoiler]

[spoiler]I found much of the story's structure well-constructed and interesting thanks to Ethan's individuality as a more fleshed out character instead of the self-insert image he held in RE7 and the neopagan cult that was prominent within the village. Ethan is a much more relatable and compelling character in which he is basically the best father ever and is also more composed for someone who has faced BOWs already. The village in relation to the cult is an idea that goes as far back as RE4 and it does okay here, although not much is done with it outside of some files and one cutscene with the last remaining human villagers.[/spoiler]

[spoiler]For other characters, they're all great but I think they could have been given more screentime. For example, the Four Lords: Lady D, Donna, Moreau, and Heisenberg. Outside of one scene, they never make contact with each other ever again and are exclusively tied to their respective set pieces. I was expecting Lady D to be more of an overall threat through the game due to how much trailer time she got, but she's done and over with after the Castle section. It's the same case for the other lords (Donna and Moreau especially). Miranda is the most obvious one with this issue; outside the one scene you see her along with the Four Lords, Ethan and Miranda never have encounters with each other until near the end of the game - hell, Ethan barely acknowledges her existence until she actually appears before him as Mia after killing Heisenberg. As for Chris, I was already not buying the possible heel turn from the most iconic RE character into a villain when the trailers came out and of course, the subversion was there. I'm all up for seeing Chris, but there were times where I felt like there was no reason for him [b]not[/b] to explain everything to Ethan early on or to act hostile towards him so it just feels contrived.[/spoiler]

[u]Gameplay[/u]

The gameplay is similar to RE7 except it's now built for much faster pacing. There are more enemies thrown at you, albeit with more ammo drops, you're given a lot more leeway to your movement, and you can now push back enemies after you successfully block their attacks. There are set pieces here like the first village fight which reference parts of RE4 that are still fun and challenging to play through. Monsters range from Lycans to the Cadou-powered Soldats in the Factory, but it's too bad some of the enemies are derived from the common enemy type in terms of design. Despite its similarity to RE7, it's still a very solid and enjoyable gameplay system.

The map is a wide arrangement of different settings that never feel too similar from each other. There's the widely explorable Village, the Gothic-styled Castle, the Beneviento Manor, and more varieties of places to progress towards. The levels are designed different aesthetically and mechanically so you'll have different tastes to the gameplay as you continue forward. It does, however, stagnate near the end when you enter the Factory. And yes, horror is still present in this game despite the added action aspects: [spoiler]The gameplay segment with "Baby" kept me in an anxious state for a few days...[/spoiler]

Weapons are a lot more varied now with different handguns, shotguns, magnums, proximity mines, and more. The inventory system is similar to RE4's too: an attache case system where items are organized by tiles. Ammo is common, but still should be managed due to the increased enemy count. There's a treasure system where you can collect treasures (and sometimes combine them) to sell them to Duke, the Merchant character of this game. You can buy a variety of items from ammo to modifications for your guns from Duke and even give him ingredients for food recipes which can give benefits like increase your maximum health or make you run faster.

[u]Graphics & Sound[/u]

Resident Evil games in the RE engine still look as great as ever. In fact, I'd say it's getting better as time goes on. Many of the background graphics in lightly lit places like the Castle or the Manor are exquisite. Flashlights shining dimly in dark areas are always a tense moment and really bring out the refined lighting and shadow effects in this game.

The sounds are quite crisp and clean. Each enemy has their own sound cues to assist you in detecting them and the soundtrack for Resident Evil Village overall adds a lot to the tone of Gothic and eldritch horror already shown through the atmosphere the game gives off.

[u]Conclusion[/u]

Aside from a few issues I have with the flow of the story, I found myself satisfied with the time I spent playing Resident Evil Village. Even with the minor negative points I've noted, this game is still a solid addition to the series. The combined gameplay mechanics from RE7 and RE4, the extended exploration, and the added Winters' Expansion DLC makes this game an enjoyable experience with high replayability. 

Recommended for all players who enjoy survival horror with some action sprinkled in.

9/10.

Resident Evil, Metal Gear Solid, and Mass Effect are my 3 favorite video games series of all time. I've played all there games many times. Easily thousands of hours invested, so I'm going to be a very harsh critic when it comes to games I care about.  Resident Evil Village is going to receive that same treatment. I've read the reviews both good and bad and finished the game. I'm now ready to jump into my pros and cons list. 

Pros:
 * Game looks gorgeous, environments are exciting. You visit lots of locations, you aren't stuck in a village like the title implies. 
* RE8 is a mix of RE7 and RE4, both solid games in the franchise. There's no item box, you buy and sell items to a vendor. You have plenty of item space on your person and it's up-gradable. (Also a con) 
* Lots of different weapons to find, to buy or unlock with many different upgrades for each weapon
* You can craft things: health, ammo and other goodies 
* Ethan is back from RE7 and he's a very likable character, he makes a great protagonist because he behaves like a normal human being would given the situations he's put in over and over again
* The main story is more lengthy then I was expecting, I think it's a couple hours longer than RE7, but that's because there is a lot more to find in RE8 (the length is also going to show up in the cons too)
* Treasures are back, just like 4 and 5, I can't remember if RE6 had treasures (who cares that was garbage game anyway) remember some treasures can be combined and they sell for significantly more, always check each item before selling
* A wide variety of enemies and there is also a minor animal hunting aspect to the game (you'll collect meat from them)

Cons:
* Honestly, not a fan of the story. I see how they tied it in to the rest of the RE Universe but pretty uninspiring I thought 
* As far the story goes, who on Earth can keep track of what villains or evil corporations are doing what, and how they relate to the rest of the universe. We started with the T-Virus and Umbrella (game release chronologically) and now we have black mold and good corporations turning bad and bad ones turning good. Children are infected, children are important, children are evil. I don't know, we just keep getting the same damn rehashed stories! 
* I did mention length as pro, but it's also a con. I think the game went on for about 2 hours too long. The first several hours of the game was a ton of fun but then near the half way point I was ready for it to be over and the last couple of hours I hated. It brought me back to the nightmares of playing RE6. WAY WAY WAAAAY to action oriented. [spoiler] Seriously, just F*** the whole factory part, I hate the cyborg BS or whatever you want to call those enemies. [/spoiler] 
* As I just mentioned the first few hours of RE8 is great, but this game completely lost touch with what made RE so awesome. It was scary, there was tension being built through excellent story telling and the use of unique cinematography. Simply put, RE8 runs out of gas and does the old let's just throw all this stupid shit at the player and see what sticks. It lost it's survival horror feel quickly.  
* I remember when RE had only zombies, or zombified creatures. Now we have [spoiler] werewolves, vampires and paranormal shit [/spoiler] It doesn't really feel like RE anymore. 
* They did Ethan dirty SPOILER INCOMING [spoiler] he was basically made of mold, because he was killed at the beginning of RE7 so he went for several years and never knew that? Even had a child?! WHAT?! That's the big deal of RE8?! That's shit story telling! [/spoiler]
* There is zero point to inventory management, you can craft things whenever and the crafting materials don't take up inventory slots. It's easy to save on space so I ask you why bother removing the item box when you never run out of room in the first place? They took that idea from RE4 for zero reason, because it truly has no effect on how you play. 
* Interacting with enemies other than shooting them is pretty dull. There are very few times where you can shoot environmental items so they effect enemies. Even shooting different body parts doesn't hinder or play any effect on them. A lot of the enemy interactions are seriously subpar compared to other RE titles. 

I could list a few more things on the cons list, but I think everyone is getting the gist of my review. It's not good, it's not the worst RE game but it's not in the top 3 like many people are saying it is. FYI, so you understand my standards, I'd say the pinnacle of the RE Universe is RE2 Remake (as of the time of this review). It got so many things right and arguably did it better than the original. With that being said, I can't give RE8 a free pass because it did several things right. I have to look at both sides of the coin. Was this game a step forward or a step backward? Unfortunately, I think it was not as good as RE7. SO, I'd buy this game on sale and that's about the only way I'd recommend this game. Otherwise, it gets a thumbs down from me.

I am a huge Resident Evil fan and a huge survival horror enthusiast. I played this game multiple times through to truly experience resident evil 8 and I gotta say after Resident evil 7 they really fumbled the bag... RE7 was able to evolve the franchise but keep the heart of a Resident Evil while adding new life to the series. It was such a welcomed breathe of fresh air that the series and well the genre itself needed as RE7 single handedly revitalized the survival horror genre. not horror. SURVIVAL HORROR. It was universally praised by the most hardcore fans and casual crowd. they had the blueprint to really not only improve on what they built with RE7 to make a better experience... but even if they didnt do that and it was more or less the same with a little quality of life and a few changes it woulda been still great. but nah we got something that was watered down, linear, and very repetitive.. that tried to bite off things it didn't need to even chew... It's like editing a recipe that was complete. delicious, and highly praised by food critics and everyday people to then just throwing random other bs ingredients like example raisins in chicken noodle soup and blending it and calling it a better dish giving it the sequel/succesor title.... I'm not going to cover all the downfalls as many other reviews have. Resident evil 8 is what happens when you have lightning in a bottle that is readily available and can easily be produced more of  but instead they decide to intentionally empty that bottle till there wasn't a drop left. here's hoping that whatever 9 is that it's atleast better than 8.

Oh and don't get me even started on the fact that even if you bought the collectors or deluxe edition you still HAD to buy the long awaited mediocre $20 DLC that utilized a ton of re used assets and same areas you played in the main game... if you haven't played the DLC don't bother it wil not affect your outlook on the game or it's story. 

SPOILER 

it was all just a lame prequel to the main game's ending so if you wanted any answers to anything you don't really get any. all you get to know is for whatever reason they put rose in public school and she was bullied that's all you get from her was that she was bullied.
you don't get to know about who she actually is, her relationship with mia or more stuff of mia, nothing about her and chris, etc. and you could predict the events of the DLC From a mile away.. I had a huge hunch we were just going to re fight miranda with all the re used stuff.. and that obviously the cheesy michael thing was going to be ethan and that for whatever reason shes going to keep her powers whether to save someone or she learns to love her powers or some bs lol... somehow they made rose feel janky compared to ethan. 

Unless someone gifts this to you or you get a product key for a few bucks off of you know... don't waste your hard earned money here It wasn't worth the $60-70 on launch and it's not worth the $40 it is going for right now.

I love this game. In my opinion, it's the closest to a perfect Resident Evil experience since 4. This game takes a lot from 4. The setting, events, and the Duke merchant. I would argue the shop is even better here, as you can buy ammo and far more attachments than in 4. Resident Evil 4 had some bullshit sections, like the fights with the blind wolverine guys. This game has FAR less bullshit. I'd say the only bullshit in this game would be Lady D chasing you around the castle, because on a first playthrough you're gonna get lost in there, and it can be annoying finding where to go while being stalked by her nonstop. Aside from that, game has no bullshit. The section in the doll estate with the giant baby monster was a little tedious, as you're defenseless against a monster that one hit kills you. It was my only death on the first playthru, which is a good thing. Shows the game is less cheap/bullshit. 

The guns in the game have fantastic sound design. Whether it's firing, reloading, or switching weapons, it's some of the best I've heard. A good selection of weapons, with 3 pistols and shotguns, with lots more to play around with. I love packing heat in this game. You feel like a badass, but at the same time can be threatened by almost every encounter. When you hit enemies, they react unless they're in the middle of an attack animation on top of you. This is great. 

The game, however, did get quite easy after clearing the doll estate. You get so much firepower that if you play your cards right, you'll rarely get hit. It's fun to annihilate monsters after being a weakling at the beginning, but after not getting hit for 2 hours, it did click that this is kinda easy. Maybe Standard is too easy? 

Length and variety of the game is decent. I'd say it's worth full price, and new game plus is (almost) always fantastic in Resident Evil games. My weapon of choice was the Sniper Rifle, and I'm sure there's one for everyone to enjoy creaming monsters with. :)

Beautiful dark and gory fairytale. After playing this game three times already, in just few months after it was released, I can only say that this game is so great I can't stop playing it. 
Game and it's story is something new and fresh in RE world, but it is also well integrated with the rest of franchise. I was really worried about how will they connect the story to the original RE, but they did it very smoothly. Graphics are beautiful, soundtracks are just WOW, bosses are so well designed and for some reason you connect with them on so many levels that you are sad once you kill them. 
I only wish it was longer, since I managed to finish it under 12 hours in my first play through (and I'm the slow type of player, who likes to take time and explore) and each next time It was even shorter. Come on Capcom - make it longer, we know you can do it. DLC story is a nice addition, but it can't compensate main game's shortness, since DLC is a bit short too and uses a lot of assets from the main game (like 99% of it).
All in all this game is a gem and I could not recommend it more for everyone that would enjoy that twisted but enchanting horror fairytale vibe.

Capcom literally took the best parts of RE4 and RE7 to create this perfection.

Resident Evil Village is a wonderful survival horror adventure game that includes shooting, exploration, puzzles and inventory management.
Most of the action takes place in an isolated village in Eastern Europe, in Romania, but you will also visit a beautiful castle, a house of horror, a water reservoir, a metal factory and more.
The characters look amazing and bossfights are exciting, my favourite is probably a fight against Moreau.
The music and graphics are really nice, the game is also well optimised, I had zero issues while playing it.
The story can be a bit confusing but you will figure it all out in the end, especially if you don't skip the lore files.

Resident Evil Village exceeded my expectations and provided a fun and thrilling experience.
I recommend you to try it out, but it is advised you play RE7 first.

Resident Evil Village, or as I like to call it, 'Resident Evil: The Hills Have Eyes Edition', is a game that'll have you questioning whether you're playing a survival horror game or a fever dream. From the opening moments where you're chased by a giant werewolf with a thirst for blood, to the final boss battle against an eight-foot-tall vampire lady, this game is full of moments that'll make you say, 'What the hell is going on?'

But don't worry, you won't be alone in your confusion. You'll have Ethan Winters, the game's protagonist, to guide you through this nightmare. And by 'guide you through', I mean stumble around blindly while muttering to himself and getting his hands chopped off for the fifth time. Seriously, if Ethan Winters is the only hope for humanity, we're all screwed.

The real stars of the show, though, are the game's villains. You've got Lady Dimitrescu, the aforementioned eight-foot-tall vampire lady who could crush you like a grape but instead wants to seduce you (hey, whatever floats your boat, Lady D). Then there's Heisenberg, a guy who's basically Walter White if Walter White was a mad scientist with a metal arm. And let's not forget the dollhouse, which is... well, let's just say it's a whole thing.

As for the gameplay, it's your standard Resident Evil fare - lots of exploring creepy environments, solving puzzles, and fighting off hordes of monsters with limited resources. But Village amps up the tension by constantly putting you in tight spaces with enemies that can jump out at you from any angle. And if that's not scary enough for you, there's a mode where you can play the entire game in VR. Because who needs sleep anyway?

All in all, Resident Evil Village is a wild ride that's sure to leave you with more questions than answers. But hey, at least you'll have Lady Dimitrescu to keep you company in your nightmares. Just don't expect her to cuddle with you. Unless you're into that kind of thing.

I even got to skip an entire huge fight with the lycans because they simply didn't spawn. It was funny to run around a boss room where the giant werewolf guy never appeared. Overall an amazing game, couldn't recommend it more.

Capcom did a good job finally giving us an actual sequel to RE4. RE4^2. The RE Engine is fluid as it's been since RE7, RE2 and RE3, The weapon upgrade system never leaves you feeling like your weapons are under-powered, the map is fairly large with lots of treasures and items to find, the enemies feel very threatening when you first encounter them, but the weapon upgrades make this a very temporary feeling. Two things I really don't like, the only two things, is that they reuse Ethan as the protagonist, which doesn't feel very Resident Evil of them. Also, there are times when the settings make it feel more like Silent Hill than Resident Evil.
Overall, a challenging and entertaining game, would recommend.

This game captures the RE4 feel and intertwines it with wonderfully crafted horror elements from 7. This beautiful fusion makes this one of the best feeling games to play in the Resident Evil franchise. It is, of course, not without faults: moving items in the inventory is tedious, the normal enemies all have a stunlock that takes forever to end, and the defend key is not that useful- especially on higher difficulties. The post-game rewards are also lackluster and the mercenaries mode is a complete grind. You can argue a lot of these are growing pains as the series evolves and finds it's comfortable medium, or say that I am nitpicking, but hey, YMMV.

[b]However[/b], despite all this, the game absolutely shines. The story is compelling, the environment rich and bone-chilling no matter where you go, the incredibly crisp and smooth graphics that are highly-optimized and the animations and transitions are smooth as butter. Everything you would expect from a AAA game and more. Have I mentioned the combat? What is a Resident Evil game without satisfying zombie (or in this case, lycan) destruction, as well as challenging & creative boss fights? There is no shortage of either action or horror in this entry and I couldn't be happier with how it plays out. I could go on, but I don't think it's necessary. Final verdict is this:

If you're on the fence, wait for a sale. I mean, you've waited this long, right?

But if you're a Resident Evil fan, or a survival horror games fan in general, chances are [i]you already have this game.[/i] 9/10 would most definitely recommend.

First game that got me into the Resident Evil franchise. Super fun world with folk horror and incredibly well written characters. Loved it and is a fun sequel in the winters saga. Some of the scariest areas in horror games I've played. The dlc does some cool things, but ultimately falls short of what could have been a really incredible addition. Still worth picking up if you want more of the game.

While it obviously looks quite similar to its predecessor, [i]Village[/i] is far from just a retread of [i]RE7[/i]. There are some admittedly terrifying moments of horror (people who've played the game will know what I'm talking about), but for the most part, the game isn't exactly "scary". Rather, it's more like [i]RE4[/i], where the atmosphere is a little ominous, but in general, the game is just focused on being an all-around fun time. It's faster, more in-your-face and action-packed. It feels more like a crazy adventure, compared to [i]RE7[/i]'s claustrophobic fight for survival.

The question of whether this or [i]RE7[/i] is better is tough to answer, as they aren't necessarily trying to occupy the same space. Both are great in their own right—if you want tense horror, play [i]RE7[/i], and if you want fun action, then [i]Village[/i] is probably your jam.

A mixed bag of experiences that is sure to please most. It's not my personal favorite of the series but it does continue to broaden and expand the RE lore and legacy set by two plus decades of stories in other titles within the series. Combat is definitely faster paced leaning more towards a DOOM like experience with quick weapon swapping and fast movement to avoid enemy attacks. 

Visually the RE Engine is at its' best with some of the most gorgeous looking environments and character models the series has ever produced. The story and pacing are again, a mixed bag with some scenarios and locations being more interesting and fun than others. Your mileage will vary depending on what you expect out of this one. It's not straight up survival horror like the older titles or 7, but it's also not full blown action like RE 4 or 5. It manages to find a sweet spot in the middle and it works for the most part. 
By game's end however, I was excited and ready to see where the RE story will take us next. Definitely worth a playthrough.

Absolute must-play with the Praydog VR mod for those with VR headsets. Also recommend the Oculus Touch Button Prompts mod available on Nexus Mods, loadable via the Fluffy Manager 5000 mod manager.

Recommend dialing down most shadow options, moving to medium-high for mesh/model and lighting options and turning off Ray tracing and vertical sync to start. Also turn off most of the options below Ray tracing (ambient occlusion, water effects, film grain). If walking around Ethan's home in the opening section you still feel like the game is chugging, turn the settings down further. You don't need to tweak things to get them perfect at this point just get it to a state where you feel good with the quality then resume the first leg of the game, enjoy the craziness and get to the first typewriter save point. Stop at this point then do further tweaking after you save your progress, to hone in the settings before continuing.

If you're not familiar with the impact the settings each will have just go one by one until you have the best settings for your rig and try to get all of those settings settled on before continuing any further past that first typewriter checkpoint. Be sure to test outside and run a little once you are dialed in graphically.

I think a big performance increase can come if you use Oculus in the Oculus diagnostics tool and the resolution, I brought my resolution down a bit and hertz refresh to 72, I have an older I7 and an AMD RX 6800 XT.

Once you are done finding the best setting for you, enjoy getting stepped on by the good Lady.

*Light-Spoilers*

After finally finishing this game, I can understand why it has an overwhelming positive review score out of nearly 60K Steam reviews.

This is the true sequel from a design point to Resident Evil 4. Another masterpiece in the series. This review will only encompass the base campaign, not the DLC or other content. *3RD-Person Mode Used*
---

Graphics - 9/10 || The most up-to-date version of the RE Engine really shines on modern hardware. The game is absolutely gorgeous, and the lighting in particular this engine has to offer helps to create the most immersive survival-horror experience yet.

Performance - 9/10 || Runs extremely well as the engine is very, very optimized. I managed to crank the settings to the brink and use Ultra Quality mode AMD FSR and my frames stayed locked at 120FPS for most of the playthrough, with some minor spikes here and there during action intensive scenes. There were a couple spots on the map that weren't optimized and the FPS took massive drops all of twice during the playthrough.

Not a single game-breaking bug or crash for the entirety of the time I played.

i7-6800K 4.0G OC'd
32G DDR4
1080 STRIX

Gameplay - 10/10 || This takes the formula that RE4 established and perfects it. The absolute master-class level design helps to almost immediately immerse you with an overwhelming sense of dread and tension for nearly the entire playthrough. The game is extremely challenging and will demand a lot of you throughout the various experiences crafted that it has to offer you. Overcoming each section is extremely rewarding and satisfying. It will push your skills to the absolute limits.

Easily the best boss-fights of any Resident Evil game to date, hands down, and arguably the best part of the game.

It's a roller-coaster ride that barely lets you breathe.

Story - 9/10 || A direct continuation from RE7, with some nice surprises sprinkled in, ESP. during the climax of the game. CAPCOM manages to take various horror tropes and crafts them into a unique experience. This will make more sense once you figure out whats causing all the madness and hell around you to be unleashed.

*Spoilers*

In this game, you got;

Vampires
Dolls
Warewolves
Body-Horror (Cronenburg level stuff.)
KANEDAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA ~~~~~~~~~~ TETSUOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO

Sound - 10/10 || This game demands to be played with high-quality audio. Every sound effect, growl, ambient or musical note is crafted with intent and is stellar. Arguably the best audio in any Resident Evil game to date.

Controls - 9/10 || The formula that REmake-2 established is here to stay. Playing with mouse/keyboard feels effortless. Movement is snappy and precise, along with the aiming. Which you'll need - enemies in this game are -not- easy to dispatch and the more ammo you waste, the worse time you're going to have. Things will spiral out of control very quickly.

Replay Value - High || DLC, Mercs, and a vast CP store for unlocks will keep you playing this for quite sometime. I'm going to do the DLC campaign soon and will touch on Mercs. I'd imagine the campaign is pretty enjoyable with infinite ammo like the previous games.

In closing, CAPCOM did it again. They managed to push this medium forward and the franchise keeps getting better and better.

I absolutely cannot wait for REmake-4.

I started playing Resident Evil Village, defeated Bela, went to Lady D's chambers, saved the game afterwards and when I came back the next day, lost my save file. Rushed the start, defeated Bela again, saved, guess what? No save... Not happy, I tried once again, saved at the church, quit the game, came back and to my surprise, no save. I can't play it, RE keeps deleting my files. I never downloaded any mods or anything, but this game doesn't work, why play if I can't save it? Looked on the internet, and found no way to fix it. 10/10 Capcom, really cool... I even sent them an e-mail, if I have any answers, I'll update the review. The game is cool, has an amzing atmosphere, but I can't play it lol. I left the comments open if anyone knows a way to fix it. Is there any way to recover my saves and stop the game from deleting them?

Edit: I found a work around. If you have the same problem, download your saves from steam cloud, rush till the church part with a new save, replace them in the game saves folder. It's tricky, but it works. Of course I had to play the rest of the game in one go, even tho my save was BEFORE fighting Lady D lol I was scared this shit would break again, but it worked in the end...

This might be a bit unusual as I'm going to slate a game whilst still recommending it.

Resident Evil Villllllllllillllilllllllage is what happens when a committee meets and decides to make a sequel by trying to smash together the best bits of two of the best entries in a series and hope it makes an even better game. In short; it don't. I can't help but feel that this was originally going to be a whole different game (i.e. Not Resident Evil) then Capcom got hold of it, chucked Ethan Winters into it, and made it a sequel that never needed to happen.

I cannot fault the visuals, level design or gameplay of this game. It looks stunning and the world feels realistic and lived in.

HOWEVER none of it makes any flipping sense. I KNOW its not meant to be realistic, but it doesn't even make sense in it's own slightly bonkers universe. I've played it through and still cant really explain the plot, or why anything is happening, or who anyone is supposed to be anymore.

RE7, and before it RE4, were great because they changed up a tired and increasingly cliched format. RE4 knew not to take itself too seriously and was fun, scary and challenging. RE7 got (slightly) more serious, at least until the end, and was a pretty horrifying experience. You know whats not scary? Being able to craft your own ammunition from scrap metal and chemical fluid. Or having various parts of your body impaled, removed or mutilated and having it not impact your ability to perform tasks in the slightest. Again; this worked in RE7, but it just feels silly now.

Remember zombies? Zombies were pretty important in RE games. Now we have werewolves and vampires and....zombie vampires or something. Again, this would be fine if it actually made any sense in the context of the world, but it doesn't. The designers obviously realised this and just gave up making any attempt to explain it beyond "umm umm mould or something". And don't get me started on Chris F-ing Redfield.

In summary: too short, too mad and not very challenging or scary. But hey, go play it. Its Resident Evil! Apparently.

I Went into this with the expectation that they would be continuing with the RE 7 formula they had before and there would be more of the same. Regretfully, this is not the 'Resident Evil' experience you would want and this is more of the action-oriented gameplay that you would expect from RE 4. The problem this game has is wanting to be RE 7 still, but its immediately watered down and not much of a puzzle or make you have to make a lot of decisions. Its all been watered down since the last RE 7. 

That was what made RE 7 great, was the actual survival horror aspect and then having that sweet revenge when you get the unlocks after the game. In this, that feeling is missing and its not even rewarding in that regard as you wont struggle in this game. It is too easy by throwing only a handful of enemies, or to "Make it harder" they just throw a mob at you to try and make it harder. Its not harder, its silly and not what you would want in a RE title. This really does feel like the RE 2 remaster and RE 3 remaster comparison to quality of titles. except it is RE 7 with RE 8, and it really does show.

Overall, Id say 'No' for those wanting a true experience in a Resident Evil title for good puzzles, gameplay, etc.  On the flipside, i would say yes for the casual gameplay and mods.

Resident Evil is one of my favorite game franchises of all time, but RE8 is pretty low on my teir list.

It is so slow and boring. Enemies move slowly and you are encouraged to abuse furniture to make enemies walk around like idiots. The game is also constantly taking away control from the player and making them watch some slow animation like looking at blood on your hand, or flipping a switch, or turning a crank. There are also a ton of scripted sections and/or cutscenes, and skipping them is painful because it does the crap where you can't open the pause menu to skip until you are several seconds into the cutscene (probably cause loading or something). It just overall feels like a massive slog to play through.

The game is nonsensical. The story is always ridiculous in RE games, but RE8 just doesn't strike the right tone. It isn't campy. It isn't scary. I just found it dumb and I don't care about it whatsoever. Heisenberg and the Duke were decent, but I hated all the other characters. It has a lot of gore and is intending to be shocking, but the gore is so over-the-top and non-stop that it is often more comically bad than anything else. Why would I be scared of this enemy in front of me when I just survived multiple fatal wounds in the cutscene 5 seconds ago? The amount of gore goes way too far and has a very negative effect for what the game is going for.

Here are some games on Steam in the same genre I would recommend over RE8:
- Resident Evil 2 (remake)
- Resident Evil 3 (remake)
- Resident Evil 4
- Resident Evil 5
- Resident Evil 6
- Resident Evil Revelations 2
- Ghostbusters Remastered
- Dead Space
- Last of Us

Here are some additional Steam recommendations over RE8, but these are farther away from RE8's genre:
- Control 
- Tomb Raider (modern Square Enix Trilogy)
- Uncharted
- Vanquish

Capcom literally took the best parts of RE4 and RE7 to create this perfection.

Resident Evil Village is a wonderful survival horror adventure game that includes shooting, exploration, puzzles and inventory management.
Most of the action takes place in an isolated village in Eastern Europe, in Romania, but you will also visit a beautiful castle, a house of horror, a water reservoir, a metal factory and more.
The characters look amazing and bossfights are exciting, my favourite is probably a fight against Moreau.
The music and graphics are really nice, the game is also well optimised, I had zero issues while playing it.
The story can be a bit confusing but you will figure it all out in the end, especially if you don't skip the lore files.

Resident Evil Village exceeded my expectations and provided a fun and thrilling experience.
I recommend you to try it out, but it is advised you play RE7 first.

Ethan "shish kebab" Winters goes for a nice stroll, meets his in-laws on the way and has exactly the same experience as I did last summer. This game became my most favourite RE game after I played it!💖
The graphics are phenomenal and the plot for the game to be played in an open and beautifully designed world is awesome. The enemies are more unique and had their own abilities and difficulties than RE7 or some other RE games. Exploring the village and the other places in it is so enjoying and the unique twist of having 4 Powerful Lords, Mother Miranda as the main villain and the Megamycete. The twist of this game connecting all the RE games to it as because the virus and the mold originated in the village is also cool and the rest is for you to find out. First person perspective is also nice yet still has some issues with it. Weapons, combat and fights are also well made and worth it. The merchant or the Duke is also really helpful and has more options. The boss fights are also amzing yet despite having more boss fights than RE7, It's also strangely a bit easy to beat. The puzzles are also unique and vary in different special ways but can be straightforward and easy to hint though.
The scares and horrors also are both terrifying and awesome, with unexpected jumpscares, adrenaline, and the horrorific aura while exploring, never knowing what, when, where or how it will happen. The idea of making this a survival horror game is nice yet overly focused. The depth and informations behind all characters are well described and shown here, especially for Ethan, Lady Dimitrescu, Mither Miranda and some but some are still missing and left for the next game or for us to find. The Mercenaries mode and the other gameplay modes is also coola nd even having the models of each character, items and enemies in the game which you can buy is also a good concept. The songs and soundtracks used are awesome and memorable, hits a new medley and original in their own way. The story concept for the intro and credits is also uniqye and I swear I got Coraline Vibes from it. The cutscenes and acts are really pretty amazing and oh, all the items, treasures, weapons and crafted products are all still goodly unique. Although this game has issue with its action movements, camera and some bigs in the game, it's still an awesome and legendary game for us.💖💖
The voice actors also did a great job and the story, plot and overall are amazingly good and memorable. I love it and recommend to all other gamers there.
I just hope we get a DLC about the four lords soon (which is confirmed to be currently made😊) or have the famous Lady Dimitrescu, Ethan, the other lords maybe? And rose for the next game but It all depends to the developers and hope you'll all enjoy this game as much as we do.
Have a nice day!!!😇😇💖💖
